HEADLINE: Drugs, Terror and Tuna: How Goals Clash 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: GENERAL SANTOS CITY, the Philippines, May 15 

 BODY:
This industrial city on the southern coast of Mindanao Island illustrates how America's various strategic aims in the wars on drugs and terrorism can clash, alienating important allies engaged in battling terrorism.
 Among leaders of the Philippines' important tuna industry here, resentment is running high over trade legislation now on the Senate floor in Washington. The bill includes a provision to eliminate steep import taxes on canned tuna from Andean nations while keeping taxes in place for other countries like the Philippines. 
 The provision has attracted Congressional support because it is seen as bolstering America's war on drugs. The idea is that the bill will help create well-paid jobs in Ecuador and Colombia as an alternative to the drug trade. 
But in another war -- the one against terrorism -- the legislation is causing anger in a country that has become an important part of the administration's plans. 
It comes at a time when 600 American soldiers are helping the Philippine Army track Abu Sayyaf Muslim insurgents in the southernmost Philippines, and President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has staked much political capital on helping the United States fight terrorism.
Virtually all of the tuna industry of the Philippines is located here and it employs thousands of migrant workers from small Muslim fishing communities that used to be bastions of various Muslim insurgencies. Local officials warn that the legislation could wipe out the tuna industry.
President Arroyo said that passage of the trade provision would deal a severe blow to the economy here while handing a propaganda victory to the Abu Sayyaf movement.
The combination would create heavy domestic pressure for the Philippines to retreat from its active support for the American war on terrorism, she warned in a telephone interview tonight.
"I will try very hard not to, but I will be under tremendous pressure," she said.
In much of the developing world, including Latin America and Africa, trade restrictions or tariffs on products ranging from steel to textiles are causing growing resentment toward the United States. The perception that the Bush administration is a protectionist one is growing.
President Arroyo argued that General Santos, the main city on the southern coast of Mindanao and home to most of the Philippines' tuna fishing fleet and canneries, was central both to the economic future of this region and to the fight against terrorism.
A powerful pipe bomb packed with nails exploded on a crowded sidewalk outside a supermarket here on April 21, killing 15 people and wounding dozens. A second pipe bomb was safely defused before it exploded at another supermarket the same day, and two shopping complexes have recently burned down here in the middle of the night in separate, unexplained incidents.
Police detectives here say that they are still unsure whether the attacks were terrorist incidents, criminal attempts at extortion or some combination of the two. But President Arroyo expresses no such doubts, saying tonight, "The Abu Sayyaf has been trying to get into General Santos and it has been very difficult for us to justify our support for the United States."
In a city where tunas festoon everything from billboards to restaurant signs, and where even the golf tournament is the Tuna Cup, the fishing industry's influence is impossible to miss.
Workers heave baskets of fish onto crude steel carts, which they then pull by hand over to a long open-sided shed. Women wash and sort the fish on long tables, the concrete floor beneath them dark and slippery with fish blood. A few larger tuna, some the size of a man, are carried individually to large, white boxes packed with half-melted ice, to be shipped directly to Japan to be turned into sashimi.
Renato Alonzo, 47, a fisherman in a ragged T-shirt and flip-flops whose boat had just docked after two weeks at sea, said that he had sold his tiny farm and joined a boat crew 10 years ago after learning he could nearly double his income, to roughly $4,000 a year. Now he can afford to send his two sons, aged 12 and 8, to school.
The bustling fishing port here and the nearby row of tuna canneries contrast sharply with most of Mindanao, where peasants still toil on subsistence farms or on large pineapple and coconut plantations. Years of drought, coupled with inadequate irrigation, have crippled agriculture while the global glut of low-priced steel has forced the closing of a big steel mill in northern Mindanao.
The tuna industry here barely existed until the late 1980's when the United States led Japan, Italy and other donor nations in an ambitious foreign aid program aimed at rebuilding the Philippines after the fall of Ferdinand Marcos.
A full-scale guerrilla war was being waged in Mindanao then, a far broader conflict than the handful of kidnappings and possibly bombings linked to Abu Sayyaf now. General Santos City was nearly surrounded by several very large insurgencies that attracted poor youths from the island's Muslim minority. The city had a small fishing fleet, but it mostly caught fish for local consumption.
But the world's richest tuna fishing grounds lay between here and Indonesia, although boats from Thailand mainly fished them then. Foreign donors built the fishing port here as well as a large cargo airport, a container port, extensive roads and a modern phone system, hiring security guards from rebel forces and buying sand, gravel and other construction materials from rebel leaders' businesses.
With ready transportation to foreign markets, six big canneries were built, each employing more than 1,000 workers. The only two other tuna canneries in the Philippines are in Zamboanga City in southwestern Mindanao, the staging area for American troops pursuing Abu Sayyaf. Some 30,000 fishermen now supply the canneries.
The tuna boom has helped persuade all of the rebel movements except the Abu Sayyaf splinter group to lay down their arms under armistices with the government. Many former rebel commanders and foot soldiers have taken jobs at the canneries, which have had no problem with the bombings that have afflicted shopping centers.
Abuhasan Jama is a former major in the Moro National Liberation Front who studied guerrilla warfare in Malaysia in 1979 and 1980 and then spent 13 years fighting the Philippine government in the jungles of Mindanao.
Now he is the security chief at Ocean Canning here, his eldest daughter is in college and he has found jobs at the same cannery for three cousins who are also former guerrillas. "I like to work," said Mr. Jama, 41, recalling that in the jungle "sometimes you'd just eat leaves, the roots."
Mariano M. Fernandez, the general manager of Ocean Canning, said that he used to carry two Smith & Wesson handguns, one strapped on each hip. "It was like the Wild West here," he said, adding that he carries only a cellphone now.
Most of the tuna canned here is sold in the United States under less famous brands like Geisha and Dagim. Bumble Bee and Starkist used to buy large quantities of tuna here but have recently begun relying on Ecuador instead, allowing that country to edge past the Philippines last year to become the second-largest foreign supplier of tuna to the United States, after Thailand. Starkist in particular is now pushing for the elimination of import tariffs on canned tuna from Ecuador.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The fishing port in General Santos in the Philippines where the tuna industry feels threatened. (Carlos H. Conde for The New York Times)(pg. A1) Map of Philippines highlighting General Santos: General Santos is the capital of the tuna industry in the Philippines. (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Mayor's Welfare Plan Embraces Job Training 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Departing significantly from the welfare policies of his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that his administration planned to provide extensive job training, child care and other programs to help welfare recipients find and hold jobs.
 Mayor Bloomberg took pains to praise Rudolph W. Giuliani's record in putting the changes in welfare into practice, and promised to keep intact its essential elements: fingerprinting people to keep them honest; requiring most to work for their government checks; and keeping the number of people on public assistance as low as possible. 
 "Federal public assistance should be temporary," the mayor said. "If it is not, neither society nor those less fortunate who are receiving benefits will progress." 
The Giuliani administration cut the welfare rolls from 1.2 million to below 500,000. 
Mayor Bloomberg called for a new approach yesterday to help those who had trouble finding and keeping jobs. He mentioned job training to help people find work, and support programs like pregnancy prevention and child care to help welfare recipients stay employed.
Roughly 25 percent of welfare recipients are mentally or physically unfit for work, officials say.
"The success of welfare reform should not be measured solely by reduction in caseloads," the mayor said, "but also by the ability of people to become and remain self-sufficient."
Mr. Giuliani thought job training was ineffective and he did not seek some of the federal money that was available for that purpose.
Mr. Bloomberg also said he felt that certain benefits, like transportation and child care, should not be considered public assistance and not be subject to restrictions. Mr. Bloomberg also said he favored the inclusion of legal immigrants in some welfare programs that are currently limited to citizens. 
Administration officials had no estimate of the cost of the new policies, nor any figures on previous spending of both state and federal money. The city does not contribute to welfare expenditures. New York State received $2.4 billion last year in federal money for welfare recipients. 
The city's Human Resources Administration has sent a 30-page proposal to Congress asking permission to spend some surplus federal funds -- a result of the lower welfare rolls -- on the expanded programs. 
"I will not walk away from my fundamental belief that there are those among us who desperately need help," said Mr. Bloomberg, in a speech at La Guardia Community College. "That sometimes, through discrimination, happenstance or just plain indifference, some people are left out of the great opportunities that this country, state and city provide."
Mr. Bloomberg, like many Republicans in Congress, favors more local flexibility in the spending of federal welfare money. Right now, there are restrictions on the use of the money for programs like education and child care. Most restrictions, however, are imposed by the state, so the Bloomberg administration is also asking for federal legislation that would prohibit the state from interfering in welfare.
Mr. Bloomberg's announcement also marked a difference in tone. Like his predecessor, Mr. Bloomberg spoke of an intolerance for welfare fraud, a preference for work over government dependency and a belief in personal responsibility.
Mr. Giuliani had repeatedly referred to the reliance on welfare as a "sick culture of dependency," but Mr. Bloomberg took a different tack yesterday. 
"All my life, I've been taught, in my home, in my school and in my religious training, that we have an unshakable moral responsibility to help," he said, "no matter that it may be expensive, inconvenient, difficult or unpopular."
Mr. Bloomberg's 30-page proposal is intended to coincide with deliberations in Congress, which is considering how to reconfigure the 1996 federal welfare law, which expires this year. President Bush has proposed that by 2007, 70 percent of welfare recipients have a 40-hour week that includes 24 hours on a job and 16 hours of education or other activities. 
In most states, only 30 percent of welfare recipients are working. In New York City the figure is about 40 percent. Mr. Bloomberg said he hoped that a 70-percent level would not be imposed, saying the city's fragile economy would probably make that impossible. 
In many ways, Mr. Bloomberg is taking a pragmatic approach to policy that is typical of his budding mayoralty. In crime-fighting, quality of life and other social issues, Mr. Bloomberg is aware that he cannot deviate far from the policies of Mr. Giuliani. But his liberal leanings infuse much of what he retains from his predecessor. He believes staunchly that people who are entitled to benefits ought to have them. 
With each attempt to manage crime, homelessness, welfare and other issues, he risks alienating the loudest proponents of Mr. Giuliani's policies as well as the social policy advocates on the other side of the fence, who seek wholesale changes.
Both sides appear to have heard what they wanted in the mayor's remarks yesterday.
"I am very happy with the new mayor's emphasis," said Jason Turner, the architect of Mr. Giuliani's welfare-to-work program that emphasized low rolls, work requirements and, its critics charged, discouraged those who were eligible for benefits from getting them. "It builds off Mayor Giuliani's ground work. There are no major departures in either emphasis or policy contained in that proposal."
Henry A. Olsen, the executive director of Center for Civic Innovation at the the Manhattan Institute, a research organization that helped promote Giuliani policies, had a different though equally complimentary view.
"What he is proposing would stake him out more on the liberal wing of the debate," said Mr. Olsen, citing the mayor's unwillingness to require that 70 percent of recipients work and opposition to time limits on some benefits. But he said, "I think the speech had a very strong rhetorical core, which is that work and self-sufficiency is what we aim for." 
Jennifer March-Joly, the associate executive director for Program and Policy Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, also said that she believed that Mr. Bloomberg had hewed closely in many ways to Mr. Giuliani's program.
"To the extent that emphasizing work is a central component of his plan, there is no shift," she said. "But to the extent that it acknowledges that work support like education, training, housing subsidies, child care and transportation are critical things that keep people in the workplace, that is where there is a significant shift."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about changes in welfare policy under the Bloomberg administration misstated the city's share of public assistance spending under the federal welfare law. It is 25 percent, not zero.

HEADLINE: STOPPING AND GOING; 
The Open Road? It Will Be Hard to Find

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
IF it seems that traffic is worse than it used to be, that's because it is. Over the last 30 years, the number of miles that cars and trucks travel on America's highways has nearly tripled. 
 Despite a shaky economy, projections for this year point to a continuation of the trend. "Never before have we entered a summer with so many negative factors influencing travel," said Sandra Hughes, the vice president for travel at the AAA, the former American Automobile Association, at a press conference in Washington yesterday to predict travel conditions over the Memorial Day holiday. 
 Ms. Hughes said that 29.3 million people are expected to travel at least 50 miles from their homes by car for the holiday weekend, 2 percent more than the number last year, in part because fewer people are expected to fly. Because of a less robust economy, Ms. Hughes said, vacationers this summer are expected to "travel closer to home as well as reduce the length of trips and take more one-day outings."
The only way to attempt to avoid the worst traffic snarls is to listen to updates on the radio. "Everybody knows the routes," said Abraham Zadi, 57, a livery driver from Astoria, Queens. Being a professional driver gives him no special knowledge, he said, adding, "I'm like everyone else -- I turn on the radio, look at a map and take my chances."
Traffic is at its worst, of course, during those critical Friday afternoons and Sunday evenings. "If you try to work all day Friday and leave at 4 or 5, everybody's trying to get out of New York at the same time," said Stanley Nelson, a documentary filmmaker from Harlem who drives with his wife and three children to Martha's Vineyard about five times a year. "What should be that first hour of the trip can take three or four hours."
Getting back also requires some thought. Mr. Nelson said he tries to return to the city in a way that eases the return to reality. "The Cross Bronx is always a culture shock," he said. "All of a sudden you're stuck with all those huge trucks. It's a slam-bam ending to your weekend." As an alternative, he said, he takes the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, an older, truck-free highway with more bucolic scenery.
Mr. Nelson said he gave his 12-year-old daughter, Olivia, puzzle books to keep her busy on the road, and gave his twin 3-year-olds, Kai and Nola, a long break to stretch their legs. "They usually fall asleep for half the ride or so," he said. "That's what saves us."
Some who drive regularly simply refuse to travel during high-traffic days of the season. Mark and Donia Steele, who are retired, have lived in a recreational vehicle for four years, since they sold their home in Alexandria, Va.
"The main thing we've learned is that during Memorial Day, Labor Day and the Fourth of July, it's better to hide," said Mr. Steele, 53, a co-author of "Steeles on Wheels: A Year on the Road in an RV" (Capital Books, 2002). "We find an out-of-the-way place and take refuge for the weekend. We'll go to a place that has nothing to offer, that isn't by a lake or by a historic battlefield, a mountain resort, a national park or, of course, the ocean."
When all is said and done, what is the best way to keep slow traffic from getting on your nerves? "Have nice company," Mr. Zadi said. "That's all you can do."

PERSON: Sharon L. Monsky 

HEADLINE: Sharon Monsky, 48, Leader In Fight Against Rare Illness 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Sharon L. Monsky, a scleroderma sufferer who founded an organization that raised millions of dollars to look for a cure for the disease, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 48 and lived in Santa Barbara.
 The cause was systemic scleroderma, said Charles Spaulding, a vice president of the organization, the Scleroderma Research Foundation, which Ms. Monsky founded in 1987. 
 Ms. Monsky had systemic scleroderma, a chronic and painful disease afflicting the connective tissues, for two decades. She was the foundation's chairman and chief executive until she died.
"She was a leader in raising awareness and funding in search of a cure for scleroderma," said Dr. M. Kari Connolly, a professor of dermatology and medicine at the University of California at San Francisco, who has been doing research about scleroderma for 10 years. 
The struggle for awareness and money encountered problems. Ms. Monsky said in a 1990 interview with The New York Times: "It's a hard one to sell. It's a mysterious disease. It's an ugly disease. And there are no scleroderma poster children to help."
In the early 1980's, when she found out that she had scleroderma, which hardens the skin and internal organs, Ms. Monsky was given only two years to live. But as she lived on, she decided to create the foundation.
She had a master's degree in business administration and had become a highly regarded management consultant with McKinsey & Company, which she had to leave in 1985 after her health deteriorated. She applied her business expertise to the foundation.
Besides corporate donors, celebrities in the performing arts were persuaded to donate time and money to the cause. 
Ms. Monsky's activities generated more than $14 million for research and helped expand understanding of the disease. Money she disbursed for basic medical research on scleroderma led to the publication of scientific articles exploring potential cures. Her work also helped make scleroderma better known.
The foundation's activities include operating two sites for research on the disease, at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and the University of California at San Francisco. The foundation also has adjunct laboratories at Ohio State, Stanford and Duke Universities.
Born in Omaha, Ms. Monsky was a top amateur figure skater as a teenager. She received a bachelor's degree in economics from Pitzer College in Claremont, Calif., and a master's degree in business administration from Stanford. 
She was separated from her husband, Mark Scher. 
She is survived by her mother, Ramelle Monsky of Palm Desert, Calif.; a son, Max, and two daughters, Samantha and Montana, all of Santa Barbara; a sister, Robin Monsky of Chicago; and a brother, Henry Monsky of Omaha.

HEADLINE: Will Inflation Bets Continue to Pay Off? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
DO you remember inflation? To some people it is starting to show signs of life.
 That is not necessarily horrible news. As the Japanese well know, deflation can be a horrible thing, and at the height of this country's economic woes last year, there was a little evidence of deflation here. Now that evidence has gone. 
 As it happens, the financial markets provide a handy measure of inflation expectations: the difference between yields of normal Treasury securities and those that offer a lower guaranteed yield but add in inflation protection. That differential is the break-even inflation rate, as measured by the Consumer Price Index.
Last fall, the break-even inflation rate on 10-year Treasuries fell to 1.3 percent. Now it is up to 2.1 percent. Anyone with a strategy of betting on higher inflation expectations has done well.
That is also true in the stock market. James Bianco, the president of Bianco Research, points out that since the Federal Reserve's last reduction of the federal funds rate, to 1.75 percent on Dec. 11, the stock market stars have been the kind of companies that benefit the most from inflation. Over all, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 3.4 percent. But the best-performing industry group is gold stocks, up 37 percent, with industries like forest products and oil and gas drillers not far behind. 
Past is not always prologue, of course, and just because inflation expectations have risen does not mean they will continue to do so. A sustained period of 2.1 percent inflation -- the current market forecast -- would be just fine with most people. "The stock market is saying we avoided the deflation trap," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. "I'm not willing to declare that inflation is off to the races."
But Mr. Bianco is worried. "The market is trading like we don't have price stability," he said yesterday. "If it were to stop here, I would not get that worked up, but why wait until it is bad?" He thinks the Fed should move quickly to raise rates.
The chances of that seem slim. The economic data show a decent but not extraordinary recovery, one that is built on a continued willingness of consumers to spend. But while there are fewer layoffs these days, the number of people receiving unemployment checks hit a new high this week. The Fed does not appear to be worried about inflation, and it is unlikely to raise rates while the health of the recovery is in doubt. 
As long as the Fed remains happy with low rates, companies are likely to continue betting on them. "The new buzz phrase is 'terming out,' " Mr. Bianco said. Companies with decent credit are issuing 5- or 10-year bonds and then using interest rate swaps to pay far lower rates than would be indicated by the rates on the bonds they are issuing. "When rates do go up," Mr. Bianco said, "it will pinch corporations more than you would expect."
The Fed's devotion to low rates could conceivably change if the stock market's current rally, now just more than a week old, is sustained. In some ways, that move has been a throwback to the good old bubble days. Technology stocks have led the way, as Cisco System's hints of a recovery in its business are magnified by eager speculators. Cisco is up 30 percent since the rally began, while Intel has gained 18 percent. Inflation-sensitive stocks have not been leaders in the latest climb, but most have continued to gain.
On balance, it is hard to believe that inflation is really much of a threat now. But those who thought inflation was going to increase have done much better in 2002 than almost any other investors. Markets that confound conventional wisdom sometimes signal that accepted verities are no longer reliable.

HEADLINE: Notes From Charleston; 
The Fight for the Soul of Coal Country

BYLINE:  By Michael Lipton; Michael Lipton is editor of Graffiti, a monthly news and arts publication in West Virginia.

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va. 

 BODY:
At the edge of Madison, a small southern West Virginia town once populated largely by miners and mine owners, a large sign proudly informs visitors they have entered "the gateway to the West Virginia coal fields."
 Coal has been West Virginia's blessing and curse for the better part of a century. The evidence is everywhere, and the state's history follows the emotional and violent tug of war between money and human beings, nature and technology. Today the consequences of this struggle are harsher and more polarized than ever because of "mountaintop removal," the latest technique in a long history of mining methods that have been hard on the land, the miners and the communities that depend on the mines. 
 The craggy hills, narrow hollows, streams and lush hardwood forests have long held people here hostage, body and soul. This is the only state that lies entirely in Appalachia, where building a few houses often means grading and leveling steep hillsides. But though we live in a place that requires fighting the landscape, West Virginians are by nature not a confrontational sort and are generally willing to turn the other cheek whenever possible. Lately that "live and let live" philosophy has been put to the test. 
This month's flooding -- some of the worst in the state's history -- and a new ruling by Judge Charles H. Haden II of Federal District Court in Charleston that threatens to severely limit mountaintop removal have now rekindled the long-running debate over how to hang on to an ever-dwindling number of mining jobs while preserving the extreme beauty of the land.
Most of the old jobs are long gone, on a steady decline since the 1940's, when coal field employment peaked at 140,000. In 2000, there were just 15,000 coal miners in West Virginia, despite record coal production.
Yet the 100-million-year-old hills and hollows where West Virginians have camped, hunted and fished are being destroyed in ways pick-and-shovel miners never could have imagined. Draglines, 20-story-tall machines, can move more than 100 tons of rock and dirt at a time. Mountaintops, euphemistically called "overlays," become "valley fills." An Environmental Protection Agency study found that valley fills have already buried more than 700 miles of West Virginia streams.
The coal industry, which has been engaged in varying degrees of mountaintop removal for three decades, still has enormous influence over state politics and a good part of the state's economy, though the fight over environmental effects drags on in the courts. In 1999 Judge Haden handed down a controversial decision that limited mountaintop removal. The decision (overturned by a federal appellate court two years later on a jurisdictional issue) threw the coal industry into a panic. The coal companies threatened layoffs and ultimately handed out hundreds of pink slips right before Christmas. They skillfully played upon the miners' frustration and directed it toward Judge Haden and the environmentalists. The miners joined in an unlikely coalition with the companies to protest the judge's ruling; one tactic was ringing the federal courthouse with dozens of huge coal trucks.
Even those who supported the ruling had to feel some sympathy with the miners. The southern, coal-rich counties, already the poorest in the state, can ill afford to lose jobs, and the federal government projects that mining jobs will decline by another 23 percent by 2010.
As for the land, even longtime miners have mixed emotions. They too see that by the time a mining operation leaves, there are few people left in the area to take advantage of the "development opportunities" left by flat moonlike expanses of land created by mountaintop removal. Residents who haven't been bought out by the coal companies are usually driven out by blasting, dust and truck traffic. Water tables are routinely altered, and it will be many generations before any hardwoods take root on mountaintop removal sites.
Last week, Judge Haden ruled that coal companies can no longer bury streams with mining rubble and charged that federal regulators in the Bush administration who are trying to legalize valley fills have violated the federal Clean Water Act. This time there has been far less reaction from either side than during the earlier court battle. Perhaps the coal interests are regrouping. Or perhaps they realize that their legal position is weak and sense public opinion turning -- though state lawmakers here, like the Bush administration, will probably remain coal-friendly to the last.
This week, driving through flood-ravaged McDowell County, past the twisted remains of mobile homes, overturned cars and houses devoured by rampaging creeks, it was hard not to be angry. There was no visible assistance coming from coal or timbering operators.
It has been decades since the coal towns in the southern part of the state bustled with activity. Engineers, politicians and industry officials may debate how much mining and timbering contribute to the devastating floods. But as the hills literally collapse around them, the people who live there may finally turn into environmental activists.

HEADLINE: Forest Service to Recommend Opening Alaska Forest Area 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
In its first major decision on wilderness protection, the Bush administration plans to recommend that nine million acres of the Tongass National Forest in Alaska be opened for logging, mining and road building, while 1.4 million acres of the state's Chugach National Forest receive the highest designation of protection.
 The Forest Service is to announce the recommendations on Friday. In documents, it said it was acting "to ensure that the many wild and beautiful areas along with the abundant fish and wildlife resources of the Tongass were protected while maintaining the availability of some of the Tongass for more intensive resource management in support of the economies of southeast Alaska and its scattered small communities." 
 Congress must approve all declarations of wilderness, which is the highest protection except for a national park or monument. 
Alaska lawmakers and the timber industry were relieved that the administration had refrained from designating more of the Tongass forest as wilderness. Already, 6.6 million acres of the Tongass, an old-growth rain forest, are protected as wilderness. The forest is 16.8 million acres, about the size of West Virginia.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said enough of the Tongass forest was already protected.
"Nearly 97 percent of the forest is fully protected," Mr. Murkowski said. "It is only reasonable that 3 percent be left for multiple use so that Alaskans can have jobs that allow them to live in the region."
Tom Puchlerz, the Tongass forest supervisor, said that only about 10 percent of the nine million acres would be open for development.
"The economic development in our communities in southeast Alaska is important, as are the materials for the nation in terms of timber and minerals," Mr. Puchlerz said.
Environmentalists said the decisions bode poorly for the protection of other wilderness and roadless areas across the country. They said that the recommendation for the 5.5 million-acre Chugach forest protected too little of the forest's accessible land and that the Tongass recommendation was a gift to the timber industry.
The Chugach forest, the nation's second-largest national forest after the Tongass, is southeast of Anchorage and has just 100 miles of roads on the 4.1 million acres that the administration is not seeking to designate as wilderness. The part that would be protected includes forested islands, rugged mountains, extensive ice fields and tidewater glaciers.
Sue Libenson, a spokeswoman for the Alaska Coalition, said the Chugach areas recommended for wilderness designation were remote rocky and glacial parts, mostly unsuitable for economic development anyway.
"We are concerned they will not support wilderness for the areas that are biologically important or accessible to the general public," Ms. Libenson said of the Forest Service.
Administration officials said they were doing better than the Clinton administration on the Chugach forest by recommending any wilderness designation. As for the Tongass forest, they said, they were simply affirming the position of the Clinton administration. 
Environmentalists, however, said the Bush administration was playing a shell game with these terms, noting that the Clinton administration had not reviewed the areas for wilderness designation and had designated parts of the Tongass forest as roadless areas.
Jeremy Anderson, a spokesman for the Southeast Alaska Conservation Council, said: "Clinton said, You can't log or road in these areas, and now the Bush administration is saying, Have at it. They're pushing more than 30 timber sales in these areas."
Mark Rey, under secretary for natural resources and environment in the Agriculture Department, said the Chugach forest recommendation, which is final, was the largest wilderness designation that any administration had sent to Congress since 1984.
The Tongass recommendation is a draft statement from the Forest Service. It will be subject to public comment for 90 days before being proposed as a final rule. Both sides predicted that the matter would be settled in court.
Since the middle of the last century, the timber industry has clear-cut hundreds of thousands of acres of the Tongass's old-growth forest and built more than 4,600 miles of roads.
Ms. Libenson of the Alaska Coalition said the announcement on both the Tongass and Chugach forests was an effort by the Forest Service "to cover a very bad, embarrassing decision on the Tongass with a second-rate decision on the Chugach."
Mr. Rey said the Chugach decision was not meant to distract from or counterbalance the Tongass one, but that since both forests were in Alaska, the recommendations might as well be announced simultaneously.

HEADLINE: Russia and China Called Top Business Bribers 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
When more than 800 business experts in 15 emerging-market countries were asked recently to identify the most flagrant bribe-payers in richer nations seeking contracts, Russian and Chinese companies emerged at the top of the list, according to a report this week from Transparency International, an independent anticorruption organization.
 Speaking at a news conference in Paris on Tuesday, Peter Eigen, chairman of the organization, said that in dealing with emerging-market countries, the Russians and Chinese were "using bribes on an exceptional and intolerable scale." 
 Taiwan and South Korea were close behind, said the survey, conducted for Transparency International by the Gallup International Association.
But perhaps more surprising, in the view of Transparency International, was the perception that anti-bribery laws in the United States and other industrial nations were apparently not deterring bribe-payers from multinational companies based in the West and Japan. 
In the survey, the names of 21 industrial countries were given to business and banking leaders in emerging-market nations for comment and ranking. On a scale of 1 to 10 -- with 1 being the most prone to bribery and 10 the least -- the United States got a score of 5.3, the same rating as Japan. The "cleanest" countries, though not perfect, were Australia, Sweden, Switzerland, Austria and Canada. Singapore, and most companies in Europe, were considered less corrupt than their American counterparts.
Bribing foreigners to gain business has been against the law in the United States since 1977 under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which groups most industrial countries, introduced a worldwide convention against bribery three years ago. 
Transparency International, whose founders are former World Bank officials, introduced the "bribe payers' index" in 1999 in order to balance its older "corruption perception index." That index routinely cited developing countries as the most corrupt in the eyes of international business analysts.
The reaction from those developing countries often was a countercharge that somebody has to offer or agree to pay bribes for corruption to take place. It was the strong message that Jerry Rawlings, who was president of Ghana, brought to the United Nations in a General Assembly speech two years ago, in which he accused the rich nations of creating the corruption in Africa that they then criticized.
Both indexes from Transparency International measure only the perceptions of those engaged in business around the world who have experience in dealing with bribery and other irregular or illegal transactions. No attempt is made to quantify corruption, which even international organizations like the World Bank or International Monetary Fund find difficult to calculate with certainty.
In its new bribe-payers report, released on Tuesday, Transparency International said the most bribery appeared to take place in the construction and military sectors, where government officials can exert pressure on foreign companies to pay bribes or lose contracts. Agriculture was the least likely economic sector to be affected, the survey found, although it was also not free of bribery. No companies are identified in the new report.
The 835 business experts interviewed between December 2001 and March 2002 by Gallup organizations in emerging market economies were in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Mexico, Morocco, Nigeria, the Philippines, Poland, Russia, South Africa, South Korea and Thailand. The experts included senior executives in multinational and domestic companies, chartered accountants, chamber of commerce leaders, bankers and lawyers.
In some cases, the countries they represented were both receivers and sellers of goods and services in developing economies. The survey of business leaders found that bribery was also prevalent in domestic transactions in these countries.
Transparency International, based in Berlin and calling itself a coalition against corruption, has chapters in countries around the world and is supported by grants from governments, foundations and corporations. A copy of the index is online at www.transparency.org.

HEADLINE: Police Dept. Reports Jump In Applicants 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
The number of applicants to take the exam to become a city police officer has risen to more than 35,000, nearly three times as many as applied for last June's exam. The Police Department attributes the sharp rise in part to a new system that allows applicants to register on the Internet. 
 About half the applicants, 17,651, used the Internet to file for next month's exam. The department said the large increase would enable it to find replacements for the large number of officers retiring. 
 The surge is a welcome sign for the department for other reasons, as well. The precinct station torture of Abner Louima and the death of Amadou Diallo in a hail of police bullets made it more difficult for the department to attract recruits. The police union's public complaint about low starting salaries also hurt. 
There was some change in recruiting in the aftermath of Sept. 11. The heroic acts of officers vastly improved the department's image, and as the economy dipped after the attack, the prospect of a stable job with a secure pension and benefits package became more attractive.
Those gains were offset, though, as thousands of officers decided to retire after earning large amounts of overtime that sharply increased their pension benefits. (Pension calculations are based on officers' earnings for their last year on the job.) 
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, alarmed by the retirement rate and disappointed that only 6,000 candidates showed up for a police exam in February, expanded recruitment in other states and on military bases and appointed an assistant chief to supervise recruiting efforts and to report directly to him. 
Allowing applicants to file for the exam online -- at www.nyc.gov/html/nypd /home.html -- is simpler, but it is unclear whether those applicants will be as committed to pursuing a police career as past recruits have been. Before the department's system went online in March, the only way to apply was to get an application -- usually at a police station or a recruiting fair -- fill it out and mail it back with a $35 fee. That fee was rescinded last year in an effort to attract more applicants. 
So next month's exam will measure whether the higher application rate actually produces more officers for a city in need, as well as test whether the department has hit upon a new, cost-effective way of expanding the recruitment pool.
Even with the recruiting problems, the number of applicants had slowly crept up over the last two years. Altogether, 8,617 signed up for the May 2000 exam, 12,122 for the December 2000 exam, and 12,929 for the exam the following June. The number dropped again early this year while the department continued to hemorrhage officers, at so fast a rate that today, it is left with 37,465 officers, the lowest level in five years. Its highest level was 40,710.
The increase in applicants is only one sign of a renewed interest in law enforcement careers, police officials said. In the last two months, 1,979 other people have taken the test at walk-in locations around the country, including 373 who took it May 11 at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
At that forum, police recruiters had to turn away more than 700 people because there were not enough seats; most of the applicants were not students but local residents in need of work. Fifty-nine people signed up for the June test in a recruiting drive at Columbia, 29 applied at Yale, and 78 applied at New York University.
What remains an open question, however, is how many of the 35,689 people who have signed up this time -- the highest number since 57,888 applied in 1993 -- will actually show up when the three-hour exam is given June 8 at about a dozen city high schools.
In prior years, only about half of those who had applied showed up on test day. Of those, about 75 percent got a passing grade of 70 or better. Only 1 in 10 of those who pass are found suitable to hire. Many are rejected because they cannot meet the educational criteria -- at least 60 college credits are required -- or do not meet the standards for physical or psychological fitness.
About a quarter of the online applications have come from other states and from many foreign countries, including Canada (25), Australia (7), and France, Italy and Ireland (2 each). Clearly, many of those applicants will not make a long and expensive trip to New York.
Even if only half the 35,000 applicants arrive on test day, it would be the largest number to take the exam in nearly a decade. If past trends hold, that could provide a pool of nearly 1,800 recruits, said Chief Rafael Pineiro, who was the assistant chief appointed by Mr. Kelly to take charge of recruitment and who has since been promoted to chief of personnel.
Some in the police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said the high number of applicants was short of what was needed because the pay scale is driving hundreds of officers out before retirement age. Some skeptics, for example, have criticized the department's efforts to recruit at elite universities because, they say, such college graduates could earn far more than the $31,305 annual starting salary for a city police officer. 
"What good is spending money to recruit and to train, only to have the successful candidates leave for the first better-paying job that becomes available?" said the union president, Patrick J. Lynch, through a spokesman. "That money would be better used to pay New York City police officers a salary that will keep them at the N.Y.P.D. Otherwise, New York City has become the nation's job fair for police officers."
In part because of the Internet, however, the current recruitment drive cost $2.8 million, when other, far less successful campaigns cost $10 million. 
Nearly 60 percent of the current applicants are members of minorities, who have typically had more college credits than white recruits. That higher educational level, Mr. Kelly said, undermined any notion that the department might have to lower its standards to attract minority candidates. 
Alexander S. Ford, the chief executive of PoliceOne, a law enforcement technology company in San Francisco, said that very few police departments have Internet recruitment systems, though some allow Internet users to print an application form and mail it in. 
Saying the New York department was ahead of the trend, he said he was working with the police in San Francisco and Oakland in developing a system to allow Internet users to file applications online and to communicate with the departments electronically.
Thomas M. Sharkey, a doctoral student at Columbia who signed up for the police exam after he was laid off from a job in private business in December, said that despite the low starting pay, he was one of many young people with a newfound sense of public service after witnessing the heroism police officers showed on Sept. 11.
"I guess the pay is not a lot to start out," said Mr. Sharkey, 31. "But what is more important to me, and especially since 9/11, is a sense that I want to contribute to other people, and that I have a civic responsibility to help others."

HEADLINE: Lindh Lawyers Claim 'Selective Prosecution' 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
In another novel legal argument, lawyers for John Walker Lindh, the Californian accused of fighting alongside the Taliban, said today that the government was using "selective prosecution" in indicting him but taking no action against others who have conducted business with or worked on behalf of the former Afghanistan regime.
 One of those, the defense lawyers said, is Laili Helms, the niece of Richard Helms, the former director of central intelligence, who was born in Afghanistan and until the Sept. 11 attacks was "the Taliban's unofficial envoy to the United States." 
 In 2 of the 10 counts against him, Mr. Lindh is charged with "supplying services to the Taliban" and conspiracy to do so. 
But his lawyers argue that the statute on which the government is basing its claim applies only to commercial and financial transactions. 
They say Mr. Lindh had been singled out for prosecution only because he was exercising his right to practice whatever religion he chose and to associate with whomever he wanted.
Moreover, they said Mr. Lindh could not get a fair trial in Virginia because of its proximity to the Pentagon, where a hijacked plane crashed on Sept. 11, and because of repeated statements by government officials that have "poisoned the atmosphere" against their client. 
They asked the judge to dismiss the case or at a minimum transfer it.
The defense, seeking an additional hearing on the matter of selective prosecution, made these arguments in papers filed today in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. The prosecution is to respond to these papers in its own court filings.
The argument about selective prosecution was novel insofar as it relates to the Taliban.
Basing its assertions on newspaper articles, the defense said that a telephone company, based in Parsippany, N.J., won a $240 million contract to build a wireless telephone system for Afghanistan and began work on it in May 1999. In July 1999, in the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, President Bill Clinton barred transactions with the Taliban. At that point, one of the company's officers said he would disregard the sanctions and move the company out of the United States.
The defense also said that Unocal, an American oil company, pursued its business interests in Afghanistan after the ban. Unocal officials said they abandoned the project long before the sanctions, but defense lawyers cite later articles asserting continuing contact about the pipeline with the Bush administration.
In another instance, the defense cites Ms. Helms, who is the granddaughter of a former Afghan minister. In an article in The Village Voice before Sept. 11, she talked about her services to the Taliban, saying she "patches together conference calls between the Taliban leadership and State Department officials," paying $1,000 for one of those calls from her own pocket. 
Finally, the defense cites the case of Abdul Hakim Mohahid, who was sent to New York in January 1997 as the Taliban's envoy to the United Nations. He did not have a seat with the international body but operated from an office in Queens.
Again quoting newspaper articles, the defense lawyers said that he was not asked to leave after sanctions were imposed. 
Mr. Lindh, his lawyers said, "is apparently the first and only person to have been prosecuted" under the regulations that imposed the sanctions, "despite evidence that several other individuals and organizations have engaged in activities in violation of the same prohibitions." They also said the prosecution never described what services Mr. Lindh is alleged to have provided the Taliban.

HEADLINE: Home Building Was Off in April 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16 

 BODY:
The construction of new homes fell in April to the lowest level in six months and the number of workers seeking unemployment benefits rose unexpectedly last week, two reports released today showed, pointing to a moderating economic expansion.
 Builders started work at an annual rate of 1.56 million homes last month, down 5.4 percent from March, for the slowest pace since October, the Commerce Department said. 
Initial unemployment claims increased to 418,000 last week, and the number of people drawing benefits earlier this month, 3.9 million, was the highest in almost two decades, the Labor Department said. 
 "It will take some time for vigorous growth to extend to all industries and regions of the nation," said Michael Moskow, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, in a speech today.
The employment report reinforces the concern of central bankers that businesses are skeptical about increasing investment and hiring.
April is the first month this year that housing starts have fallen below a pace of 1.6 million units. They surged past 1.7 million in January and February, helped by mild weather and low interest rates, and fell to 1.64 million in March.
Analysts had expected the number of starts to drop in April to 1.625 million, based on the median of 58 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. Starts for single-family homes decreased 2 percent in April, to a rate of 1.27 million units. Starts for multifamily homes plunged 18.1 percent in April, to a 285,000 annual rate.
By region, starts fell 19.5 percent in the Midwest, to an annual pace of 276,000; 5.8 percent in the West, to 377,000; and 24.1 percent in the Northeast, to 126,000. Starts rose 5.6 percent in the South, to 776,000.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Waterfront Could Still Be a Contender

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IF you wanted an analysis of New York's decrepit waterfront, on Wednesday you had a choice. You could either listen to the governor of New Jersey deliver the keynote address at the Waterfront 2002 Conference, or you could go cruising on a catboat with William Kornblum. 
 It wasn't all that hard a choice, especially if you knew Dr. Kornblum's curriculum vitae. He is an expert in decrepitude on and off the waterfront. As a sociologist at the City University of New York Graduate Center, two decades ago he led a research team that meticulously documented the old Times Square. The social scientists analyzed where drug sales took place. They watched kung-fu movies and peep shows. They monitored pimps' favorite bars and drew maps of prostitutes' strolls. It was the kind of sociological research you could talk about at cocktail parties without anyone's eyes glazing over. 
 When he was not immersed in vice at the center of Manhattan, Dr. Kornblum was out sailing New York's waterways in his small catboat, a 24-foot fishing boat. It nearly ended up on the bottom of the harbor a few times, but it survived long enough for him to write "At Sea in the City: New York From the Water's Edge," just published by Algonquin Books. It's an exploration of New York's greatest natural resource, which is remarkably unfamiliar to its inhabitants. 
As he cruised along the shores of Brooklyn and Manhattan, Dr. Kornblum pointed out what wasn't there: people. "So much of the waterfront remains underused," he said. "It's hard for an average family to get to the water. There are thousands of sailors at the edge of the city, across the line in the suburbs, but they regard the waters of New York as dirty, industrial, inhospitable -- a place to get through on their way somewhere else."
Go to Baltimore or, better, Sydney, Australia, and you'll see a harbor filled with boats ferrying tourists and residents from one attraction to another. Why is our waterfront property abandoned? Why, until a company from Sydney proposed it recently, didn't anyone in New York try letting people climb the Brooklyn Bridge? 
New York's regulatory morass is often blamed for the moribund waterfront, but there are plenty of regulations in Sydney, too. It took nine years (and overcoming 62 bureaucratic objections) to get permission for tourists to climb Sydney's Harbor Bridge. 
New York's chief problem may simply be its size: too much waterfront, too many distractions. Baltimore and Sydney are smaller cities whose identities and economies depend on their harbors, so politicians pay attention to the waterfront. So do politicians in Jersey City, where old railroad yards have recently been turned into a thriving community.
Across the water, meanwhile, there are empty lots and buildings in Brooklyn. Manhattan has barely managed to build a bike path and a few parks. Boaters have a hard time landing. If the Upper West Side were a separate town (or People's Republic), it would probably never have allowed the 79th Street Boat Basin to be converted from a recreational marina into a subsidized residential community. A small town wouldn't want its waterfront taken over by a bunch of permanent squatters whose "boats" never leave the dock, but the problem isn't big enough to matter at City Hall.
IF Astoria or Staten Island were separate towns, there might already be tourists clambering atop the Hell Gate Bridge (the railroad span next to the Triborough Bridge) and the Bayonne Bridge, which are steel-arch bridges quite similar to Sydney's Harbor Bridge. (In fact, the Bayonne Bridge to Staten Island is slightly longer.) But city officials have had too many other concerns, like persuading tourists to visit Times Square.
"Times Square got attention from the city's powerful actors because theater owners feared for their survival," Dr. Kornblum said. "Now you've got an increasing coalition of neighborhood groups and community activists trying to do something about the waterfront, and they're attracting some attention. But it's easier to focus on a specific place like Times Square than to develop initiatives for a 500-mile waterfront."
What could the waterfront look like 20 years from now? "In a lot of areas there probably won't be much improvement," Dr. Kornblum said, "but we could see changes in places like the Gowanus Canal and Governor's Island and Newtown Creek. Parts of New York City could have very, very active river life, somewhat like Venice."
Venice on the Gowanus? It's hard to imagine, but then, 20 years ago, so was Disney in Times Square.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 Dell's Financial Results Slightly Beat Expectations
Despite the depressed state of the personal computer business, Dell Computer reported that its quarterly sales and profits matched the results of a year ago. Its financial results slightly surpassed Wall Street's expectations. The performance was regarded by analysts as further evidence that Dell stands apart from the rest of the industry, gaining market share while rivals fade. Page C5.

US Airways Seeks Big Concessions
Executives at US Airways met with union representatives to discuss a plan to cut costs by $1.3 billion with the goal of obtaining a $1 billion federal loan guarantee. Of that, $950 million would come from nonmanagement labor costs and $50 million from management. C2.

Shouting Match at Andersen Trial
Tensions between lawyers for Arthur Andersen and the federal judge overseeing the firm's criminal trial exploded in a shouting match. The judge, Melinda Harmon, accused the defense of being "underhanded" and the lead lawyer, Rusty Hardin, responded that the judge was biased against them. C7.

Schwab to Grade Stocks on a Curve
Charles Schwab has begun rating stocks as part of its gradual move toward advising investors. Schwab is rating about 3,500 companies as investments, but unlike competitors on Wall Street, it is grading on a curve. C2.

ImClone Systems Dealt a Setback
In another potential blow to ImClone Systems, the company with the European rights to its cancer drug, Erbitux, Merck of Germany, has decided not to modify its clinical trials in some ways ImClone thought would help the drug win approval in the United States. C6.

Hackers Steal Ford Credit Reports
Hackers posing as Ford Motor Credit employees have in recent months harvested a trove of 13,000 credit reports -- a virtual one-stop shop for fraud and identity theft -- with data on consumers in affluent neighborhoods. C5.

F.B.I. Is Conducting Kmart Inquiry
The F.B.I., working with the United States attorney in Detroit, said it was examining Kmart's records to determine whether its activities warranted criminal charges. C4.

Prada Confirms Plans for Offering
Patrizio Bertelli, left, announced that Prada would offer shares on the Milan stock exchange by the end of the summer, market conditions permitting. Mr. Bertelli, who owns the company with his wife, the designer Miuccia Prada, said that because it was the only major luxury goods group not publicly traded, Prada lacked some of the economic power its rivals enjoyed. World Business, Section W.

Fox Starts Almost From Scratch
The Fox network, coming off a season of ratings setbacks and needing to find hits to replace two of its departing signature shows in "Ally McBeal" and "The X-Files," announced that it would alter six of seven nights of its prime-time lineup. Advertising. C6.

The CBS Television president Leslie Moonves spoke to advertisers on behalf of UPN, the youthful network that was added to his portfolio at Viacom earlier this year. C6.

Vivendi Ends Deal, but With a Catch
The News Corporation rejected a decision by Vivendi Universal to abandoned its planned acquisition of Stream, an Italian pay-television company owned by the News Corporation and Telecom Italia. Vivendi is under pressure to reduce debt. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: America's Poor Standards 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
On Tuesday Standard & Poor's, the private bond rating agency, announced that it would do something unprecedented: It will try to impose accounting standards substantially stricter than those required by the federal government. Instead of taking corporate reports at face value, S.&P. will correct the numbers to eliminate what it considers the inappropriate treatment of "one-time" expenses, pension fund earnings and, above all, stock options -- a major part of executive compensation that, according to federal standards, somehow isn't a business expense. S.&P.'s estimate of "core earnings" for the 500 largest companies slashes reported profits by an astonishing 25 percent.
 Why does S.&P. -- along with Warren Buffett, Alan Greenspan and just about every serious financial economist -- think that current accounting standards require a drastic overhaul? And if such an overhaul is needed, why doesn't the government do it? Why does S.&P. think that it must do the job itself? 
 To see the absurdity of the current rules, consider stock options. An executive is given the right to purchase shares of the company's stock, at a fixed price, some time in the future. If the stock rises, he buys at bargain prices. If the stock falls, he doesn't exercise the option. At worst, he loses nothing; at best, he makes a lot of money. Nice work if you can get it. 
Yet according to federal accounting standards, such deals don't cost employers anything, as long as the guaranteed price isn't below the market price on the day the option is granted. Of course, this ignores the "heads I win, tails you lose" aspect: executives get a share of investors' gains if things go well, but don't share the losses if things go badly. In fact, companies literally apply a double standard: they deduct the cost of options from taxable income, even while denying that they cost anything in their profit statements.
So how could it possibly make sense not to count options as a cost? Defenders of the current system argue that stock options align the interests of executives with those of investors. Even if that were true, however, it wouldn't justify ignoring the cost -- no more than it would make sense to deny that wages, which provide incentives to workers, are a business expense. Furthermore, it's now clear that stock options, far from reliably inducing executives to serve shareholders, often create perverse incentives. At worst, they handsomely reward managers who run their companies as pump-and-dump schemes; executives at Enron and many other companies got rich thanks to stock prices that soared before they collapsed. 
Options are only part of an accounting system in deep trouble. As David Blitzer, S.&P.'s chief investment strategist, recently wrote, "Financial markets are as much a social contract as is democratic government." Yet there is a growing sense that this contract is being broken, undermining the trust that is so essential to the operation of financial markets. Clearly, major reforms are needed. And bear in mind that this isn't a left-right issue; it's about protecting investors -- middle-class and wealthy alike -- from exploitation by self-dealing insiders. So who could possibly be opposed? You'd be surprised.
Harvey Pitt, the accounting-industry lawyer who heads the Securities and Exchange Commission, has clearly been dragging his feet on reform. And his boss, George W. Bush, has declared himself opposed to treating stock options as a business expense. Wouldn't it be nice, just once, to see the Bush administration oppose the interests of a privileged elite? 
But the administration is not alone in its foot-dragging. In fact, perhaps the biggest foot-dragger of all is Senator Joseph Lieberman. Way back in 1994 Mr. Lieberman gave crucial aid to lobbyists trying to head off new accounting standards, which would have forced companies to recognize the cost of options; now he is once again defending the status quo, urging his colleagues to go slow.
Some politicians do see the problem; John McCain and Carl Levin have introduced legislation to reform America's accounting standards. But it seems unlikely that government will fix our dysfunctional accounting rules anytime soon.
Mr. Blitzer of S.&P. points out that in previous periods of corporate scandal, "legislators and prosecutors took the lead in tackling public concerns over the market." It is a sad commentary on our leadership that this time he feels that he must do the job himself.

HEADLINE: Budget in Albany Has Few Cuts But Relies on One-Time Revenue 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 16 

 BODY:
While states around the country are reducing spending, New York lawmakers today approved an $89.6 billion budget that sidesteps cuts in services by relying heavily on one-time revenues and nearly exhausting the state's reserves.
 As they debated the bills, several lawmakers said that Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders were betting that the regional economy and the stock market would improve enough to save them from ugly cutbacks or tax increases next year. 
 The spending plan, which passed overwhelmingly today, comes at a time when a recession, worsened by the effect of the terrorist attacks, has forced the majority of states to cut spending, defer tax refunds and take other drastic measures. Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the leader of New York's Republican Senate majority, said that the lawmakers had "truly worked a miracle." 
But other lawmakers said the effect was more akin to a mirage. The plan leaves the state with a bare $710 million in reserves at the end of the fiscal year, next March 31. It also uses about $3.1 billion in revenue that will not be available next year and adds $900 million in debt.
"There are a lot of fingers being crossed that the assumptions used in this budget don't lead us to come back later in the year to cut back on our commitments," Assemblyman Alexander B. Pete Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat, said.
Some Democrats said they would have preferred to have raised income taxes temporarily rather than rely on what they characterized as fiscal gimmicks. The Republican governor, however, dug in his heels in negotiations and refused to raise income or business taxes.
Mr. Pataki, who said he would approve the budget, has argued that it is the right time to spend the savings the state has built up over the last five years to make it through a tough economic time. He and the Senate Republicans predict the budget will stimulate the economy by providing $600 million in seed money for high-tech industries and expanding tax breaks for upstate businesses. They say that tax collections will then grow.
"We did what few other states did, and that was to put away money for a rainy day," Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman, Michael McKeon, said. "We are ready to weather this storm without massive cutbacks you see all over the country."
All told, the budget raises spending about 6 percent, though the portion paid through state taxes and fees will go up only 3 percent. It also imposes some new taxes and increases a number of obscure fees to bring in about $85 million more. The tax on cellular telephones, for instance, will rise to $1.20 a month from 70 cents to get $38 million. Hunting and fishing fees will be raised to generate about $6 million more.
The budget also counts on reducing the state work force by at least 5,000 through incentives for early retirement and a hiring freeze.
The governor and lawmakers also agreed to shift many costs from the state to the federal government. College scholarships, for instance, will be financed with $380 million from a surplus of federal welfare money that the state has built up since 1996 as people have left the rolls. Using welfare money for scholarships is particularly ironic since, under new rules, welfare recipients are required to work, making it virtually impossible for them to go to college, advocates for the poor said.
"The money can go to college, but the people can't," said Michael Kink, a lobbyist for Housing Works, an antipoverty group. "They are basically just using it to plug a hole."
The Legislature is also raiding special funds for the environment and health care to get $400 million for general purposes. Another $150 million will be taken from the state mortgage agency accounts.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat running for governor this year, sharply criticized the use of one-shot revenues, new debt and raids on dedicated funds.
"At a time when we need strong leadership and new approaches from the governor, we are getting a budget that relies on the types of gimmicks that left New York lagging behind other states during the boom times," Mr. McCall said. Mr. McKeon dismissed Mr. McCall's criticism as a partisan attack.
While Mr. McCall stopped short of calling for an increase in taxes to raise revenues, some Democrats said the state's financial condition warranted new levies. "There is not enough money in this budget to pay for the programs we are funding," Senator Eric T. Schneiderman said during the floor debate. "Let's tell our constituents the truth: we have to raise revenues."
For most of the lawmakers, the most important slice of the budget is state aid to local schools. The final budget raises the state aid to local districts by $420 million over last year's total, despite the governor's initial proposal to freeze aid. The state will spend a total $14.6 billion on schools this year under the budget passed today.
New York City will receive at least $163 million of the increase in school operating aid, though the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has promised to raise that figure to $200 million through the use of funds under his control.
But the city schools will also get a one-time infusion of about $200 million to reimburse the city for school programs it paid for in past years. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the extra $400 million would allow the city to limit cuts to the city's education budget.
The budget does not include other revenues Mayor Bloomberg requested, like the authority to raise the city's cigarette taxes and parking fines. Nor does it grant the mayor control over the city schools. Those issues will be dealt with in a separate bill next week, aides to Mr. Silver said.
There were some small surprises hidden in the voluminous budget documents. The state has agreed to extend the franchise of the New York Racing Association, a nonprofit organization that operates the state's premier thoroughbred tracks. The franchise will be extended for an extra five years, to 2012, and the state is providing financing to help it install video lottery machines at Aqueduct Raceway in Queens.
A few new programs are being born as well. For the first time, the state will provide $5 million to directly combat AIDS in black and Latino neighborhoods, where 9 out of 10 new infections now occur.
Even with the uncertainty surrounding future revenue, lawmakers did not cut back on the pool of money they get each year to spend as they choose in their districts. Each house will receive $85 million for what are known as member items and the governor will receive $30 million.
The budget passed 46 days late, but no budget has been passed on time for 18 years. In a break with tradition, the leaders did not hold an all-night session and force tired legislators to vote on bills they had barely read. Several lawmakers congratulated themselves on having passed the budget in daylight, as if it were a significant achievement.
Most Assembly members received the first batch of bills -- a stack of paper 10 inches thick held together with rubber bands -- at 8 a.m. The debate on those measures began two hours later. A second batch of bills was delivered in the late afternoon. The lower house finished passing the bills at 4:35 p.m., and the Senate finished voting a half-hour later.
Most of the lawmakers left in high spirits, but a few expressed worries about the economic assumptions underlying the budget.
Pataki administration officials said the steep drop-off in tax collections in April, which opened a $1.2 billion hole in the state's spending plan, had caught them off guard, as many partners in small companies paid far less income tax than anticipated.
Budget officials predict that income tax revenue will shrink slightly this year after falling 4.5 percent in the last fiscal year. One reason is that the stock market, which drives much of the income tax revenue in the state, is not expected to return to its 2000 apex.
