HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 5-19-02: ON LANGUAGE; 
Weapons Grade

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
Are you in favor of same-sex marriage? Have you recently gone through wrong-site surgery leading to a near-death experience? Do you search a drop-down menu to find a with-it shop so that you can look (to use a compound adverb) drop-dead gorgeous in your bare-midriff dress? 
 When the vogue for compound adjectives was just getting under way, the hyphenated terms were usually literal: a white-collar worker wore a white shirt to the office, and a blue-collar worker's collar at the factory was often blue. The literal meaning is expressed today in disco-inspired tees (formerly T-shirts) and Gucci's under-the-breast corset. But the hyphenations could also be metaphoric: lace-curtain Irish required some knowledge of social history, much as baby-boom generation does today. Early on, the precedent was established permitting the stringing-together of several words: the going-out-of-business sale of the Depression is matched in word number by out-of-the-box thinking today. 
 Now the hyphenation of modifiers rules the linguistic roost. This rule-roosting device -- See? Nothing to it -- satisfies the need for the new: "Hyphenation gives the impression," says Frank Abate, former editor in chief of the U.S. Dictionaries program at Oxford University Press, "that the compound is novel, imaginative or requires some background knowledge." He notes that some of these double-word modifiers grow out of adverbial phrases: in "technology at the cutting edge," the adverbial phrase is swung around in front of the noun to become cutting-edge technology; in the same way, "you can track changes in real time" becomes real-time data.
The compression of modification suits headline writers and e-mail correspondents, whose shortness of space or haste in composition makes them the language's leading squeezers. A statement like "a host is on duty at our Web site continuously" is whittled down to 24/7/365-hosting. Some compound adjectives are dying: push-button convenience is passe, and solid-state electronics, which substitutes transistors for vacuum tubes, is not needed in an age that assumes vacuum to be a noun for a device that sucks up dirt. State-of-the-art anything died from overuse, and world-class is out of the competition, falling back into the nonce-word category. And parody has weakened industrial-strength.
I am not the only language maven to notice this. At Astrakhan State Pedagogical University, located in the Volga River delta, Maya Ryashchina had found three patterns: noun plus postpositive, as in hands-on manager and heads-up tennis; verb plus postpositive, as in drive-by killing; and a modal verb plus infinitive, as in can-do mentality, must-have wine and must-see film. (Go, Astrakhan S.P.U.!)
Euphemizers have reached out for compound adjectives. Adults of generous girth or a tendency toward obesity (whom the insensitive used to call "fat people") wear big-and-tall clothes for men, plus-size for women.
The soul-satisfying impetus for our compound-modifying discourse . . . it's getting to me . . . begin again. The biggest boost to the use of hyphenated adjectives in the way we write has come from the military. In that target-rich environment, we find the World War II use of company-grade and field-grade officers. In the 1960's, zero-defect quality control and zero-tolerance policies made their mark, promptly picked up by politicians. "An unfortunate inclusion in the U.S. legislation," biologists observed at the Royal Society of London in 1967, "was the use of the term 'zero tolerance,' which implied a nil residue level." (In the scandal affecting the Catholic Church today, a zero-tolerance policy toward pedophile priests is in the headlines.)
What single term epitomizes the triumph of the compound adjective? The hands-down winner (in the old days, I would have written, "The winner, hands down," and come to think of it, that's more emphatic) is weapons-grade. 
This was coined in a 1952 policy statement by the Atomic Energy Commission calling for "nuclear plants which are economically independent of government commitments to purchase weapons grade plutonium." It was not then hyphenated; that was done a year later by the scientist George L. Weil, the colleague of Enrico Fermi at the University of Chicago who physically initiated the first nuclear chain reaction. Weil started a linguistic chain reaction as well: the meaning became "fissionable material of a quality for use in nuclear weapons," and its serious meaning now applies to biological agents as well.
As with all horrific words, it was quickly absorbed into popular culture. Voted the "catch-all superlative" of last year by the American Dialect Society, weapons-grade has been used to modify everything from a Toyota's torque output to Elvis Presley's charisma. Allan Metcalf, the Dialect Society's executive secretary, explains, "Weapons-grade salsa would mean really hot."

STOVEPIPING
The new bete noire of the military, and of the most modern managers, is stovepiping.
"Flat organizations work better than vertical organizations," decrees the Pentagon's manpower analysis handbook. "It should be noted that stovepiping is not inherently evil, but the burden of proof should be on the stovepiping function to demonstrate that it is not."
Lt. Gen. Ed Rowny, retired, urged in The Wall Street Journal that Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security, be given authority to order widely dispersed bureaucracies into coordinated action. Ridge's present problem? "Rampant stovepiping -- different agencies under different command."
Rowny was present at the time of the creation of the word. When he was working for James Forrestal in forming the Defense Department in 1947, he notes, "we all went up and down our particular chain of command, but when it came time for the Army to cooperate with the Navy, we'd stovepipe -- go up to the top of the pipe and then back down, instead of cross feeding."
The noun stovepipe is a vertical cylinder carrying a stove's smoke up through the roof. As an adjective modifying "hat," it describes the tall top hat that Lincoln wore. Now that business schools use the participle form, stovepiping, in derogation of managers who fail to look around, the question arises: what do rising managers call horizontal cooperation that avoids direction from the top? Floorboarding comes to mind, but other entries will be considered at OnLanguage@nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: From Ruin to Renovation, Philipsburgh Hall Bustles Again 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
IF you are in downtown Yonkers past 4:30 and want a cup of coffee, let alone a beer, you are pretty much out of luck. Even in the dead of winter, the shops and lunch spots on and around Getty Square close well before dark.
 But the recent, meticulous restoration of Philipsburgh Hall -- a crumbling but impressive historic building -- has been attracting people with concerts and lessons in swing, salsa and ballroom dancing. A few weeks ago, people from all over Westchester drove to hear a jazz quartet from Juilliard, filling the Philipsburgh concert room for the first time in decades. The performances scheduled for the summer through the winter at the Philipsburgh Performing Arts Center range from an Aeschylus tragedy to jazz guitar and Irish music. 
 "We wanted to reconnect people to what it was," said Charles G. Lief, president of the Greyston Foundation, a nonprofit community group that co-owns the building. "And we wanted the community to have a place for performances that's not a school gym."
A contingent of painters, musicians and writers have moved into 28 newly restored apartments in the building. Most are from Manhattan and Brooklyn, said Mr. Lief, and were attracted by relatively low rents set aside for artists, as well as the marble halls and sweeping views of the Hudson River.
"The myth is that artists are always on the front edge of neighborhood revivals," he said. "We hope that's what's going to happen here. They're bringing a whole new energy here."
At the turn of the century, the streets of downtown Yonkers were filled with bustle and energy. When Philipsburgh Hall opened in 1905, the city was a major manufacturing center, with more than enough prosperous burghers to support an elegant building for vaudeville, concerts and dances. (In 1917, for instance, 1,200 people crammed into the hall for the first Yonkers Police Association reception, featuring bango-strumming, singing and dancing until the early hours of the morning.) But the factories started closing more than 50 years ago and the downtown has been deteriorating since.
In recent years, there has been a determined push to revive the downtown and its waterfront rim. There are plans to build a parking garage and 400 units of market-rate housing overlooking the Hudson. Metro-North is refurbishing the rundown riverside train station, and the Greyston Foundation, which began 20 years ago as a little bake shop run by Zen students, has broken ground for a $9 million bakery designed by Maya Lin.
Yonkers officials introduced the Greyston Foundation to St. John's Episcopal Church, which owned Philipsburgh Hall and wanted to restore it but lacked the expertise. Greyston -- which has built and is the manager of 215 units of low-income housing in Yonkers -- became the building's co-owner, sharing the cost and work of the restoration and the management of the building.
"This was a wreck," said Mr. Lief, as he opened extra-wide mahogany doors into the marble-walled lobby the other day. When he first saw it, more than a year ago, a ballroom wall was torn away, exposing exterior brick. The skylight glass was cracked and tarred. The floor buckled in waves high enough to please a skateboarder.
After digging through three layers of flooring, the original oak was uncovered. Many of the replacement boards had to be custom-made because the 1905 oak slats were slimmer than the ones available now. The elaborate ornaments decorating the walls and ceiling were replaced, using molds from the few whole examples that were left.
Now there are fanlights over the mahogany ballroom doors and intricately detailed pillers, cornices, garlands and vases all over. The wide railing is also mahogany, the polished floor shines and there is a carved and curlicued balcony and organ room above the polished semicircle stage.
The air-conditioning posed a problem. At the turn of the century, big blocks of ice were placed in the basement, and fans blew cool air from them into the ballroom through ducts. The new system uses a homemade system of fabric, cold-air ducts attached to fishing-pole reels that retract them in the winter. The task now is to bring in performances worthy of the newly restored ballroom. 
"The hope is to create a Yonkers version of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, revivals," said Mr. Lief. "We hope that's what's going to happen here."
On the shorter term, there will be swing and salsa dancing in the ballroom on summer evenings. On June 8, there will be a performance by the Movement Arts Collaborative of the Greek tragedy "The Eumenides," and on June 18, the Santa Rosa Youth Orchestra will play. And many more shows are being planned, said Matilda Hohensee, the center's executive director.
For information and performance schedules: (914) 964-8977 or www.philipsburgh.org.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Philipsburgh Hall in Yonkers and its newly restored auditorium, where a variety of events, from jazz guitar concerts to salsa dancing, are scheduled. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Then, Now: New Rock City 

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
JOEY RAMONE, who died of lymphoma last year, might have been tickled to know he has simultaneous birthday parties tonight.
 One, where bands will compete to appear on the B-side of a Joey Ramone tribute single, is at CBGB, the Bowery dive that was founded in 1973 and soon nurtured the Ramones, punk-rock and a circle of disparate but influential New York rockers including Television, Patti Smith, Blondie and Talking Heads. 
 Meanwhile, the Joey Ramone Birthday Bash, a benefit for lymphoma research with Ronnie Spector and many others performing, takes place four blocks downtown at the Bowery Ballroom, a 1990's arrival that's just one of the places where a New York rock resurgence is gathering momentum. 
The Strokes (who are already too popular for clubs), the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, the Walkmen, Oneida, Ex Models, the Rapture and a dozen other bands are seizing and stretching the legacy of CBGB in its heyday: rock that's smart, skeletal and recklessly ambitious, eager to provide an antidote to synthetic pop and self-important mainstream rock. The first words on Radio 4's new album, "Gotham," are, "New electric sounds rattle underground." 
New York City has hardly been silent since the late 1970's, not with hip-hop, hardcore and any number of individual breakthroughs: Sonic Youth, Moby, Marc Anthony, Alicia Keys. Yet the current New York rock renaissance, with bands spanning the spectrum from arty to party music, strongly echoes and parallels an era that many of the new prime movers never saw. 
"I've been waiting for something to happen for most of my life," said Karen O, 23, the singer of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. "What's cool now is that there are so many different avenues of music coming up. People are making music that they don't care if people like, and people are making music to rock out to. People are willing to experiment. We're all trying to build on something that was leveled."
Once again, individualistic music is being pounded out in clubs on the Lower East Side (and in its newer annex, Williamsburg in Brooklyn, where high rents have driven many musicians and artists). And once again, musicians are discovering the power of pithy minimalism coupled with repetition, muscle and noise, strategies long identified with New York City.
"It was only when we left New York that people kept saying it sounds like New York," said Julian Casablancas of the Strokes, whose lean, disillusioned songs virtually sum up guitar-driven New York rock from the Velvet Underground onward. "I wasn't going for a specific New York thing. I was just trying to make good music. For me it's a lot more about substance over style."
There was little evidence of a nascent style in 1973, when Hilly Kristal took over a Bowery club under a flophouse and named it Country Bluegrass Blues and Other Music for Uplifting Gourmandizers (CBGB and OMFUG). He started booking local rock bands with a crucial proviso: they could play only their own material. "They kept coming out of the woodwork," Mr. Kristal said. CBGB quickly filled a void left by the (literal) collapse of the Mercer Arts Center, where the New York Dolls had played, and the closing of Max's Kansas City, where glam-rock had held sway.
The bands that converged on CBGB (and later the reopened Max's) rejected the blandly professional pop, overblown guitar jams and elaborate progressive rock they were hearing on the radio. But instead of attempting some kind of revival, they reconfigured old rock virtues into music that had not been heard before. 
Self-consciousness was crucial to the bands at CBGB. Though the music often seemed simple, it was primitivist, not primitive. "We knew that what we were doing was revolutionary," said Tommy Erdelyi, better known as Tommy Ramone, the Ramones' first drummer. "We were connoisseurs of rock's history and where it should go. We wanted to bring back short songs, pop melodies, things like that. But I think we were the first group to consciously use the fact that we weren't virtuosos, to realize that this was an advantage. We stripped down a lot of things and just put in the gist of what was needed." 
At CBGB, that determination to purge inessentials led not just to the Ramones' definitive punk rock but to music as multifarious as Television's jazzy, elastic drones and jams, Patti Smith's incantatory poetry merged with garage rock, Talking Heads' clean-lined bubblegum funk, Blondie's radically deflected girl-group rock, DNA's atonal jolts, Richard Hell and the Voidoids' gnashing guitars, and the relentless, confrontational organ-and-drum-machine songs of Suicide. In the mid-1970's, none of it seemed headed for the Top 40 anytime soon. 
But New York was in a recession then, and the living was cheap, if not easy. David Byrne recently recalled that the three original Talking Heads shared a Chrystie Street loft for $300 a month. So there was far less commercial pressure on musicians. Bands like the Patti Smith Group and Blondie woodshedded at CBGB, playing four sets a night for weekend after weekend. And in 1975, Mr. Kristal seized media interest with a festival of what he called the top 40 unsigned bands in New York -- actually, about 70 of them. What had been downtown entertainment was suddenly seen as a movement, and it would go on to seed do-it-yourself rock worldwide.
Decades later, independent rock has a firmly established infrastructure: clubs, college radio stations and coverage from both ingroup fanzines and a mainstream determined to detect the latest thing immediately. Yet for a few years, New York's rock resurgence hid in plain earshot, amid a glut of grunge, hardcore, rap-rock and punk-pop. The new rock has also kept its distance from heavy metal, roots-rock and self-pitying collegiate rock. As it renounces bombast and decoration, it inevitably harks back to the first salvo of CBGB's rock. 
This time around, there is a hint of a revival, the same nostalgia that's driving other bands to rediscover early synthesizers and write so-called electroclash tunes. But unlike most electroclash bands, the rockers are twisting together their sources, not simply imitating them. And this time, while New York is the music's stronghold, there are already like-minded bands elsewhere, like the White Stripes and the Von Bondies in Detroit. 
"What's really refreshing to me about this scene, so to speak, is that it does have a sense of history," said Mike Stuto, the co-owner and booker of Brownies on the Lower East Side. "It does understand the 30 years of history that have led up to its being, as well as the 20 years before that." 
The music can be as sparse and vociferous as the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, with Ms. O sending out put-downs and come-ons with a sharp giggle over short, splintered lines for guitar and drums. It can be as frenetic as the scrabbling guitar patterns of the Ex Models, as haggard as the woozy moans of the Walkmen, as troubled as the wary anthems of Longwave. Or it can be as barbed as the dissonant rebel yelps of the Panthers, as choppy as the punk-funk variations of the Rapture or Radio 4, as cantankerous as the improvisations of Black Dice and as inexorable as the overloaded, pulsating ostinatos of Oneida. 
Alongside countless other hopefuls, these bands have played around unpaid or low-paying neighborhood clubs, downtown and in Brooklyn. Soon, midsize club bookers like Ryan Gentles (now the Strokes' manager) at the Mercury Lounge and Mr. Stuto at Brownies were presenting full nights of what Mr. Gentles dubbed "the new sound of New York," on posters for one quadruple bill.
But in the late 1990's the music business was seeking hits elsewhere. "The lack of major-label interest in underground rock enabled the music to be itself for a little while," Mr. Stuto said. "Because there isn't the attention, people do it from the heart. And because they're not trying to create hit records, they're trying to express themselves and make great music." 
Now the bands have been noticed, perhaps with increased urgency since Sept. 11 focused the world's attention on New York. With the Strokes on a major label and record-company scouts swarming around the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Longwave and others, Mr. Stuto said he expected carpetbaggers and opportunists to move in on the scene soon. (He is closing the music room at Brownies in August. "Why not go out on top?" he said. The closing could shift some of the new bands back to CBGB.)
"Right now," said Mr. Casablancas of the Strokes, "in the grand scheme of the music business, we're all relatively small. The music is slowly surfacing, but I don't know how successful we're all going to be in the future."
Yet with various gradations of New York irony, the new bands are already singing manifestos. "It's our time, sweet baby, to break on through," Karen O of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs sings as she sprinkles beer on her adoring club audiences. "It's our time to be hated."
Shahin Motia of the Ex Models cackles, "Rock 'n' roll can't be made no more," amid skewed, hurtling guitar chords that prove him completely wrong.
Rock was moribund in the mid-1970's, too, when Joey Ramone and his band decided to get back to basics. His best birthday present is to have New York kick-start the music one more time.

Furious Guitars and Harried Vocals
Here is a list of recordings by leading new New York City bands, in order of preference. Most are on independent labels that can be tracked down through mail order, the Internet or stores like Other Music (15 East Fourth Street, 212-477-8150), Rocks in Your Head (157 Prince Street, 212-475-6729), Kim's Mondo Music (6 St. Mark's Place, 212-598-9985) and Earwax (218 Bedford Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-486-3771).

THE STROKES' "Is This It" (RCA). Guitars scrape old wounds raw or push toward the next encounter as love goes wrong again and again.

YEAH YEAH YEAHS: "Yeah Yeah Yeahs" (Wichita Recordings, P.O. Box 27754, London E5 OFP, England; www.wichita-recordings.com; will be rereleased in July by Touch and Go Records). Just drums, guitar and Karen O, hopscotching from rockabilly to P. J. Harvey, from flirtation to flippancy.

THE RAPTURE: "Out of the Races and Onto the Tracks" (Sub Pop, P.O. Box 20645, Seattle, Wash. 98102; www.subpop.com). Brittle, austere, sometimes furious guitar funk, with dire existential ruminations and feedback seeping into the empty spaces.

EX MODELS: "Other Mathematics" (Ace Fu, P.O. Box 3388, Hoboken, N.J. 07030; www.acefu.com). Speed, odd meters, dissonant interlocking guitars and harried vocals add up to songs that go haywire with utmost precision.

THE WALKMEN: "Everyone Who Pretended to Like Me Is Gone" (StarTime International, 285 Fifth Ave., PMB No. 452, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11215; www.startimeintl.com). Rock anthems with a dire hangover, groaning their excuses while the lo-fi band plays with brusque deliberation.

ONEIDA: "Anthem of the Moon" (Jagjaguwar, 1021 South Walnut, Bloomington, Ind. 47401; www.jagjaguwar.com). Minimalism gets the caffeine jitters, as repeating keyboard lines batter relentlessly against frantic guitars and drums.

MAHOGANY: "The Dream of a Modern Day" (Darla, 3460 Potter Lane, Sacramento, Calif. 95821; www.darla.com). Over the crisp geometry of drum-machine rhythms and rectilinear vocal melodies, a la Stereolab, guitars and cellos shimmer and splash, enriching the structures by blurring them.

"THIS IS NEXT YEAR: A BROOKLYN-BASED COMPILATION": (Arena Rock, 68 Greenpoint Ave., Brooklyn, N.Y. 11222; www.arenarockrecordingco.com). A 42-song, 42-band anthology.

THE PANTHERS: "Are You Down??" (Troubleman Unlimited, 16 Willow Street, Bayonne, N.J. 07002; www.troublemanunlimited.com). Wrangling, discordant guitars build pressure, and discordant vocals discharge it in insurrectionary slogans.

RADIO 4: "Gotham" (Gern Blandsten, P.O. Box 356, River Edge, N.J. 07661; gernbland@aol.com). Guitar-scrubbing, fuzz-toned funk that's determined to make agitprop danceable.

AARKTICA: ". . . Or You Could Just Go Through Your Whole Life and Be Happy Anyway" (Darla). Guitars, voices and electronic pulses are layered together in stately, gradually changing, mostly instrumental songs that could come from a less neurotic version of the Cure.

FRENCH KICKS: "One Time Bells" (StarTime International). Bouncing along on keyboards one moment, facing guitar barbs the next, the French Kicks' songs are as unstable as the romances they sketch.

AVEY TARE AND PANDA BEAR: "Spirit They're Gone Spirit They've Vanished" (Animal, 67 Atlantic Avenue No. 2, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201; animal@myanimalhome
.com). Deep within a very private world, gentle songs are spattered with noise and clutter turns into phantasmagoria.

SECRET MACHINES: "September 000" (Ace Fu). Serenely unfolding instrumentals ease gradually into songs that end up someplace between Tortoise and Wilco.

LIARS: "They Threw Us All in a Trench and Stuck a Monument on Top" (Gern Blandsten). Furious, one-note rants top music that grinds and churns and squalls, an irritant and proud of it.

PALOMAR: "II" (Self-Starter Foundation, P.O. Box 1562, New York, N.Y. 10276; www.selfstarterfoundation.com). Three women and one man play wry, galloping pop that can switch to punk overdrive.

BRENDAN BENSON: "Lapalco" (StarTime International). A thoroughly unpunk songwriter splits his attention between getting the girl (not easy) and finding the perfect chiming guitar line (not hard).

ENON: "High Society" (Touch and Go, P.O. Box 25520, Chicago, Ill. 60625; release date June 4). Slyly mercurial pop that changes style with every track, putting new crimps into each minigenre.

LES SAVY FAV: "Go Forth" (Frenchkiss, 111 East 14th Street, PMB No. 229, New York, N.Y. 10003; www.lessavyfav.com). Upbeat, jaunty rock, deliberately curdled with dissonant guitar lines and critiques of captialism.

THE REALISTICS: "Real People Are Overrated" (Tiswas, 332 Bleecker Street, Suite G11, New York, N.Y. 10014; www.tiswasnyc.com) Anglophile new wave rock on the rebound, complete with vocal harmonies and analog oscillator swoops. JON PARELES

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
A Master Passes On Ashton's Mastery

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
AMERICAN Ballet Theater will present the company premieres of "The Dream" on Friday and "La Fille Mal Gardee" on May 31 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Created for the Royal Ballet, the two classics are signature works by Sir Frederick Ashton, a choreographer who in many ways defined English ballet in the 20th century.
 "Fille" (1960) tells the story of two sunny, impudent peasant lovers. It is also Ashton's tribute to his beloved English countryside. 
 "The Dream" (1964) retells Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream." The central roles of Oberon and Titania were created for Anthony Dowell, then a green young dancer, and the ballerina Antoinette Sibley. The dance began one of ballet's greatest partnerships. The roles are being taught to the Ballet Theater dancers by Sir Anthony, the artistic director of the Royal from 1984 to 2001. 
He and Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of Ballet Theater and an Oberon with the Joffrey Ballet in 1974, recently talked about Ashton (who died in 1988) with Jennifer Dunning, a dance critic of The New York Times. They met at the Ballet Theater studios in Manhattan. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

JENNIFER DUNNING -- Why "La Fille Mal Gardee" and "The Dream"?

KEVIN McKENZIE -- I've had a long history with "The Dream." It had a huge impact on me, through a lot of my career. And a surprising development gave me my first exposure to Anthony. I got ill. Anthony had actually been off with an injury, but he came back and did "The Dream" for the Joffrey Ballet. So I had this double whammy of being exposed to the genius of that work and then suddenly being able to see it in 3-D for the first time as a youngish dancer, to see Anthony do it.

ANTHONY DOWELL -- I flew in quite at the last minute. Of course it was very exciting, but the jet lag hit almost in the middle of the pas de deux, which is unusually long and at the end of the ballet. It's bust-a-gut time for Oberon. I remember feeling, "I'm not here and I don't want to be here." I was almost on automatic pilot. I really felt my whole body mechanism had switched off. It was terrifying. And Misha Mikhail Baryshnikov had come, too! Word had gotten round.

McKENZIE -- That was the first connection I had had to a masterpiece being created on a role model of a dancer. So it was a natural thing when I came back as director to want to have "The Dream." Not only is it a great work, but if I could get that experience for these dancers, all would be well in the world.

DUNNING -- Why "Fille"?

McKENZIE -- Same thing. It's one of Ashton's great masterpieces. And long overdue for us to do.

DUNNING -- It has been said that love is an essential theme in Ashton's ballets. Is this true of "The Dream" and "La Fille"?

DOWELL -- I think that human relationships were a very important thread in all his works. He didn't ever show the seamier side of life. He wanted glamour and allure, which was one of his favorite words. I don't know if one can say he saw love entirely through rose-colored glasses, but it was without too much pain and brutality.

DUNNING -- But things get pretty passionate and conflicted for Titania and Oberon.

DOWELL -- Yes, but they're supernatural and powerful forces. The dancers must not fall into the trap of making Titania resemble the fairy at the top of the Christmas tree. Ashton saw her as a creature of both power and sexuality and he found these characteristics in Antoinette when she danced. He saw that she was a very sensual, very tactile performer. The original wig was very straight and wild and almost green, and she loved that. I want to impress on the dancers that they have to be sensual and powerful.
I think it would be very difficult to dance an Ashton ballet if you loathed your partner. There are very tender moments in his ballets.

DUNNING -- Was Ashton himself tender?

DOWELL -- Yes. And of course "Fille" was his great homage to his love of the countryside. I was lucky enough to visit him down at his country place in his last years. I was putting on my own production of "Swan Lake." I wanted to tell him personally that I wasn't going to use his fourth act, and I wanted him to create a new waltz in Act I.
He was very good. He said: "I quite understand, Anthony. You must do what you want and all that. But no, I won't do you another waltz. I've done a perfectly good one." I was not prepared for that. Anyway, this visit enabled me to see him in the surroundings that made him happy. He adored the country. So apart from romance, "Fille" is very much his homage to pastoral landscapes.

DUNNING -- How do you feel, Sir Anthony, about restaging Ashton ballets in such a different time? Are there still national styles of dancing?

DOWELL -- That's an old chestnut. I feel any dancer who gets to the top of their profession gets there because of their own individual style, whatever nationality they are. Yes, there are certain linear details that Ashton required. And so a dancer who is used to working in a certain style will have to get used to the differences and make changes.
You must preserve ballets. A ballet can't be frozen in time, or become a museum piece. It lives on through the dancers. You must respect the structure and choreography but at the same time allow the individual artists to find their own way. One day, horror of horrors, when the copyright expires on the Ashton, MacMillan and Cranko ballets along with many others, they could be up for grabs, rather like Petipa's work is today. So, for example, you might have another version of Ashton's "A Month in the Country" or "The Dream." Hopefully, I won't be around to witness this. But of course in Petipa's time there was no film, no video. Luckily now we have a record through these mediums of what was intended.
Life goes on. Dancers change. You try to protect what you know. But you mustn't make the guidelines too rigid. Otherwise they can't move freely.
When I first danced "The Dream," I think those early performances were just a sketch. I was still a young dancer. Over the years, you add layers and as you get older as a dancer you learn about economy. It's what you don't do that sometimes counts. I learned that from Fonteyn. It's the moments of stillness that are important. When a young dancer learns something, everything's busy and they think they have to put the whole kit and caboodle in. You pare that down and leave the essence, the strong focal points. So now when I teach a role, I can give the dancers a head start as they are learning the final and distilled version of the role that made Sir Frederick happy.

McKENZIE -- That's one of the reasons I was dying to get this here. That essence in the studio is something the dancers have a direct link to. And that in turn refers back to the day when we have "The Dream," "a version after Ashton." There's a link directly through Anthony to Ashton, because although Ashton created the work, Anthony colored it.

DUNNING -- How much did Ashton allow or expect his dancers to contribute to the choreography?

DOWELL -- Oh, that's what was so wonderful. He gave you so much freedom, you felt that you'd created 85 percent of it, so that the role fitted you like a glove. When I first started to work with Ashton, he didn't demonstrate much. He had ideas, or ideas from dreams. There's rather a strange move in the pas de deux in "The Dream" where she revolves under your arms. Ashton had had a dream about it. He left us in the studio to work it out. He said: "Try to make it work. I don't know how." Then he came back and we'd succeeded. He was always steeped in the music. That's why when you hear a piece of music that he had choreographed to, it's so perfect and you can't imagine any other steps working better.
"A Month in the Country," which was Ashton's last work, had a small cast and we'd all sit around chatting for at least 10 or 15 minutes. He'd put off starting. But he enjoyed that. He had such humanity. He was so fascinating to talk to. And that sort of broke the ice. No, once he got going, the creative process was very fast. I very rarely found there were bad days with him.

DUNNING -- Was Ashton unusually relaxed in his give-and-take with the dancers?

DOWELL -- In later life I worked with a young choreographer who shall be nameless, naturally, and Antoinette and I were in the studio, expecting to work in the same way as we did with Ashton. We would start showing things and ideas for movements to the music. "What about this?" we would ask. And the reply was always, "No, no. No, no." So we just stood there waiting to be told what to do.
Well, Ashton and MacMillan were so experienced, but they were terrified of the studio the first days of starting. Ashton was physically ill with nerves, but he always gave you the freedom of letting things happen naturally. Oh, it was wonderful, wonderful.

(Jack Mitchell)(pg. 18); Anthony Dowell, foreground, and Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, watching a rehearsal at the Ballet Theater studio. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. 40)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
Priceline.com Adds Vacation Packages

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
Priceline.com has been something of a boon to travelers who are looking for bargain air fares, hotels and car rentals, provided they can live with some uncertainty, like not knowing what airline or hotel they'll be using. Now, the company is expanding into the realm of vacation packages, without some of the uncertainty. 
 Priceline last week introduced a vacation feature that allows travelers to select a hotel at a given destination and specify the dates of their trip and the price they'd like to pay for the package (which includes air fare). As with Priceline's airline ticket service, travelers are not given the airline name or travel times until the package is purchased, nor can they apply these purchases toward their hotel or airline affinity programs. 
 Available destinations, the company said, include places in the Caribbean, Mexico, Europe and Canada, as well as Chicago, St. Louis, New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Florida. 
Henry Harteveldt, an online travel analyst with Forrester Research, a business consulting company, said that in offering this service, Priceline would compete with some established sites, including Expedia. While Expedia does not ask consumers to suggest prices they are willing to pay, it does allow customers to choose travel dates and hotels at certain vacation destinations. Expedia then offers flight times, using a carrier that remains anonymous until the package is purchased. BOB TEDESCHI

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Travel Advisory column last Sunday about Priceline.com vacation packages referred incorrectly to a similar service by Expedia.com. Expedia indeed tells customers the name of the airline before a vacation package is purchased.

HEADLINE: 'Free' Music at Jones Beach 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
KEN WALDMANN is a financial analyst, so statistics come easily to him. For starters, Mr. Waldmann, 43, of North Bellmore, says he has attended more than 400 rock concerts. More than 100 were by the Grateful Dead, 40 by David Bromberg and 20 by Bruce Springsteen. Also figuring prominently in Mr. Waldmann's rock patronage are the 80 shows he has attended at the Jones Beach Theater.
 But of those 80, he has actually seen only 50. 
 For the rest, he has heard the music sitting outside the Jones Beach Theater, the way Chicagoans watch the Cubs from porches and rooftops just beyond Wrigley Field.
In Mr. Waldmann's case, hearing concerts this way is an arrangement that lets him happily straddle his youth and middle age. As his children grew over the years, Mr. Waldmann wasn't about to let fatherhood curb his concert attendance. Nor was he going to let concerts cramp his style as a parent, or force a break with the cardinal rule that comes with it: Never bore your kids.
For others who have adopted their own improvised bleachers in Wantagh, the impetus is economic.
"Ticket prices are out of control -- 50 or 60 bucks -- and going without a ticket is a good last-minute thing to do," said Peggy Gluszak, 39. "If it doesn't work out, you leave."
Last summer Ms. Gluszak, a Queens nurse, heard the band Yes as well as Tom Petty from the free seats, and she expects to return for many more shows.
Each summer, dozens of Long Island music lovers without concert tickets dot the beach at Zachs Bay's eastern end. Some sit at the parking lot area near the Jones Beach Theater entrance. Others anchor their boats just beyond the floating barrier behind the stage. Sometimes kayaks edge closer, darting near the shoreline. They soak up sounds that waft from the arena on warm breezes.
Wearing sweatshirts outside the Yes concert near last season's close, Maureen Gilligan, 35, and Karla Helgans, 35, sat on the beach, leaning against a lifeguard stand turned on its side. On a bed sheet spread before them were their vegetable wraps, wine and a Tupperware bowl of rice and vegetables.
Three summers ago, the two women discovered they could ride their bicycles to the arena in daylight and then go home on the bike path by following car taillights, as fans departed along the Wantagh Parkway.
It takes the skills of a meteorologist and an audiophile to pick the best listening location. Ms. Gluszak and a co-worker, Marga Giotta, 38, of Brooklyn, missed parts of the wind-muffled Yes concert, even from the spot between the arena's ticket booth and the main entrance, where many say the sound is usually best. On a humid night, listeners say, the sound couldn't be better there.
"When I came for Tom Petty you could hear it as if you were inside," Ms. Gluszak said, as Ms. Giotta nodded in agreement. "And if it isn't a theatrical stage show, just a guy standing with a guitar, do I really need to be up close? When I was younger, yes. Not anymore."
The wind wasn't enough to spoil the Yes concert for the two nurses. They reveled in the sliver of giant projection screen that they could see, as Jon Anderson, the lead singer, waved a larger-than-life arm overhead.
Rob Elznic, 44, a Queens bus dispatcher who lives in Hicksville, agreed that the spot where the nurses sat was prime real estate for a nonpaying fan. 
"There's a science to this," Mr. Elznic said. "The best sound is closer to the entrance, plus you're getting the best of both worlds. When you're listening to music on a warm night, the sound travels better and you're seeing the show on a screen."
But Mr. Waldmann, the financial analyst, said he would rather sacrifice sound quality to sit on the beach instead of near the parking lot. Similarly, he would rather sit on the sand outside than in one of the front rows in the venue, which would cut off any view of the beach and bay. 
"I could always sit sixth row at a concert and see the stage anywhere," he said. "Jones Beach is more than just a stage."
For Mr. Waldmann, last summer's Yes concert capped a busy season. He paid for Phil Lesh, who was the bass player for the Grateful Dead, and Crosby, Stills & Nash. But he heard the Allman Brothers, Rod Stewart, Ringo Starr, Jackson Browne and James Taylor from a beach chair, flipping through ESPN magazine and keeping an eye on his children, Rachel and Matthew, now 9 and 6, sipping Yoo-Hoos and apple juice and playing in the sand.
But Mr. Waldmann has an unwritten rule for such play: It should be relatively quiet, because the music is not nearly as crisp as inside. Loosely knit audiences have become such a fixture outside the Jones Beach Theater that Mr. Waldmann expects the etiquette within to apply outside as well.
"What bothers me is when there are rowdy groups and they don't realize there are people who are here to listen to the music," he said. "You don't play volleyball, and you don't bring a boombox."
Long Island concertgoers can spread out blankets at the Brookhaven Amphitheater, the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay and Paul Simon's summer concerts at a Montauk horse ranch. But operators at those venues charge for the informal seating. And none of those shows equal the Jones Beach concerts for the diversity of artists who appeal to baby boomers, regulars at the Wantagh theater say.
Mr. Waldmann said: "From where I live, it's a bit of a trek to Brookhaven, and they don't have the artists I'm interested in. It's either artists from the 50's or the 90's." 
"It's a combination of money and timing," he added of the draw to Jones Beach. "I'll try to see a concert every three or four weeks inside at Jones Beach, and then I'll go outside the theater for the other shows there."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Karla Helgans, left, and Maureen Gilligan listen to the Jones Beach Theater's offerings without having to pay.; Finding a spot with good sound is crucial to "attending" a concert. Ken Waldman, above, arranged his own preferred seating while other music lovers laid out blankets on the sand to enjoy a concert at Jones Beach. (Photographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Setting Worthy of the Sculptures 

BYLINE:  By PHYLLIS BRAFF 

 BODY:
GLASS spears by Dale Chihuly sparkle in the sunlight, supersized flowerlike forms by Dennis Oppenheim impress with their wit, and a massive, undulating abstract bronze by Lynda Benglis produces a sense of energy that recalls the rolling surf. 
 These and dozens of other artworks are part of the outdoor sculpture program at the 16-acre LongHouse Reserve in a wooded area of East Hampton. The land, cleared for farming by early settlers, was then abandoned and allowed to become a second-growth forest in the 19th century. The reserve has added specimens, created gardens and shaped the terrain to provide strolling paths through pines, spruces, Japanese maples, California redwoods, magnolias and other flowering trees. This rich combination of textures is at its best with full summer foliage. 
 The reserve, now in its 10th year, is a nonprofit organization started by the textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen, who heads a board of trustees populated largely by specialists in horticulture, cultural affairs, creative design and art in every form. An art committee arranges the sculpture loans, which are usually for one or two years. A few pieces are long-term loans, and some are part of the LongHouse Reserve collection.
From Mr. Larsen's own collection came a sculpture by Grace Knowlton, a mixed-media work of five round forms of different sizes placed near the end of a broad lawn. As with everything at LongHouse Reserve, the positioning is obviously thoughtful. The work stimulates perceptual questions about scale and cerebral questions about the relationship between natural boulders and synthetic shapes. 
Mr. Larsen began construction in 1986 on the main multiuse building that gives the Reserve its name. A seventh-century Shinto shrine at Ise in Japan served as its architectural inspiration.
Most artworks at the reserve present themselves unexpectedly, as visitors walk the varied terrain.
In a few instances the art has a more formal setting, and the results can seem quite striking. Claus Bury's "Bridge," a large wood and steel abstraction originally done for the Brooklyn Bridge centennial, is effective at the end of a white pine allee. Toshiko Takaezu's stoneware piece "Closed Form" looks ritualistic at the end of what is known as the Red Garden.
Perhaps the greatest drama and sense of engagement comes from several strong abstract works that incorporate the spirit of nature and have a heightened impact in the outdoor setting. The churning wavelike piece by Ms. Benglis looks wonderful as the ambient light activates the hundreds of facets on its swelling white surface, making everything seem part of some momentary flux.
Takashi Soga's welded steel construction based on intersecting geometric forms borrows nature's rhythms, particularly breeze-driven gentle movements. The 31-foot central beam is intricately balanced to produce a continuous pattern of action that can seem both uncanny and reassuring.
A number of other pieces use nature's imagery, characteristics or materials in a very direct way. John McQueen's 10-foot-high "Shrouded Mantle" is made from interlaced lotus branches. Ricardo Regazzoni gives a streamlined industrial quality to a cluster of treelike stainless-steel columns, and Mr. Takaezu creates an imposing installation with seven bronze trunk-shaped forms titled "Tree Men in the Forest." Jim Owen's more informally placed coiled stoneware and fiberglass verticals, "Asperagi," emphasize their handmade surfaces and the way this quality blends with the outdoor locale. 
Yoko Ono's 16-foot configuration of a chess game encourages philosophical speculation about life, chance, nature and universal concepts with its title, "Play It by Trust." The contrast between the permanent forms of the chess pieces, made of white marble dust, and the variables of the surrounding trees and sky underscores the message.
"People read the label, and they always respond," said Matko Tomicic, the reserve's director. "They stop and think."
There is a broad social message in the largest piece on view, "Fly's Eye Dome," an adaptation of Buckminster Fuller's last geodesic dome, which offers a prototype for economical, ecologically sound and sturdy housing anywhere in the world.
Here, on one of the tree-ringed lawns, it generates responses that are largely aesthetic. Circular window openings create shadow patterns and frame both the sky and the lush green surroundings; satiny beige and white surfaces provide a sensuous glow, and metal fastenings register as pleasing, regularized high-tech schemes. 
It seems inevitable that one of this season's star loans, Magdalena Abakanowicz's "Mutant," will generate solemn interpretations. The weighty bronze, cast from a burlap-surfaced form, is the size of a bear. This featureless, imposing creature leans forward as if alert to threats and a need to test its environment. "Mutant" embodies courage, but its burlap markings imply vulnerability. It easily takes on a mythic role as a symbol for all organic beings. 
Serendipity is part of the range of experiences generated by the arrangement of art and gardens. Sunlight and prevailing atmospheric tones contribute to this feeling when Mr. Chihuly's cobalt blue glass reeds come into view. Depending on the day and hour, the translucent forms might have a purple or a red cast. They echo the tall grasses surrounding them, and their image is repeated as a reflection in the nearby pond.
A more traditional exhibition format is observed for the special summer show. On an open, grassy area near the main building, this year's presentation surveys 15 years of Tony Rosenthal's large works in aluminum and wood.
Information: (631) 329-3568 or www.longhouse.org.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tony Rosenthal and "Mandala, 1994-95," part of LongHouse Reserve's summer retrospective of 15 years of his large works in aluminum and wood.; Other sculptures on view at the LongHouse Reserve in East Hampton are, from top, Buckminster Fuller's "Fly's Eye Dome"; Dale Chihuly's "Cobalt Reeds"; Tony Rosenthal's "Big Red," in foreground, and "Mandala, 1994-95"; Yoko Ono's "Play It by Trust"; and Magdalena Abakanowicz's "Mutant." An art committee arranges the sculpture loans, which are usually for one or two years. A few pieces are long-term loans, and some are from the LongHouse Reserve collection. Jack Lenor Larsen, the textile designer, is LongHouse's founder and heads its board of trustees. (Photographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Builders Are Moving to Fill Demand for Lab Space

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
IN response to a growing demand for biomedical laboratory space in Westchester County, a 30-year-old, 700,000-square-foot research park in Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant is planning to expand by as much at 570,000 square feet.
 LCOR Inc., an owner and the manager of the 280-acre Landmark at Eastview research and development park, which was built in the early 1960's for the Union Carbide Corporation, already has zoning approval from Greenburgh for a 320,000-square-foot expansion. It will begin building to suit tenants as early as this fall. LCOR, a national development, asset management and operations management company, is also planning to seek approval for 250,000 more square feet of office and laboratory space on a 100-acre section of the park that is in Mount Pleasant. 
 The decision to enlarge and upgrade the complex comes as the county is seeking bids to turn a vacant site it owns in Valhalla -- next to Westchester Medical Center and New York Medical College and less than a mile from the Landmark at Eastview -- into a privately financed biotechnology and medical research park. Under that plan, up to a million square feet of laboratory and incubator space for biotech companies would be built on 60 acres. 
Peter T. Gilpatric, senior vice president for LCOR, which is based in Berwyn, Pa., said the company might also submit a bid to develop the county's site. More than 30 private developers that have expressed interest in the project are being asked to submit their qualifications to the county. A final developer will be selected by late fall.
With about 8,000 employees, Westchester already has the state's largest concentration of biotech and pharmaceutical companies -- among them Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, which is at the Landmark at Eastview, and Acorda Therapeutics in Hawthorne.
But with many new biotech companies being spawned in New York City -- at academic institutions and hospitals like Columbia University and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, for example -- that are not able to afford or find space in the city, Westchester and other surrounding areas are stepping up efforts to accommodate them.
"At the current time, we don't have enough good incubator space for new and emerging companies who are taking their first step out of the research institution and attempting to become profit making," Mr. Gilpatric explained.
In its first expansion since buying the park in 1999 for $82 million, LCOR will build new lab and office space to suit tenants like Aton Pharma, a year-old company outgrowing its current quarters. The company, which is researching a new cancer-fighting drug, was founded in New York City by Dr. Paul A. Marks, president emeritus of Memorial Sloan-Kettering, and his associates at the hospital, and Ron Breslow, a chemistry professor at Columbia. Felix G. Rohatyn, the former ambassador to France, is chairman.
Aton started with 6,000 square feet at the Landmark and is now expanding to 15,000 square feet, said Nicholas Bacopoulos, its president and chief executive. 
Mr. Gilpatric said LCOR was offering what he called mezzanine space -- typically 5,000 to 30,000 square feet of office and lab space to new and emerging biotech companies like Aton Pharma -- as well as larger blocks of space to mature companies like Progenics Pharmaceuticals. It moved from Manhattan to the Landmark 13 years ago, when the park was owned by another developer. Progenics started out renting 3,000 square feet and now occupies 50,000 square feet -- and will soon need more. The company, which was started by Dr. Paul J. Maddon when he was a medical school student, is developing drugs used in the treatment of H.I.V. and cancer.
Robert McKinney, vice president of finance and operations at Progenics, said that the company wanted to remain close to scientific and medical institutions and to the talent pool they generate but that as a start-up, the company could not afford New York City rents.
For example, lab space at the Audubon Business and Technology Center, which is a part of the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park across the street from Columbia-Presbyterian Center in Washington Heights, rents for about $40 a square foot a year, according to Mitch Gipson, executive director of the Aubudon complex. By comparison, rents for laboratory space at the Landmark are about $25 a square foot, not including taxes and utilities, Mr. Gilpatric said.
Many of the 1,200 people working for companies at the Landmark commute by car from Westchester and surrounding counties, although some take the Metro-North train from Grand Central Terminal to North White Plains, where a shuttle bus transports them to the Landmark.
As more biomedical companies like Progenics and Aton need additional space and new companies join them in Westchester, LCOR will add space at the Landmark in 50,000-square-foot increments contained in three-story, precast concrete modules, said Steven Rosenstein, the president of SRA in White Plains, a firm working with LCOR as a planning consultant. Those modules could be connected at a later date.
The main building at the Landmark is a three-story poured concrete and glass structure designed by Vincent Kling of Philadelphia for Union Carbide, which occupied it until 1985. Its aging heating, ventilation, air-conditioning and other delivery systems are being updated, Mr. Gilpatric said.
I N the new buildings, flexibility will be the key," Mr. Rosenstein said, adding that suite sizes would be able to accommodate companies needing as little as 1,000 square feet. In addition, delivery systems for heat, electricity, plumbing and air-conditioning will be designed to go where they are needed, he said. 
"We've learned our lessons from projects where we've guessed wrong," Mr. Rosenstein said. "Now we're planning for blocks of space that can be configured in a lot of different ways -- completely open or closed, for biotech or chemistry. We not going in with a specific tenant in mind. We're looking at a broader target.
"This is an emerging and dynamic industry, and what many landlords fail to do is transition with tenants."
The new construction at the Landmark need not be in competition with whatever is ultimately built at the county's site, Mr. Gilpatric said. For example, the county site could offer space to incubators and to established biomedical companies -- hospitals and research institutions -- that need core facilities like clean rooms and animal testing labs. By contrast, he said, LCOR -- which has $7.5 billion in developments completed, under construction or in predevelopment -- is focusing on small and midsized biomedical companies. 
"It's all unknown at this point," he said, "but whatever is built could be complementary rather than competitive. There's definitely a synergy created -- in terms of the labor force and infrastructure -- when an industry like this is clustered."
Several miles to the south of the Landmark, the Ardsley Park Science and Technology Center, the former headquarters for Ciba-Geigy, has more than 500,000 square feet of office and lab space. Its major biotech tenants include Purdue Pharma and Cultor Food Science, although it also leases space to the county and to the Westchester Library System.
Jason Halpern, the managing director for Halpern Real Estate Development, which owns and manages the center, said that like the Landmark, Ardsley Park was 95 percent occupied, although the owners had development rights to build 250,000 more square feet.
In another effort to develop more biotech space in the county, New York Presbyterian Hospital is seeking approvals from White Plains officials for a twin-building 384,000-square-foot complex. It would house a $100 million center for advanced proton therapy to treat 46 different forms of cancer, as well as labs intended for research into brain and neurodegenerative diseases affecting the elderly.
On June 28, the first Lower Hudson Valley Regional Biotechnology Conference will be held at the Dolce Tarrytown House conference center to explore the economic and development opportunities for biotech. The event is being organized by a group of public and private organizations, including New York Medical College, New York Presbyterian Hospital, the Westchester Medical Center and the Landmark at Eastview. 
"Are we all being overly optimistic?" asked Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of of economic development and real estate.
"No," he answered. "There's a tremendous amount of pent-up demand for more biotech and medical research space. This is not a dot-com phenomenon. We're talking about well-funded companies in an industry that is on the cutting edge for finding cures."

HEADLINE: The View From/Bridgeport; 
City of Bridges Weighs Repairing Two of Them

BYLINE:  By JEFF HOLTZ 

 BODY:
ACCORDING to city historians, bridges have been a source of controversy in Bridgeport since it became a borough in 1800, when it was named for its bridges over the Pequonnock River and its port on Long Island Sound.
 "A lot of mayors have run on bridges: whether to reopen them or fix them," said Mary K. Witkowski, the director of historical collections for the Bridgeport Public Library and author of the book "Bridgeport on the Sound" (Arcadia Publications, 2001). "And the Congress Street Bridge was one of the ones that really seemed to have the most trouble over the years. It was closed many times for repairs, especially during Jasper McLevy's time." 
 Now more than 40 years after Mayor McLevy's tenure, the Congress Street Bridge is the center of attention again. Along with the Pleasure Beach Bridge, it is one of two bridges in the eastern part of the city that have been closed for years and must now be replaced at a projected total cost of $50 million.
Part of the $30 million price tag for the Congress Street Bridge could be obtained through the state's Local Bridge Program. But because of budget problems, the city is not sure if it can find the remaining money.
"The city has to consider, three years down the line or later, when it comes time to pay for the bridge, whether we will have the funds available," said Joe P. Gresko, the municipal government's spokesman.
In the case of the Congress Street Bridge, many residents of the predominantly Hispanic East Side are feeling angered, alienated and frustrated. "Because of the closing of the bridge, the whole East Side of Bridgeport has gone down the drain," said Millie Maldonado, the president of Bridgeport's Spanish Merchants Association. "It has just deteriorated tremendously."
The drawbridge, which was built in 1919 and is on the Connecticut Historical Commission's list of bridges, connects the East Side of Bridgeport with downtown. The crossing, the fourth bridge at the site, has been left in the open position since 1997, when the state Department of Transportation determined that its substructures were moving.
Many residents and business owners said they believed that the inoperative bridge had increased response times for emergency vehicles. 
But Mr. Gresko said the East Side was served by a fire station and police station house. "We use the Stratford Avenue Bridge and the East Washington Bridge, which are just blocks away from Congress Street -- maybe adding about one minute worth of response time to a fire that would potentially be happening on the East Side that the main firehouse would be responding to," Mr. Gresko said.
Residents and merchants near Congress Street also said the economy of the East Side and downtown had suffered.
Victor Soukarieh, who has owned the Casa Grande Supermarket (about a half-mile east of the bridge) for the last three years, said business at the store had dropped by 60 percent. "I'm feeling like I'm on an island," he said. "This area has been dead."
Lawrence Fernandes, who, along with his brother, Sam, owns Larry and Sam's Seafood at the eastern base of the bridge, said he was close to laying off employees.
"As soon as they closed the bridge down, we lost about half of our clientele," he said. "We've been working hard to get it back through advertising, but the best advertising is the traffic."
Karen Lee Pulver, who lives in nearby Harborview Towers, is concerned because the elderly people in the building can no longer walk downtown.
"If the businesses start to leave because of the inconvenience, then this will become a ghost town," she said. "I feel like we're being cut off." But not everyone is convinced that replacing the Congress Street Bridge is the right option. Councilman John D. Guman, a Democrat and co-chairman of the budget committee, who, along with the rest of the City Council, is studying the problem, insists he needs more information.
"Do we spend $30 million to fix this bridge?" asked Mr. Guman, "Or can the $30 million be better spent somewhere else, and can there be a better solution?"
Mr. Guman said the same financial questions surround the Pleasure Beach Bridge, which joins the city's East End with Pleasure Beach. However, he feels that unless action is taken, Pleasure Beach could turn into a permanent wildlife sanctuary.
"Again, to fix the bridge, you're talking millions of dollars," he said. "But unless you fix the bridge, or come up with another solution, now you've got a prime piece of real estate that's going to the birds."
The Pleasure Beach Bridge, a wooden plank structure built in 1920 now in the Historic American Engineering Record, has been in the open position in the middle of the Lewis Gut channel since fire damaged its southern end in 1996.
City council member James Holloway, a Democrat from the East End, said Pleasure Beach is important to his constituents.
"Pleasure Beach is probably the only open-air space we have in the East End," he said. "It's used for picnics, outings, weddings, for the kids to go out there and fish. And right now the kids in the East End can't go."
The state has agreed to offer the city a grant of $5.8 million and a loan of $8.8 million through its Local Bridge Program for the Congress Street Bridge, but said that it does not see a benefit in replacing the Pleasure Beach Bridge because no one lives at Pleasure Beach.
Mr. Gresko said the city would be "considering pursuing the application" for the Local Bridge Program money, and he hopes that a courthouse for juveniles that the state is planning to build on the west side of the Congress Street Bridge might lead to additional state funds.
"The Congress Street Bridge is the priority of the city, because of the link that it creates with the downtown and the East Side," he said. 
"The Pleasure Beach Bridge is still important, but obviously it's linking the East End with vacant land. So, we're going to treat the bridge that has more impact on people first."
According to the city's official historian, Charles W. Brilvitch, keeping the Congress Street Bridge out of service means the city has reneged on a promise it made when it bought the bridge from the late P. T. Barnum and annexed the highly industrialized East Bridgeport for its tax base.
"We've gone against what the City of Bridgeport promised the residents of East Bridgeport in 1864: this bridge will be open and forever remain free and open to the public," Mr. Brilvitch said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Congress Street Bridge, above, linking downtown Bridgeport to the East Side, is closed for lack of repair funds. Bottom left, Lawrence Fernandes, whose seafood store near the bridge has lost business. Bottom right, the Pleasure Beach Bridge also needs repairs. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Downtown, a Menu of Incentives

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
TO help revive the downtown office market in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack, a complex set of federal, state and city incentives -- cash allowances and tax breaks -- are being offered to businesses that renew leases or move into the area. The incentives, together with rents that have gone down since the attack, have reduced the cost of office space to the point where it is 40 to 45 percent less than in Midtown, rather than the traditional 20 to 25 percent, according to real estate executives.
 Although few deals have been done in recent months, brokers say this price gap has begun to attract the attention of professional service firms, like lawyers and accountants, whose partners would pocket the savings. The question for these people, said Andrew M. Peretz, a managing director of Insignia/ESG, a real estate services company, is, Would you be willing to move downtown for $1 million? 
 Vacancy rates have continued to climb downtown and rents to soften as more space has come on the market than has been leased. More than 500,000 square feet of space was added to the downtown market in April, pushing the vacancy rate higher by six-tenths of a point, to 14.8 percent, according to a report by Insignia/ESG. Average asking rents declined 32 cents a square foot, to $39.15 a year. But some brokers caution that asking rents may not reflect the true state of the market because some landlords are offering concessions that reduce the effective rent.
The government-administered incentive programs, which are substantially financed with federal money, may influence the pattern of development throughout the city by attracting to lower Manhattan businesses that might otherwise consider locations in other boroughs. A case in point may be the 37-block sector of Long Island City in Queens that was rezoned last year to encourage development of high-rise office buildings.
According to Sanford H. Zuckerbrot, president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot, a commercial brokerage active in Long Island City, the downtown incentives are likely to nullify the objective of the Queens rezoning. "It will be hard to convince people to move to Long Island City if the price in lower Manhattan is the same," he said.
But the incentives will also have to overcome what many brokers describe as a psychological resistance to moving downtown, where the transportation system is still snarled and the proximity to horrific events is inescapable. "A lot of New Yorkers want to distance themselves from what happened there," said Ruth Colp-Haber of Wharton Property Advisors, a brokerage that represents tenants. "It is as if Manhattan has been divided into two cities, with 14th Street as the border."
Others say that dollars will ultimately trump fears, that the transportation will be rebuilt and improved and amenities developed. "There is $21 billion committed to downtown, so it is going to be a wonderful place to be five or seven years out," said Marc Shapses, a senior managing director for Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that specializes in representing tenants. "Once people figure that out, they will start to react."
It is this combination of factors, rather then the incentives alone, that will bring about the revival of downtown, said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "The incentives will combine with the infrastructure changes to make lower Manhattan the most attractive place to live, work and visit," he said. "It will be the only place in the city with a 21st-century transportation system."
Brokers report there has been little leasing activity downtown in recent months, despite the existence of large amounts of vacant sublet space left by companies that decided to move out of the area. Nevertheless, Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, which promotes the southern tip of Manhattan, sees the glass as half full.
Even if there has been no rush by businesses to move there from other parts of the city or the suburbs, he said, neither has the outflow continued. "We are clearly seeing a stabilization of the downtown market," he said. "The ones that were going to leave have left. We don't see more companies leaving."
DESPITE the loss of about 13 million square feet of office and retail space in the attack and related events, he said, downtown remains the third largest central business district in the United States (after Midtown Manhattan and Chicago). As such, it is receiving "an unusual amount of attention from all levels of government," Mr. Weisbrod said.
The incentive programs are part of that attention. Although the impact of the incentives will vary with each company or professional firm based on size, activity and location, they could be substantial, according to calculations made by the alliance. 
A company with 10 employees that could take advantage of the incentives, for instance, might have a total rental cost downtown of $279,659 for a five-year lease. A similar company in Midtown would have a total rental cost of $612,500 over five years, according to the estimates of Mr. Weisbrod's group, well over double the cost downtown. 
Similar savings could be achieved by larger companies, the study found, although the mix of benefits might be different because companies with more than 200 employees are not automatically eligible for some incentives.
Since the incentives are intended to draw businesses downtown or persuade those already there to sign new leases, the benefits are concentrated at the early years of a lease and the savings decrease as time goes on. According to the alliance's calculation, a downtown tenant would save $48.48 a square foot compared with its Midtown counterpart in the first year of a lease because of incentives and lower rental rates downtown. That premium would diminish to $22.31 a square foot in the fifth year as the incentives would largely expire. 
One major program has nothing to do with rent, but is intended to compensate companies for revenues lost as a result of the attack and its aftermath. It is called the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program and is administered by the state's Empire State Development Corporation. Applications for these grants must be filed by Dec. 31 of this year.
Businesses would have to show that they had losses in revenue not compensated by insurance or other government programs. They must have been in operation on Sept. 11 and must have continued in operation or plan to resume in New York City. They need to have had one to 200 employees at the downtown location and no more than 500 in the overall company.
The grants have a maximum amount in each of four zones, which are intended to reflect the degree of disruption based on proximity to the attack. The largest grants are available in the Restricted Zone immediately adjacent to the World Trade Center, where there is a maximum of $300,000. The Restricted Zone is bounded by Chambers Street on the north, Rector Street on the south, Broadway to the east and the Hudson River on the west.
Outside the Restricted Zone south of Canal Street and Rutgers Slip, the limit is $150,000. In the area north of Canal and south of Houston Street, river to river, the limit is $100,000. And in the area between Houston and 14th Streets the limit is $50,000.
Another plan to put cash in the hands of businesses that commit to move to downtown or to stay there is the Small Firm Attraction and Retention Program. Established by the city and state governments, it is aimed at companies employing 10 to 200 people who sign or renew leases for at least five years in the designated zones. A recent proposal, still not approved, would reduce the size threshold to businesses employing one person. 
Companies that have stayed in the Restricted Zone are eligible for $5,000 per employee, payable in two installments. Businesses that have stayed or moved into the area south of Canal Street and Rutgers Slip but outside the Restricted Zone are eligible for $3,500 per employee. 
In addition, the city's Economic Development Corporation has the discretion to make grants to companies with more then 200 employees that relocate to lower Manhattan or extend their leases.
Breaks in federal taxes for businesses that invest in lower Manhattan are contained in the New York Liberty Zone Tax Relief Act of 2001 passed by Congress as part of the Bush administration's economic stimulus plan. The Liberty Zone includes the area south of Canal Street and an additional segment in eastern lower Manhattan south of East Broadway and Grand Street.
The provisions are complicated, as federal tax matters tend to be, but one significant provision is greatly accelerated depreciation for leasehold improvements to buildings in the zone, said Jordan Silbert, an analyst with the Downtown Alliance.
"Companies in the area can write off the cost of those improvements over five years, rather than 39 years," he said. "We figure that for a company of 100 people, it could amount to a savings of $60,000 a year."
The law also includes a variety of deductions and tax credits, not all of which can be used at the same time, including a credit of $2,400 per employee per year for companies in the zone with fewer than 200 employees in the years 2002 and 2003.
Also included was a provision to defer taxation of insurance proceeds for destroyed or damaged buildings as long as the money is invested in lower Manhattan. The law also provides for up to $8 billion in bonds exempt from federal, state and city taxes to finance private investment, with $6 billion earmarked for lower Manhattan, Mr. Silbert said. 
THESE new programs come in addition to the existing Lower Manhattan Economic Revitalization Plan, which has been effect since 1995 to draw tenants downtown. This city program is intended to promote investment in buildings completed before 1975 by granting tax abatements.
The program, which is scheduled to expire in 2004, is open only to businesses operating below Chambers Street. Large companies, those with more than 125 employees, must sign a lease for at least 10 years and invest $35 per rentable square foot to be eligible.
In return, they get a 100 percent abatement of their real estate taxes, up to a cap of $2.50 a square foot, and a lesser break in the last two years of the program, which is in effect for five years. The landlord must pass the benefits through to tenants in the form of lower rents.
Smaller companies -- those with fewer than 125 employees -- need only sign a five-year lease and invest $5 per square foot to be eligible for the benefits, which also include reduction in the occupancy tax.
This program is available for office or retail tenants expanding or renewing leases downtown or coming to downtown from outside the city or from elsewhere in Manhattan below 96th Street. There is no limit on the number of employees a company can have.
Another existing program available to companies that relocate or begin operations in lower Manhattan is a 20 percent reduction in the cost of electrical power. Mr. Weisbrod noted that the power capacity needed to supply the World Trade Center towers is now available to other users in the area.
Although less attractive than outright grants and tax breaks, there are also low-interest loan programs for businesses and nonprofit organizations available through the Small Business Administration and other agencies in the city and downtown.
The cumulative effect of lower rents downtown compared with Midtown and the government programs "gets people thinking" about making the move despite the physical and psychological barriers, said Mr. Peretz of Insignia/ESG. "For a professional services firm, we are talking as much as $75,000 per partner per year," he said. Over a 15-year lease, that savings could be more than $1 million for each principal in a firm.
Most of the transportation problems in the area, including rebuilding PATH train tunnels from New Jersey and subway facilities destroyed in the attacks, should be resolved within 18 months, said Gerry C. Miovski, an associate director at Insignia/ESG. "And there are no problems east of Broadway," he added.
The complexity of the incentive program is something of a barrier itself, Mr. Shapses of the Studley firm reported. "A lot of these programs are as-of-right -- you just have to know about them," he said. "But I keep running into tenants who do not know about them."
With plans to rebuild 7 World Trade Center moving forward and a music festival set to run for much of the summer downtown, some brokers say the time to make deals is now, rather than later when lower Manhattan seems more inviting.
"Historically, large gaps between downtown and Midtown have led to deals downtown," said Michael Gottlieb, a senior managing director of Grubb & Ellis, a real estate services company. "In the current market climate with lowered rents and the recent incentives, there is a window of opportunity to make good economic deals."
He said the last time incentives were offered to promote development downtown -- in the mid-1990's during an economic downturn -- the initial response was slow, just as it has been recently. But, he said, a few notable examples could alter the mood of the market. "All you need is a few big deals, and a lot of people will follow," Mr. Gottlieb said.
BECAUSE more than half of the space on the market downtown is being offered for sublease, the landlords are still collecting rent from the primary tenants and are under little pressure to accept tenants will less than solid credit, brokers said. Even where dot-com companies vanished, they left behind multiyear letters of credit to cover the rent, they add.
Mr. Peretz said the current vacancy rate of about 14 percent downtown is modest compared with the rate of 25 percent in the mid-1990's. And, he said, the type of space available is different from that of the previous downturn.
Much of the space available today is in the most modern, best appointed buildings in the area. "Never has there been as much quality space on the market downtown," he said. "Most of the space in the mid-1990's was in secondary prewar buildings."
He said a lot of prospective tenants are tromping through buildings downtown, which could lead to deals later in the year. "There is a lot of prelease planning going on right now that could lead to leases in the third and fourth quarters," he said.
Even if that does not happen, the incentives put financial limits to procrastination. "To get the incentives, tenants have to make a commitment before the end of 2004," Mr. Peretz said.
