HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
The Billionaires' Boat Maker

BYLINE:  By JAMES V. O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK 

 BODY:
TUCKED in among the diners and seafood restaurants on the Boston Post Road in this town on the Long Island Sound, a shipbuilder makes 150-foot custom sailing yachts for billionaire clients from all over the world.
 Derecktor Shipyards makes sailboats, powerboats and high-speed ferries ranging in size from 75 to 150 feet long. Since 1947, when the shipyard opened, the specialty here has been aluminum-hulled crafts. Derecktor built the first aluminum yacht in the United States; it is the only company in the country building aluminum yachts bigger than 100 feet. 
 Ship building and repair was a small but vibrant industry in the area before World War II. Now Derecktor is one of the last ship builders in Westchester and despite the sagging economy, it is doing so well that it is outgrowing its current space, and moving some of its operations to Bridgeport, Conn. 
"There was a lot of money floating around in the 90's and we are an ultimate high-end product," said Gavin Higgins, the company's chief operating officer. "But it takes a long time to build boats like we do. We are building one right now that will take 30 months." The stock-market downturn had a minor effect on powerboat orders but orders for sail boats and ferries have always remained steady, said Mr. Higgins. Sailing yachts can cost from $1 million to $5 million. Motor yachts can cost as much as $15 million. 
Orders for more and bigger boats are outpacing Derecktor's space at the yard here. The company is building two to three new boats and servicing 15 boats of various sizes each year. With its physical plant stretched to capacity, the company built a new yard in Bridgeport that is about 10 times the size of the 60,000-square-foot yard in Mamaroneck. "There are space constraints in Mamaroneck so the Connecticut yard will become the primary assembly yard and Mamaroneck will be used primarily as a service yard," said Krista Stanley, director of planning and communication. "The joinery work will still be done in Mamaroneck." 
Moving boats during construction is almost impossible in Mamaroneck because the yard isn't equipped with a travel lift. Workers use a 120-ton stationary derrick, which looks like a huge crane. The space constraints and congested location on Boston Post Road make it impossible to pull a tractor-trailer into the yard to upload whole boats or hulls. One of the yard's customers, Larry Ellison, the founder and chief executive officer of Oracle Corporation, transports his 84-foot sailboat from the Long Island Sound to Chicago to race on the Great Lakes every year. The mast and the keel have to be removed from the boat in the yard and hoisted by the derrick over the warehouse and fence and into the parking lot of the diner next door, where it is loaded on a tractor-trailer. 
Most of the new construction work that will be done in Mamaroneck will be the cabinetry and woodworking that go into yachts' interiors. Every yacht that Derecktor builds is one of a kind. There are no patterns, templates or standard parts to be used. Building a 100-foot yacht takes two to three years and entails hundreds of thousands of hours of work.
"Most owners have a vague idea of what they want when they decide to build a yacht," said Gilbert Mello, the company's production manager, who has been building yachts for 30 years. "So we build them a three-dimensional wooden mock-up on a one-to-one scale so they can see what it will look like in the interior and how everything will fit."
Mr. Mello travels the world to select the woods that will go into the interiors: teak from Singapore, spruce from Seattle. The challenge in ship joinery, said Mr. Mello, is that everything has to be square and plumb as in building a house but it also has to be attached to a curved hull. All of the woodwork has to be hollowed out and filled with foam to keep the boat light. "When you build a house, a kitchen is a kitchen, but yachts are all different and are much more challenging," he said.
Zingaro, which means gipsy in Italian, a 112-foot sloop, was a recent Derecktor project, built for a South American client. The boat can travel 13 knots under 5,000 square feet of sail. It has two cabins for a crew of four, guest cabins for four and a captain's cabin with a queen-sized bed. Teak paneling lines the interior, 17th-century Italian seascapes hang on the walls, and a plasma screen television and treadmill await use. Space was a major factor in the decision to build the Bridgeport yard, but the work force was also an issue. "Being located in Westchester is a problem because it is expensive to live here and it is hard to attract good workers," Mr. Mello said. "Very few of the guys that work here live here."
A high cost of living means an expensive labor force, which explains the absence of shipbuilding in the area. The United States has the same problem when trying to compete with foreign shipbuilders. Asian shipbuilders have much lower labor costs, but shipyards that build ferries are protected under the Jones Act. The law was enacted in 1920 to ensure that the country had a shipbuilding and ship repair industrial base in place to respond in the event of a war. It requires that all vessels used for commerce on domestic waterways be built in the United States, protecting shipbuilders like Derecktor from foreign competition.
Derecktor has built high-speed ferries and has supplied boats for most of the ferry lines servicing the waterways around New York. Two will be servicing the route between Atlantic Highlands, N.J., to Lower Manhattan, and a 65-foot cargo ferry for Fire Island and two more ferries for use in Alaska are in the works. 
Aluminum hulls, which are light and very strong, worked well for yachts and high-speed ferries, said Mr. Higgins. The aluminum design enables the boat to take lots of stress, pounding and use. Its light weight enables higher speeds of up to 45 miles per hour and creates a shallow draft allowing the boat to navigate shallow water carrying up to 1,000 passengers. 
There are structural similarities between ferries and yachts, which made the production an easy switch. The clients are completely different, however. Ferry operators put out a request for a proposal and the contract is awarded to the lowest bidder. "Commercial operators want a boat that runs so fast and carries so many people in these particular conditions and seasons," said Mr. Higgins. "The look of the boat is usually not a requirement; they leave that up to the shipyard." 
On the yacht side, the customer will go to a naval architect first; the way the boat looks is very important. Sailboats are usually built for customers who have sailed their whole lives and have a passion for sailing. Powerboats are for people who want lots of staterooms inside.
"You can get a lot of state rooms in a powerboat that you can't in a sailboat because they have the nasty habit of being pointy at both ends," said Mr. Higgins. "Powerboat buyers are looking for a floating condo that they can park in Florida in the winter and Nantucket in the summer."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Men work on a boat at Derecktor Shipyards in Mamaroneck. A crane lowers a sailboat from an adjoining shipyard onto a work area. The shipyard, which is expanding to Connecticut, is thriving despite the slowed economy. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; 
A Little Tax-Free Shopping? Some Smiles, A Few Shrugs

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
For shoppers who need an excuse, state and city lawmakers hope to make spending money a bit more guilt free.
 Under the budget passed in Albany last week, the state's portion of the city's 8.25 percent sales tax (about half) will be suspended below Houston Street during three 3-day periods in the next three months. The City Council supports doing the same with the city's half of the sales tax, but Mayor Bloomberg remains uncommitted. 
 The tax-free days, which are expected to cost the city and state (and save consumers) $20 million total, would apply to all retail items sold in Lower Manhattan that cost less than $500, except for tobacco and alcohol. 
On the streets, reaction ranged from smiles to shrugs. Typical of the latter was Nelly Lanti, a legal secretary who works downtown. "If I had to buy something," she said, "I don't think about the tax."
The proposal, introduced by Sheldon Silver, the state assembly speaker, initially faced some opposition. The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, wanted the tax-free zone to begin farther south, at Chambers Street. But Mr. Silver, who represents the Lower East Side, insisted that the border be expanded north to Houston Street to include an area he has dubbed "the Lower Manhattan resurgence zone." 
"You have to cast a slightly broader net," said Dan Weiller, a spokesman for Mr. Silver. "The speaker felt really strongly that all businesses in the resurgence zone had suffered."
In the end, Mr. Silver prevailed and the $89.6 billion state budget hammered out last Thursday will cover all retail businesses south of Houston Street on June 9 to 11, July 9 to 11 and Aug. 20 to 22. 
But the fate of the city's 4 portion of the sales tax is tied up in budget negotiations. A spokesman for Mr. Bloomberg said Friday that the mayor had concerns about the effect the proposed tax break would have on the city's hefty budget deficit. 
While much of Lower Manhattan has bounced back economically, business groups there say that the retail sector remains sluggish. 
In Chinatown, jewelry stores were among the hardest hit, with workers reporting an 80 percent decline in wages, according to a recent report. 
In TriBeCa, restaurants like Chanterelle have largely rebounded, but many mom-and-pop shops are having trouble meeting their rent. "Those businesses are way down," said Julia Pershan, chairwoman of the TriBeCa Organization, a neighborhood assistance group formed after Sept. 11. "This would be a great kick in the pants." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Pushing the Limit 

 BODY:
Congress, which was all ears when George W. Bush wanted to cut taxes, has turned hard of hearing now that the president needs to raise the legal limit on the national debt. Virtually everybody agrees that the debt level will have to go up soon by $750 billion, to $6.7 trillion. But Congress is understandably reluctant to go on record as admitting that its most significant achievement during the Bush presidency has been to plunge the nation deeper into hock. If our elected officials cannot properly manage the country's finances, the least they can do is face the music like adults. 
 Republicans are worried that if they vote to raise the debt limit, their Democratic opponents in November will claim that the tax cuts for the wealthy they passed last year, along with the economic downturn, have drained away both the budget surplus and the money that was intended to be stored away -- in that famous locked box -- to shore up the Social Security system. 
 The chances of that happening are excellent since the scenario is absolutely true. The only problem for the Democrats will be explaining away the votes some of their members produced in the Senate to help put the whole sorry tax package into law.
State legislatures all over the country are currently reeling because they followed Congress's lead and cut taxes in boom times to a level that could never be sustained when recession kicked in. The economic slowdown America suffered turned out to be relatively mild, but virtually every state in the union is wrestling with a budget crisis that can be traced to big tax cuts in the 1990's. Like Congress, none of the state legislatures are prepared to do the things necessary to make the books balance. So they are engaged in a wild dance with budget mirrors and accounting tricks -- the favorite idea seems to be spending the next 30 years' worth of revenue from the tobacco settlements tomorrow.
Fiscal conservatives are fond of comparing the government to a family that must cut expenses in tough times. But when they are preparing to eliminate government revenue, they never seem to ask themselves how many families would encourage mom to quit her job without estimating whether the loss of income could be afforded.
And the theory that tax cuts can be used to force the government to shrink never seems to quite work out in the real world. In the 1980's, Congress found it easy as pie to deliver the Reagan tax cuts, but impossible to produce the budget reductions that were supposed to go along with them. The size of government continued to grow apace during Ronald Reagan's tenure, as did the budget deficits, with all the strain on the private economy that huge federal borrowing always entails.
This year, the orgy of pandering to special interest groups that produced an obscene $190 billion farm bill is still not over, and the administration is finding it hard to achieve its one significant plan to eliminate useless defense spending: cancellation of the Crusader artillery system.
Having failed to be sensible when it comes to tax cuts, or disciplined when it comes to budgets, or responsible when it comes to setting a good example for the states, Congress can at least be realistic. Raise the debt limit and admit defeat.

HEADLINE: The World: Westward Ho; 
An Empire Tries to Become a Normal Nation

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH told Russia's foreign minister he is preparing for his first trip to Russia by reading the works of Fyodor Dostoyevsky, the 19th-century author whose works explored the dark recesses of the Russian soul.
 But Mr. Bush has picked the wrong author, Russians say, because the Russia he will be visiting this week is not the Russia of Dostoyevsky, with mystical saints and guilt-stricken madmen, but a more rational and forward-looking nation that is being pushed, prodded and promoted by his host, President Vladimir V. Putin. 
 "Bush is reading Dostoyevsky, but he should be reading Nabokov, because that is where the future is, not the past," said Nina L. Khrushcheva, a professor in international affairs at the New School University.
Like Dostoyevsky, Mr. Putin is a nationalist. But like Vladimir Nabokov, the emigre writer, Mr. Putin also seems to have a clear understanding of what Russia lacks, and of what the West has to offer. 
In his two years in office, most particularly since Sept. 11, this former K.G.B. agent has set Russia's course westward -- economically, culturally, politically and now strategically, through a bilateral arms control agreement with the United States and a new alliance with NATO that gives Russia a seat at Europe's head table.
Still, the gap separating Russia and the West, while narrowing, remains wide -- and can be measured in many ways, not just by economic statistics that show Russia lagging significantly behind even Poland, let alone Germany, France or the United States.
So is this the historical moment that has beckoned for decades, even centuries, the moment when Russia becomes a member of the club of civilized countries? Can it be that Russia -- so vast it sprawls across 10 time zones and two continents -- is ready to check its baggage at the door, its history of exotic, often brutal despotism, its messianic ambitions and its belief in its own special destiny?
WESTERN leaders last week were quick to pronounce the end of one era, and the opening of a new one. Jack Straw, the British foreign secretary, said that the new Russian-NATO council amounted to a "funeral of the cold war," and others spoke effusively about Russia's long awaited integration into Europe.
But to many Russians, these pronouncements seemed both short-sighted and outdated. On one hand, they say, the cold war ended more than a decade ago, with the political reforms begun by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which led to the fall of the Berlin Wall and then of the Soviet Union itself.
"I am sick and tired of attending funerals for the cold war," said Vyacheslav Nikonov, head of the Politika Foundation, a research group. "Gorbachev ended the cold war in 1989. It died then, and I think it is still dead."
On the other hand, Russia has proved resistant to change in the past at least as far back as Peter the Great, who in the 17th and 18th centuries tried to modernize and Westernize his country. Even the communist revolution of 1917, many argue, only perpetuated a traditional despotism with an imperialist foreign policy, even if clothed in the language of Marx and Lenin. 
"The process has begun," was a phrase used by Mr. Gorbachev in those years (in Russian, the phrase is more vivid, suggesting a train that has left the station). But from the Russian perspective, that process is far from over. 
RUSSIA is getting closer, and the West is letting it get closer," said Ms. Khrushcheva, a granddaughter of the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev. "But the process is not always linear, and that is not only Russia's doing. We have centuries of mistrust between us, and they cannot be overcome in 10, or 20 years. This is one chapter in a series of chapters, and all that we can say is that the chapters are getting shorter."
Otto Latsis, a political commentator at the newspaper Noviye Izvestia, also believes that Russia's rapprochement with the West still has a way to go. "I agree with the word historical," he said, referring to last week's headlines about Russia's new relationship with NATO, "but not with the word moment. This is the subject of an eternal debate that has been going on for hundreds of years. The adoption of the Western model for Russia is the key question behind our economic reforms, and it is the key to our political change. It can only be a process, a long and difficult one, with twists and turns."
Even if they couldn't quite comprehend it a decade ago, most Russians have now come to understand that the loss of their superpower status was the price they had to pay to become a "normal" country -- if by normal they meant free, democratic and market-oriented. And as painful as that can be sometimes, most Russians have made peace with their choice. 
Even before Sept. 11, Mr. Putin seemed ready to accept that reality and make the best of it, by choosing to cooperate with the West, rather than confront it. 
But he has done so in the face of resistance from much of Russia's institutional elite, from the military and the remnants of the old Soviet foreign policy establishment, many of whom still bridle at the concessions made by Mr. Gorbachev as the cold war was winding down.
"For Russia, it is difficult to become a minor partner," said Anatoli I. Utkin, director of international studies at the Institute for U.S. and Canadian Studies in Moscow. "Since 1480, with the defeat of the Mongols, Russia has never been in second place to anyone. It is difficult to imagine that Russia would ever be happy to be behind the leader, just one member of a pack."
And yet, as many argue, Russia really has no choice. The Soviet Union bankrupted itself by keeping its economy on a war footing for 60 years, Mr. Latsis said. "Now our economy is even worse off," he said. "So how could we conduct ourselves like a superpower? On the basis of what? I can believe that there are some people in the Pentagon who would like to destroy Russia, as they did the Soviet Union, but we should not take up their challenge."
MANY Russians still harbor deep misgivings about the West -- or rather about the West's intentions toward Russia. Those feelings are particularly strong among the elite, but then, as Mr. Nikonov said, here Mr. Putin benefits from the Russian tradition of a strong, even all-powerful leader.
"Russia is still a czarist country where the elite can be ignored," said Mr. Nikonov. 
In any case, he added, the general population has more positive feelings towards the West in general, and the United States in particular. Only twice in the last decade have those feelings soured significantly: once during the American-led bombing campaign in Yugoslavia in 1998, and again during the Salt Lake City Olympics, when Russians felt that their top figure-skaters were the victims of an anti-Russian hysteria generated in the North American press.
The vehemence of the Russian reaction to these events reflects, in part, a sensitivity over their country's weakened position. For many Russians, the bombs that fell on Serbia, a Russian client state, were an ominous hint that bombs could fall again on Russian targets, should Washington will it. At Salt Lake City, too, Russians felt powerless, voiceless and victimized.
So far, the larger strategic issues raised by Russia's new role at NATO, or the terms of the latest arms control agreement, seem barely to have registered on Russian public opinion. But that could change, some experts predict, as NATO takes on the Baltic states as members, or if the American military presence in Central Asia and in Georgia looks set to become long-term.
These issues -- and others, like a possible American invasion of Iraq -- could upset the delicate balance built into Russia's relations with the West, and could, some argue, even lead to Mr. Putin's eventual eclipse -- just as Mr. Gorbachev is thought to have dug his own political grave by being overly eager in his accommodation of the West.
"There is a feeling of deja vu," Mr. Utkin said. "For the second time, Russia is going bearing gifts." The question is whether this time, it will get enough in return to warrant staying the course.
Russia's democracy has advanced since Communist hard-liners mounted a coup against Mr. Gorbachev in 1991: Mr. Putin, unlike Mr. Gorbachev, was popularly elected, and today enjoys a popularity rating of 70 percent or more, about equal to Mr. Bush's. 
THESE things can change, however, and there is no guarantee -- either institutional or cultural -- that Russians next time won't swing away from Mr. Putin's pro-Western policies, leaving the next leader with the same broad powers to move in an entirely different direction.
"Essentially we are talking about two approaches," Mr. Utkin said. "One, taken from American folklore, is if you can't beat them, join them. The other path, which was taken by Winston Churchill or Charles de Gaulle, is to show defiance even in defeat." 
How would the second approach be put into effect? "This is a big country, a very patriotic country, and people could be made ready for mobilization," Mr. Utkin said.
In other words, the debate over Russia's role in the world and history is not over. Even as the Russian foreign minister Igor Ivanov was clasping hands with Western leaders at a NATO meeting in Reykjavik, Mr. Putin was playing host to five presidents of ex-Soviet Republics who came to Moscow to turn a 1992 military alliance into a formal organization.
"This is a kind of insurance policy," Mr. Utkin said, "a guarantee against being melted into the crowd, being put somewhere between Portugal and Spain."

HEADLINE: New Mining Laws, But Only if Fair 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "A Bad Law's Birthday" (editorial, May 13): The mining industry does, in fact, support mining law reform. We supported the 1995 bipartisan reforms, which resolved many issues raised by your editorial, but President Bill Clinton vetoed the bill. 
 The industry now complies with a range of federal and state environmental laws. The regulatory changes made by Bruce Babbitt when he was interior secretary represented an anti-economic-development agenda he knew Congress would never approve. The Bush administration's re-evaluation restores a semblance of balance between reasonable environmental protection and the country's economic objectives.
Instead of focusing on divisiveness, the coming Congressional debate should look at fair, meaningful reform. The industry will certainly do its part.

JACK N. GERARD
President, National Mining Assn.
Washington, May 14, 2002

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Mexico Embraces Microsoft, Stirring a Debate

BYLINE:  By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY 

 BODY:
WHEN he was 17, Miguel de Icaza wrote his first computer program on the supercomputers of Mexico's nuclear institute. In college, he developed Ximian Gnome, a desktop program that is a lot like Microsoft Windows but differs in one fundamental way. It is free.
 Today, at 29, he lives in Boston and is chief technology officer of Ximian Inc., whose software can be freely downloaded from the Internet and is used on millions of desktops worldwide. 
 When he learned that President Vicente Fox had announced a nationwide plan to make millions of Mexicans computer-literate, Mr. de Icaza saw a great opportunity to promote his software at home. But he has since found that Mexico is eager to develop its technology market only with companies that offer millions of dollars to take part. 
And that is how Microsoft, which up north has faced years of regulatory battles over what critics call its monopolistic practices, came to be handed what could fast become a monopoly here.
When Mr. Fox took office, in December 2000, he announced an ambitious project to bring nearly all of Mexico's 100 million people online, but he soon realized that his digital revolution was severely short of financing. Congress, in fact, did not give him one centavo for the first year of the project, called e-Mexico.
Mr. Fox's administration began asking for ideas, but most of all for cash. And international companies, led by Microsoft, have been racing to answer the call.
Mr. de Icaza was quick to offer his services. In January 2001, granted a few minutes with Mr. Fox at a social event, he asked the president to support open-source software instead of proprietary software, the kind Microsoft sells. He said that with the millions of dollars the government saved on licensing and upgrade fees, it could train and employ a generation of programmers to create a software industry to rival Microsoft.
When his time was up, Mr. de Icaza recalled Mr. Fox saying, "Thank you, but that's exactly what we're getting with Microsoft."
Last month Mr. de Icaza learned that Mr. Fox's government had signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Microsoft to train 23,000 computer technicians for the first round of community centers going online with e-Mexico.
Three more deals are on the way. The first of them will be a $56 million investment to help the commerce ministry train 23,000 professionals and schoolteachers. The second will give an estimated $10 million to train those running small and midsize businesses in using Microsoft Office software. And the third, a gift from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to Mr. Fox's philanthropy wing, Vamos Mexico, will bring the nation's 6,000 libraries online using Microsoft technology.
When all four deals are in place, Microsoft will have pledged more than $100 million to the Mexican government and trained more than 70,000 professionals and teachers.
Only 4 percent of Mexicans now have access to the Internet, but the number is expected to grow rapidly, placing Mexico in the middle of a global debate about how to develop its emerging technology market.
One camp, led by Mr. de Icaza, asserts that with open-source software, Mexico can avoid a debt burden to companies like Microsoft, while providing jobs to thousands of underemployed computer scientists. The other side contends that Microsoft offers a quick and efficient method to train millions of people.
With only a $65 million budget for e-Mexico this year, Mr. Fox's government decided that it could not complete the project on its own.
"We don't have the resources, and these communities need something to start with," said Julio Cesar Margain, director of e-Mexico. "Microsoft has been one of the tools to democratize knowledge in the computer era." When people become computer-literate, Mr. Margain said, they can decide whether open-source software is an option for them. But his job now is to help millions of Mexicans start using computers.
Technology analysts are divided about the merit of this decision.
James F. Moore, chairman of GeoPartners Ventures, a technology consulting firm in Boston, says open-source software can reduce the debt burdens of developing countries in the long term. But he also says commercial software can play a big role in a country like Mexico.
"If you're trying to get your people trained so they can get jobs with companies, then you really want them trained with Microsoft software," Mr. Moore said.
But analysts are concerned that Mr. Fox's government is too willing to cede control of e-Mexico and the nation's technology market to the company that is quickest to offer a multimillion-dollar package.
"It's a good deal for the country in the near term because it helps accelerate some things," said Michael Kleeman, a principal at Quintessence, an information technology consulting business, which is based in Washington. "But who did they make themselves hostage to?"
MR. KLEEMAN said that Mexico might be committing itself to Microsoft without first discussing the possibility of adopting open-source strategies, which are gaining steam elsewhere.
The defense ministry of Germany has switched to open-source software, primarily to reduce reliance on outside parties for running and maintaining sensitive computer systems. China has embraced similar technologies, for similar reasons and to avoid copyright fees. France, out of national pride, is discussing making its entire public school system open-source rather than relying on American software.
In South Africa, the Parliament passed a resolution that public schools must use open-source software, as did a few states in Brazil. Argentina and Peru have similar legislation pending.
But Mexico, for now, has chosen to align itself with the market leader.
Analysts say that beyond budget constraints, another factor may have played a role.
Historically, Mexico has chosen international companies for federal projects -- the development of oil wells, the electricity grid, the railway system, the telephone system and Mexico City's subway lines.
"Mexicans who are in power, for some reason, have a hard time believing that there are other Mexicans who are competent in building a national economy and may have some interesting answers," said Gary Chapman, the director of the 21st Century Project at the University of Texas. "This is a very serious liability for the country."
Some computer scientists in Mexico believe that history is repeating itself. "It's frustrating and slightly insulting that they haven't considered Mexicans to develop the software for e-Mexico," said Federico Mena Quintero, 25, a programmer in Mexico City. "It's like saying Mexicans aren't smart enough and we can't do the job, which is not true because Mexicans do make software that is just as good as Microsoft. Microsoft is not superhuman."
But Microsoft said that it is confident it can demonstrate that its software is right for this program. "We are convinced that our software is the best on the market, and we think that a project this big has room for everybody, including free software or software like ours," said Lorenzo Ortiz, Microsoft's spokesman in Mexico. "We are doing our part, and if the other guys would do their part, this market would be much bigger."
But how does a man like Mr. de Icaza participate in e-Mexico if his company, founded only three years ago, lacks the resources to train a nation of computer scientists? Perhaps he will not compete.
"I feel like I've been betrayed," Mr. de Icaza said. "I don't think anybody in Mexico was given the opportunity to participate in e-Mexico."
Mr. de Icaza has become a vocal critic of the government, contending that it is its duty "to protect the country's technology market, and they're not doing it."
"They're giving it away," he said.
That sort of philosophy does not find much support from Mr. Fox's pro-business, pro-market government, or from Mr. Margain, who said, "If open-source was the best practice, my question would be, 'Why doesn't everybody use it?' "

HEADLINE: U.S. Hasn't Kept Promise to Latin America, Critics Say 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18 

 BODY:
During the 2000 campaign, George W. Bush promised to make relations with Latin America a "fundamental commitment of my presidency."
 From Mexico City to Buenos Aires, governments took notice. Leaders stuck to often harsh American economic prescriptions, aligned their foreign policies closer with Washington's and reworked their export regimes to prepare for free trade with the world's largest economy. 
 The United States responded, critics say, with nothing. 
As President Bush travels on Monday to Miami, a city often described as the capital of Latin America, he runs into a wall of dashed expectations, impatience and even a sense of betrayal by many countries in the region. Latin Americans complain that they have become the "afterthought" Mr. Bush had deplored.
Rather than ease their concerns, Mr. Bush's visit to South Florida merely underscores the region's sense of abandonment. While there, he will attest to the importance of domestic politics by attending a Cuban-American fund-raiser, then outline tough policy measures against Cuba that are opposed by virtually every country in Latin America.
"I think they're missing the ball," said Francisco Santos, the leading candidate to become Colombia's new vice president in elections later this month. "They're missing the sense of urgency of the problem in Colombia. I know they have big problems with Afghanistan, the Middle East, but this is the backyard."
For a Spanish-speaking president who revels in the Mexican influence in the American Southwest, the miscues and missed opportunities are striking after 16 months. Argentina, the region's third-largest economy and a close American ally for more than a decade, has been left to sink into economic collapse. Venezuela, the third-leading supplier of oil to the United States, is struggling to emerge from an attempted ouster of its president that the administration briefly appeared to endorse.
Chile, the region's economic wunderkind, sounds like a jilted bride. It has struggled since 1994 to seal a free-trade agreement with Washington. "We've been waiting since then," said Heraldo Munoz, the general secretary of the government, who noted that Chile just signed a trade pact with the European Union. "That's a bad signal for the region. If you have your house in order, then there should be some benefit coming out of it. That hasn't been the case."
After a decade of growth, trade contracted by nearly 4 percent in 2001 in Latin America, according to the Inter-American Development Bank, and the region's largest economies have stumbled, largely due to the American slowdown.
Republican and Democratic officials and analysts worry that the gains in Latin America over the past decade in democracy and free markets could be reversed. "I just think we're ignoring the hemisphere," said Representative Cass Ballenger, Republican of North Carolina and chairman of the House International Relations subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere.
Without intensive engagement by the United States, critics say, a model region -- in which 34 of 35 nations now have popularly elected leaders -- is showing signs of strain. As Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said in a recent speech, democracy must deliver a better life to sustain itself. "There is a disenchantment with the institutions of elective government," Secretary Powell told the Council of the Americas.
The administration has little to show for its stated priorities. Its plan to extend free trade across the hemisphere has languished for months, though the Senate now appears poised to grant the president trade promotion authority. Even that progress has been undercut by Mr. Bush's protectionist moves this spring to benefit American producers of steel and by his embrace of farm subsidies. Brazil, the linchpin of any future hemispheric deal, is considering retaliatory steps.
Meanwhile, the administration is wading more deeply into Colombia with a growing $1.7 billion investment and severe misgivings; officials do not see any easy solution for that drug-fueled civil war. 
Amid the signs of discontent, the cruelest cut for Mr. Bush came earlier this month from Mexico. President Vicente Fox, who may be Mr. Bush's closest friend among foreign leaders, blasted the administration for failing to act on his appeal to reform American immigration laws. 
In a speech in New York, Mr. Fox asserted that the United States-Mexico relationship had "stalled" and admitted that he had paid a political price for aligning Mexico more closely than ever with Washington.
"There can be no privileged U.S.-Mexico relationship without actual progress on substantive issues in our bilateral agenda," Mr. Fox said. "And there will be no substantive progress without comprehensively addressing the issue of migration."
Mexico is seeking changes in American policy that would regularize the status of millions of illegal workers, provide a temporary worker program and make border crossings less hazardous. So far, it has received the opposite: a crackdown on the border, which Vice President Dick Cheney this week defended as a "temporary necessity" in the struggle against terrorism.
By most accounts, Mr. Bush was off to a promising start. Within three months of taking office, he addressed the Organization of American States, a regional forum that previous presidents had long ignored. His first foreign trip was to Quebec, where he laid out his vision for a hemispheric free-trade area. He declared that the United States had no more important relationship than that with Mexico.
But now, officials acknowledge that the region has receded as a priority in the wake of Sept. 11. "It's not where the war is being fought," said one State Department official.
There was an improvised nature to Mr. Bush's trip to Mexico, El Salvador and Peru in March. He appeared at a United Nations summit meeting in Monterrey, Mexico, after a personal appeal from Mr. Fox, and hastily assembled a foreign aid package that officials said would grow by 50 percent over three years.
If the White House moves swiftly ahead on trade, it could mitigate the pent-up concerns of several countries. The president has said he will seek a free-trade agreement with Chile, a regional pact with Central America and the extension of trade preferences to Andean nations.
It may be more difficult to ease a perception of callousness by officials who stepped into the breach as the president focused elsewhere. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill harshly dismissed calls to help bail out Argentina, saying, "Nobody forced them to be what they are."
Moreover, the administration's early embrace of the brief ouster of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela last month left some Latin Americans doubting American support for democracy. After that, one Latin American diplomat lamented, "It's hard to believe how misinformed the administration was and is in relation to the region."

Map of Latin America highlighting Mexico, Colombia, Argentina, Chile, Cuba, Venezuela and Brazil.

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
You Read Your Book and I'll Read Mine

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
In Thomas Mann's novel "The Magic Mountain," Hans Castorp, a young bourgeois about to embark on a conventional career, visits an Alpine sanitarium for tuberculosis patients, becomes infatuated with one of them and is conveniently discovered to have a spot on one of his own lungs. He gets to spend the next several years as her fellow inmate. At the sanitarium Hans experiences an astonishing awakening. His infatuation inspires a craving for knowledge -- about art (his inamorata has posed for paintings), anatomy (her diseased one in particular), chemistry (disease again), consciousness, botany, the passage of time and the biological mystery of life, to name just a few of the topics his desire leads him to. Each book he reads functions as a fetish object: it magically ushers him into the presence of his beloved. Drifting off to sleep over a work on pathology, Hans "beheld the image of life, its voluptuous limbs, its flesh-borne beauty," Mann writes. "She bent toward him, bent down to him, over him, he sensed her organic aroma, sensed the lacelike pounding of her heart." 
 Mann's is probably the most satisfying account of passionate reading ever written. As any teacher can tell you, students read best when their reading brings them in contact with something or someone they love or are at least madly attracted to. We forget most of what we read, but we're more likely to retain some dim memory of books assigned to us by professors we idolized, lent to us by friends we had unspoken crushes on or connected to the heart-stopping events of our lives. Of course, most people no longer have access to the pedagogical eros that roils exciting classrooms or teacher-student or student-student relationships. So for us postgraduate Americans, there are substitutes: reading groups, the One Book, One City program and, until several weeks ago, Oprah Winfrey's book club. 
 Actually, Oprah's book choices never had any connection to pedagogy. She picked books that spoke to her. "The aim is pleasure and personal growth, not discomfort," D. T. Max wrote in a 1999 article on Oprah's Book Club. This explains its success. Oprah's book recommendations were meant not to instruct but to entertain and heal. Her books served as substitutes for the overflowing mother love that has always made Oprah so soothingly irresistible. Oprah's club was a way for her to nurture her fans even after they turned the television off, which may be why she was drawn to stories of recovery and redemption. 
Mother love, on the other hand, couldn't be farther from the minds of the administrators of the One Book, One City program. This reading drive, which began in Seattle four years ago and has since swept the country (except for New York, where it occasioned a rousing outburst of disagreeableness), seeks to boost "community," whatever that is, as well as library attendance. Each book is selected to attract as many readers as possible and to offend none, which is to say that most of the choices are mediocre. Every time I hear of library officials priding themselves on the program's social benefits, I think of George Babbitt jerry-building some shady real estate scheme and telling himself it will be good for the city of Zenith. Even if the chosen book is great, I can't imagine a reader getting a thrill out of something officials have designated a tool of civic improvement unless he miraculously manages to wriggle free of that crushingly unsexy concept.
Despite what your high school English teacher may have told you, literature does not make us or our society better. To be seduced by fiction is to live at cross-purposes with most of the really important things in life. I've never entirely succumbed to a story without blowing off housework, neglecting social obligations and flubbing career-critical deadlines. Mann linked reading to lust and disease and decay. "The Magic Mountain," the critic James Wood says, "is a Bildungsroman and a parody of one, because Hans Castorp's education at the sanatorium is really an education in death." Hans is a man alarmingly blessed with the quality Keats called negative capability, which is the ability to suspend one's impatient presumptions long enough to take in the new and the difficult. This may be admirable in a poet, but enlightened passivity is surely not what mayors have in mind when they say they want cities full of readers.
What they have in mind is what economists call social capital, which is the trust between people that lets them get along well enough to build businesses and other useful institutions. One Book, One City people believe that reading as a group will turn us into a unified body of productive citizens. That's a noble goal, I guess, and not all that different from what some cultural pundits hope for when they call for a return to a traditional curriculum. Our students need a common body of knowledge, they say; otherwise, we will not cohere as a culture. 
What canon warriors often overlook, though, is that few of the books included on the usual lists actually espouse the Western values they're supposed to espouse. We're told to read the canon because it's the repository of our cultural heritage, which is broadly true in the sense that some of our forebears read some of these books on occasion. In the narrow sense, however, most writers now considered canonical wouldn't have recognized a Western idea if it bit them -- they considered themselves Greek or Hebrew or Christian, not Western, and bitterly opposed most of the other ideas now mushed together into the porridge pot that is our idealized past. "Western civilization" is a construct of early -- that is to say, 18th-century -- modernity, not a product of what's in those books. 
None of this matters if core curriculum classes teach students to question the falsely coherent narrative of intellectual progress that canonical books are said to exemplify, which is what happens in the best of such classes. Likewise, there's nothing wrong with a reading group if it leads to vigorous debate. I can't think of any better training for the lifelong struggle with good books that Harold Bloom believes is the prerequisite for serious reading than learning to hold one's own against a group. 
This process, however, has nothing to do with coming together and everything to do with breaking apart, with figuring out how to live as an independent intellect and a soul loyal to its own needs. Literature takes root in a rich and stubborn particularity, not in some powdery notion of communal uplift. I've been to reading groups where participants understood this, and groups where the majority seized on some stifling banality and spent the rest of the evening ganging up on anyone who challenged it. It all depends on who's leading the group and what that person hopes to accomplish by it. I'd feel safer attending a group animated by Oprah than one haunted by George Babbitt, but I'd be happiest reading my book at home.

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
It's in the Stars: ABull Market Is Ascending

BYLINE:  By AMY CORTESE 

 BODY:
Up? Down? Sideways? Investors frustrated by the zigzagging stock market can take heart: if all unfolds according to a cosmic plan, we may be in for another roaring bull market.
 That is the outlook from the Astrologers Fund, a New York-based financial advisory firm that uses astrology to divine market performance. On Friday, the firm presented its forecast for 2002 and 2003 at its 10th Annual Astrology and Stock Market Forecasting Seminar in New York. The date was no coincidence: May 17 was the 210th birthday of the New York Stock Exchange (making the Big Board a Taurus, sign of the bull). 
 The main celestial indicators are a shift late this month from the apprehensive gloom of the Saturn-Pluto cycle that started last August to the more expansive combination of Jupiter and Neptune, according to Henry Weingarten, a 54-year-old Leo who is the founder and managing director of the Astrologers Fund and an author of books on astrology and investing. 
Compared with Saturn-Pluto, the impending Jupiter-Neptune configuration could be downright giddy, setting off a bull market late this year that could continue into 2003. Or so say the planets.
Mr. Weingarten warns of a "new silly season," in which valuations, particularly in the biotechnology sector, could once again become unrealistic. While that could mean profitable trading opportunities, Mr. Weingarten warned, "Investors better have learned the lessons of 2000." 
Mr. Weingarten not only charts the big picture, but also takes into account the charts of individual companies, based on their date of incorporation. I.B.M., one of his top stock picks for 2001 based in part on its astrological chart, remains one of his favorites despite being down almost 30 percent so far this year. He is also bullish on gold, which could offset Jupiter's inflationary tendencies. Defense stocks, a Saturn-Pluto staple, are downgraded.
Mr. Weingarten, who also uses conventional research techniques, says astrology is a great tool for timing the market. But other influences can come into play, too. 
After being given 250,000 shares of U.N. Dollars, the over-the-counter stock of an Astrologers Fund client, Mr. Weingarten started recommending it in his weekly newsletter in January 2000 and bought $75,000 of the shares for his clients' portfolios. That inspired earthly intervention by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to which he paid a $15,000 fine to settle a complaint in March, without admitting or denying wrongdoing. AMY CORTESE

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Many 'Star Wars' fanswent online to avoid a long line.

BYLINE:  By Sarah Milstein 

 BODY:
WHEN "The Empire Strikes Back," the first "Star Wars" sequel, opened in 1980, fans dressed as their favorite characters and lined up days before to buy tickets. Predictably, the latest sequel, which opened on Thursday, also had strong advance interest.
 But fewer moviegoers waited in line. Instead, many bought their tickets online -- through AOL Moviefone, MovieTickets, Fandango or the ticket-sales Web sites of various theater chains. 
 Consumers who pay a fee of $1 or so to buy movie tickets online now make up about 3 percent of box office sales, according to industry estimates, and ticketing executives predict the number will grow to 10 percent or more within a few years. And as each service hopes to grab a bigger share of the online market, the three main ticketing companies are looking to sell more than tickets, through advertising and marketing deals.
"Ticketing is a great sign of vitality for your site, but the real business is advertising," said Tommy McGloin, senior vice president and general manager at AOL Moviefone, a unit of AOL Time Warner. He said that many consumers who once looked to newspapers for movie listings and reviews now turn to the Web, and he predicted that movie studios would begin to apportion their marketing budgets accordingly. 
"Movie marketers are realizing that more investment should go into reaching moviegoers where they make decisions about going to the movies," Mr. McGloin said. "I want to grow Moviefone as the place where people go to get movie information." 
Jupiter Media Metrix, a Web measurement firm, said that in October, AOL Moviefone, MovieTickets and Fandango had a combined 4.4 million individual visitors to their sites. By April, that number had increased to just over 7 million -- about 4.7 million visitors to Moviefone, 1.2 million to Movietickets and 1.1 to Fandango.
The Web did not even exist when Moviefone made its debut in 1989 as a phone service. Initially, moviegoers in New York and Los Angeles could call 777-FILM and hear movie schedules from the rumbling voice of Mr. Moviefone. The service later expanded nationwide, and a ticket-buying feature was added in 1991. 
Moviefone still sells about half of its tickets through its automated telephone service, and Fandango sells an undisclosed portion of its tickets by phone through an independent service provider, 800-TellMe. But executives for both companies say phone sales are now more a customer convenience than a big revenue generator. MovieTickets sells only through the Web. 
Rick King, a spokesman for AMC Theaters, recalled that Moviefone had initially obtained show schedule information free, whether directly from the theaters or from their published advertisements, and built its business selling sponsorships and ads that ran during phone calls. "Theater companies at the time didn't realize the value of their own show times," he said. "This company came along and said, 'I'd like to sell tickets by phone, and I need access to your inventory and show times.' They were selling our goods and services." 
Theater owners learned from the experience. When the Internet became a hot medium for ticket vending in the late 1990's (the Moviefone.com Web site started in 1995, and America Online bought the company for $388 million in 1999), theater companies sought to gain control of their own remote sales. 
A consortium of leading theater chains and industry companies, including AMC Entertainment, National Amusements and Famous Players, which is part of Viacom, banded together and founded MovieTickets in 2000. Fandango was created that same year by six major exhibitor partners and two venture capitalists.
The ticketing companies have deals with specific theater chains. Fandango, for instance, sells tickets for Cinemark, a major chain in the Midwest that also sells tickets through its own Web site. Moviefone and MovieTickets sell tickets for each other's chains, which include AMC Theaters; National Amusements; United Artists Theaters, controlled by Regal Entertainment; and Clearview Cinemas, part of Cablevision. 
In April, Fandango filed suit against Moviefone and Onex, which owns the Loews Cineplex chain, saying that Moviefone had interfered with a deal that was supposed to have made Fandango the exclusive online ticket distributor for Loews Cineplex. Moviefone has denied the accusation.
Whatever the specifics of any one deal, the business works essentially the same way for all the ticketing companies: they divide the service fee with theaters after credit card companies take a percentage for processing the transaction. That is another reason the online ticket sellers want to expand their advertising revenue -- to generate more money that they can keep for themselves. 
According to the Motion Picture Association of America, there were 189 major Hollywood studio releases in 2001, with an average advertising budget of $27 million. Web sites that post film information hope to draw moviegoers away from newspaper listings and capture a parallel share of those studio budgets. 
"Movie marketers haven't decreased their ad spending online, unlike a lot of other categories," said Mr. McGloin of Moviefone, who noted that Moviefone.com derived 90 percent of its revenues from advertising. 
A new study commissioned by AOL Moviefone found that Hollywood studios spent only 1 or 2 percent of their ad dollars online. But the study reported that about 30 percent of moviegoers indicated they were influenced to see a film by information they found on the Web. 
For ticketing companies, the gap in ad spending and the level of Web activity represents an advertising sales opportunity. For exhibitors, Internet ticket sales may help reduce costs, because online sales incur much lower labor costs. And theater executives say they glean useful information from ticket sales made before films open. 
"We are opening new product every week, and we're never fully certain how it's going to perform in the marketplace," said Mr. King at AMC. "With advance ticketing, we can get much more accurate attendance projections, which influence staffing, show times and the number of screens for a film." 
To lure more customers, theater and ticketing companies are offering additional services on their sites. MovieTickets and Fandango have recently started print-at-home ticketing for a small number of theaters around the country already equipped with the necessary bar-code readers, and many more are to be added this year. Promotional deals involving the online vendors, theaters and local restaurants are also in the works. 
Even as the number of visitors to ticketing sites grows, though, some analysts question whether there is room in the market for all the Web ticket sellers to succeed. David Card, a senior analyst with Jupiter Media Metrix, is one of those who predict that one or more of the three ticketing sites will eventually merge.
Whatever antitrust concerns might arise, consumers, who must visit at least two sites to buy tickets at competing theaters, might benefit from a streamlined search process. And certainly, a single ticketing company with most of Web traffic could gain more studio marketing dollars. 
"You're looking at a hybrid step now," said Mitchell Rubenstein, co-chief executive of MovieTickets. "Later in the year or next year, you might see just one company."

HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal; 
It's a First-Class Gridlock, but No Easier to Unlock

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 19 

 BODY:
Rush hour is an oxymoron in this impossible metropolis. It takes two hours to crawl across town. The city is choking on the fumes from three million private cars, 150,000 taxis and 100,000 buses.
 Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador is, God help him, the mayor of the capital, home to roughly 20 million people, a fifth of the nation. He would like to be Mexico's next president. If he could solve Mexico City's traffic problems, he could probably be elected emperor. 
 So should he extend the astoundingly cheap and efficient subway system, or start a billion-dollar project to turn the city's busiest roads into double-decker highways?
That is not a simple question. The answer involves money and politics, of course, but also questions of race and class.
"What is the best way to ease congestion?" said Dr. Mario J. Molina, a Mexico City native, Nobel Prize-winning scientist and consultant to Mexico's City's government. "It's a classic dilemma: when you build more highways, do you decrease pollution or increase traffic? The only way to solve it is to increase public transportation."
The mayor first chose the highway route, with a plan to add a second story to the city's two most heavily traveled roads, the Periferico and the Viaducto, where the average speed is now seven miles per hour. His administration says that if there is more space on the roads and cars can move more freely, pollution will decrease.
Construction was to have started this month, promising years of chaos and providing a chance for even more cars to complicate life in this megacity. Last week, Mayor Lopez Obrador tapped the brakes: the cost and complexity may cause cause him to scale down the project, adding a double deck only to the most choked sectors of the city. 
But he is also planning the first expansion of the subway system in years, though a relatively modest one: four more miles of track that could serve an additional 250,000 people, most of them poor.
The subway costs 20 cents and traverses the heart of the city in 20 minutes. Figures compiled by New York City's transit authority show the Mexico City subway system tied with New York's for fourth place among the world's busiest, with 1.3 billion riders a year. (Moscow, with 3.2 billion, takes the gold, followed by Tokyo and Seoul.)
The argument in Mexico City over whether to build more roads or better mass transit breaks down sharply along class lines. People who are richer -- and, to put it bluntly, whiter, with more Spanish than Indian blood -- tend to favor the idea of the double-decker highways. People who are poorer and browner would like to have more Metro lines.
"The lower you go in the social scale, the more people use public transportation," said the city's environmental coordinator, Claudia Sheinbaum. "Richer people prefer to use private cars."
Manuel Sanchez, 36, is a chauffeur for a rich family in a far-flung suburb of the city. His daily commute lasts four hours, and he spends much of his working day in traffic.
"The second deck isn't going to solve anything, except give people a reason to use the cars that they don't use now because there's too much traffic," Mr. Sanchez said. "The more roads they build, the more cars will appear. 
"The children will use the second car -- the mothers, the fathers. It's too much.
"The Metro is a magnificent system," he added. "It's fast, safe and doesn't pollute. Lopez Obrador should be thinking of more ways to expand it."
But the subway is beneath many middle-class Mexicans, who refuse to ride it because the poor people do.
"People on the Metro push and shove," said Francisco Estrada, 41, a theater technician. "And they smell like onions."
Santiago Creuheras, 28, an economic development officer for the city, said simply, if a bit sniffily, "The Metro is for people who don't have cars."
Owning a car is the only sure sign in Mexico that one has arrived in the middle class. For decades, there has been one car in Mexico that striving people could afford, and only one: the Volkswagen Beetle.
At a cost of less than $8,000, the "Bocho," or Bug, has been the key to the highway for the masses in Mexico for many years. The old Beetle is still manufactured in Mexico -- a plant in Puebla is the only one in the world still making the classic car in its original form -- and hundreds of thousands are on this city's streets.
Most of the cars in the city's taxi fleet are also Beetles, many of them old and in poor repair. Part of the mayor's transportation strategy is a $10 million program of credits and subsidies to persuade taxi drivers to trade in their old Beetles for four-door cars with higher environmental and fuel-efficiency standards.
Ms. Sheinbaum says she is convinced that the double-decker highway will lead to less pollution, even if it leads to more cars, by allowing traffic to move more freely. 
"Mexico City is so densely populated right now, our traffic and congestion problems are so bad, that we have to have more roads," she said. "You can only expand one of two ways: expropriate land for more streets, ripping up trees and waterways, or build a second floor for the highways."
"We hope to have reduced atmospheric pollution and increased the average velocity in the city," she added -- if the money holds out and the project is completed by the target date of 2006, which happens to be the year of the next presidential election.
"Life in the city will be better," she said, hopefully.
Mr. Estrada, the theater technician, has his doubts, though.
"There are," he said, "simply too many people in this city in too little space."

HEADLINE: New York Expands Experiment to Bring Courts and Communities Closer 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
Judge Rolando T. Acosta may be sitting in Manhattan, but when he speaks -- calling the defendants by their first names and imploring them to listen to their parents' advice -- he sounds more like the small-town judge in "To Kill a Mockingbird."
 "I'm going to release you to your mom, but only on certain conditions," the judge told one defendant last week, a penitent-looking 14-year-old boy in a T-shirt and baggy jeans who had confessed to writing graffiti on a city-owned building. "You've got to be home every night by 9 p.m. You must continue to attend counseling sessions here at the court. And you've got to attend our Hard Hats program on Saturdays." 
 Judge Acosta is the lone presiding judge at the Harlem Community Justice Center, the latest addition to the city's ongoing experiment with community courts. The court's juvenile intervention wing, which began hearing cases in January, will officially open today in a ceremony to be attended by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city and state officials. 
The new court, in a spectacular Victorian Gothic building on East 121st Street, is intended to make justice more accessible to a community plagued by crime, and to address crime's root causes with a battery of social services like drug treatment, psychological counseling and mentoring for adolescents. It is part of a nationwide movement toward community-based problem-solving courts that began with the Midtown Community Court in Manhattan in 1993.
Planners hope to redefine the way courts work by bringing them closer to communities. 
"If you were to distill this down to its essence, it's about improving public confidence in the criminal justice system," said Greg Berman, the director of the Center for Court Innovation, a public-private partnership in New York that is the prime mover in the courts' development.
The new courts, which handle low-level crimes and some civil matters, like housing disputes, have generally been well received. But some lawyers and academics say that in their efforts to address the social problems that lead to crime, community courts can become overly paternalistic, generating harsher punishments and funneling more people into the criminal justice system. 
"I appreciate the effort to do things differently, but I share some concerns about courts of this type being more expansive than necessary," said Leonard E. Noisette, executive director of the Neighborhood Defender Service of Harlem, which has represented several people in the new courthouse. 
In a sense, the new courts represent a return to tradition. The city's courts were once spread throughout its neighborhoods, and it was not until the 1960's, burdened by excessive caseloads, that they were centralized. (The Harlem and Midtown community courts are in buildings that once housed local courts.)
But by the late 1980's, some judges were frustrated by the courts' inability to change the chronic problems that plague low-income areas.
"For some problems -- drugs are a good example -- dealing with the individual case alone doesn't help," said Judith S. Kaye, the chief justice of the New York State Court of Appeals, who helped create the city's community courts. "It's better to deal with the underlying problem."
With that goal in mind, the Midtown Community Court was created in 1993. Paid for in part by local business groups (including The New York Times Company Foundation), the court handles misdemeanors like low-level drug use, prostitution and vandalism. 
Two years ago the city introduced a second effort, the Red Hook Community Justice Center, in a refurbished Catholic school in Brooklyn.
In a sense, the Red Hook and Harlem courts are the more radical experiments. Situated in low-income residential areas, their goal is to restore a trust in the criminal justice system that has been badly frayed, said Jeffrey Fagan, a professor of law and public health at Columbia University who is directing evaluations of both courts.
The courts bring together elements that are usually separated -- housing, family and drug cases -- in one small building, so people can deal with several related problems at the same time. 
On a recent morning at the Harlem court, for instance, landlords and tenants who showed up to sue each other were greeted cheerfully by a case manager with a clipboard who asked them to fill out a form describing their problems and complaints. At the court's Resource Center, three employees of the Human Resources Administration help them apply for public assistance or loans in an effort to forestall litigation.
"With housing court, 99 percent of the cases are nonpayment, so it makes sense to deal with those economic issues in the building," Judge Acosta said.
Although many people who have used the court note that it is less crowded than the courthouses downtown, this may change. The Harlem courthouse will eventually hear about 18 percent of all housing matters in Manhattan, roughly 15,000 cases annually.
The Harlem court's juvenile intervention wing also provides a stark contrast with the more crowded courts downtown. Teenagers arrested for nonviolent felony and misdemeanor offenses in its jurisdiction, which includes all of East and much of Central Harlem -- the 23rd, 25th and 28th Precincts -- are generally referred to the court. When a teenager arrives, a probation officer conducts an interview, to get as much information as possible about the problems that may have led to the arrest.
Court officers try to contact the defendant's parents and teachers.
They schedule drug tests, and soon appear at a hearing with Judge Acosta. He can order counseling, drug treatment or a mentor for the teenager, or even recommend job training for the parents. Often he orders appearances at the court's weekend community service program, which may involve painting rails or raking leaves at the Harlem Art Park, behind the courthouse.
The court also has a Youth Court program, in which children or teenagers who have been caught in minor crimes by the police or at school face a court composed entirely of peers, complete with school-age prosecutors, defense advocates, judges and juries. Sentences consist mostly of community service or essay-writing. Although the penalties are voluntary, few fail to obey them, court officers say.
Teenage offenders are likely to face a tougher -- or at least more time-consuming -- penalty in community court than they would have encountered downtown. To some local residents, this is just fine. 
"Kids need to do something constructive," said Edna Smith, who sat in Harlem Art Park on a recent Saturday, watching her son rake leaves as part of a community service project. "Especially in a neighborhood like this. This morning I walked out of my hallway and saw eight guys walking in to buy drugs from a dealer who lives in the building."

HEADLINE: Fear and Rage in Gaza, And Threats by Hamas 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: GAZA CITY, May 19 

 BODY:
As graphic scenes of the latest suicide bombing flashed across his television screen, a top political leader of the militant Palestinian group Hamas hunched forward on his living room couch today, speaking to the broadcast over his cellphone.
 "Sharon and his government have been assassinating our people, our women and our children!" the leader, Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, told the viewers of an Arab news network, who saw his picture in a box beneath the gore. "They must pay a price for every crime they commit." 
 Dr. Rantisi said he had no idea whether the military arm of Hamas was responsible for today's attack, as an anonymous caller told one news agency office in Jerusalem. Another militant group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, issued a statement saying it had carried out the bombing. 
But in an interview as he took calls from television and radio stations around the world, Dr. Rantisi waved away any notion that the bombing might have ended a lull in the violence between Israelis and Palestinians.
"This hasn't been a quiet week," he said. "Every day, the Israelis were killing Palestinians -- in Rafah, in Tulkarm. So we have to attack them -- in Tel Aviv or Jerusalem or anywhere else in Israel."
If the Palestinian leadership around Yasir Arafat was quick to condemn the killing of Israeli civilians today, Dr. Rantisi, a 54-year-old pediatrician, was just as quick to justify it. "Martyrdom operations," he said, would continue unabated so long as the Palestinians had no better way to fight the Israeli occupation of their territories.
Despite the bullet holes still visible in his garage door from a failed attempt by Mr. Arafat's police to arrest him last December, Dr. Rantisi added that he was unperturbed by the prospect that the Palestinian authorities might again crack down on Hamas and other Islamic militants.
Of at least 17 men said to be Hamas militants who were arrested by the Palestinian authorities after the last suicide bombing inside Israel on May 7, he said, none were actual members of the group and most of them had already been freed.
"Mr. Arafat is under two sets of pressures," he said. "One is from the Israelis, the Americans and the Europeans. But the other pressure is from his own people, and nearly all the Palestinians support martyrdom operations."
Along the sandy, unpaved streets surrounding Dr. Rantisi's home here, old men sat chatting on plastic chairs and scruffy children ran around playing before dinner. A chorus of distant television sets blared the same news.
Once again, the talk turned to the possibility that after the Israeli Army's offensive against Palestinian cities and towns in the West Bank, Gaza could be next.
"People are very worried," said Ahmed Dahsan, the owner of a hardware store in downtown Gaza City. "It's been more than a month now that they have been preparing for this. But if they come into Gaza, it will be worse than in the West Bank. It is very crowded here, and the people are very angry."
Israeli officials concurred with the notion that the recent lull in violence was more apparent than real, citing a series of Palestinian attacks against Israeli soldiers and settlers. Last week, a senior Israeli military official told reporters in Washington that one more suicide bombing might be enough to activate the offensive into Gaza that commanders prepared and then put off two weeks ago.
But after long weeks of waiting in which they laid in stores of food and supplies, people in Gaza also seemed to have more concrete problems in mind.
Im Maher Karmout, an elderly woman in a head scarf, complained that Israeli troops had demolished her home last month to make room for a military post, leaving her with only paltry compensation from the Palestinian housing ministry and the United Nations.
Abdel Karim, a 40-year-old marine engineer, said he had not been able to find work for months. Khalil Abu Warda chimed in that nobody had been finding any work -- not in a place where the labor force is blocked from travel into Israel and more than two-thirds of workers are unemployed.
"People here have nothing to do but pray," Mr. Karim said. "Not for money or for a new car, but for something to eat."
Such grievances have left rich political terrain for Hamas, which opposes any peace talks and hopes to replace Israel with an Islamic state. Opinion polls indicate that Palestinian support for the group, which also operates a network of social charities, has doubled to about 25 percent since the current uprising began in September 2000.
That popularity has coincided with new political maneuvering by Hamas, including suggestions by the group's leaders that it might participate in a transitional coalition government or even in new elections -- in the unlikely event that they were free of any constraints by the Israeli government.
"We need elections," another Hamas leader, Ismail Abu Shanab, said in a separate interview. "But what is an election under Israeli occupation? An election is about freedom -- freedom of travel, of association, of speech -- and we do not have any of those freedoms."
Another Hamas leader, Mahmoud al-Zahar, said the group saw no reason to change its tactics now.
"Give me one reason why the Palestinians should give up armed struggle" demanded Dr. Zahar, a surgeon. "The peaceful methods, democracy and negotiation, have failed."
