HEADLINE: Philadelphians Jittery Over Plan to Privatize 20 Schools 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 17 

 BODY:
The students and teachers at John B. Stetson Middle School spent much of this week immersed in the age-old rituals of the season, preparing for a last round of standardized tests and gossiping about who was escorting whom to the eighth-grade prom.
 But the excitement has been tempered this year by sudden jitters about Edison Schools Inc., the for-profit company whose plans to take over management of Stetson and 19 other public schools here have been cast into doubt by several shocks to its precarious finances. 
 Edison officials said this week that they needed to raise up to $50 million from investors in the next few weeks, largely to cover start-up costs in Philadelphia. Without that money, Edison said, the company will have to pull out of the city. The new school year, meanwhile, is less than four months away. 
While Edison said it had enough cash to reopen for business next fall in the more than 100 schools it already manages in 22 states, its financial crisis could eventually threaten its ability to sustain those operations, at least at current levels. With the company's future at stake, so is the very notion at the heart of the Edison experiment: that the private sector can run public schools more effectively and efficiently than the districts themselves.
This was a difficult week for Edison, by far the nation's largest commercial operator of public schools. It settled an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday, confirmed that it had lost a longtime contract for a large charter school in Boston on Wednesday and had run afoul of one of its biggest clients, the Las Vegas school district. The district disclosed that it was withholding about $3 million until Edison secured $2.2 million in charitable contributions that the company had promised it.
"I look up the Edison stock almost every day," Juan Oquendo, an eighth grader at Stetson, said on Thursday, when the company's share price fell as low as $1.63, a tenth of what it had been only a few months ago. "I feel like they're going to take us down." 
As word of the company's setbacks has reached the halls of the schools it runs or is committed to running around the country, some districts have begun reviewing contract provisions that would limit the disruptions to classroom life should Edison suddenly retrench.
While emphasizing that they saw "no immediate threat" of Edison's demise, officials in Long Beach, Calif., where Edison helps manage an elementary school, said the school would revert to the district if that happened. Edison would be entitled to take back its computers and perhaps textbooks, though the district would seek to keep any supplementary materials until the end of the school year, said Chris Eftychiou, a district spokesman.
Other schools and districts said they had yet to consider any contingency plans. "We have been informed that things are business as usual," said Denise Patton, principal of San Jose Edison Academy, a school operated by Edison and the West Covina school district in California. "The fickleness of investors, I can't spend time dwelling on that."
The situation is far more tenuous in Philadelphia, where no one can say for sure how the company's flagging fortunes will affect the 14,500 children who are to be entrusted to the company's care.
The greatest unknown remains whether Edison can raise enough money to meet its early obligations in Philadelphia, which include training teachers in Edison methods as well as buying books and computers, all before September.
As the state panel overseeing the district continues, meanwhile, to negotiate a contract with the company and municipal unions, it has yet to determine whether principals will be employees of the district or Edison, or whether those principals will have the authority to pick their teachers. Nor is it clear whether Edison will extend the school day and year, as it has elsewhere. 
Questions about Edison's intentions and stability were raised repeatedly on Thursday night at Laura W. Waring School, another school assigned to the company, where Richard Barth, an Edison senior vice president, met with several dozen parents, children and community members.
"We are confident we will get the cash to open these schools," Mr. Barth said. But, he added, if the money is not raised, Edison will abandon its plans for the city. 
His words did little to ease the fears of some parents here.
"It is really a lot of red tape," said Crystal Wright, a parent of two children at Waring, and a teacher at an elementary school that is not part of the Edison experiment. "You don't come into an urban area that is already strapped and say you're going to raise $50 million."
The next afternoon, the company's stock price lost another 38 cents, closing at $1.37 today, its lowest point since the company went public in 1999, at an initial offering price of $18. It reached its high of $36.75 in February 2001.
At Stetson Middle School, an 87-year-old red-brick shoe box, the main worry is that Edison, however inadvertently, may interrupt the progress that the school has made in recent years.
The principal, Lucy Rodriguez, takes special pride in the school's sprawling library, from which Stetson's 987 students have checked out 17,142 books this year -- a sixfold increase from 1995.
Over the same period, the percentage of students scoring at or above the "basic" level on reading tests nearly doubled, to more than 40 percent, in a school in which 1 of 6 students arrive speaking only Spanish.
Still, the principal and parents at Stetson acknowledge that they have a long way to go -- fewer than 10 percent of students scored at or above the "proficient" level on those tests -- which is why the state is turning the school over to Edison.
Rhonda Thompson, vice president of Stetson's Home and School Association, a parent group, said she had learned from Edison's Web site that it strives to involve parents in managing schools, retrains teachers and puts a premium on test scores.
"Anything 'extra' is very much welcome," said Ms. Thompson, the mother of an eighth grader. 
Should Edison leave any time before the end of its contract -- the duration under negotiation is two to three years -- then, Ms. Thompson said, the school will have lost nothing for having tried.
The school's teachers, whose union had opposed Edison's arrival, were more skeptical. They said they had puzzled over the logic of transferring 20 city schools from a district with a $100 million operating deficit to a 10-year-old company that had never made a profit.
"If the stock is dropping like that, it means there's not a lot of faith out there in what they're doing," said Michele Miller, a computer science teacher. "I don't want to be a part of that."

HEADLINE: Midwest Towns Feel Gambling Is a Sure Thing 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: BOONVILLE, Mo. 

 BODY:
To this quaint Missouri River town named for Daniel Boone's discovery of a salt lick nearby, the new Isle of Capri casino's promise is more than 800 jobs and $4.5 million in annual tax revenue for City Hall. It is seen as the long-sought catalyst that could turn an anonymous community into a regional destination. 
 Already, a Holiday Inn Express has opened near the Interstate, and half a dozen new restaurants are sprouting amid the spruced-up store fronts of Main Street. With an $800,000 donation from the casino, the Friends of Historic Boonville are renovating Thespian Hall, the oldest continuously operating theater west of the Mississippi. A display at the entrance of the turquoise-and-peach gambling palace points visitors toward the Katy Trail, a 19th-century railroad now popular for hiking and biking. 
 "Like Highway 40 and like the river before that, this casino's going to be another turning point for Boonville," said Judy Shields, 62, a local historian whose family's roots were planted here in 1821. "I'm not saying it's Boonville's salvation, but it does bring opportunity." 
The Midwest casino boom -- there are now 86 commercial casinos in six states and 87 American Indian operations -- is part of a broader diversification of the economy in a region long-dependent on dying industries that now increasingly relies on tourism and entertainment, not as supplemental extras but as necessary pillars. The strategy was validated this winter as mild weather and post-Sept. 11 fear of flying kept many vacationers close to home. Casino revenues here in Missouri were up 18 percent in February and 11 percent in March compared with last year, and two St. Louis casinos had their best months ever in February. 
As manufacturing and agriculture have sagged, rural areas and cities alike have turned to the service sector to create jobs and generate economic activity. Casinos, which locate where factories will not and succeed where malls and multiplexes cannot, have been among the most reliable engines of change, helping to spawn glossy new museums, reconstructed downtowns and a slew of cultural festivals that draw thousands to unlikely places. 
"It's not just casino and it's not just convention center and it's not just sports venue," said Don Phares, an economist at the University of Missouri-St. Louis who has studied gambling and tourism. "There's a critical mass when you get enough of these things that begins to set you apart. The whole is more than the sum of its parts." 
In Deadwood, S.D., which brought commercial casinos to the Midwest in 1989, there is a Mardi Gras extravaganza and five-day summer rodeo; the actor Kevin Costner, who runs a casino in town, plans a $110 million resort. 
A trio of casinos has helped bring Council Bluffs, Iowa, out of Omaha's shadow, with up to 10 million visitors a year flocking to the city of 58,000. 
Then there is the mini-Orlando thriving in the Quad Cities (Davenport and Bettendorf in Iowa, and Rock Island and Moline in Illinois) where modern riverboat gambling was born a decade ago. An IMAX theater just opened in Davenport, across the Mississippi River from the John Deere museum in Moline, which has logged one million guests since opening in 1997. A botanical center with meeting rooms was built on the river banks in Rock Island three years back, and there is talk of a new amphitheater, which the Davenport mayor wants to build in honor of Buffalo Bill Cody. 
Before casinos, the Quad Cities "was just a river stop on I-80 -- a lot of people would stop and say, 'Gee, is that the Mississippi River Mark Twain wrote about?' " said Bernie Goldstein, a a Bettendorf scrap-metal magnate who turned the first riverboat into the 14-casino Isle of Capri chain. 
"Now we are at the nucleus of a small recreation area," Mr. Goldstein said. 
Politicians and business leaders who turned to gambling during the last recession as a stopgap measure to save hard-hit communities and buffer state budgets have seen, through the recent downturn, that casinos have become a linchpin of the region's slow but steady economic shift. 
"We still have a notion in the economic development field that we can get home runs -- the reality is that economic development is happening in increments," said Geoff Hewings, a professor at the University of Illinois who runs the Regional Economics Applications Lab, a research organization based in Chicago. 
"As our region's economy has transformed itself to become almost as diversified as the nation as a whole, we're better off," Professor Hewings said. "The tourism industry is part of that diversification, and the casino industry is part of tourism." 
In the past decade, slot machines have become as common as smokestacks on the heartland horizon. Airports in Kansas City and St. Louis, Omaha and Detroit, beckon travelers with billboards hawking Las Vegas-style blackjack and buffets. Except for Deadwood, where nearly every storefront has a gambling license, the number of casinos in the region has jumped from 38 to 46 in the past four years, with three major outlets opening as part of an effort to revive downtown Detroit in 1999 and 2000. State and local governments facing deficits have grown addicted to gambling revenue. The region's casinos paid $1.8 billion in taxes last year, up 71 percent from 1998. With 56,000 workers in 2001, up 30 percent from 1998, the Midwest's commercial casinos have helped stabilize employment rates as factories close (Indian casinos would not provide comparable numbers). 
The Missouri Riverboat Gaming Association estimates that one in four of its workers is a former welfare recipient, and 16 percent came off the unemployment rolls. Buoyed by record revenues this winter, Missouri lawmakers tried to raise casino taxes and remove the state's loss limit -- unique in the nation -- which bars players from risking more than $500 every two hours. At the same time, the Kansas and Ohio Legislatures have bills pending to allow slot machines at racetracks, while Indiana may soon let gambling drift from boats to docks. 
Towns without casinos are on the verge of being at a disadvantage, said Steve Rittvo, president of the Innovation Group, a New Orleans consulting company that does feasibility studies for the industry. "I don't think conventions go to Kansas City because they have casinos now, but I think they might not go to Indianapolis because they don't have them." 
Though critics complain of increased rates of bankruptcy and crime in casino towns, economists have found solid benefits, particularly in the Midwest, where regulation protected markets against oversaturation. 
Boonville, a town without a movie theater, represents the industry's next frontier, with a casino in the state's center, rather than along its borders, and moored, not on the river, but in a large puddle filled from fire hydrants (state law no longer requires the "riverboats" to ever sail, and demands only that they be within 1,000 yards of the water, making it easier for the industry to operate). 
Despite the familiar din of slot machines swallowing coins, the $75 million casino here, like many in the Midwest, is not a vast show palace but a clubby place where dealers know players' names. The average loss per visit is $45, compared with $60 in bigger casinos. 
For every player like the wholesaler who drives 106 miles from Lebanon, Mo., a few times a week and has lost $30,000 since the casino opened, there is a local like Arlin Baker, the town's retired florist, who stops by on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons after hunting to pick up the free cookie offered to those over 50. 
"Twenty-five-dollar cookie," clarified Mr. Baker, 63, referring to his losses on a recent visit. 
The casino, which opened in December, has already bought this town of 8,202 about 100 miles east of Kansas City new streetlights and repaved roads, along with the long-sought Thespian Hall restoration. The mayor insists she will not use the projected tax revenue from the casinos, nearly a third of Boonville's $15 million annual budget, for operating expenditures, but will save it for dream projects, like new sewer lines and a community center. 
More telling is the economic activity not directly connected to the casino, in a town where Toastmaster, the small appliance maker, and Atchison Products, a small luggage manufacturer, closed plants last year. Now, a developer is planning to turn the abandoned shoe factory into apartments. The state is renovating the landmark Ballantine House as an office building. 
On Main Street, where there are several new awnings and "above the store" apartments are rented for the first time in years, Snapp's Hardware has sold three lawn mowers, totaling $10,000, to casino customers from out of town and dozens of appliances to the 70 Isle of Capri supervisors who were transferred here. 
The casino is the largest employer not just in Boonville, but in surrounding Cooper County, with jobs ranging from $7-an-hour housekeepers to $35,000-a-year pit bosses; almost everyone gets benefits. 
Dean Smith, 65, retired from the lumber business and earns $10 an hour as a slot attendant, paying jackpots like the $4,500 that Floyd Kronk won on the Triple Diamond Deluxe the other night. 
Robyn Watson, 40, sold her convenience store in nearby Jamestown, trading 16-hour days for a shift at the bar that she hopes will lead to travel when the company opens another casino. For health insurance and $100 a day, Denice Haile drives 75 minutes each way from Jefferson City to walk among the gambling tables offering cocktails. 
"I'm starting over and they're giving me this opportunity to be able to take care of myself," said Ms. Haile, who is newly divorced and has children ages 15, 6 and 4. 
About half the players come from Boonville and neighboring villages, but others travel on buses from Kansas City and St. Louis, favoring the small size and safety here to the busier casinos in their hometowns. This summer, the Isle hopes to fill its tables with vacationers from the Lake of the Ozarks, 67 miles away, and Branson, Mo., the theater and country music magnet that is building a convention center. 
As the sun falls, the senior citizens who sit tethered to the slot machines all day are replaced by students from the University of Missouri in Columbia, 27 miles away, and professionals from Jefferson City. After the bars close at 2 a.m., there is often a little influx. 
Renee Cosner, 39, a casino hostess, strolls the aisles, greeting gamblers, picking up trash and straightening stools. Nowadays, wherever she goes, people know where she is from. 
"When you're in here," said Ms. Cosner, a lifelong resident, "you don't feel like you're in Boonville."

HEADLINE: A Fierce Race Leaves Deep Bruises in Newark 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 19 

 BODY:
Whether saint or robber baron, Cory Booker and his high-octane but unsuccessful campaign against this city's four-term incumbent mayor, Sharpe James, has shaken Newark more than any single event since Kenneth Gibson became the first black mayor here 32 years ago. It has also left behind a wake of clashing sentiments: anger and disappointment for some, joy and relief for others.
 The race, which pitted Mr. James, a hard-nosed survivor of urban America's tumultuous past, against Mr. Booker, a privileged child of the integrated suburbs, unexpectedly exposed racial and cultural rifts in an increasingly diverse but stubbornly divided city, the state's largest. 
 For the legions of Booker believers -- some 47 percent of the electorate was willing to give him a shot -- Mayor James's campaign, backed by a formidable political machine, unfairly vilified a man who was poised to usher in an era of new ideas, energy and prosperity. "I feel like we've been set back," said Crystal Bayyane, 34, an unemployed executive assistant who said she voted last Tuesday for the first time in her life. "The whole city is going to suffer." 
But for the 53 percent of voters who delivered Mr. James to a record fifth term, the outcome vindicated a belief among many that Mr. Booker, 33, would have swept away a homegrown administration that, while imperfect, had at least earned the right to preside over Newark's long-awaited recovery. "We didn't struggle for so many years just to have some rich kid and his friends ride into town and take over City Hall," said Manfred Jackson, 71, a retired factory worker who bitterly recalled the years after the 1967 riots, when mass abandonment by the middle class gave way to decades of economic and social turmoil. "Where were they when the National Guard was shooting us down in the streets? Where were they when nobody wanted to step foot in Newark?"
Like many James supporters, Marcus Roper, 65, felt insulted by Mr. Booker's out-of-town donors, the visible contingent of white volunteers and the candidate's own storybook origins, which included an education at Stanford, Yale and Oxford and a childhood in affluent Bergen County. "He has no respect for us; he thinks we're stupid," Mr. Roper said, noting how Mr. Booker's campaign ads highlighted the city's shortcomings. "It's the Caucasian establishment saying a Rhodes scholar is better than our Sharpe James."
The mayor, 66, deftly turned his opponent's origins into a liability. His campaign punch line, "The Real Deal," suggested that Mr. Booker was somehow inauthentic, a theme that was expanded in speeches and in literature, and through strategists and allies. Mr. James continually questioned his rival's Democratic credentials, citing past associations with Republican officials and a talk he once gave at a conservative policy institute. At one event, the mayor mocked Mr. Booker for not being black enough.
Ronald Lester, a pollster for the James campaign, described the election not as a struggle between races or generations but as a war between "outsider and insider interests." Mr. Lester, who has worked for the biggest names in the Democratic Party, including Gov. James E. McGreevey and Bill Clinton, said he believed Mr. Booker and his supporters were not enlightened do-gooders but carpetbaggers eager to seize a city ripe with unrealized potential. "The land in Newark is so valuable because of where it sits, at the nexus of transportation routes and so close to Manhattan," he said. "It's not only valuable property, but it's pivotal in statewide politics."
While Mr. Booker's supporters brushed off such sentiments as paranoia, those ideas found fertile ground in a community long distrustful of outsiders. Even voters who were drawn to the Booker campaign's central message, "It's time for a change," expressed unease with his Ivy League associates and the fact that he arrived here only six years ago. 
Some refused to believe that Mr. Booker's intentions were as benevolent as he claimed. Zykeeya Barnes, 23, who like nearly one out of 10 Newark residents is unemployed, said she took a risk and voted for Mr. Booker despite warnings from friends and family members. "They said he was going to move all the black people out and move all the whites in, that he was going to close down the public schools," Ms. Barnes said, standing in front of Brick Towers, the troubled housing complex where Mr. Booker also lives. "But I just decided he deserved a chance."
In the final analysis, familiarity and loyalty were powerful factors in Tuesday's outcome. While Newark, with 274,000 residents, may look like a big city, it often behaves like a small town. Anyone with any longevity can name someone who went to high school with Mr. James and nearly everyone knows someone who works in City Hall. In a place where jobs are hard to come by, devotion to Mr. James, who is the single biggest employer of local residents, is often seen as a matter of survival. 
Sam Brown Jr., 47, a custodian at a private school, had a simple answer for why he pulled the lever for Mr. James last week. The mayor, he said, had helped his wife get a janitorial job with the Board of Education. "Let's put it this way," he said. "If I didn't vote for him, I'd be sleeping on the couch tonight."
Many city employees said they were told they would lose their jobs under a Booker administration. Others said they were just frightened of change. Dan O'Flaherty, an economics professor at Columbia University and a Newark native who has been involved in local politics since the 1950's, said residents here have always been wary of change. "When you go to City Hall with a problem, you want to know there's someone there who went to school with your mother's cousin," he said. "The last thing you want is an outsider like Cory to bring in his own people."
Such reasoning is cold comfort to Mr. Booker's supporters, who feel that fear, ignorance and petty self-interest doomed his candidacy. Like many of those who voted for Mr. Booker, Louis Fernandes said it was the first time he and his friends had been excited about local politics. "Put it this way, I'm 31 and I've only known two mayors my whole life," said Mr. Fernandes, who lives in the East Ward, a largely Portuguese and Brazilian neighborhood that has always been aloof from City Hall. "We didn't care where he was from," said Mr. Fernandes, a pilot for Continental Airlines. "We just wanted a change."
Americo Seabra, 42, whose family owns restaurants and produce markets in the city, was one of the few prominent business leaders to back Mr. Booker openly. He said he was especially troubled by the well-orchestrated effort to turn Mr. Booker's background into a negative. "Here's someone who bettered himself and who came back to give," he said. "It's very upsetting that he was penalized for that." 
Then there was the notion that Mr. Booker, whose political promise was frequently touted by the news media, was using Newark to better his own career. To Ms. Bayyane, that argument was irrational. "What people fail to realize is if Cory wanted to go to higher office, he had to do good here," she said. "We would have benefited from his ambition. With his education and resume, he could have gone anywhere."
Even though Mr. James has said this will be his final term and Mr. Booker has vowed to run again in 2006, some wonder whether the campaign, with its attacks on Mr. Booker's authenticity, might deter an emerging generation of black leaders raised outside impoverished cities. Walter Fields, the former director of the N.A.A.C.P. in New Jersey, worries that Mr. Booker's defeat might chill the ardor of young black professionals who have been increasingly drawn to down-and-out cities. "If you want places like Newark to grow, you want the Cory Bookers of the world to become an active part of the city," he said. "To have black elected officials question his legitimacy, to have him penalized for his own success, that's the tragedy of this election."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
A Tough Sale for WorldCom in Latin America

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
WorldCom, short on cash and intent on selling some of its international assets, could have trouble finding buyers because of problems at the company and in the industry, some analysts say.
 Most of the attention has been focused on two WorldCom units in Latin America: Embratel, a Brazilian long-distance carrier, and Avantel, a Mexican telecommunications company that competes with Telefonos de Mexico and AT&T's Alestra unit. WorldCom is also said to be considering selling United States assets that include wireless reselling operations and wireless spectrum properties. 
 "WorldCom indicated that these assets were worth approximately $2 billion," a Merrill Lynch analyst, Adam Quinton, said in a report. "This seems far too high to us." 
The effort to sell the foreign assets is a radical departure from the previous strategy of WorldCom, the United States' second-largest long- distance company, after AT&T, to strengthen its international businesses. WorldCom has an extensive set of foreign holdings, which include Internet backbone and data transmission assets. Just last year, WorldCom consolidated its entire Latin American activities into a single entity, WorldCom Latin America, with operations across the region. But that was before WorldCom's financial crisis. The company needs about $5 billion of new financing to honor its obligations with creditors.
In addition to Embratel in Brazil and Avantel in Mexico, WorldCom has operations in 11 other Latin American countries and Puerto Rico. Other assets in the region include Star One, a venture with the Societe Europeenne des Satellites that provides fast satellite Internet access; SkyTel, a paging company; and Proceda, an information-technology outsourcing company.
Embratel, which WorldCom's MCI unit acquired for $2.3 billion in the privatization of Brazil's telecommunications system in 1997, was once the jewel of WorldCom's international properties. But like other long-distance carriers around the world, Embratel has suffered from a decline in revenue as competitors gnawed at its once monopolistic domination of the market.
In the most recent quarter, Embratel's international long-distance revenue declined 22 percent from the period a year earlier because of price cuts and a sharp drop in calling between Argentina, which is mired in an economic crisis, and Brazil. The company lost $16 million in the quarter, or 5 cents a share.
WorldCom's controlling stake in Embratel is now estimated to be worth only $200 million to $300 million, according to analysts, in light of the Brazilian company's stock plunge of 60 percent the last year. But WorldCom would be fortunate to get even that amount for transferring control of Embratel to another company, said Tucker Grinnan, director of Latin American telecommunications research at Deutsche Bank.
For one thing, Brazilian regulations designed to avert the concentration of power in telecommunications among a few companies prevent WorldCom from selling its stake in Embratel until next year. So any deal would probably have to wait until mid-2003, or long after WorldCom's most pressing cash requirements need to be resolved.
Only three companies with large local telephone operations in Brazil -- Telefonica of Spain, Telemar Norte Leste and Brasil Telecom -- are thought to be interested in buying Embratel. Of those three, Telemar, because of a relatively high debt burden, and Brasil Telecom, which has shown interest in acquiring Intelig, an Embratel competitor, are thought to be out of the running.
That could leave Telefonica with the upper hand in negotiating a deal with WorldCom.
"Embratel is basically doomed in its current form," said Mr. Grinnan, the analyst at Deutsche Bank.
WorldCom, of course, may have already come to the same conclusion. Last year, the company maneuvered to remove Embratel from its financial results by transferring the rights to dividends and distributions of some of its Embratel stock to a Brazilian nonprofit educational institution called Institute Embratel 21.
Also uncertain are prospects for WorldCom's selling its stake in Avantel. WorldCom owns the Mexican long-distance carrier together with Citigroup, which inherited a controlling stake in Avantel after acquiring Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival last year.
WorldCom denied reports in Mexico earlier this month that it was planning to sell Citigroup its stake in Avantel, which like Embratel also loses money. Another possibility, analysts said, is a merger of Avantel with its financially troubled competitor, Alestra.
But it is not clear how the companies would fare either as a merged entity or separately against their larger rival, Telefonos de Mexico. WorldCom has declined to provide details on exactly how it plans to go about shedding some of its international businesses.
"WorldCom management is continuing its review of our entire business, which obviously includes our investments in Latin America," said Bradford Burns, a spokesman. "It would be premature for us to speculate on what conclusions will be reached once the review is complete."

HEADLINE: A Quiet Attack on Women 

BYLINE:  By Elizabeth Warren; Elizabeth Warren is a professor at Harvard Law School.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Women's rights are suddenly at the center of the Congressional debate over the nation's bankruptcy laws -- but only in the most cynical and opportunistic way. After five years of enormous contributions and lobbying from the financial industry, Congress now stands ready to dismantle protection for families under the nation's bankruptcy code. Diverting attention from the harm rewriting the law would do to women, members of Congress have managed to turn an argument about financial affairs into a debate over abortion.
 Congressional negotiators are scheduled to meet Wednesday to see if they can reach a compromise on a bill that would make it harder for individuals to file for bankruptcy. At issue is a provision, included in the Senate's version but not in that of the House, that would prevent abortion opponents from declaring bankruptcy in order to avoid paying court fines and damages. If the negotiators can agree on a bill, President Bush is likely to sign it. 
 Banking and credit lobbyists have been trying to change the bankruptcy laws for years. The current bill was stuck in conference between the Senate and House until Senator Joseph Biden of Delaware -- where many banks and credit-card issuers are incorporated -- agreed to vote with Republicans on almost all the issues that were holding up the bill. But Mr. Biden also told his Democratic colleagues that he would support an amendment to stop abortion protesters from using bankruptcy protection to avoid damages they might otherwise have to pay for violating federal law in violent clinic protests.
Regardless of one's views of the amendment, the bill itself is unconscionable. If it becomes law, the economic effects on more than 1.2 million women each year will be devastating. Apparently many politicians believe they can remove the last safety net for families facing financial disaster (many of which are led by women) so long as they can find another highly visible issue that lets them proclaim their support for women.
In the past 20 years, bankruptcy filings for female-headed households have increased at more than double the rate of bankruptcies for comparable households with an adult male present. (Families with children are more economically vulnerable than those without, and since women keep the children more often in the case of divorce, more women are filing for bankruptcy.) Women -- married, divorced, widowed and single -- now outnumber men seeking bankruptcy protection by more than 300,000 a year. The more than one million women filing for bankruptcy protection this year will bring nearly two million children into bankruptcy court with them.
Most of these women will be in bankruptcy court for reasons beyond their control. More than 90 percent of women who file for bankruptcy have been hit by some combination of unemployment, medical bills and divorce. Women are more likely than men to seek bankruptcy in the aftermath of a divorce or a medical problem, though both men and women cite job problems as the biggest difficulty.
At the same time, 200,000 women will find themselves in bankruptcy court not as debtors but as creditors -- trying to collect alimony or child support from their ex-husbands. Traditionally, alimony and child support are nondischargeable, which means these debts must be repaid even if the ex-husband files for bankruptcy, because women and children, unlike commercial creditors who can choose their debtors, cannot charge their husbands or fathers a premium for being bad credit risks. 
Yet in the pending legislation, credit-card companies and car lenders have devised a number of ways to ensure that more of their debt, including interest and penalties, is made similarly sacrosanct and payable forever. This puts divorced women in direct competition with credit-card companies for some of an ex-husband's limited income.
Some 30 women's groups, from the National Organization for Women to Hadassah to the Y.W.C.A., have announced their opposition to this bill. Do politicians like Mr. Biden who support the bankruptcy bill believe they can give credit-card companies the right to elbow out women and children so long as they rally behind an issue like abortion? The message is unmistakable: On an economic issue that attracts millions of dollars of industry support, women have no real political importance.
Wednesday's meeting of the House-Senate conference is the final showdown. Will the credit industry's bankruptcy bill pass the conference? Or will it stall over the issue of abortion? If Senator Charles Schumer, who wrote the abortion provision in the Senate bill, holds his ground, he will do a great service to the women who have fought hard for their rights to access to abortion clinics. But if the amendment prevents the bill's passage, he will do an even greater service to hundreds of thousands of women trying to collect child support and to millions more who are trying to survive after financial disaster.
These women are not fighting a pro-life or pro-choice battle. They are just fighting to make it to the next payday.

HEADLINE: Taking the Russia Summit a Step Further 

BYLINE:  By Michael McFaul; Michael McFaul is a Hoover Institution fellow and professor of political science at Stanford University.

 BODY:
President Bush is poised to have a terrific trip on his first visit to Russia. He will sign an agreement with President Vladimir Putin that will eliminate thousands of nuclear weapons. He and Mr. Putin will celebrate a new, closer relationship between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Russia, paving the way for an uneventful expansion of the alliance this fall. Mr. Bush will proclaim Russia a market economy and urge Russian integration into the West. Finally, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin will make joint statements about their shared commitment to the war on terrorism. 
 The summit will be only a partial success, however, if Bush fails to push for greater democracy. Soviet, then Russian, democratization was indispensable in preparing all the achievements of the upcoming summit. Autocratic Russia opposed NATO, resisted arms control and suppressed markets. Democratic Russia has sought to join the West and cooperate with the United States. A return to dictatorship in Russia would quickly undermine all of these achievements. 
 Unfortunately, the trend in Russia is going away from democracy. Most worrying has been Mr. Putin's disregard for human rights in Chechnya. Russia must defend its borders and respond to terrorist acts, such as the attack, said to have been by Islamic fundamentalists, in Dagestan earlier this month. The conduct of the Russian armed forces and units of the Ministry of the Interior in Chechnya, however, does not serve these purposes. Russian tactics in Chechnya have been routinely inhumane, especially against civilians. These methods have inspired more fanaticism within Chechnya and made Russia less secure.
Mr. Putin also has silenced many of his critics. He and his surrogates have gone on the offensive against critical independent media outlets, seizing control of NTV -- the country's only national opposition network -- and threatening others. Through new laws and registration procedures, Mr. Putin's government has also limited the freedoms and powers of independent trade unions, political parties and nongovernmental organizations like the Glasnost Defense Foundation, the Socio-Ecological Union and the Russo-Chechen Friendship Society. The state security service has stepped up harassment of investigative journalists, human rights activists, environmental leaders and academics.
Mr. Putin has even weakened alternative power centers within the state. His so-called reform of the upper house of parliament, the Federation Council, has gravely weakened this once important check on presidential power. Most disturbing, as demonstrated by the recent election in Ingushetia, the Russian federal government has begun to manipulate elections by disqualifying front-running candidates deemed unacceptable. Even Mr. Putin's generally positive legal reforms are tainted by the selective application of the law for political purposes. 
In isolation, any one of the anti-democratic trends might not be cause for alarm. Taken as a whole, they cannot be ignored.
W hy should Mr. Bush or the American people care? First, the obvious: Democracy is a good system of government and one desired by Russians. In nationwide polls in 2000, 60 percent of respondents believed democracy was a very good or fairly good system of government for Russia, while only 24 percent portrayed it as fairly bad or very bad. Eighty-seven percent of Russians think it important to elect the country's leaders. Most Russians are not willing to take the trade of more order for less freedom. Nearly 80 percent believe the military should not rule Russia. 
Second, dictatorship is unlikely to help the economy. Russia needs a more effective state to sustain markets. There is no reason to assume, however, that an autocratic regime in Russia would be an effective state. Russia's last autocratic regime -- the Soviet Union -- produced neither an efficient state nor economic growth. In the post-communist world, the correlation between democracy and economic growth is robust. 
Third, an autocratic Russia will eventually threaten the United States. Such a Russia would depend on the military, the intelligence services and military industries to stay in power. Many in these sectors distrust the United States and seek to reassert Russian influence in Georgia, Ukraine and Central Asia; to sell nuclear technologies to Iran; and to increase weapon sales to Iraq. The negative impact of an antidemocratic Russia on American security interests would be direct. 
On his visit to Moscow, Mr. Bush must speak the truth about Russia's democratic backsliding. He needs particularly to speak about Chechnya, acknowledging that terrorists there must be stopped but emphasizing that not all Chechens are terrorists and the only road to peace and security in the Caucasus is political, not military. Second, if Mr. Bush truly values his relationship with Mr. Putin, then he should speak candidly about the democratic criteria for genuine partnership between our nations. Third, he must make a special effort to meet with those in Russia fighting for democracy and human rights.
Mr. Putin is not a dictator, and he wants Russia to become a thriving capitalist economy fully integrated into the West. Rhetorically, he also has championed democracy. This is why Mr. Bush's message in Moscow could have a significant impact. By emphasizing democratization, he could impress on Mr. Putin the urgency of moving in the right direction now.

HEADLINE: Impoverished East Timor Exults Over Independence 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: DILI, East Timor, Monday, May 20 

 BODY:
East Timor became the world's newest nation today, a miniature Pacific Ocean country born of centuries of colonization by the Portuguese, decades of occupation by Indonesia and nearly three years of United Nations governance, which ended at midnight Sunday.
 During an emotional ceremony in a dusty field attended by many thousands of people, the new leaders of this nation of 800,000 and an array of international figures, the national flag was carried into the arena by former guerrilla fighters who led the war of resistance against Indonesia. 
 The Indonesian president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, looked on stoically as East Timor's first president, Jose Alexandre Gusmao, who is known as Xanana and who was imprisoned by Indonesia for seven years, exhorted his impoverished citizens to make the best of their hard-won freedom.
"We gained our independence to improve our lives," said Mr. Gusmao, who addressed the crowd from an outdoor platform rigged from bamboo poles. "I remind everyone, especially the leaders: discipline to affirm our power, tolerance to affirm democracy, reconciliation to affirm unity." 
The presence of Mrs. Megawati, who had opposed East Timor's referendum for independence in 1999, was welcomed as a gesture of reconciliation. Mr. Gusmao accompanied her onto the platform, then clasped her hand, holding it aloft with his in a victory wave to the crowd. He diplomatically said that the "difficult relations" between Indonesia and East Timor belonged to history. 
In a passing moment of bitterness, the arrival of four Indonesian warships with her motorcade and more than 100 security guards for her short visit was described by the East Timorese as an excessive show of force.
Former President Clinton, who urged the United Nations to send a peacekeeping force to East Timor after the Indonesian Army backed rampaging militia members in September 1999, led the United States' delegation.
In a referendum organized by the United Nations on Aug. 13, 1999, 78 percent of the voters chose independence. The result, which Indonesia had not fully expected, was followed by the destruction of Dili, the seaside capital, and other areas by the pro-Indonesia militia as Indonesian soldiers who had been occupying East Timor either participated or looked on. By United Nations estimate, about a thousand people were killed during the violence.
Indonesia invaded East Timor in December 1975 after it was abandoned by Portugal, its colonial ruler, and annexed the territory. The occupation was particularly brutal. By 1979, the Indonesian government acknowledged, 120,000 people had been killed or died of disease.
East Timor will join the ranks of the world's poorest countries. The sandalwood that first attracted the Portuguese ran out years ago, and the coffee that used to fetch high prices faces stiff competition in the current market glut. In Dili, many people earn less than 55 cents a day.
The scars of neglect and the violent departure of Indonesian forces were still evident on this day of celebration. As tens of thousands of elaborately dressed people flocked to the midnight ceremony in the backs of trucks and on foot, they passed the burned hulks of buildings. But there were also signs of the United-Nations-fostered rebirth, with fresh white paint daubed on a few new hotels.
East Timor's economic future depends on offshore natural gas deposits. After contentious negotiations, the new government is set to sign a treaty today with Australia. Under the treaty, East Timor will receive 90 percent of the revenues from the deposits and Australia 10 percent.
But the revenue streams will not start for another three years, leaving East Timor with tremendous shortfalls as it embarks on an independent existence. When benefits from the gas do flow, there will be the potential for East Timor to become perhaps as comfortable as the richest regions of Indonesia. 
But the country will need international aid for years. Its choice of language, currency and telephone codes reflects the unusual degree of dependence on the outside world.
The official language is Portuguese, chosen by Mr. Gusmao in deference to Portugal's long stay in East Timor, even though only an estimated 5 percent of the people, most of them older, speak Portuguese. Many speak Indonesian, the language of the occupation. The local language is Tetum.
The official currency is the American dollar. The Australian telephone company, Telstra, runs the East Timor system.
A recent report by the United Nations Development Program described a country in deep poverty. Life expectancy is 57 years. Preventable diseases like malaria, respiratory tract infections and diarrhea are major killers. Maternal mortality is high, with 420 deaths for every 100,000 live births. Only 37 percent of people over age 15 in rural areas can read and write.
Because of these deficiencies, "The United Nations will stay," said Kofi Annan, the secretary general, in a short speech just before the United Nations flag was lowered Sunday night. "Your friends around the world will continue to help." 
The United Nations peacekeeping force, now numbering about 5,000 soldiers -- chiefly from Australia, Portugal, Japan and New Zealand -- will be phased out over 18 months to two years, Mr. Annan said. This will allow the fledgling East Timor Defense Force, currently consisting of 600 soldiers from the Falintil guerrilla movement, to grow. 
"I cannot emphasize enough that material and financial support for the full establishment of East Timor's police and military are essential and require urgent action," Mr. Annan said in a recent report to the Security Council.
At an international conference last week, donors pledged $360 million in development assistance over three years. Mr. Annan said the country's civilian needs are as big as its military ones. He said there was a desperate need for trained judges. 
Despite the difficulties ahead, the East Timorese were in high spirits on Sunday night. A fireworks display donated by the Thai and Chinese governments was a big hit. People from all the districts in the hinterland, some wearing feathered headgear and bearing swords, performed in a show produced by Australian public event specialists.
The day began with an outdoor Roman Catholic Mass offered by Bishop Carlo Belo, who together with the foreign minister, Jose Ramos-Horta, won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1996. 
"People are ready, they have been waiting for this moment," said Hugo M. Fernandes, the 30-year-old chief editor of Talitakum, a new weekly magazine. Respect for the past and an eye to the future was uppermost in everyone's mind, he said. "I think all 800,000 people will dedicate themselves to those who were killed or died during the struggle, not only for the 24 years of the Indonesians but the whole 500 years. Today is a commemoration for the very long story of East Timor."

HEADLINE: In Czar Peter's Capital, Putin Is Not as Great 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, May 19 

 BODY:
In the Kremlin office of President Vladimir V. Putin hangs a portrait of the founder of this glorious, if faded, city, Mr. Putin's hometown and the object of his fierce pride.
 The founder, Peter the Great, was Russia's first imperial czar. But more than that, he was Russia's great Westernizer, the ruler who scoured Europe for the best of its culture and science, then made it Russia's own. 
 President Bush heads to Moscow this week for his first summit meeting there, one that his advisers call a historic start to Russia's integration with the West. Then Mr. Putin will bring Mr. Bush here for a weekend coda amid the faux-Venetian canals and sprawling palaces that Peter erected three centuries ago. 
The temptation to draw PeterPutin parallels is irresistible.
It is also baloney, says Lev Luriye, the dry, urbane columnist for the St. Petersburg newspaper Kommersant. "He's not a hero -- he's a functionary," Mr. Luriye said last week of Mr. Putin, between drags on a cigarette in one of the city's sophisticated bars. "His personal liberty is very limited. He has to do what he has to do."
Mr. Luriye is not knocking a native son. By breeding and experience, Mr. Putin may be the most Westernized leader in Russian history. And since Sept. 11, when Mr. Putin was the first world leader to offer President Bush sympathy and support, his desire to lash Russia's fortunes to Europe's has seemed unassailably clear.
But to Mr. Luriye and many others the story of this meeting is not Russia's romance with the West. It is the shotgun nature of the courtship.
Past summit meetings proceeded on the notion that the United States and Russia were equals, if only by virtue of their mutual ability to destroy the planet. This meeting strips away that fiction. The agenda for the talks, which are to begin on Thursday, is overwhelmingly an American one, not because Russia completely agrees with it, but because in Mr. Putin's shrewd judgment, it cannot afford not to.
The list includes nuclear arms cuts negotiated on American terms and an agreement to cooperate on a missile defense shield that the Russians have condemned. It contains a pledge to curb the spread of weapons of mass destruction to some countries, like Iran, where the White House has stated that Russia is part of the proliferation problem.
The American view, as espoused this month by one senior Bush administration diplomat, is that the summit meeting "really puts the Russian-U.S. relationship on a firm course of long-term partnership, even a long-term alliance."
"This could very well be the last summit whose success is measured by the achievement in arms-control agreements," the diplomat said. "Arms control will no longer be the be-all and end-all of these high-level meetings. This will shift to new security challenges, and increasingly to economic and political issues where our relationship is more and more based on cooperation."
Russian experts see the summit meeting through a different lens.
"For five centuries Russia never paid tribute to anybody," Anatoly I. Utkin, a foreign policy expert at the Institute for U.S.A.-Canada Studies in Moscow, said in an interview. "Now for the first time we became a minor partner. You are boss; we are partner. I would never have said it before September of last year."
Officially neither side would describe the state of the relationship so baldly. Russians are proud of their long history as a first-tier global power. To make it government policy that those days are over would be not only politically incorrect, but politically risky for Mr. Putin.
For their part, American officials are not trying to spare Russian sensibilities. A Washington elite schooled in the notion of a superpower rivalry is only now coming to grips with the idea that Russia has abandoned the cold war playing field. The same is true for most Americans over the age of 35.
But in the ranks of American academics who grind out the papers that shape White House policy, the view of 21st-century Russia is bleak and pitiless.
"There is nothing inevitable about Russia's comeback," Eugene B. Rumer, a senior fellow at the National Defense University's Institute for National Strategic Studies, wrote last year as part of a roundup of policy advice for the new Bush administration. "It will not bounce back from its troubles anytime soon. Its current decline may well continue indefinitely.
"The United States has to deal with a weak and retreating Russia whose residual international ambitions will usually exceed its capabilities and whose principal near-term challenge will be downsizing in a predictable, responsible manner."
That is an almost perfect precis of the White House approach to the talks this week, and to Mr. Putin's management of foreign policy.
After a decade of drift, the Kremlin has moved to slash the military, close needless bases in Cuba and Vietnam, and focus Russian interests on economic cooperation with Europe and the United States. 
In Moscow Mr. Putin will agree with Mr. Bush to pare some 4,000 warheads from a nuclear force that Russia cannot afford and has no need to maintain anyway.
Peter the Great explored Europe as the leader of a vigorous and expanding Russia. Mr. Putin seeks to anchor Russia in the West at what may be his nation's weakest period in three centuries, when its borders have shrunk to those of the 1700's and when it is surrounded by economic and military giants: China, Japan and a unifying Europe.
His policy has its risks. "There are real criticisms of Putin's policies at home," said Dmitri Trenin, a foreign policy expert at the Moscow Center of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "But I think there's a recognition, not only in Putin's mind but in the minds of others, that there is now an essential asymmetry in the relationship, and you have to be realistic about it."
But no one should labor under the illusion that Mr. Putin views himself as the orderly steward of Russia's imperial decline. Mr. Putin is, after all, a Petersburger. 
St. Petersburg has seethed with frustration for 85 years now, since Lenin's Bolsheviks stormed the Winter Palace, seized control of government and unceremoniously moved the empire's capital to Moscow.
Whatever the Russian government's public posture, Mr. Putin and his subjects are seething over their country's new second-city status and are itching to recover lost glory.
A glance at St. Petersburg underscores that. Peter's imperial capital, founded 299 years ago on a frozen swamp near the Gulf of Finland, lost a million residents to disease and starvation during the Nazi siege in World War II. Its Soviet masters later left it to rot.
Mr. Putin has embraced this decrepit but unspoiled museum piece and its 4.8 million residents and now seems determined to turn it into a northern Paris or Venice. From Tony Blair to Gerhard Schroder and now George Bush, world leaders have been swept out of Moscow to the former Leningrad for entertainment.
Early in Mr. Putin's tenure, grandoise plans were floated to move Parliament here. That seems to have foundered, but talk is rampant that the Central Bank will relocate. And St. Petersburg has become Russia's chosen forum for international conferences, diplomatic spectaculars and global events, like the world hockey championships in 2000.
Word has it that Mr. Putin wants a resurrected St. Petersburg to serve once again as Russia's window on Europe, the engine of its integration into Western culture.
Mr. Luriye, the columnist, applauds Mr. Putin's vision but says his timing is off: Mr. Putin may think Russia is ready for the West, he says, but the democracy he is pursuing may not yet agree.
"It's like chess," he said. "We have to make this move now, because we have nothing else. But the real decision won't be made by Putin but by the average man in the street -- or by his son."

MEETINGS FROM MOSCOW TO ST. PETERSBURG
Highlights of the Putin-Bush Summit Talks This Week

NUCLEAR ARMS -- President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin are to sign a treaty to winnow their nuclear arsenals by two-thirds in the next decade, from about 6,000 warheads each, to between 1,700 and 2,200. An important American provision, unsuccessfully contested by Russia, allows either side to store inactive nuclear warheads, which could be quickly remounted on launchers in case of a global crisis.

MISSILE DEFENSES -- The presidents are expected to agree to cooperate on developing a defense against ballistic missiles. That is a direct result of Washington's decision in December, much criticized by Russians and Europeans, to withdraw from the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

LONG-TERM COOPERATION -- The men are to lay out a "strategic framework" for efforts to curb weapons proliferation and international terrorism and to address political instability in key regions. The document will also address closer economic relations and cultural exchanges.

OTHER FACETS -- More details are expected on cooperation in energy development and counter-terrorism. After the Moscow talks, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin are to meet with university students and visit religious sites in St. Petersburg before Mr. Bush departs for France, the next leg of his tour.

HEADLINE: Arts Groups In New York Brace for Cuts In City Funds 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
When representatives of many of the large city-supported cultural institutions gathered for a news conference on Thursday to protest Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed budget cuts, the speeches seemed more dutiful than fiery, and the auditorium at El Museo del Barrio was practically empty. 
 Only James A. Lebenthal, the municipal bond magnate who serves on the board of the Museum of the City of New York, managed to muster some passion in warning the 10 or so people in attendance, "You take away any part of the cultural life of this city and you strike at the very heart of what all public investment is supposed to do, and that is improve the quality of life." 
 Perhaps the city's cultural groups are finding it tough to get all worked up for a fight they seem largely resigned to losing, or maybe they are hoping to be rescued, at least to some extent, by the City Council, as they have been in past years. 
Typically this is the season of the dance in which the mayor cuts the cultural budget, and the City Council restores the funds. The budget is to be adopted June 5 and to take effect July 1. But with the city facing a deficit of nearly $5 billion and an almost entirely new roster of Council members learning the ropes of budget negotiations, this year may well be different. 
"We don't know if we're going to be able to do it the way we have in years past because we're facing such a shortfall," said Jose Serrano, a freshman councilman who heads the committee on culture and libraries.
In his preliminary budget, Mayor Bloomberg proposed cuts of $19.1 million to the Cultural Affairs Department. This breaks down to reductions of about 18 percent to the 34 members of the Cultural Institutions Group, institutions whose buildings or land is owned in part or whole by the city, and about 13 percent to the more than 500 institutions that are considered program groups. The Cultural Institutions Group includes the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Studio Museum in Harlem; among the program groups are the Museum of Modern Art, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater and the Queens Historical Society.
Mayor Bloomberg has asked the Cultural Affairs Department staff to cut its capital budget by $263 million over the next five years, down from the current $862 million. Over his eight years in office, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spent $487.7 million on capital cultural projects.
Everybody knows there is less money to go around. As the economy was turning down, the events of Sept. 11 drastically escalated the slump, and every city agency expects to be in for severe sacrifices. Mayor Bloomberg has proposed contingency cuts of $63 million from the Police Department, nearly $17 million from libraries and $10 million from the Sanitation Department.
"I'm having difficulty figuring out how the Council is going to restore funds to any constituency unless the question of revenues is resolved," said Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, a citywide advocacy group.
During most of his eight years in office, Mayor Giuliani proposed cuts for the members of the Cultural Institutions Group, but these cuts were restored by the Council in an almost ritualistic way that Mr. Giuliani foresaw and participated in. But Kate D. Levin, the city's commissioner of cultural affairs, said that given the severe projected budget shortfall, Mayor Bloomberg's budget proposal was real, not a starting point.
"We devised the cuts with the charge: If the music stops here, what would be the best way to allocate funding knowing we're facing a horrible fiscal crisis, and what can we do to help culturals sustain themselves in a very difficult period?" she said.
Mr. Bloomberg's would not be the first city administration to argue at the outset that there was no room for horse trading and then have to negotiate with the State Legislature. The City Council has already called for maximum cuts of only 2 percent, compared to Mr. Bloomberg's double-digit proposal. 
The mayor's proposed cuts "will severely impact the ability of cultural groups to provide services that are essential to who we are as a city," said Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council.
But the 2 percent cuts are dependent on tax revenues that are highly unlikely, budget experts say: City Council proposals to reinstate the commuter tax and impose a personal income tax surcharge. Mayor Bloomberg has said he would veto any budget that included tax increases, for fear they would drive New Yorkers out of the city, and a commuter tax would also have to go through the Legislature, where it is thought to be a virtual nonstarter. 
Meanwhile many cultural organizations are struggling with lower ticket sales because of the dramatic drop in tourists and reduced contributions from foundations, corporations and individuals. Many have cut staff, reduced programming or postponed construction plans.
David E. McKinney, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said that attendance was still down 30 percent from last year, having dropped by 60 percent right after Sept. 11, largely because of the reduction of tourists from the West Coast, Europe and Japan. In the fiscal year 2001 the museum had 5 million visitors; attendance is expected to be down to 3.9 million for the fiscal year 2002, which ends in June. 
"It's a severe impact," Mr. McKinney said. "And we're expecting that to continue."
How much money will be available to the City Council after it negotiates with the mayor is one great unknown. Another is which services will be most successful in competing for whatever funds remain. Rather than proposing across-the-board cuts, the Cultural Affairs Department for the first time this year cut some organizations more than others, depending on their size and strength, Ms. Levin said. "The mayor wanted us to give particular consideration to the groups having the hardest time financially," she added.
At Thursday's news conference, officials of El Museo del Barrio said the proposed cuts would force their museum to lay off one-quarter of its guards, shut down its permanent Caribbean exhibition and close the institution one day a week.
Arts executives like Lowery Stokes Sims, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, and Donna Walker-Kuhne, the director of community outreach and education initiatives at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, said the cuts are likely to hurt their education programs most. 
The city's cultural groups are stressing their importance to the economy of the city. They point out that the member organizations of the Cultural Institutions Group employ 11,000 people and last year brought 19 million visitors into their buildings. For every dollar the city spends on the arts, it collects $2 in tax receipts, said a study by the Alliance for the Arts, an advocacy group. 
Councilman Serrano said, "Cultural institutions are a core service for New York City because they are a fiscal engine." 
Ms. Levin said Mr. Bloomberg understood that. "The mayor values what the cultural sector does for New York very highly," she said. "The problem is, you can't wish away a $5 billion deficit."

HEADLINE: Bush Faces Pressure From Congress to Alter Cuba Policy 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19 

 BODY:
As President Bush heads to Miami on Monday to lay out tougher restrictions on travel to Cuba and lend support for government opponents there, a growing number of lawmakers from both parties are visiting the island on their own and demanding that the United States open it up to tourism and trade.
 Mr. Bush is personally and politically committed to a hard-line policy toward Cuba. In his speech on Monday, he will condition any easing of this policy on Cuba's adoption of democratic reforms, such as freeing all political prisoners and giving opposition parties the freedom to organize and speak. 
 In excerpts released by the White House on Sunday night, Mr. Bush laid out specific conditions that also included allowing outside observers to monitor the 2003 assembly elections and giving human rights organizations access to the country.
His appearance at a lavish fund-raiser of Cuban-Americans who support continued pressure against Havana will be a reminder of this group's pivotal role in the president's victory in 2000, and a vivid example of where domestic politics and foreign policy intersect.
But after decades in which the forces for isolating Cuba have dominated the policy, a new crop of lawmakers have demanded change. Advocates say that a majority in the House and Senate favor lifting the travel ban, but that the House Republican leadership has stymied any action. Farm groups, with substantial Republican support in Congress, are the most important growing organized constituency pressing to open lucrative overseas markets to American agriculture.
"For the first time, we have a debate on this when there may be a real balance of forces," said Lisandro Perez, a sociologist at Florida International University and a critic of the current American policy.
On Capitol Hill, Cuba is no longer a partisan issue with Republicans generally urging strict measures and Democrats advocating an end to them. Now, Midwestern Republicans have joined Northeastern Democrats to challenge the sanctions on trade and travel, and to call for a new approach in dealing with Havana.
"I'm with the president 95 percent of the time, but not on this one," said Representative Tom Osborne, a Nebraska Republican and former University of Nebraska football coach. "After 40 years, let's not just keep running up the middle. Let's throw a pass. Let's try something different."
But hard-liners say loosening the pressure now would be a mistake. Jaime Suchlicki, the director of the Institute for Cuban and Cuban American Studies at the University of Miami, said that a cash infusion would give new life to Fidel Castro's government and that farm-state lawmakers were undercutting the president by trying to strip him of his ability to punish rogue regimes.
Arguments that tourism and greater engagement would help open up Cuba, Mr. Suchlicki said, "are at best naive and at worst hypocritical." He added: "They see Cuba as a bonanza, which it's not. Cuba is bankrupt."
Former President Jimmy Carter's call for easing sanctions against Cuba during a visit there last week elevated this running debate, and was groundbreaking on several other levels, said Jorge Dominguez, a Cuba expert and professor of government at Harvard.
"He compelled the Cuban government, and Fidel in particular, to recognize the opposition," Mr. Dominguez said. "He got to have his remarks in Spanish broadcast over Cuban national television. Only the pope has had that opportunity."
Cuba policy takes on added importance because of its political implications in Florida, where President Bush's brother, Gov. Jeb Bush, is running for his second term and has relied on the strongly Republican Cuban-American vote. In recent years, Florida has emerged as a crucial swing state, magnifying the importance of Cuban-Americans, who represent only about 5 percent of the state's electorate.
Al Cardenas, the chairman of the Republican Party in Florida, said Cuban-American support for President Bush had increased to about 80 percent since he took office.
But Cuban-Americans are no longer united in their stance toward Cuba. Sergio Bendixen, a Miami pollster who tracks Hispanic issues, said that slightly more than half of Cuban-Americans in South Florida arrived since the early 1980's, and that they supported a more moderate policy. But their political influence is eclipsed by those who arrived in the 1960's and 70's, who generally take a much harder line and make up 70 percent of the Cuban-American electorate, Mr. Bendixen said.
"The challenge for the president will be not only to make hard-liners happy, but also hang onto a significant chunk who want more moderation," Mr. Bendixen said.
The tone and content of the Cuba policy debate are evolving. A decade ago, Cuban-American lawmakers, their allies and a well-financed lobby blocked discussion of engagement by questioning the anti-Communist credentials of the policy critics. Now, with the cold war a fading memory, the forces for engagement are demanding to know why the United States pursues trade or political dialogue with authoritarian states like China, but not Cuba.
A growing number of lawmakers are traveling to Cuba. This year, two Republican senators, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, dined with Mr. Castro and crossed paths with a bipartisan group of six House members.
"There's no question that Congress is moving toward a different policy with Cuba based on the reality that the current policy is outdated and irrelevant," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska.
Nonetheless, there is a growing sense among Democratic critics that some members of the Bush administration are using the possibility of a new national security threat to blunt calls for improved relations with Cuba. John R. Bolton, the undersecretary of state for arms control, this month accused Cuba of developing biological weapons; both Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld distanced themselves from the charge.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who heads a Western Hemisphere subcommittee, announced hearings for this week to "review discrepancies" among administration officials on Cuba's ability to produce biological weapons.
Lawmakers on both sides of the debate said they faced an uphill struggle. There are enough votes in the House and Senate to lift the travel ban, advocates say. But the House leadership has twice blocked majorities seeking to open Cuba to travel. Even if supporters of change could muster enough votes, however, any easing of sanctions is likely to face a presidential veto.
"We're butting heads with the administration on this," said Representative John Thune of South Dakota, whom the White House has championed as the Republican candidate in the state's hotly contested Senate race this fall. "But we'll keep applying the pressure."

HEADLINE: New Jellyfish Problem Means Jellyfish Are Not the Only Problem 

BYLINE:  By OTTO POHL 

DATELINE: PORT DOUGLAS, Australia 

 BODY:
When Robert King climbed back on the boat after snorkeling off the Great Barrier Reef here on March 31, he knew something was wrong. "I don't feel so good," he said, rubbing his chest. 
 He had been stung by a jellyfish, and his condition deteriorated rapidly. By the time the emergency helicopter arrived, he was screaming in agony; a few hours later he was in a coma, eyes frozen wide, bleeding into his brain. He never regained consciousness. 
 Mr. King, 44, from Columbus, Ohio, was the second person in Australia to die this year from the sting of a species of jellyfish, Carukia barnesi, found only in Australia and never before known to be fatal. More than 200 other victims went to hospitals, several times the number in a normal summer season here.
In many places around the world, jellyfish populations are sharply increasing, stinging more people and wreaking economic damage. While in some areas the increase appears to be part of a natural cycle (jellyfish populations are declining in some other areas), scientists have noticed an overall upward trend. And they suspect that human activity is to blame.
"Jellies are a pretty good group of animals to track coastal ecosystems," said Dr. Monty Graham, a jellyfish scientist at the University of South Alabama. "When you start to see jellyfish numbers grow and grow, that usually indicates a stressed system."
Those stresses include increased water temperature, a rise in nutrients in the water and depleted stocks of other fish, all of them often caused by humans.
Higher nutrient levels in the water, which tend to support larger populations of jellyfish, can result from runoff of fertilizer and sewage. Overfishing removes the jellyfish's main competitor for food. 
Debate continues about the rising water temperatures worldwide and whether they result, at least partly, from global warming -- the greenhouse effect caused by the burning of fossil fuel. Being mostly water, jellyfish react strongly and quickly to all of these changes. In a sense, the jellyfish is like the pigeon in today's cities, able to flourish in environments distorted by humans while other species cannot survive at all. 
Distinctly unlike the pigeon, however, jellyfish release millions of microscopic harpoons when touched, shooting tiny hypodermic needles into a victim's skin. They are lined with barbs and filled with venom, and they often linger painfully in the skin for months after the toxin has worn off. 
That experience is becoming more common around the world. On Waikiki Beach in Hawaii, for example, a lifeguard, Landy Blair, counted more than 900 stings on a single day this season, about 1 percent of them sending victims to hospitals. Mr. Blair has been keeping track of jellyfish populations near the beach since 1991. The problem has grown steadily worse, he said, adding, "We have seen the highest numbers ever over the past year."
On the beaches near Auckland, New Zealand, half a dozen sting victims have required hospitalization this year, Robert Ferguson of Surf Life Saving New Zealand, a lifeguard group, reported. "It's the first time I've ever heard of victims needing hospital care," Mr. Ferguson said. "This is a new type of jellyfish with stings that are much more severe, much harsher."
The situation is the same in Australia. "This year is incredibly abnormal," said Dr. Jamie Seymour, a jellyfish expert at James Cook University. He believes that strong, unusual wind patterns help blow the jellyfish toward the shore, where they flourish in unseasonably warm waters. Dr. Seymour, who has analyzed the venom from each sting that receives hospital treatment in the Barrier Reef region for years, had never seen the type of venom that killed the two tourists this year. 
Dr. Seymour believes that the enormous increase of jellyfish near the shore has brought rarer, more deadly subspecies into contact with humans for the first time.
Booming jellyfish populations can also take a high economic toll. In the Gulf of Mexico, shrimp fishermen are struggling with a jellyfish boom that fills nets with slimy gelatin and financial ledgers with millions of dollars in losses.
While populations appear to be down this year, Dr. Graham, of South Alabama, sees a "statistically solid increase" in the region over the longer term.
Jellyfish first gained major scientific attention in the 1980's, when a huge jellyfish bloom devastated the Black Sea, an ecosystem already weakened by overfishing of anchovies. Scientists believe that the jellyfish, an Atlantic native named Mnemiopsis leidyi, hitched a ride on the bottom of a ship and then rapidly multiplied, feeding on anchovy eggs and the plankton that young fish rely on. 
More recently in Hawaii, overfishing of stocks like ahi and mahi-mahi -- as well as a depletion of sea turtle populations, another predator of the jellyfish -- is partly responsible for the jellyfish boom there, said Dr. Angel Yanagihara, who heads a jellyfish research laboratory at the University of Hawaii. For her, jellyfish blooms are simply responses to the stresses that humans have put on the environment. "It's a wake-up call by nature," Dr. Yanagihara said.
Australia was stunned into action by the two deaths, which officials fear could hurt tourism. "No one cared until someone died," said Dr. Seymour, a member of a hastily convened commission. 
At the same time, some here see the jellyfish boom as an opportunity. The Queensland Fisheries Service, intrigued that Australian waters are so hospitable to jellyfish, is considering setting up a commercial fishing operation for the edible jellyfish Catostylus mosaicus. That fish is popular in many Asian countries, but it is declining in Asian waters, probably because of pollution. 
Dr. Seymour said people could eat the highly venomous box jellyfish if they cut the tentacles off, although he remains fairly unimpressed with jellyfish as a food source. "They basically taste like whatever sauce they've got on them," he said. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two deaths in Australia this year have been linked to this jellyfish species, Carukia barnesi, which had never been known to be fatal. (Lisa-ann Gershwin)
