HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Guess Who Doesn't Back Fannie, Freddie And Farmer

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
Perhaps the only warning label more ignored than the one on cigarette packs is the one stamped on debt offerings issued by government-sponsored enterprises like Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and Farmer Mac. 
 The boldface disclaimers state that the securities are not guaranteed by and do not constitute debts or obligations of the United States government. 
 But the warnings are roundly dismissed by the analysts who follow the issuers' stocks, the agencies that rate their senior debt and the money managers who put their commercial paper in money market funds. In interview after interview, market professionals said that even if the paper did not carry an overt government guarantee, there was an implied guarantee, which was just as good, and the government would not allow weakness in the securities to wreak havoc.
That market confidence is evident in the low interest rates that the organizations have to pay investors for financing, often only half a percentage point more than what the United States Treasury pays. 
It also shows up in a financial instrument that is really an insurance policy that would pay off if one of the government enterprises defaulted. The cost of that insurance has barely budged for the biggest companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, whose default is so unthinkable that Wall Street charges less than half what it charges to provide similar peace of mind to an investor in J. P. Morgan Chase or American Express. But the cost has more than doubled in the last month for investors who want to protect against a default by Farmer Mac, the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, on a report that management may have engaged in risky practices. 
The best-known enterprises, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, use their low borrowing costs to buy home mortgages from banks, repackaging the loans as tradable securities and thereby supporting the secondary market for home loans. Farmer Mac, begun 14 years ago, aims to do for farm lending what Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have done for home loans.
The charters, written by Congress, in most cases allow the secretary of the Treasury to lend the government-sponsored enterprises money if the situation warrants. "You can't underestimate the strength of the G.S.E. charter," said Paul Miller, an analyst who covers government-sponsored enterprises for Friedman Billings Ramsey in Washington. 
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac can each ask the Treasury to buy as much as $2.25 billion of their obligations, while Farmer Mac can request $1.5 billion in support.
Though the numbers sound big, the money would not go far, given how much these entities have grown. Fannie Mae's $2.25 billion figure was last revised in 1957, when its portfolio was $3.64 billion. Today, Fannie Mae has $769 billion in obligations on its balance sheet, and $896 billion in off-balance-sheet guarantees. 
Careful reading of the charters also suggests that the backstops are there to protect the guarantees these entities affix on loans or securities in furtherance of their mission. It is far less clear whether these entities would be able to turn to the Treasury if they overextended themselves and had difficulty, say, rolling over their commercial paper, the preferred method for short-term financing.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have a policy of keeping three months of liquid investments on hand as a contingency. Farmer Mac, in contrast, has $1.4 billion in cash and securities on its balance sheet, versus some $2.2 billion of short-term obligations that roll over every week on average.
Farmer Mac was asked by investors to describe how it might handle a hiccup in the commercial paper market, according to several people who visited the company's Washington office on April 8. Henry D. Edelman, the chief executive, said that if a sale of investments failed to raise enough cash, "well, we do have a $1.5 billion guarantee from the U.S. government," the investors said they were told. In a follow-up question, though, he allowed that the backstop could not be used to cover general obligations, the investors said.
Asked about that conversation and other issues on Friday, Jerome G. Oslick, Farmer Mac's general counsel, replied that the company would not respond. 
For all the potential risks lurking on their balance sheets, the government-sponsored enterprises argue that the government gets a lot of bang for its theoretical buck. So long as the government never has to mount a rescue, they have a point.
But the bigger they get, the greater the public's exposure. 
Certainly, Fannie and Freddie are already so large that some argue the government could no more let them fail than Chrysler, which got federal help in 1980. "The issue is what would the government do here, and I'd argue there is an implicit guarantee with Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase, General Electric" as well, Mr. Miller said. "The government cannot allow any of these big institutions to fail." 
Contagion would be one problem. Two-fifths of all United States financial institutions hold one to five times as much debt from these agencies as they do capital. The system encourages banks to treat the agencies' paper as a near substitute for Treasuries, so that concentration limits do not apply. Central banks are also big holders.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have at least enough financial heft to garner an A- financial-strength rating from Moody's when assessed solely on their merits. With the government's implicit backing, their senior debt rises to Aaa.
How Farmer Mac might fare without its government-issued safety net is less clear, partly because it has never agreed to have its securities rated. This might be news to Fulcrum Trust, which held Farmer Mac medium-term notes in its strategic income portfolio as of June 30, 2000, and described them as Aaa paper in a government filing.
Michael Buckley, spokesman for Allmerica, Fulcrum's investment manager, said the ratings information came from a third-party provider that consults Bloomberg when unsure of the information. Until two months ago, Bloomberg's terminals also incorrectly characterized Farmer Mac's medium-term notes as Aaa, according to market participants.
A Bloomberg official said last night that the company believed that the initial information came from one of Farmer Mac's underwriters.
As Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has warned, a lack of due diligence is inevitable in a world where market participants assume the government will make things right. George J. Benston, a finance professor at Emory University who served on Farmer Mac's board in its early days, said the failure of a smaller enterprise would actually give the government "a wonderful chance to teach the market a lesson at a bargain price."
"Legally, the government is not obligated," he said. "But Congress tends to bail these people out."
There are rumblings that even Congress is having second thoughts. Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, and Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, want Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to comply with the same disclosure rules as other public companies. And Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman, has stated publicly that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may have become larger than Congress intended.
Richard H. Baker, the head of a House subcommittee that has long sought to rein in the government-sponsored enterprises, reports feeling less lonely these days. Featured last week in a Friedman Billings Ramsey conference call with investors, he joked that he used to make his staff check his car before climbing in. Now, he says, congressmen still won't take the podium but do support him privately. "More people are willing to stand up and say at least something should be done," he added in an interview on Friday.
For now, his energies are devoted to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac "to make sure taxpayers are not called upon in difficult times," he said. Asked about Farmer Mac, he told the investors that "we have significant exposure there."
"The only solace I take," he added, "is that it is not as big as the housing G.S.E.'s, so hopefully we can get to them when we get to them."

HEADLINE: Afghan Warlord Muddles Interim Government's Plans 

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: KHOST, Afghanistan, May 20 

 BODY:
Over the last three weeks, Afghanistan's interim leader has declared him a wanted killer. A handpicked successor has been dispatched here to dethrone him, and 3,000 government troops in Kabul have been put on alert to attack him. 
 But today Padsha Khan Zadran did what he has done for the last several months: laughed at Hamid Karzai and his interim government in Kabul. "Mr. Karzai has some problem with his mind," Mr. Zadran said this afternoon, as a smug grin spread across his leathery face. "He is nothing. He is a common man." 
 Three weeks after Mr. Karzai demanded Mr. Zadran's arrest, this warlord is the most glaring example in Afghanistan of the central government's inability to control events outside of Kabul, the capital. 
Mr. Zadran still controls large swathes of Khost and Paktia province, strategic areas where American forces are hunting for Al Qaeda fighters. The threatened military attack is on hold. Further, Mr. Zadran, a fierce, illiterate man brimming with bluster, appears to have grown even bolder. 
After delivering his usual taunts aimed at Mr. Karzai this afternoon, Mr. Zadran announced that he would attend the loya jirga, a grand council of leaders and tribal elders from around the country planned for mid-June that will choose a government for the next two years.
His goal? To unseat Mr. Karzai. "I will send my representatives and I will go myself," he said as he sat in the governor's complex here that he was ordered to leave months ago. "Karzai is only a temporary chairman. Nobody supports him."
Mr. Zadran's threat is largely empty. He is unlikely to go to the loya jirga, where he could easily be arrested. But he remains a glaring failure for the Karzai government as political violence appears to be spreading gradually. A man was shot dead Sunday after winning the first of two rounds to represent the western district of Chaghcharan at the loya jirga. It was the first killing to mar the selection process.
Mr. Zadran's position here appears intact. Scores of men toting assault rifles and wearing bandoleers milled around the governor's complex here today. A dozen tribal elders lined up outside his door to pay their respects. Hakim Taniwal, the soft-spoken sociology professor sent to unseat him, remains in the governor's official guest house a mile away.
Western diplomats and some of Mr. Zadran's Afghan rivals blame the United States military for propping him up. American Special Forces have hired 600 of Mr. Zadran's soldiers and 500 of Mr. Taniwal's soldiers to help seal the nearby border with Pakistan, a move that rivals say inflates Mr. Zadran's political and economic power. 
In an interview tonight, Mr. Taniwal, an Afghan exile who left his wife and children and a comfortable teaching position in Melbourne, Australia, to take on Mr. Zadran, said he was the one who asked Mr. Karzai to hold off on a military attack. 
Wearing white trousers and tunic and a prayer cap in a room full of ferocious-looking men in black turbans, he looked and sounded like the out-of-place academic he is in Khost. A volatile provincial capital near the Pakistan border, Khost was once a Qaeda and Taliban stronghold.
"I want to remove the Kalashnikov culture," he said, using the name of a popular rifle to refer to the decade-old Afghan practice of resolving political disputes with force. "I am a teacher, not a commander."
He proceeded to lay out a strategy that was a microcosm of the gamble Mr. Karzai's government and his American backers appear to be taking across Afghanistan. Instead of confronting Mr. Zadran with force, Mr. Taniwal hopes to bury his rival with cash. 
Mr. Taniwal is mounting a two-pronged effort to show local residents and local gunmen that he has the funds from international donors to pay salaries. At the same time, he is trying to cut off Mr. Zadran's access to all local government agencies that produce revenue.
"I am cutting his sources," Mr. Taniwal proudly announced tonight. "He cannot pay his people." He went on to predict optimistically that Mr. Zadran would surrender to the authorities before the loya jirga convenes on June 10.
The same dynamic is occurring on a national scale. The United States and other countries are funneling much of their aid money through Kabul to give Mr. Karzai economic leverage over defiant warlords. 
But this morning Mr. Zadran insisted that he still controlled revenue-producing offices in the local government. There is also a panoply of practices -- like smuggling -- that Mr. Zadran and other warlords can use to raise cash. 
This afternoon, he held court in the governor's office as a dozen elders from his native Zadran tribe paid their respects. He looked on like a beaming father when one tribal leader assailed Mr. Karzai for unfairly attacking Mr. Zadran. He then stood up and excused himself. "I have many tribal leaders who have come to see me," he said. "I have to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Padsha Khan Zadran controls large parts of Khost and Paktia Province and has resisted the interim Afghan government's efforts to oust him. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hailing an Old Cry, 'Viva Cuba Libre!' 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 20 

 BODY:
Many Cuban immigrants felt they had a lot to celebrate today: not only their homeland's centennial but also the growth of their political strength here in the new homeland they have adopted.
 President Bush added weight to that sense of power today by traveling to Miami to proclaim that the "Cuban people's love of liberty cannot and will not be denied." 
 Mr. Bush called for free elections in Cuba and the release of political prisoners; he also said he supported giving American scholarships to Cuban dissidents and families of political prisoners. In a city with its own Little Havana, his message played well. 
"This is why we like him," said Cirilo Cabezas, 64, a retired Las Vegas casino dealer who is Cuban-American. "We think he will keep his promise."
Another supporter, Miguel Fuentes, 80, said the president gave him hope. "I feel very positive about what he said and the initiatives he proposed. I feel he was able to relate to our sentiments, not just politically, but as a human being."
There were skeptics, too. Nolis Mesa, 64, a real estate broker, citing the slogan "Viva Cuba Libre!" -- "Long Live Free Cuba!" -- said Mr. Bush had "said the same thing that Clinton said and that Reagan said," then added, "I have been listening to the same phrase for 42 years."
Asserting that political parties came to Miami merely to fight for their own interests, and that Mr. Bush was working the Cuban community for votes, Mr. Nolis said, "I'm not going to participate in this dance." 
But political experts did not see such minority views standing in the president's way as he pursued what they called a strategic effort to begin mobilizing voter support.
"I think he is trying to kill two birds with one stone," said Jim Kane, director of the Florida Voter Poll, a political news and polling service, alluding to the Bush brothers' political future -- George's in 2004 and Jeb's in the November governor's race. 
Cuban-Americans, Mr. Kane said, represent about 8 percent of Florida voters, and as many as 90 percent are Republicans.
"Florida is a very important state politically, a state that elected him in 2000," Mr. Kane said. "Coming here allows him to solidify his position with the Republican base in Florida."
Not to mention that "following Jimmy Carter's recent trip to Cuba, it's even more important," Mr. Kane added, pointing out that Mr. Bush "needs to end that concern among Cuban-Americans about the embargo and reassure them that the embargo will continue."
As the president used the occasion to do just that, Haitian immigrants used the occasion to protest what they and a growing group of lawmakers from both parties say is a discriminatory administration policy: basing treatment of asylum seekers on whether the rickety boats they took to the seas in were from Cuba or Haiti.
In December, the Immigration and Naturalization Service began requiring officials here to detain Haitian refugees with plausible asylum claims -- instead of releasing them to relatives or sponsors while their claims are pursued. The requirement applies only in South Florida.
The agency defends the policy as a way to deter thousands of Haitians from taking to sea in unstable rafts and flooding South Florida, or dying en route. But that is not the view of Marleine Bastien, executive director of Haitian Women of Miami Inc. and one of the protest organizers.
"It is really sad that the U.S. that is supposed to be the champion of human rights keeps violating the rights of Haitian refugees who come to this country in search of freedom," she said.
In a city often accused of being overly segregated, many Cuban and Haitian immigrants agreed today that the government should treat all asylum seekers equally. So while Cuban-Americans praised the president's speech, some said they could not help wishing his outlook could apply in some measure to Haitian causes. They linked the disparity to a basic difference between Cuba and Haiti: one is Communist, the other simply impoverished. 
Antonio Ramos, 48, a Cuban-American architect, said, "I believe Haitians are like any other immigrant group and deserve the same treatment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nolis Mesa, 64, expressed skepticism about Mr. Bush's visit. (Alex Quesada/Matrix, for The New York Times)

President Bush, speaking to Cuban-Americans in Miami on the 100th anniversary of Cuban independence, said he would not lift travel restrictions and a trade embargo against Cuba unless President Fidel Castro met a broad array of democratic and economic changes. HEADLINE: Long-Shot Winner Turns Dark Horse 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., May 17 

 BODY:
Bill Simon Jr. beamed here the other day when he introduced a high-powered group of business and political leaders who had agreed to advise his campaign for governor. On the dais, standing rigid, were Rudolph W. Giuliani, former mayor of New York; George P. Shultz, former secretary of state; and several onetime state officials.
 Then Mr. Simon came out swinging, at least by his standards. The advisory group, he said, will provide "the kind of vision that has been so sadly lacking" under the Democratic incumbent, Gray Davis. Mr. Davis's budget policies have been "terribly flawed," said Mr. Simon, who promised to "put California back on the right track again." 
 He was speaking to an almost empty room. 
It has been less than three months since Mr. Simon, a wealthy businessman, son of former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon and first-time candidate for political office, won a come-from-behind victory in the Republican primary. But already his candidacy appears to have lost the momentum from that upset.
Mr. Simon has been holding campaign events that are all but ignored, and the gap between his war chest and that of Mr. Davis remains vast. The governor, a prodigious fund-raiser, has a little more than $28 million in hand; Mr. Simon, who had less than $700,000 after the March primary, has been able to amass $6 million or so with help from President Bush.
One problem, many members of his own party complain, is the soft, sunny tone that Mr. Simon adopts in his efforts to strike a Reaganesque pose, in contrast to the hard-hitting Davis campaign, which has called Mr. Simon a "rank amateur" and a "sanctimonious hypocrite."
Mr. Simon's aides argue that opponents who underestimated him in the primary paid the price, and maintain that voters will respond more to his hopeful, pro-business themes than to slashing attacks. But even some senior Republicans criticize his distaste for the harsh offensive and his insistence on describing himself as a Reagan conservative above the fray.
"There are some situations where he's just politically naive," said Dave Cox, who heads the Republican caucus in the State Assembly. "Ultimately he has to define himself better, and when you run for governor you have to be prepared to play with the big boys."
Mr. Cox did add that "he's a quick learner, and his positive image, that could be an asset."
But Dan Schnur, a Republican consultant who worked in the primary for Mr. Simon's principal opponent, former Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles, said of the nominee's campaign team: "It's clearly taking them some time to shift out of primary mode and into general-election mode. And in a general election, you have to be prepared to go on the attack."
Mr. Simon roared through the primary, not only having closed a 30-point deficit to defeat Mr. Riordan but also, according to some polls, emerging with a small edge over Mr. Davis. He ignored both the centrist tack taken by Mr. Riordan and President Bush's "compassionate conservatism," but conservatives here liked his strong opposition to new taxes, abortion and gun control.
His campaign reeled in mid-April, however, when it appeared caught completely unprepared by demands from Democrats and news organizations that he release his tax returns. He refused, though issuing a few financial summaries and saying he had paid millions of dollars in taxes in recent years. The effect was to make him look evasive in the face of Mr. Davis's attacks.
A poll issued by the Field Institute on April 28 found that the governor had opened a 14-point lead.
It is not that Mr. Davis has been without recent problems of his own. First came disclosures that his campaign received a $25,000 contribution from the software giant Oracle Corporation shortly after the company had signed a $95 million state contract that auditors have called too expensive and potentially unneeded. Then Mr. Davis acknowledged that after several years of surpluses, the state was facing a budget shortfall this year and next that could reach nearly $24 billion.
Such unpredictable developments could turn the tide several more times before the November election. That is why it is so important, many experts say, that Mr. Simon become more combative. So far, he has not been able to exploit the governor's stumbles.
"Simon has gotten no traction from his upset in the primary," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at the University of Southern California. "His people are right to try and fashion that kind of Reagan dynamic, but people knew a lot more about Reagan. Simon's really been under the radar screen since the primary, and he hasn't defined himself."
Clearly he is trying. In an interview the other day after touring a City of Commerce printing plant where he was trailed by a mere three or four reporters, he first hinted that laws might have been broken in the Oracle case. Then he turned back to the issues he is most comfortable with, like taxes.
"Absent evidence of criminal wrongdoing on his part," Mr. Simon said of the governor, "I think the campaign will revolve around schools, jobs and stimulating this economy." 
His chief strategist, Sal Russo, sounded a more aggressive note, but the tactics he outlined nonetheless painted the candidate as a man more of ideas than of political warfare.
"There is a perception that Gray Davis has fostered a culture of corruption, and we will make that point," Mr. Russo said. "We will talk about the culture of extortion that has grown up around Gray Davis. But that's not the easiest thing for Bill. Bill is more comfortable in the realm of ideas. That's what motivated him to get involved in the first place."
Despite several joint appearances with President Bush in California and Washington, Mr. Simon has not grown much closer to the White House, which openly backed Mr. Riordan in the primary.
The Bush administration has since sought to embrace Mr. Simon, and a senior White House official said in an interview that he believed the nominee was an excellent candidate with a great chance of success. A number of Mr. Bush's California fund-raisers have now joined Mr. Simon's campaign.
But none of this has brought closer coordination between Mr. Simon and the White House. Perhaps the most conspicuous example was the way the candidate responded to the newly disclosed depth of California's budget crisis. Criticizing Mr. Davis, Mr. Simon said at the printing plant tour that any political leader who inherited a surplus and turned it into a big deficit ought to be thrown out of office. Asked if that applied to Mr. Bush, Mr. Simon sought to explain that the state and federal budgets were different and that the two officeholders had differing amounts of time to deal with the issue.
Mr. Russo insists that whether or not Mr. Bush and Mr. Simon see eye to eye, Mr. Bush needs the nominee, and his victory here, to help the president's own re-election prospects in 2004.
But Democratic strategists are growing more confident. They are researching business dealings by Mr. Simon's family in an effort to develop attacks against his record, and say they will hit him with a barrage of tough television advertisements this summer.
"I can tell you, come Nov. 5, Bill Simon will not be a pretty new face in California politics any longer," said Garry South, Mr. Davis's chief strategist. "This guy is a rank amateur."
Mr. Simon dismisses such talk.
"I'd like to stay away from what I call the old style of politics, the 'gotcha' politics," he said. "I'm interested in the new politics of opportunity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Simon Jr., Gray Davis's opponent this November, has cast himself in the Reagan mold. To some fellow Republicans, that's a problem. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Online Travel Booking Site Files for Public Stock Sale 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Orbitz Inc., the Internet travel booking site owned by the country's five largest airlines, filed for an initial stock offering yesterday that is intended to raise $125 million.
 Started in June 2001, Orbitz.com is the country's third-largest online booking site for airline tickets, rental cars, hotel rooms and other travel-related products. Its filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission did not say when the offering would take place or how many shares would be offered and at what price. 
 The lead underwriters are Goldman, Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston; two other investment banks are taking part.
Orbitz has been engaged in a battle with Travelocity and Expedia for online bookings. In contrast to most other online business, the purchasing of travel online has been increasing. Airlines are encouraging travelers to book tickets over the Internet because it saves carriers the cost of printing and mailing tickets.
Many passengers have found that electronic tickets are more convenient, allowing them to bypass long lines at the check-in counter, especially after Sept. 11. More and more travelers are also going to Web sites to search for inexpensive last-minute fares that are often unavailable elsewhere.
Expedia is a public company that is mostly owned by USA Network; Travelocity was also public until it was bought by Sabre Holdings Corporation in March.
Orbitz is owned by five carriers that account for about 70 percent of domestic sales -- American Airlines, United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines. That has led Orbitz's competitors and antitrust groups to criticize the company, saying it gives those airlines the opportunity to collude on fares and offer exclusive low fares on the Web site.
The Departments of Transportation and Justice are investigating the accusations, and some people are speculating that the offering is an effort by Orbitz to distance itself from its owners.
"By diluting the airlines' ownership, Orbitz becomes less controlled by the airlines and to a certain degree controlled by shareholders," said Henry Harteveldt, a travel industry analyst with Forrester Research. The offering by Orbitz comes as no surprise, he added, because "its five airline founders have invested substantial money in Orbitz, and they're all financially challenged right now.
"They're desperately seeking payback on their investment in Orbitz to shore up their own financial coffers," Mr. Harteveldt said.
Albert A. Foer, president of the American Antitrust Institute, a nonpartisan research organization, said that although Orbitz might be trying to distance itself from the carriers, it remained to be seen who would own controlling shares and who would appoint the directors.
"If the major airlines continue to appoint the board members and control the policy, then it won't reduce the concerns," Mr. Foer said. "If this were spun off to a company that had no airline ownership, then it would be a different animal."
It is not known when the federal government will conclude its investigations. Orbitz will almost certainly take that into consideration as it tries to select a date for its offering. The investigations could also influence the price.
As the American economy continues to struggle, discount travel options have become increasingly popular. Southwest Airlines and JetBlue have earned more profit this year than the larger carriers, which charge more for unrestricted fares. JetBlue's stock soared 67 percent after a public offering last month that raised $158.5 million.

HEADLINE: No Cuba Libre, No Trade 

 BODY:
President Bush's speech on the centennial of Cuban independence amounted to an invitation that Fidel Castro is almost certain to decline: Hold free elections and liberalize your economy, and we will trade with you. Coming on the heels of Jimmy Carter's trip to Havana, the speech was an unfortunate, if nuanced, reaffirmation of Mr. Bush's support for the counterproductive, four-decade-old economic sanctions and ban on travel to the island nation. 
 There were, to be sure, things to applaud in Mr. Bush's address, which he delivered before flying to Florida to speak to a Cuban-American rally and attend a fund-raiser for his brother Jeb, Florida's governor. Nobody can argue with the president's depiction of the Castro regime as an anachronistic Communist dictatorship, nor with his praise for Cuba's internal dissidents. 
 Mr. Bush also pledged to loosen restrictions on private humanitarian assistance offered Cubans, to seek a resumption of normal mail service and to finance scholarships for Cuban students to study in the United States. Moreover, the suggestion that his administration could someday normalize ties with Mr. Castro's regime -- provided the dictator ensures "certifiably free" National Assembly elections next year -- was a departure from the usual rhetoric that holds the passing from the scene of Washington's bearded old nemesis as a precondition for normalizing ties. 
Yet the fundamental principle of the Bush approach toward Cuba -- that normal trade relations are a reward for deserving democracies with free markets -- remains deeply flawed. That view is at odds with America's approach to much of the rest of the world, including China and Vietnam, where trade and foreign investment are rightly seen as a means of advancing economic reforms and democratization, not as a prize for them.
When the Senate voted in the fall of 2000 to fully normalize trade with China, Mr. Bush, then governor of Texas, issued an approving statement: "This measure will help open markets to American products and help export American values, especially freedom and entrepreneurship." Certifiably free local elections were not demanded from China. Cuba is a different case because of domestic political concerns, notably Florida's large Cuban-American electorate. 
There is an increasingly bipartisan clamor on Capitol Hill to lift sanctions against Cuba. American big business and American tourists are eager to launch a commercial invasion across the Straits of Florida, and it is hard to overstate their power to overwhelm Mr. Castro's control over all facets of the Cuban economy. It is also hard to overstate how deflated Mr. Castro's regime would become politically if it could no longer pose as the aggrieved victim of Yankee imperialism. That is the reason Cuba's most prominent dissidents favor lifting the embargo. Mr. Bush would do well to listen to them.

HEADLINE: Becoming Less German 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L.ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 20 

 BODY:
Ten years ago, it would never have occurred to anyone that a Swiss citizen could end up running a German powerhouse like Deutsche Bank. Today, the big question is whether a Swiss citizen can save it.
 When Josef Ackermann, a former chief executive at the Credit Suisse Group who arrived here in 1996, takes over on Wednesday as chief executive of Deutsche Bank, he will do so with three simple thoughts at the forefront. Bold new visions are out, cost-cutting is in -- and time is running short. 
 Deutsche Bank remains one of the biggest banks in the world, an institution with more than $800 billion in assets and tens of thousands of people working in London, on Wall Street, in Central Europe and in Asia.
But it is also an institution that is remarkably frail. Its profit margins are among the lowest and its costs are among the highest in the banking industry. Its $44 billion market capitalization, or total value to investors, is smaller than that of many European rivals and barely one-sixth that of Citigroup. Deutsche Bank's home market is stagnant, overcrowded and barely profitable. 
All of the German banks have had their profits wilt and their stock prices languish. Dresdner Bank became so feeble that it was taken over by its biggest shareholder, Allianz, and Commerzbank is a perpetual subject of takeover speculation.
In private meetings with top executives, Mr. Ackermann has warned that Deutsche must raise its stock price if it is to avoid being eclipsed. He has warned that executives have a matter of months, not years, to make their case with investors.
If the campaign fails, he says, the bank will at best be unable to make any big acquisitions. At worst, it could itself become a takeover target.
No one expects Deutsche Bank to fall victim to a foreign takeover any time soon. But the bank that used to be at the very heart of Germany Inc. has already ceased to be a German institution in many respects.
Mr. Ackermann, 54, is merely the most visible sign of the cultural shift. More than half of the bank's powerful new executive committee, led by Mr. Ackermann, are non-Germans and three of them are Americans.
English, not German, is the language in meetings of the executive committee as well as on the Vorstand, or management board. The bank's incoming media spokesman is British; he is not entirely comfortable speaking German.
The international complexion of the top management directly reflects the change in its business. Bank executives estimate that 85 percent of profits come from outside Germany; more than half of employees are elsewhere. Investment banking is now the engine of profits, and those operations are based in London and New York. Asset management and Swiss-style private banking are the other main pillars, and those are largely outside Germany, too.
The problem is that Deutsche Bank has not been able to trim its costs. Like Germany's other big banks, it remains bogged down by a home market that has too many banks fighting for too few profits.
Until now, the banks have been nervous about closing branches and losing market share, yet at the same time, they have not been able to solve their problems by merging with one another. Making matters worse, German economic growth has been the slowest in Europe for years and is nearly stagnant right now.
But German market woes do not explain the entire problem. Deutsche Bank, which has long considered itself the gold standard in banking, has high costs even in businesses outside the German market. Costs eat up 89 percent of income in transaction banking, 91 percent of income of private banking and 92 percent of income in asset management.
Those numbers make Deutsche Bank, at the moment, the least efficient of almost any big international bank -- worse than big Swiss rivals like UBS and Credit Suisse; much worse than American giants like Citigroup; and not even comparable to a brutally frugal institution like Lloyds TSB, the big British bank that has set the standard for European banks in cost-cutting.
Mr. Ackermann is already shaking up Deutsche Bank. Earlier this year, he pushed through a revamping that concentrates more power in an American-style chief executive and dilutes power in the consensus-driven management board.
The plan prompted one top board member to resign in protest, while German newspapers published scare articles about plans to move the headquarters from Frankfurt to London. But Mr. Ackermann prevailed, and he has clearly begun to crack the whip.
Last month, he announced plans to reduce annual costs by about $1.8 billion and to eliminate about 9,200 jobs. In league with his departing predecessor, Rolf E. Breuer, Mr. Ackermann has also moved to sell businesses that no longer fit with its basic strategy. Deutsche is selling the last of its insurance companies, as well as its securities services.
The third element of Mr. Ackermann's strategy is to accelerate the sale of Deutsche's huge pile of industrial holdings, which include a big stake in DaimlerChrysler, and to use the proceeds to buy back up to 20 percent of the bank's stock.
The combined effect of this new buzz has been to give Deutsche Bank shares an Ackermann lift based partly on the allure of a stock buyback and partly on the hope that the bank will finally do something about its high costs.
Still, Deutsche Bank has announced so many cost-reduction plans over the last five years, only to see its costs eat away even more profit, that investors are profoundly skeptical.
"The omens look better now than they have in a long time," said Stuart O. Graham, banking analyst at J. P. Morgan in London. "But the market is going to benchmark these guys very closely on cost control, and their track record on that is not great."
In the last few weeks, Deutsche Bank shares have risen faster than the market. Mr. Graham estimates that the recent lift reflects a belief that Mr. Ackermann will pull off only about half the $1.8 billion in savings he has advertised. Shares closed down fractionally today, to 77.45 euros ($71.28).
Though soft spoken and eager to avoid the limelight, Mr. Ackermann has won praise as a tough-minded and shrewd executive. Until recently, he spent nearly all his time in London and New York, where he also owns a home.
But these days, he has been telegraphing a very different message: not only will the base remain in Frankfurt, but the bank will hold on to its unprofitable retail banking business in Germany.
The problem is how to keep up with the competition. Bank executives confirm that Deutsche held merger discussions two years ago with Lloyds TSB before Deutsche concluded that the two did not make a good fit. Since then, Lloyd's market value has become far higher than Deutsche's.
"The problem now is that they can't do a deal because it would amount to being taken over," said one senior executive who recently left the bank.
That is why Mr. Ackermann has placed such a high priority on raising Deutsche Bank's stock price. And his only tool for doing that right now is reducing costs and raising profits. Surprisingly, at least a few of Deutsche's sharpest critics think Mr. Ackermann has a chance. 
"The new C.E.O. and the people around him seem more pragmatic, more focused," said Mark Hoge, banking analyst at Banc of America Securities in London. Almost every bank in Germany, he added, has belatedly come to the realization that it has to cut costs drastically.
"This time," Mr. Hoge said, "I believe they will deliver -- and that is a major change from our view in the past."

HEADLINE: EMBARGO REMAINS UNTIL CUBA ALTERS POLICY, BUSH SAYS 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 20 

 BODY:
President Bush, in a speech harshly critical of Fidel Castro, said today that he would not lift a trade embargo against Cuba without substantial movement toward democracy there.
 His remarks were greeted by roars of approval from thousands of Cuban-Americans in a state that is critical to the president's re-election campaign in 2004. 
 "Nearly a half century ago, Cuba's independence and the hopes for democracy were hijacked by a brutal dictator who cares everything for his own power and nada for the Cuban people," Mr. Bush said. "In an era where markets have brought prosperity and empowerment, this leader clings to a bankrupt ideology that has brought Cuba's workers and farmers and families nothing -- nothing -- but isolation and misery." 
Mr. Bush's remarks, made on the 100th anniversary of Cuban independence, placed him in direct opposition to the recommendations made by former President Jimmy Carter, who called for an easing of the economic sanctions last week when he became the most prominent American politician to visit the island since Mr. Castro took power in 1959.
The president's pronouncements were also at odds with Democrats and a number of Republicans in Congress, who consider an approach that Mr. Castro has survived for more than four decades to be outdated and ineffective.
But Mr. Bush said that he would only consider lifting the embargo, as well as travel restrictions to the island, if Mr. Castro met a broad variety of democratic and economic changes. 
"Then, and only then, I will explore ways with the United States Congress to ease economic sanctions," Mr. Bush said, to chants from the crowd of "Libertad! Libertad!" 
The president also threatened to veto any attempt by Congress to ease trade restrictions to the island. Republicans from farm states have been pushing for liberalized trade with Cuba, and two years ago Congress passed a measure allowing food exports to Cuba, though anti-Castro lawmakers placed a number of restrictions on those sales.
"I want you to know that I know what trade means with a tyrant," Mr. Bush said. "It means that we will underwrite tyranny, and we cannot let that happen."
This morning at the White House, the president said that Mr. Castro -- Mr. Bush never once referred to him as "President Castro" -- had "turned a beautiful island into a prison."
Mr. Bush's remarks at the James L. Knight Center here were a more rollicking version of his speech earlier in the day at the White House, and the result of a five-month administration review of Cuba policy. 
Mr. Bush laid out a long list of conditions that Cuba must meet before his administration would consider a change of policy. Specifically, the president demanded that Mr. Castro release all political prisoners and give opposition political candidates in Cuba's National Assembly elections in 2003 the freedom to organize, assemble and speak. 
"For 43 years, every election in Cuba has been a fraud and a sham," Mr. Bush said. "Mr. Castro, once, just once, show that you're unafraid of a real election."
Mr. Bush also demanded that Mr. Castro allow international human rights organizations to monitor those elections. 
The president's remarks drew criticism from Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. "President Bush has set forth a laundry list of actions that the Castro government must take before the U.S. takes even one step toward modifying U.S. policies," he said in a statement. "By doing so, he has guaranteed that the current political system in Cuba will remain the same -- as it has for the last 40 years that the U.S. has pursued this ill-advised policy."
But the president's position was enthusiastically applauded today by huge numbers of Cuban-Americans, who were essential to Mr. Bush's slender victory in Florida, and the presidential election, in 2000. The Cuban-American community is also important to this year's re-election campaign of the president's younger brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.
Tonight the brothers were the guests of honor at a $2 million fund-raiser for the Florida Republican Party at the Coral Gables home of Armando Codina, a Cuban-American real estate developer and a former business partner of Jeb Bush. Contributors paid $25,000 per couple to attend, and most of the money was expected to go to Jeb Bush's campaign. The White House closed the event to the news media.
While underscoring a hard line toward Cuba, the president did say that he would take some minor steps to ease life for Cubans living under the Castro regime. He said that his administration would support private organizations that aid Cuba, and that it would provide scholarships in the United States to Cuban students, professionals and children of political prisoners. 
In addition, Mr. Bush said that he was willing to negotiate resuming direct mail service between the United States and Cuba, and that he would "continue to look for ways" to modernize Radio and TV Marti, American government broadcasts in Cuba.
But Mr. Dodd, for one, dismissed the administration's proposals as "much ado about nothing" and said direct mail service and scholarship programs for Cuban students were unlikely to happen without the cooperation of the Cuban government.
Mr. Bush's speech today was delivered at a sometimes raucous event where Jeb Bush delivered remarks almost entirely in Spanish and Gloria Estefan sang the Cuban national anthem. "Ironically, the citizens of Cuba are still waiting for the freedoms embodied in this anthem," Ms. Estefan said from the stage.
Several times, the president inserted in his own remarks Spanish somewhat less practiced than his brother's, including the line "No quiero destriur un idioma que bonita, y por eso voy a hablar en ingles" -- "I don't want to destroy a beautiful language, so I'm going to speak in English."
The crowd interrupted the president's remarks frequently with huge waves of applause, particularly when Mr. Bush said that his administration would continue to bar tourist travel to Cuba. (People with professional business or family ties in Cuba are permitted to go.) 
Despite predictions last week that Mr. Bush would further restrict travel to Cuba, the president made no mention of that today. But a senior administration official with the president on Air Force One said the White House might still impose further restrictions on travel. "As we move on throughout the year, we're going to be looking at all steps at our disposal," the official said.
The official also said that Mr. Bush's speech was about foreign policy, not domestic politics. Asked if Jeb Bush had any input into the president's speech, the official said, "Not to my knowledge, no."

HEADLINE: Big Blimp That Apparently Couldn't 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 20 

 BODY:
Carl von Gablenz, the founder of Cargolifter A.G., had more than just a big idea. He had a gigantic and enchanting and almost quintessentially German idea.
 Blimps. A blimp that would be longer than two football fields. A helium-filled blimp so big that it would be able to carry a 100-ton oil rig to the frozen Arctic tundra or a power-plant turbine to the Amazon rain forest. It would be an "air crane," lifting more than any helicopter and reaching more places than any truck, ship, train or plane. 
 But 65 years after the Hindenburg exploded over New Jersey and effectively ended the era of the zeppelin, Mr. Von Gablenz's dream of lighter-than-air transportation is crashing and burning as well.
Having raised and spent more than $250 million in the last five years, he now presides over a mammoth hangar on an abandoned Russian military airfield 40 miles outside Berlin. But he has exhausted his money and the patience of investors.
His flagship flying machine, the 160-ton-capacity self-propelled blimp, needs another $300 million and is now on ice. His backup idea -- a giant balloon that can lift 75 tons -- needs another $50 million or so.
"People only ask me about the burn rate, about the money, about the time we need," Mr. Gablenz grumbled in a recent interview. "But we have made many new advances with the technology, and we know there is even more potential than we first thought.
"People don't ask about that."
Cargolifter's story is a piquant fillip to the dashed dreams of the dot-com bust. Here, too, was a company that went public on a vision and a technology. Here, too, was an entrepreneur who was a master at selling.
The difference was that this vision seemed concrete, logical and elegantly simple. Anyone could understand "the power of zero gravity."
That apparent simplicity was deceiving. Transportation experts say that in hindsight the concept was much harder to make workable than Mr. Von Gablenz or his investors ever understood. "It is easy to get this up in the air," said Peter Klaus, a professor of business logistics at the University of Erlangen-Nurenburg who has followed Cargolifter closely. "The problem is when you come back down."
An immense helium balloon can indeed hoist up gigantic payloads. But when it comes time to lower and then release the oil rig or power turbine, engineers had to figure out how to keep the airship from shooting skyward the moment it released the enormous weight.
Cargolifter designed ballast tanks that can be pumped with up to 160 tons of water as the unloading progresses. But that assumes 160 tons of water are available, which may not be the case in the Siberian tundra or the Sahara.
Then there is the problem of keeping a 100-ton piece of delicate engineering equipment from swinging and drifting as it dangles from the airship during unloading. "This isn't something that would happen in a few minutes," Mr. Klaus said. "This is something that would take hours."
Cargolifter executives say extensive studies have confirmed their concept. The company has built a working scale model of the 160-ton-capacity airship and a full-size prototype of the 75-ton balloon, which is almost 70 yards across.
Still, in its annual report last year, it noted that "combining an airship with a crane constitutes an enormous technical challenge" and that it would not be known until 2004 or later if the airships would be viable.
Mr. Von Gablenz, meanwhile, has run through money faster than he hoped. A former logistics executive and professor, who worked out his basic ideas on a sabbatical in North Carolina, Mr. Von Gablenz started Cargolifter in 1996 and raised more than $150 million privately. He got land and more than $30 million in cash assistance from the German state of Brandenburg to build the hangar.
It was a huge achievement in persuasion, especially in a country as habitually risk averse as Germany. But fascination with technology and entrepreneurship took hold here as well, and Cargolifter raised nearly $60 million more in a May 2000 public stock offering.
The company benefited from constant media attention. Its gleaming hangar is a photographer's dream. The idea of a modern zeppelin was easy and appealing to describe. Cargolifter shares jumped from 13 euros ($11.98), to more than 25 euros, within months.
But with the end of bull-market euphoria, Cargolifter's stock plunged along with countless other new companies, disrupting Mr. Von Gablenz's plans.
He knew from the beginning that the company would need more money before its airships were ready for business, he said, but he assumed that the markets would provide that money if he kept showing progress.
Mr. Von Gablenz said he made enormous strides by building the hangar and the prototypes, carrying out tests and signing up component suppliers. "The only thing that really did not work out according to plan was the market," he said ruefully.
That is not quite true: Earlier this year, Mr. Von Gablenz increased his estimate of how much more money he would need from about 300 million euros ($276 million) to 420 million euros ($387 million). An internal consulting report suggested that the gap could be more than 500 million euros ($461 million).
Cargolifter is far from finding it. The company tried to raise 50 million euros this month through a convertible bond offering, but received subscriptions for fewer than 4 million. Brandenburg, with money problems of its own, refused to contribute any more unless the German federal government joined in, but last week, the economics ministry refused.
Company officials refuse to say how much money they have left. Work has all but stopped, and bankruptcy appears imminent.
There are still a few glimmers of hope. A few weeks ago, the Boeing Company's technology-scouting subsidiary signed a letter of intent to explore new ideas based on Cargolifter's technology. The deal involves only a study of technical possibilities, but it could at some point lead to an investment.
Heinrich Grossbondant, a spokesman for Boeing in Hamburg, said his company was not interested in cargo carriers but might have other uses for lighter-than-air craft.
"One idea would be to put an airship 20 kilometers high as a surveillance platform and just have it stay in one place," he said. "No other company has spent as much energy and money on lighter-than-air technology in the last few years. That's where they probably acquired some valuable knowledge."
If all else fails, there is still tourism. Cargolifter may not have gotten off the ground, but its hangar and museum attract busloads of gawking tourists almost every day -- about 330,000 people so far -- who have paid 10 euros a ticket. The vision, at least, has not yet died.

Lifting is relatively easy, but keeping the airship from shooting skyward the moment it releases its cargo is more difficult. (Photographs by Mark Simon/Black Star, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
San Diego's High-Rise Slump Lingers

BYLINE:  By KEVIN BRASS 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
After 10 years without any high-rise office construction, this city's dormant downtown market showed signs of life last year. Two developers, using almost identical language, announced plans to build the first Class A office towers in San Diego in a decade.
 Both projects have been delayed, however, as the developers struggle with the lingering effects of a downtown office building boom in the late 1980's and early 1990's. 
 In 1989 to 1991 alone, five high-rise headquarters towers were completed downtown, financed primarily by locally based savings and loan associations. The subsequent contraction of the savings and loan industry left downtown San Diego with millions of square feet of unused office space. 
More than two million square feet emptied out during a single 12-month period, according to Bradford Perry, vice president of Burnham Real Estate Services. Through much of the decade, more than 20 percent of the office space downtown was empty.
The rest of San Diego County's office markets, meanwhile, were rapidly expanding, particularly in the city's northern region. Fast-growing high-technology companies, primarily in the wireless communications and biotechnology sectors, preferred the "campus" environments of suburban office complexes. Law firms, accountants and other service companies migrated to the suburbs, following the new companies.
In the last 10 years, more than 15 million square feet of office space was built in the county, almost none of it downtown, said Gary London, a San Diego-based real estate analyst.
The Catellus Urban Development Group, one of the companies that announced plans to build an office tower starting this spring, originally received city approval in 1993 to build office towers as part of Santa Fe Place, a commercial and residential complex covering six city blocks near San Diego Bay. But with downtown vacancy rates soaring, the office element of the project was shelved. Part of the parcel was converted into a golf driving range.
Then, in 2000, the downtown vacancy rate fell below 10 percent for the first time in 10 years. Expecting an upturn in the market, Catellus spent $3 million to design and market the office complex. The first phase would be a 440-foot, 27-story tower with 458,000 square feet of office space, and a second 20-story tower with 373,900 square feet would follow. 
But the office project was delayed after Catellus was unable to find tenants willing to pay the $39 a square foot annually that the company needed to make the project economically feasible, said William B. Scott Jr., senior vice president for San Diego development at the Catellus Urban Development Group, which is a subsidiary of the Catellus Development Corporation, a publicly traded company based in San Francisco.
"The market was at a point where rents downtown were heading up," Mr. Scott said. "Unfortunately, the trend settled back in the other direction."
The other company that has announced plans to build an office tower, the San Diego-based Lankford & Associates, now appears closer to starting construction.
Although the company missed a spring target date after a tenant backed out, it now expects to break ground in October on a 26-story, 460-foot tower near the city's new courthouse complex, according to Robert V. Lankford, president and chief executive of Lankford & Associates.
The project, called Broadway 655, is to have 430,000 square feet of office space and 13,000 square feet of retail space, as well as a four-story residential building. Several companies have committed themselves to lease space in the project, including the law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, which has agreed to occupy 113,000 square feet in the top six floors of the tower. 
Prelease tenants are paying $36 to $38.50 a square foot annually in the Broadway tower, Mr. Lankford said. With space readily available, in recent years downtown landlords have rarely been able to get more than $30 a square foot, according to local real estate analysts.
Developers like Mr. Lankford hope a spurt of residential development downtown will help to revive the office market.
A total of 5,800 new housing units are currently in development downtown -- 1,800 planned as single-family homes and 4,000 apartments -- according to Russell T. Valone II, president of MarketPoint Realty Advisors, a San Diego-based company that tracks residential markets.
Last year, Catellus sold two parcels totaling 120,000 square feet, part of its downtown master plan, to Bosa Development of Vancouver, British Columbia, for $26.5 million. In April, Bosa started construction of a 410-foot, 39-story tower to house condominiums on one of the parcels.
Coupled with new shopping and restaurant developments, the residential development is part of the "Manhattanization" of downtown, according to Mr. London, the real estate analyst. He says increasing traffic jams on the city's northern roads will lead people to look for places where they can live and work in the same area.
"Employment-based development downtown will see a whole new set of dynamics over the next five years," Mr. London said.
Plans are also moving forward to redevelop the southeastern portion of downtown around the construction of a new ballpark to house the San Diego Padres. After several legal challenges, construction has resumed on the stadium, which is expected to be completed in 2004.
Two low-rise office complexes are in development near the site of the new baseball park. Almost 100,000 square feet of the space is already preleased, according to Mr. Perry of Burnham Real Estate Services, which oversees the leasing and marketing of the ballpark area's office space controlled by JMI Realty, owned by John Moores, the majority owner of the Padres.
But the city has been frustrated in its efforts to encourage high-rise office development. "We would much rather see high-rise than low-rise or uneconomical use of the land," said Bradley Richter, principal planner for the Center City Development Corporation, the city's downtown redevelopment agency.
Despite picturesque bayfront locations, San Diego developers have found it difficult to persuade companies from other areas to relocate downtown. About a year ago, Sun Microsystems, the maker of computer networking equipment and software based in Santa Clara, Calif., was expected to take more than a million square feet of downtown office space, but it dropped the plan when the economy changed.
"We're not seeing a lot of interest in a new migration to the market in the whole county, not just downtown," Mr. Lankford said.
In the face of this lack of activity, downtown business owners, including Catellus and Lankford, have banded together with local economic development agencies to undertake a new marketing effort. The group will focus on trying to attract companies from other metropolitan areas to downtown.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.; 
Mall in Need Is Provided A Face-Lift For $500,000

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Since the Wykagyl Shopping Center opened half a century ago on North Avenue in the northern section of New Rochelle, it has always looked much the same -- until very recently. Now the shopping center has been given a makeover that seeks, with minimum interference to the operation of the stores, to update its look in a striking way. 
 The old North Avenue train station has long since gone and malls and shopping centers have sprung up nearby, but people from the neighborhood have continued to patronize the 25,000-square-foot shopping center. The property has always been profitable, according to Jean Minskoff Grant, who manages the mall with her husband, Francis T. Grant. But several years ago, Ms. Grant mentioned to a neighbor, Wendy Evans Joseph, who owns Wendy Evans Joseph Architecture in Manhattan, that the mall looked tired. Then in 2000 Ms. Joseph's firm was given the go-ahead for the $500,000 makeover. 
 Their design produced what Robert G. Furno, an architect in the firm, described as "architecture as advertising." 
Along with a new entry pylon with signs, the architects added an aluminum facade and they redesigned the roof-mounted lighting system with 28 rooftop high-intensity metal halide lights that go on and off automatically, thus providing additional security, safety and unobtrusive advertising, illuminating the store signs. The lighting system, which cost $25,000, will pay for itself in about six years through the savings compared with the cost of incandescent lighting fixtures. The sidewalks are scheduled for repaving this summer. 
But the most striking feature of the redesigned mall is the undulating anodized aluminum panels affixed to the facade of the single-story building: a series of stacked narrow 10-foot-long panels near roof level along the front running from the Starbucks at one end of the L-shaped mall to the Oshlag-Eisner Realty Corporation office at the other end. The panels are fitted over brackets attached to the facade, a process that saved on construction costs. 
Anodized aluminum was chosen, Ms. Joseph said, because "it never rusts or changes, it's lightweight, easily prefabricated and an economical choice." The use of prefabricated aluminum enabled the contractor, Lyons-Minskoff Inc. of Manhattan, to complete the makeover in a relatively short four months, she added. But it took some time to find a company that knew how to work with prefabricated aluminum before the contractor settled on We Build Inc. in Mount Vernon, N.Y.
The changes were made without requiring any work on the interiors of the existing buildings, which would have been expensive and time-consuming, and the center remained open while the work was being done. Rather than change the individual lettering on each of the eight existing stores, which include a cleaner, a pizzeria, an Italian restaurant, a clothing store for women and girls, a toy store and a combination greengrocer and deli, the architects suggested that the stores retain their original lettering. (A ninth store is empty, awaiting a tenant.) "Changing the lettering would have been too much of a cliche for such a radical design, so we encouraged people to do things their own way," Mr. Furno said. 
Ms. Grant is an owner and president of the Minskoff Grant Realty and Management Corporation; her husband is chief executive. She is the granddaughter of Sam Minskoff, a noted real estate developer, whose company developed Wykagyl Shopping Center and many apartment buildings, office buildings and shopping centers in New York and its suburbs, as well as in Baltimore, Detroit and Philadelphia. The Minskoffs also built the Minskoff Theater on Broadway.
While this is Joseph Architecture's first shopping center, the eight-employee firm has designed a variety of projects in its six years of existence. One notable effort was Ms. Joseph's design of a pedestrian bridge over 63rd Street, linking the residential and scientific areas of the Rockefeller University campus in Manhattan. It is the only cantilevered bridge in New York City, she said, and its cables are parallel, in what is known as a harp arrangement. The bridge's design has won awards from the American Institute of Architects, the Engineering Society, Business Week/Architectural Record and Construction News magazine.
If it were up to Frances Eisner, the president of the Oshlang-Eisner Realty Corporation, who has been a tenant in the mall since 1961, Joseph Architecture would also win awards for what she praised as its "futuristic" makeover of the Wykagyl Shopping Center.
"They took an undistinguished shopping center and made it into something that's part of the contemporary world," Mrs. Eisner said, "and that's very appealing to me."

HEADLINE: Sharon's Domestic Battle: A Gamble 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, May 21 

 BODY:
As a soldier, Ariel Sharon had a reputation for defying odds and orders, brashly gambling on his own judgment and sometimes losing as big as, at other times, he won.
 Late Monday night, he gambled again, astonishing ministers of a scrupulously religious Sephardic party by kicking them out of his government despite their importance to his coalition. Mr. Sharon acted after the party, Shas, voted against his proposed emergency economic package, intended to address a budget deficit caused in large measure by the military offensive he recently ordered in the West Bank. 
 Mr. Sharon also shoved out deputy ministers of a smaller party, United Torah Judaism, that had also opposed his budget plan. The plan was narrowly defeated in the Parliament. 
Defying common political wisdom, which predicted a face-saving compromise, Mr. Sharon continued tonight to swat aside any suggestion of a deal. He was said to have instructed supporters not to take calls from Shas members seeking a compromise to stay in the government. The dismissals do not go into effect until Wednesday.
Mr. Sharon's brinkmanship was sure to impress Israelis as brave, political analysts said, but it also threatened to leave his government with barely enough certain votes in the Parliament to stave off new elections.
If Mr. Sharon becomes embroiled in a fight for political survival, efforts by the Bush administration, Saudi Arabia and other governments to press for peace here would probably be stymied for months.
His dismissal of the ministers was consistent with Mr. Sharon's take-it-or-leave-it approach to being prime minister. Just in the last two months, he has conducted Israel's biggest military operation in 20 years; defied the United Nations; defied his own party's central leadership, and resisted pressure from the Bush administration. 
The long-term consequences of these actions are far from certain, but for now Palestinian attacks on Israelis have subsided, Palestinian criticism of Yasir Arafat has grown and Mr. Sharon's popularity among Israelis has soared.
"It was very courageous to make such a decision," Moshe Lissak, a sociologist at Hebrew University, said of Mr. Sharon's treatment of Shas. "Shas is a party which actually brought him most of his votes, beyond the Likud," which is Mr. Sharon's party.
Just over a week ago, Mr. Sharon rejected a decision by the Likud's central committee to oppose any Palestinian state west of the Jordan River, though he is in no hurry to create such a state himself. Earlier, he successfully beat back a proposed United Nations mission of inquiry into the fighting in the Jenin refugee camp in April. He said the planned investigation was biased.
Mr. Sharon resisted the Bush administration's calls for a withdrawal, and Israeli troops are still operating in Palestinian-controlled territory in the West Bank.
Rather than easing Israel's blockade of Palestinian areas, Mr. Sharon is tightening it, using barbed wire and restricted permits to limit dramatically Palestinians' movement through the West Bank. On April 4, President Bush declared, "Israel should take immediate action to ease closures and allow peaceful people to go back to work."
Mr. Lissak said that the public would overwhelmingly support the treatment of Shas, because, although Shas presents itself as the guardian of the poor, it is viewed as a blinkered interest group, jealously protecting state subsidies for its constituency.
Shas broke with Mr. Sharon over his plans to reduce subsidies for families with more than two children. Devout Jewish families tend to have many children.
The Parliament was expected to vote again on Wednesday on the budget measure, and Mr. Sharon indicated that he would then permit negotiations with the renegade parties.
There was a palpable sense of pleasure among some politicians over the humbling of Shas, a pivotal swing party that helped bring down the previous prime minister, Ehud Barak. "We'll get along without Shas," said Zeev Boim, the Likud whip in the Parliament.
Asher Arian, a political scientist at Haifa University and the City University of New York, predicted that Mr. Sharon would ultimately reach a deal to hold on to Shas. "What we know is that no government in Israel ever fell over budgetary matters," he said.
"The pivotal party in Israeli politics today is Shas," he added. "You cannot really have a stable long-term coalition without them."
Although it is in dismal condition, the economy is not the political trump card here that it is in the United States. Even when only a small minority of the public has expressed approval of Mr. Sharon's handling of the economy, large majorities have approved of his overall performance. Here, it is a prime minister's handling of security that determines if his popularity, and his government, rises or falls.
Without Shas, Mr. Sharon would be more dependent on the restive, left-leaning Labor party to sustain his government, and it might break with him over his more hawkish policies.
"He knows that he needs the support of Shas in the confrontation with the Palestinians," Mr. Lissak said. Mr. Sharon's Likud allies were on the prowl today for other potential members to bolster the coalition. One possible new partner was Shinui, a secular centrist party.
Mr. Sharon's government has been an uneasy assortment of unlikely partners, ranging from Labor, which supports an eventual Palestinian state, to the National Religious Party, which represents the interests of settlers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
For 14 months, Mr. Sharon has been successful in sustaining this coalition, partly by arguing that national unity is now a strategic necessity. But with the fighting having eased somewhat for the moment, ministers might feel freer to break with the prime minister.
In brief remarks today, Mr. Sharon suggested that he had little patience for opponents. "Look, we are facing a difficult campaign, both a difficult security campaign and an economic campaign," he said, while touring a navy base in Haifa.
Before this dispute, Mr. Sharon had a governing coalition of 82 seats in the 120-member Parliament. Shas's departure would cost him 17 seats, and the loss of United Torah Judaism another 5, reducing him to just 60 seats. That could leave him just a seat away from losing a no-confidence vote, which would force new elections.
After suggesting this morning that he was interested in reconciling, Eli Yishai, Shas's leader, sounded a tougher note on television tonight. "If the prime minister wants elections, we'll go to elections," he said.
In a remark that echoed, perhaps unconsciously, opposition criticism of the government's approach to security, Silvan Shalom, the finance minister, complained this morning about the selfishness of those who opposed the economic package. "Everyone who today tries to maintain his own little God-given plot of land will see that there will be nothing left to watch over," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, right, in Parliament on Monday. He removed a key party from his government after its members voted against his emergency economic package, intended to address Israel's budget deficit. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: 2 Retailers' Earnings Are Up 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Two big retailers, Home Depot Inc. and the Target Corporation, said yesterday that their quarterly earnings rose as the companies reined in expenses and kept inventory levels low.
 Still, shares of Home Depot fell 7 percent on concerns that the company did not raise its forecast for the current quarter or full year and that sales at stores open at least a year did not meet some expectations. 
 Home Depot ordered goods through its headquarters instead of nine regional offices, while Target controlled inventories to avoid price cuts. Retailers are looking for ways to trim expenses amid concerns that consumer spending, having kept up through the recession, may moderate. 
"The retailers are cautious like the rest of us and are putting particular emphasis on controlling inventory," said James Luke, who manages the $200 million BB&T Large Company Growth Fund.
Net income at Home Depot rose 35 percent, to $856 million, or 36 cents a share, from $632 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter ended May 5 increased 17 percent, to $14.3 billion, from $12.2 billion.
Profit at Target climbed 36 percent, to $345 million, or 38 cents a share, from $254 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the period ended May 4, including credit card fees, increased 15 percent, to $9.59 billion, from $8.33 billion. 
Shares of Home Depot, which is based in Atlanta, dropped $3.60 yesterday to $44.90, after the company reported that same-store sales rose 5 percent. Some analysts had expected a gain as great as 8 percent. 
Same-store sales are expected to rise 2 percent to 4 percent this quarter, executives said in a conference call with investors. Home Depot said it expected to meet a 47-cent second-quarter profit estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.
Shares of Target, formerly Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, fell $1.16 yesterday, to $41.54. The company said it expected to meet estimates this quarter and added that profit for the year would be $1.80, or 1 cent less than analysts' average estimate.
Total retail sales at Target rose 14 percent, to $9.34 billion, including a 19 percent gain at the Target Stores division. Sales at stores open at least a year increased 5.2 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Approves Aid Resumption for Yugoslavia 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it was ending a freeze on economic aid to Yugoslavia. The aid was suspended on March 31 because of Belgrade's failure to cooperate fully with the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said that in light of increased cooperation between Belgrade and the court, he had approved a resumption of aid. The country, now made up of Serbia and Montenegro, has been devastated by years of war. 
 At stake is $40 million in aid this year. More important is the resumption of support for Belgrade in international lending groups, where Washington's vote is often crucial. Only last week, for example, the United States voted in the International Monetary Fund against a loan to Yugoslavia; the no vote was required because of the aid freeze.
The secretary spoke to reporters after a visit from Zoran Djindjic, prime minister of Serbia, and the Yugoslav foreign minister, Goran Svilanovic. "We take this as an acknowledgment for what we did in the last year and a half," Mr. Svilanovic said. "This will continue."
The two men are reformers who took office after the ouster of President Slobodan Milosevic in 2000. He is now on trial in The Hague.
Secretary Powell said he had acted "on the basis of new laws that have been passed in Belgrade, voluntary surrenders that have taken place and indictments that have been issued to those who remain still outside the jurisdiction of the tribunal."
Last month the Belgrade government told suspects wanted for atrocities in the Balkan wars to surrender or face arrest. Six heeded the call; about 18 are at large.
Two of those still wanted are the wartime Bosnian Serb leader, Dr. Radovan Karadzic, and his military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic. Their whereabouts are not publicly known.
But Mr. Djindjic appeared optimistic that there would be further action soon. "Now the police should do its job and find these people and transfer them to The Hague, and I'm sure it will happen very soon," he said.
Human Rights Watch criticized the resumption of aid, saying Belgrade was still hindering the tribunal in The Hague by failing to provide archive materials to the prosecution.
