HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Shares Fall a 2nd Day; Home Depot Outlook Is a Factor

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Shares slumped for the second consecutive session yesterday after a disappointing profit forecast from Home Depot and renewed worries about the possibility of more attacks on the United States. 
 Stocks touched lows for the session after a law enforcement official said New York City might issue alerts about possible terrorist threats over the Memorial Day weekend. 
 Investors are also nervous about slack corporate profits and high share prices after last week's rally that drove technology stocks up almost 9 percent -- the biggest one-week gain this year. 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 123.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,105.71. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 12 points, or 1.1 percent, at 1,079.88. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index slipped 37.41 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,664.18. 
Merrill Lynch was up 47 cents, to $43.85, after it agreed to pay $100 million to settle charges it misled investors by tailoring its research to please investment banking clients. 
Home Depot fell $3.53, or 7.3 percent, to $44.90. Home Depot posted quarterly earnings yesterday that rose 35 percent, aided by cost-cutting and an early start to the gardening season. But investors worried that Home Depot's rate of growth was slowing, compared with its rival Lowe's, which said on Monday that it expected to top analysts' estimates for the year. Lowe's stock fell 67 cents, to $46.13.
"Home Depot is a big catalyst," said Michael O'Hare, head of block trading at Lehman Brothers. "It was a disappointment, and it's taking the wind out of retailers, which have driven this market." 
Terrorism fears weighed on stocks, as the New York warning showed. Investors said more attacks could hurt consumer confidence, leading to less spending and travel, which in turn could hurt corporate profits. 
Ford Motor emerged as a bright spot yesterday, gaining 85 cents, to $17.58. Merrill Lynch raised its investment opinion on Ford and said that its turnaround plan, which calls for $7 billion in profits by mid-decade, is on track. --------------------

Treasury Prices Increase
By Bloomberg News
 Bonds gained for the fourth day in five as stocks fell and investors sought safety in Treasuries.
Demand for government debt has picked up as traders scale back expectations as to when the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to keep inflation in check. 
By late in the day, the 10-year note rose 11/32, to a price of 97 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.15 percent from 5.20 percent.
The 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 95 29/32. Its yield increased to 5.67 percent from 5.70 percent.

HEADLINE: Bill to Raise City Revenues Stalls in Albany 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN and DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
A bill that would net the city $400 million through an increase in the cigarette tax to $1.50 a pack and other measures is stalled in Albany until at least next week.
 Last week, legislative leaders presented the city's package as a sure thing, saying it would be passed early this week and enumerating the measures that would be included, from refinancing debt to raising parking violation fines. 
 But the bill has not materialized, and today, as a more combustible battle over control of the schools and money for Lower Manhattan played out, the reasons seemed many.
Some lawmakers suggested that the City Council, in a disagreement with the mayor over the city budget, was holding things up. There clearly were bitter words exchanged between the Republican leaders of the Senate and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly. Others suggested that the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, was holding up the tax package because he was unhappy with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over the breakdown in talks for control of the schools. 
Assembly officials began the day by suggesting that reporters should go to a noon news conference with Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, prepared to ask if his views had changed on certain aspects of the city's wish list, the intimation being that the Senate was holding up the bill.
But Senator Bruno said that his position had not changed. He placed the blame for the delay on both the Assembly and the City Council. The Assembly has asked for a home rule message -- in effect a formal request that the measures be passed -- from the Council.
Senator Bruno suggested that the request was simply a stalling tactic. "We don't think we need a home rule message to do what the city would like to have done. And we're prepared to act on it, but the Assembly is not prepared to act on it and I sure hope that they have not tied that in any way with anything else because that would be a disservice to the people of the city."
He added: "We haven't changed our position. We're waiting to hear from the city."
Mr. Silver responded angrily later in the day to accusations that he was the impediment. "In fact, it is Senator Bruno who's angry at the mayor and has held it up today," Mr. Silver said. He added that the sticking point was whether Lower Manhattan should be included in a federal economic stimulus package."Senator Bruno, through his agents, objects to that, and that's what is holding up the bill," Mr. Silver said.
As for the home-rule message, Council officials have steadfastly maintained that Albany must act first. Christopher Policano, the Council's chief spokesman, said that the Council's wishes had been clear for months. The Council has proposed several new taxes that the mayor has adamantly refused to ask Albany to approve in an election year, including an educational surcharge on the personal income tax, a liquor sales tax and a restoration of the commuter tax.
Weeks ago, Mr. Policano said, state officials announced an agreement on a budget package that included "certain details that need a home rule message." But not until the package is introduced as legislation in Albany, he insisted.
Still, Senate and Assembly leaders said they were looking for a less formal list from the mayor and the Council.
But the mayor's laundry list has been on the table for months. One city official involved in working with state legislators said: "We know what we want in the bill. They know what they want in the bill. This is an issue between the two houses. It has nothing to do with us. We're waiting for a bill print.".

HEADLINE: University Announces Ban on Fraternities and Sororities 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Benjamin Klein was a 21-year-old junior from Putney, Vt., majoring in economics at Alfred University in western New York State. He sang, he was the principal second violinist in the university orchestra, and was a member of one of the university's eight fraternities, Zeta Beta Tau. In February, his body was found in a creek behind the town post office. The university suspended his fraternity as it looked into reports that fraternity brothers had beaten him.
 Although the medical examiner said that his death was not a direct result of a beating, the incident led to a decision by Alfred University's trustees to examine the college's fraternity and sorority system. Last Friday, after receiving a sharply critical report from a task force they appointed, the trustees voted to end fraternities and sororities at Alfred. 
 "The Greek system is beyond repair," said Robert McComsey, the chairman of Alfred's board. "From this report, it became clear to all of us that our Greek system simply does not contribute to the type of learning environment we want at Alfred University."
With the vote, announced yesterday, Alfred became one of a small but growing number of colleges that have banned Greek life on campus. Critics say the fraternity system leads to drinking, hazing and other dangerous practices that sometimes result in death. Many campus officials also say that the fraternity and sorority houses are antithetical to the educational climate they want to create.
Some campuses, like Bowdoin and Colby, have eliminated Greek houses entirely, according to Alfred officials. Others, like Dartmouth, are still grappling with systems they would like to change.
"It takes a determined and courageous group of trustees to do this," said Alfred's president, Charles M. Edmondson, "because Greek alums are vocal."
Alfred University is in Alfred, N.Y., a small town near the Pennsylvania border about 75 miles south of Rochester. There, as on many campuses, Greek life was once central to the social life of many students. In the mid-1960's, more than 40 percent of the students belonged to a fraternity or sorority.
But the role of fraternities and sororities at Alfred has dwindled considerably. Today, only about 200 students -- about 10 percent of undergraduates -- belong to Greek societies, and only about half of that number actually live in the houses, which have been poorly maintained and are undersubscribed.
But despite their shrinking presence, the houses were a continuing source of problems, university officials said. In 1992, Alfred assigned an assistant dean of students to oversee the houses. Even that did not help. After Mr. Klein's death, the board initiated its study.
In the spring semester alone, 6 of Alfred's 12 Greek organizations (8 fraternities and 4 sororities) were sanctioned for violating university regulations.
As the task force studied Greek life at Alfred it found a variety of problems. The students in Alfred's Greek houses tended to drink more, and more often, than other Alfred students, and their overall academic standing was both lower than the campus average and lower than their SAT scores and high school grades might have suggested. (There were exceptions, the task force said.)
"The students were voting with their feet by not joining Greek houses as much," said Gene Bernstein, an Alfred graduate and former chairman of the Alfred board, who led the task force. "But of more concern to us on the board was the fact that despite the decline, the violations of the university's policies on alcohol and hazing were continuing and increasing."
Last month, the Allegany County district attorney's office announced that Mr. Klein had been the victim of an assault but that his death was not a homicide and could not be directly attributed to the assault. The office said it anticipated that charges would be brought in connection with the assault when the police completed their investigation.
Although five of the eight members of the task force had participated in Greek organizations themselves at Alfred or elsewhere, they concluded that efforts to reform Alfred's fraternities and sororities had been unsuccessful. Dr. Bernstein, a semiretired business executive with a doctorate in English literature, who formerly taught at Notre Dame, said that by the group's fifth meeting, in late April, a straw vote showed that everyone had reached the same conclusion, that the system had to be closed down.
"Emotionally, it was difficult, because many of us had fond memories of the experiences we had had in Greek houses," Dr. Bernstein said. "But on a factual, intellectual level, it was not hard to reach the conclusion we did."
Not everyone applauds the trustees' decision. Hank Nuwer, the author of "Broken Pledges" (1990, Longstreet Press), a book that examined the death of another Alfred University student in a fraternity hazing incident in 1978, argues that even when a university ends its involvement with Greek houses, the problems do not disappear.
"When you get rid of Greek organizations, they are going to stay there in some other form," Mr. Nuwer said. "They go underground. The problem doesn't go away. It's just that the liability for the university goes away."
Mr. Nuwer said there had been public reports of at least 84 deaths connected with fraternities since January 2000. But he added that he would have preferred to see the university work harder to reform the Greek culture, despite a decade of unsuccessful efforts.
One Alfred fraternity leader who spoke on the condition that he and his fraternity not be named, said that he was disappointed by Alfred's action, but not surprised.
"This is the easiest way for them to get rid of their liability," he said. "But when you ban Greek houses, all you do is push them underground, and they're going to get worse because then there's nobody to watch them."
He said the university should have enforced its policies more strongly and provided more leadership training to Greek officials. "This," he said, "was definitely the wrong path to take."

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: THE BIOTERROR THREAT; 
Anthrax Scare at Bank; Lie Tests at Army Labs

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
Still looking for clues about who sent deadly anthrax through the mail last year, federal investigators plan to give lie detector tests to workers at two Army laboratories that handle anthrax, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.
 There have been no confirmed anthrax attacks for more than six months, but tests conducted this week detected anthrax in the mail at the World Bank and at the International Monetary Fund here. Officials suspect that these results are false positives, but the mail was sent for further tests. 
 The F.B.I. spokeswoman said the lie detector examinations would be given to workers at laboratories at Fort Detrick in Maryland and the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah. Capt. Amy Hannah, an Army spokeswoman, said soldiers and Army employees were expected to cooperate.
The plans for tests were first reported by ABC News.
Law enforcement officials have said they have no prime suspect in the anthrax crimes. Five people died and more than a dozen others became ill from anthrax spores that apparently leaked from letters.
Experts in microbiology have advanced the theory that the culprit is a scientist, technician or contractor who gained expertise in anthrax from working in a military laboratory.
At the World Bank, Caroline Anstey, the chief spokeswoman, said that all mail is routinely tested and that a preliminary test on Monday came up with a positive result. A more sophisticated test was negative, but as a precaution, the mail was sent to a private testing laboratory, she said. Results are expected on Wednesday or Thursday.
Thousands of workers who have offices that share an air-conditioning system with the mail room were told not to go to their offices until the matter was resolved. They are working elsewhere, Ms. Anstey said.
At the monetary fund, mail that tested negative on Friday was retested on Monday before it was distributed inside headquarters here because the fund is so closely linked in people's minds to the World Bank, Francisco Baker, a spokesman, said. The new tests had a positive finding, and that mail was sent with the World Bank mail for further tests, Mr. Baker said.
The officials said workers were not being advised to take antibiotics.
Early this month, mail at the Federal Reserve Board tested positive for anthrax. Follow-up testing is not complete, but no other evidence of anthrax has been found, David Skidmore, a spokesman, said.

HEADLINE: Nonprofit Sector of City Economy Is Fastest-Growing Source of Jobs, a Study Reports 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The nonprofit sector is the fastest-growing source of jobs in New York City, according to a new study of the sector's economic role. 
 The study shows that unlike other business sectors, the nonprofit sector has been a steady and growing source of jobs for a decade, a finding confirmed by economists and labor analysts. 
 The study, which is to be released today, found that the 9,078 members of the New York City nonprofit sector reporting to the state and federal governments put more than $43 billion into the city's economy in 2000, accounting for 11.5 percent of economic activity in the city, and employed 528,000 people, or 14 percent of the city's work force.
For the purposes of the study, the nonprofit sector is defined as including schools, hospitals, zoos, museums and the like, but not foundations, religious organizations, unions or other groups that serve only their members. In other surveys of work force strength, hospitals, almost all of which are nonprofit institutions, are lumped together with for-profit businesses and tracked as health services. Private schools and universities are similarly put into a category called educational services. 
While the city's employment as a whole grew only 4 percent in the 1990's, employment in the nonprofit units surveyed increased 25 percent, the study found. The biggest job sector is wholesale and retail sales, followed by government employment, nonprofit groups and the influential finance-insurance-real estate field, the study found. 
"This is a huge economic engine in the city, and better yet, it's stable," said John E. Seley, a professor at City University of New York who compiled the study with Prof. Julian Wolpert of Princeton University. "It can't be easily tempted to relocate to New Jersey with tax incentives, it's not beholden to swings in the stock market, and it is growing much faster than any other sector." 
James P. Brown, a labor market analyst at the State Department of Labor, discussing the increase in jobs, said, "A variety of trends have favored those industries that nonprofits tend to dominate." 
Economic and social trends have increased the demand for private schools and universities. A larger and larger portion of the city's gross domestic product is being spent on health care and social services. The push to move people off the welfare rolls and into jobs has increased demand for job training that is largely provided to the nonprofit sector, which is also a source of many entry-level jobs.
The study, which was financed primarily by the Atlantic Philanthropies, a foundation that often underwrites studies of the nonprofit sector, is an effort to make policy makers and residents more aware of the role the nonprofit sector plays in the city economy. 
Quantifying the expansion of the nonprofit sector is a rare exercise, and some argue that it is not even a sector. "Nonprofits are not an industry," Mr. Brown said. 
The last comparable effort to define the sector came in 1990, but it is difficult to make comparisons between that study and this one. 
The 1990 study placed the sector's contribution to the city economy at $32 billion, but it included a variety of organizations that are left out of the new study, including unions and foundations that are membership organizations or do not provide services directly. 
The report and its findings have caught the eye of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his officials. His office, knowing that it will fall largely to the nonprofit sector to cope with the effect of the projected $5 billion budget gap, has ordered 30 copies of the study.
Their interest contrasts starkly with that of Giuliani administration, which alienated the nonprofit sector by eliminating its traditional access to city commissioners, giving city contracts to for-profit service providers and being notably slow to make contract payments.
In addition to the 528,000 people working in the nonprofit sector, more than 99,000 people serve on nonprofit boards and 342,000 volunteer their services. 
Roughly 2.2 million people have some contact with the nonprofit sector each day, the study showed, and that does not include the 3 million people who listen to public television or radio or those who pass through religious institutions.
The nonprofit sector is diverse, and includes the Museo del Barrio, Lenox Hill Hospital, the Chinese American Planning Council and Friends and Relatives of the Institutionalized Aged Inc.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Letter Says Labor Deal Was Never Very Close

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As negotiations between baseball club owners and players for a new labor contract remain stalemated, debate continues to boil over the fallout from secret talks the two sides held during a three-month period in the first half of last year.
 Players, fueled by information from their union leaders, have been critical of Commissioner Bud Selig, saying that before he yanked the owners' representatives out of the 2001 talks, the negotiators were close enough that a deal could very likely have been achieved by the All-Star Game last July. Selig has repeatedly and vehemently rejected the idea that a deal was in the works. 
 A letter that Rob Manfred, the owners' chief labor lawyer, wrote to Donald Fehr, the head of the union, last December appears to support Selig's position on the status of those secret talks. 
Manfred wrote the four-page letter, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times yesterday, to provide details of a proposal Selig gave to Fehr at a meeting in Milwaukee last Dec. 3.
In the letter, dated Dec. 14, Manfred reminded Fehr that throughout their talks last April, May and June he and Paul Beeston, then Major League Baseball's chief operating officer, emphasized the need for the players to address "three key issues": a significant increase in revenue-sharing, a meaningful luxury tax and a worldwide amateur draft.
The players had made a proposal June 20, Manfred recalled, noting that it had been suggested "that the proposal put us close to an agreement." But he disputed that characterization.
"It is, however, both inaccurate and unfair," he wrote, "to suggest that the proposal was a major step forward, let alone one that put the parties close to an agreement." The proposal, Manfred wrote, "addressed only one of the three major issues that we have consistently identified as central to the negotiations. Your proposal, of course, was limited to the topic of revenue-sharing."
Fehr, Manfred reminded him, had said he saw "no need" for a luxury tax of any type. And in its proposal on revenue-sharing, Manfred said, the union proposed a different distribution method from the one "the vast majority of the clubs prefer." Furthermore, he said, the union proposal increased the amount of local revenue shared -- $166 million in 2001 -- by only $15 million to $20 million.
"Given the magnitude of the industry's problems," Manfred wrote, "such a small increase in revenue-sharing, in a format unacceptable to the clubs, left us with few options."
In the letter, Manfred reminded Fehr that he had told him the previous spring that the clubs could proceed with negotiations "directed at an early agreement" only if the union was prepared to deal with the luxury-tax issue.
Further confusing matters, at apparently the same time the players thought an early deal was possible, Beeston was telling Selig and the owners that he believed he could achieve the goals of a blue-ribbon panel report, a management official said.
The panel, appointed by Selig, issued a report on baseball economics in July 2000. Selig based his proposal last December on that report, including an increase in revenue-sharing to 50 percent of the clubs' local revenue and a 50 percent tax on portions of payrolls over $98 million.
Beeston, who left Major League Baseball earlier this year, has declined to talk about the negotiations or his role in them.
In his letter to Fehr, Manfred also reiterated Selig's offer that if a new labor agreement could be promptly negotiated, he would consider recommending to the clubs that their plan to eliminate two teams for the 2002 season be deferred for a year.
Selig subsequently called off the contraction plan for this season in the face of legal challenges to it. The old collective bargaining agreement expired last Nov. 7, the day after the owners voted to eliminate two teams. Negotiations since then have been held sporadically with much of the negotiators' time consumed by the union's challenge to contraction.

HEADLINE: In Much of Connecticut, Go-Go 90's Went Nowhere, Data Show 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 21 

 BODY:
Despite the economic boom during most of the decade, Connecticut's median household income fell slightly between 1990 and 2000, according to Census data released today.
 Unlike the rest of New England and most other states, where household income rose in the 1990's, Connecticut's dropped by $213, to $53,935. 
 Median household income is only one measure of economic well-being, and while household income fell in 102 of Connecticut's 169 cities and towns, the state's per-capita figure rose by 9 percent, to $28,766, easily the highest in the nation.
The slight decline in median income combined with the increase in per-capita income illuminates Connecticut's growing income disparity between its poorest and wealthiest residents and, by extension, its withering cities and blooming suburbs, economic analysts said. 
"If you have per-capita income going up and median income going down and poverty going up, it sort of necessarily means that the rich are getting richer, the bottom half aren't doing that well," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College who did the income analyses, adjusted for inflation, for The New York Times.
"It certainly says that there is a bigger disparity between the suburbs and cities," he said. "Wealthy places are getting more wealthy."
The figures showed that income fell in the state's largest cities, Bridgeport, New Haven, Hartford, Stamford and Waterbury, while individual and family poverty rates increased.
In Hartford, for instance, one of the nation's poorest cities, median household income dropped 15.8 percent, to $24,820 while poverty grew steadily, afflicting nearly one in three city residents. In New Haven, median household income fell 13 percent, to $29,604, while the poverty rate increased, affecting one in four residents.
Although the decrease seemed small, Connecticut's $213 decline in median income during a decade in which many states saw the figure go up left some economists and demographers surprised or skeptical.
"Wow," said Steven Lanza, executive editor of the Connecticut Economy, a quarterly produced at the University of Connecticut. "That's a stunning number. It really shows the extent to which the economy of Connecticut got hammered by the great recession of the early 1990's, where the state lost the heart of its manufacturing sector."
Indeed, the most severe income declines occurred in Hartford County, where the state's once-mighty insurance and financial services industry were decimated by layoffs, declines in the real estate market and corporate mergers by out-of-state companies.
Hartford County, in fact, was the only county where household and family income fell during the 1990's, the Census data shows. Per-capita income also grew the least, by 5.7 percent, compared to 13 percent in prosperous Fairfield County, where the stock market's historic run in the 1990's kept incomes among the highest in the nation.
Median family income also rose in Fairfield County, by 2.6 percent, to $65,521, the data show.
But even in wealthy regions like Fairfield County, median household income rose by only $500 in the 1990's, to $65,249.
"This is the richest state in the country," said Stan McMillan, manager of the University of Connecticut's Center for Economic Analysis. "We had the largest run-up in the stock market in United States history and yet we're looking at increases in median household income of only 1 or 2 percent?"
But Fred Carstensen, the director of the center, said the drop was to be expected, perhaps.
"When you're as rich as Connecticut is, it's hard to maintain the growth," said Mr. Carstensen, who is also a University of Connecticut economics professor. "On a lot of indicators, you're going to fall back."
Gov. John G. Rowland, through a spokesman, said today that the growing income disparity was no surprise. "With the stock market performance over the last several years, it's not surprising that the wealthy would have gotten wealthier," said Chris Cooper, Mr. Rowland's press secretary.
Over all, Fairfield County grew -- by income level, population and number and type of immigrants -- by considerable margins.
Towns like Darien, Wilton and Easton each recorded median household income gains of 20 percent or more (beating famously wealthy Greenwich by about 4 percent).
The county's 7 percent population growth, to 882,567 people, was fueled by a large influx of Asian and Hispanic immigrants.
Nearly one of four county residents speak a language other than English, up from one of five.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Americas: Argentina: Reserves Tapped For Debt 

BYLINE:  By Larry Rohter (NYT) 

 BODY:
 With a deadline today to make the first installment on repayment of a $2.5 billion loan from the World Bank, the Ministry of the Economy has elected to dip into Argentina's foreign reserves. 
The reserves, which have fallen nearly 20 percent this year, to about $11.7 billion, are currently at their lowest level in more than seven years. The government made the decision to use almost $800 million in reserves, rather than default on the loan and be denied further credits, only after the United States and the International Monetary Fund strongly urged President Eduardo Duhalde to abandon an earlier plan to ask neighboring countries for a bridge loan to make the payment. Larry Rohter (NYT)

HEADLINE: China Called Close to Deal To Import Natural Gas 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 21 

 BODY:
The Chinese government is close to concluding its first big contract to import liquefied natural gas, in a deal worth at least $9 billion that will not only help turn the Chinese energy industry into a global player but will also have strategic and commercial implications for all of East Asia.
 Three big consortiums, each including one of the giant international energy companies, have emerged as finalists, offering to ship natural gas from Indonesia, Australia or the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar. The winner may gain a long-term advantage in what is expected to be one of the world's largest markets for natural gas, several people involved in the negotiations said. 
 Chinese officials have said a final decision could come this month. But as it has sometimes done in the past, China may instead winnow the three finalists to two this month and then conduct another round of bidding, in the hope of extracting even better terms. 
The winning consortium and country will be locked in a large-scale commercial embrace with China for a long time. The initial contract being let by the Chinese is for roughly $450 million worth of liquefied natural gas to be delivered each year to Shenzhen, a city adjacent to Hong Kong, for 20 to 25 years.
At 3.2 million tons a year, the contract would account for nearly 3 percent of all internationally traded liquefied natural gas. China is trying to wean itself off high-pollution coal in favor of cleaner-burning gas, and its officials have said they may pursue two more contracts for another four million tons a year.
China is demanding that its offshore drilling and production company, CNOOC Ltd., be granted an equity stake in whatever gas field becomes the winning supplier for the current contract. Together with the recent purchase of Indonesian oil fields for $591 million from Repsol-YPF of Spain, the natural gas deal is part of the Chinese company's transformation into a truly international energy company with broad ambitions across Asia.
CNOOC Ltd. is 70.6 percent owned by the Chinese government; the remaining 29.4 percent of its stock trades publicly in New York and Hong Kong. Merrill Lynch is advising the company on this gas deal.
While the United States has been active in trying to influence where Central Asian oil pipelines are built, hoping to route them through friendly countries and away from Iran, Washington has been silent on the bidding for the Chinese gas project. All three finalist nations are American allies.
The bidding has attracted particular public attention in Australia, where Prime Minister John Howard is trying to build closer political, strategic and commercial ties with China. Mr. Howard flew to Beijing today, and will personally present to Chinese leaders on Wednesday his case for why China should choose a group of companies, including Royal Dutch/Shell and BHP Billiton, that are now extracting gas from Australia's North West Shelf.
"I take the view that it's my responsibility, my job, to give it the best shot I can and to argue very strongly," Mr. Howard told reporters during a stopover in Singapore today on his way to Beijing.
But Mr. Howard noted that Australia faced a "very difficult" challenge to win the contract. Liquefied natural gas is fairly expensive to transport overseas, because it must be kept very cold and under extreme pressure in special ships. The closest gas field being offered to the Chinese government is in Indonesia; the Australian field is next, and Qatar, which is in a partnership with Exxon Mobil, is the farthest away.
BP and the Indonesian government are offering China gas from a new offshore field, mostly owned by BP, in a bay off Irian Jaya, the Indonesian half of the island of New Guinea. Oil companies traditionally have offered slightly lower prices to sign up the first customer for a new gas field, because of the risk of problems and delays.
In addition to being closest to China, BP's bid may have an advantage because the company is already in a consortium with CNOOC to build the terminal in the Shenzhen area that will receive and distribute the gas. Its disadvantage is Indonesia's record of political instability: Exxon Mobil has had trouble keeping open its liquefied natural gas operation on Sumatra, at the western end of Indonesia, because of fighting with a separatist movement there, and Irian Jaya, at the eastern end of Indonesia, also has a separatist movement. 
Analysts say it is hard to predict how the Chinese government will balance the many issues involved in the gas contract decision. "The important things from a Chinese perspective are the pricing and security of supply, the potential for expansion of the contract at competitive prices and the ability to participate in the equity of the project," said Tom Hilboldt, the director of Asian oil and gas research at Salomon Smith Barney.
The contract is meant to address a conundrum facing Chinese economic planners: How to supply enormous quantities of energy for the vast network of factories that has sprung up in Guangdong Province, up the Pearl River from Hong Kong. The province has virtually no oil, gas or coal deposits of its own; it now buys huge amounts of coal from the rest of China and oil from abroad, playing a big role in China's $10 billion annual bill for oil imports. China is building a gas pipeline across the width of the country from near its western border to Shanghai, but it will not carry enough gas to supply southern China's expected needs as well.
Coal burning has badly fouled the air in Guangdong and Hong Kong, to official embarrassment. At the same time, railroads and other resources are tied up with the increasingly difficult job of moving mountains of coal to Guangdong. "The transportation and storage capacity for coal compete with industrial capacity that could be used to bring in foreign currency," said Mark Qiu, CNOOC's chief financial officer.
Environmentalists have applauded China for trying to switch to natural gas, which contributes much less to global warming than the burning of coal.

HEADLINE: House Votes $1.3 Billion in Aid for Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
The House of Representatives voted tonight to provide $1.3 billion in economic and military aid to Afghanistan after demanding that President Bush devise a strategy to establish law and order there.
 Lawmakers of both parties said they feared that the United States's military success could be undermined if lawlessness persisted in Afghanistan. 
 The bill, to rebuild Afghanistan and combat the production of narcotics, was passed by a vote of 390 to 22. 
The money, to be made available over four years, would be used to create jobs, clear land mines, pay for education and health care, vaccinate children and revive the nation's agriculture.
"This recovery effort must be sustained in the months and years ahead," said the chief sponsor of the bill, Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Committee on International Relations. But, he emphasized, "the administration needs a coherent strategy." 
The House approved an amendment offered by Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, that calls on the president to devise "a strategy for meeting the immediate and long-term security needs of Afghanistan." The president would have 45 days to send such a plan to Congress.
"Afghanistan is in grave danger of relapsing into the very conditions of violence and warlordism that created the Taliban and attracted Al Qaeda to operate there," Mr. Lantos said. "Outside Kabul, Afghanistan continues to be a land where every thug with a rifle can set up an illegal checkpoint to extort money from travelers while the unarmed and outnumbered police cower in their makeshift headquarters."
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, supports major goals of the House bill and has hinted that he might seek more money for security assistance.
"If current trends continue in Afghanistan," Mr. Biden said on Friday, "we may soon find that our hard-won success on the battlefield has melted away with the winter snow.."
The House bill emphasizes the need to provide assistance to women and girls, disarm and demobilize Afghan warriors, and help establish the rule of lawy.
In addition, American aid would be used to suppress the cultivation of opium poppies and substitute other crops; build health clinics; coordinate efforts to treat diseases; foster the development of independent news media; promote and monitor human rights; and recruit and train teachers.
Under the bill, the United States would spend $10 million a year from 2002 to 2005 to help conduct local, regional and national elections, to foster development of political parties and to carry out a traditional Afghan assembly, or loya jirga.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Is lending money to Buffett a privilege worth paying for?

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
WARREN E. BUFFETT wants to borrow up to $287.5 million, and he thinks he should pay a negative interest rate on the money. That is, he thinks the lenders should pay him money.
 And what do the lenders get in return, aside from negative cash flow? They receive the right to buy shares in Berkshire Hathaway at a premium over the current market price. That right will be good for five years, by which time, the lenders will hope, Berkshire stock will have risen enough to make the investment a good one. 
 The offering is a private placement that was unveiled to institutional investors yesterday afternoon by Goldman, Sachs, which designed the structure. In its announcement, Berkshire Hathaway said it was "the first-ever negative-coupon security." It is being offered in a private placement only to institutional buyers. The exact pricing is expected to be disclosed today. 
Under the proposal made to investors, Berkshire would pay perhaps 3 percent a year on the bonds it is issuing. But the investor would also receive a warrant allowing the purchase of Berkshire stock.
To keep the warrant alive, investors would have to pay a higher rate, perhaps 3.75 percent, at the same time Berkshire made the interest payments. The net effect would be that Berkshire would receive a negative interest rate.
The warrant is expected to be priced at about a 12.5 percent premium over Berkshire's current stock price. The deal was disclosed after the market closed yesterday, with Berkshire shares up $300, to $77,900, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
The bonds would have a five-year life, but the holder would have the right to sell them back to Berkshire for face value on each annual anniversary of the offering. That would be expected to happen if Berkshire stock were to fall sharply. If it did, Berkshire would have borrowed money at a negative rate for the intervening period.
On the other hand, if the warrants are eventually exercised, Berkshire will have sold stock at a premium over the current market price.
Berkshire said the new securities are called Squarz (pronounced squares) but did not say just what those letters stood for. Investment banks love to copyright such names because they cannot protect financial structures from imitators if they prove to be popular.
Berkshire said it planned to borrow $250 million under the deal, with an additional $37.5 million available to cover overallotments if the deal sells well.
While a negative interest rate breaks new ground, Berkshire is far from the first company to take advantage of the combination of low market interest rates and the extraordinary volatility of the stock market. That volatility increases the value of an option to buy a stock, and that added value can offset the interest that a company would otherwise pay to borrow.
A number of companies have borrowed money at zero percent while offering warrants to buy their stock at a 30 percent premium or more over the price that is current when the bonds are issued. Berkshire is offering a lower conversion premium, which is good for the buyer, while demanding in return an effective negative interest rate.
It is able to do that because it requires periodic payments for the warrant, whereas warrants are usually sold as part of the original deal and require no additional payments.

NATIONAL A18-25

HEADLINE: Accra Journal; 
No Mosh Pit, This, but Some Enthusiasm for Aid

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana, May 21 

 BODY:
To Bono, the rock star who has made alleviating African poverty his cause, Ghana is "the birthplace of cool," a country so vibrant with its own metaphorical jazz that the right dose of aid and investment could secure it a place in the global economy. 
 To Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, Ghana's prospects are equally upbeat. But he is less focused on the rhythms of the country and more intent on having enforceable contracts and strict proof that aid is used effectively. 
 This is Stop 1 on the O'Neill-Bono Africa Tour 2002, nearly two weeks of fact-finding travel across the world's most ravaged continent by the well-starched former corporate chief executive who signs the dollar bill and the earring-laden, Grammy-collecting lead singer of U2. 
It is undoubtedly one of the strangest delegations ever to descend on Africa. ("I am definitely not Felix," Bono said en route here, referring to the more fastidious member of the Odd Couple.)
But it is also one that illustrates an expanding ideological consensus on the need to address poverty, disease, famine and conflict in Africa -- as well as the remaining gulf between left and right about how best to do it.
From Bono's perspective, the tour, which goes on to South Africa, Uganda and Ethiopia, is an opportunity to convince the Bush administration that aid to Africa is both a moral imperative and a good investment of taxpayer money. "Development assistance can be effective, and I want to show him it can be effective," he said. 
Mr. O'Neill said that the United States is committed to helping and that he has an open mind about how to do so. But he made clear that the United States would be skeptical about providing aid to countries that cannot show how they are improving standards of living. 
"The results of official development assistance have been disappointing, and many poor countries here have stayed that way, even as others have excelled," Mr. O'Neill said in a speech here today. "We have to be hardheaded and demand results: That is our responsibility to the impoverished people of Africa."
Even as Bono brings new public attention to debt relief and AIDS in Africa, many development economists and African leaders are stressing that only increased trade can bring permanent advancement. 
Bono and his advisers said they are all for expanded trade. But the singer is clearly struggling with how far to go in endorsing free-market solutions to Africa's problems. 
After a visit today to a company here that processes medical and dental claims for American insurers via a satellite link, Bono, unprompted, brought up the question of whether the company's 800 employees are being exploited. They are paid up to $1 an hour, four times the average wage here but far less than they would get for the same work in the United States. 
"As long as these employees and the government are exploiting the corporate world in a symbiotic relationship, that's fine," he said. Pressed by reporters, he added, "I haven't made up my mind on some of these issues." 
But he said the sight of Africans working at rows of gleaming computers was valuable just for shattering preconceived notions of the continent's limitations. 
Mr. O'Neill stepped forward. "It's not a difficult question," the secretary said, "whether you want to have people paid $1 a day or $1 an hour."
Bono and Mr. O'Neill may have some differing views. But the fact that Bono, whose real name is Paul David Hewson, has equal billing with the Bush administration's senior economic policy official on a diplomatic mission is evidence of the remarkable influence he has on the issue in Washington. 
He has become almost a regular on Capitol Hill, where he worked quietly for several years to convince conservative Republicans of the benefits of writing off some of the debts owed by poor nations to wealthy nations. 
He is now lending his support to efforts in Congress to appropriate more money to combat AIDS around the world. Earlier this year he played a key role in persuading President Bush to provide an additional $5 billion a year in aid to poor countries that could show they could get results.
"My job is to bring some applause if a politician is bold enough to make these new steps," Bono told Ghana's president, John A. Kufuor, at a meeting with Mr. O'Neill today.
But by all accounts, Bono has done more than just shine a celebrity spotlight on an oft-ignored part of the world. 
Both Democrats and Republicans who have dealt with him say he has been a shrewd operator, especially in building support among conservatives for debt relief and foreign aid. Bono has been able to package such aid, when properly accounted for, as a moral undertaking that should be a natural goal of religious conservatives.
Indeed, Bono counts Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, among his biggest fans (at least when it comes to development policy). He has close ties to other prominent Republicans, including Senator William Frist of Tennessee, with whom he traveled in Africa earlier this year.
"This guy is for real," said Representative Sonny Callahan, Republican of Alabama, who worked with the singer on relieving some of the debts owed by African governments to the United States and has proposed that the two of them form a new group called Sonny and Bono.
"He did bridge the gap between me and the more liberal community who were just calling for debt relief alone," Mr. Callahan said.
Some Republicans acknowledge privately that working with Bono is attractive to them because he gives them credibility with younger, more liberal voters, who are not their natural constituents. Bono said he is well aware of the possibility of being used for political purposes. But he said he does not care as long as he makes progress in pushing policies he supports.
"I'm not a cheap date," Bono told White House officials earlier this year.

The musician and the secretary are promoting aid and accountability for such aid. HEADLINE: Under Cheney, Halliburton Altered Policy On Accounting 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON and LOWELL BERGMAN 

 BODY:
During Vice President Dick Cheney's tenure as its chief executive, the Halliburton Corporation altered its accounting policies so it could report as revenue more than $100 million in disputed costs on big construction projects, public filings by the company show. Halliburton did not disclose the change to investors for over a year.
 At the time of the change -- which was approved by Arthur Andersen, the company's auditor at the time -- Halliburton was suffering big losses on some of its long-term contracts, according to the filings. Its stock had slumped because of a recession in the oil industry. Two former executives of Dresser Industries, which merged with Halliburton in 1998, said that they concluded after the merger that Halliburton had instituted aggressive accounting practices to obscure its losses. 
 Much of Halliburton's business comes from big construction projects, like natural gas processing plants, which sometimes run over budget. With the policy change, Halliburton began to book revenue on the assumption that its customers would pay at least part of the cost overruns, although they remained in dispute. Before 1998, the company had been more conservative, reporting revenue from overruns only after settling with its customers. 
As chief executive, Mr. Cheney had final responsibility for Halliburton's books. But the company's chief financial officer, Doug Foshee, said yesterday that he could not imagine that Mr. Cheney had specifically approved the change, which he called a routine decision dictated by a shift in Halliburton's business mix. 
Mr. Cheney declined to comment yesterday. Andersen, which was fired as Halliburton's auditor last month, referred all questions to the company.
Mr. Foshee said he was certain that the accounting change was approved by David Lesar, a former Andersen accountant who was Mr. Cheney's second-in-command and succeeded him as chief executive in 2000. Halliburton, which continues to follow the more aggressive policy, declined to make Mr. Lesar available for comment.
Accounting specialists said that the change stretched and may have broken accounting rules. 
"If they changed their accounting from recording claims when they were settled and collected to recording claims at an earlier point in time, then that would raise a red flag and would raise a question as to whether it's a permissible change," said Lynn Turner, a professor of accounting at Colorado State University and former chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A company that revises an accounting practice usually must show that its new method gives investors more accurate financial information than its old method. Halliburton's revision, Mr. Turner said, does not seem to meet that standard. In addition, such changes are supposed to be disclosed promptly, he said.
The criticism of Halliburton comes amid heightened suspicion on Wall Street about corporate accounting. Andersen is now on trial in Houston for destroying records related to its audits of Enron, and regulators and lawmakers in Washington are debating whether to tighten accounting oversight. 
Though the 1998 accounting change involved a relatively small sum for a company that had $17 billion in sales that year, it came at an important moment for Halliburton. 
The Dallas-based company was eager to win back investors' confidence after its takeover of Dresser, another energy services company. Mr. Cheney has called that deal, which was completed in September 1998, a top achievement of his time at Halliburton, though some experts say that the asbestos-related liabilities Dresser brought to the company may end up driving Halliburton into bankruptcy. 
On Jan. 20, 1999, Halliburton reported sales of $4.3 billion and profit of $66 million for the fourth quarter of 1998, both down from the period a year earlier. Mr. Cheney acknowledged that the quarter had been difficult but said he was "optimistic about the long-term outlook for our industry and for Halliburton in particular."
The change in policy enabled the company to book $89 million in unsettled claims as revenue in 1998, compared to a "de minimis" figure in previous years, Mr. Foshee said.
Exactly how much of that revenue turned into profits for the company is not stated in Halliburton's financial reports. But the impact would have been significant had the company taken the alternative route of writing the cost overruns off as losses, wiping out more than half of its $175 million in pretax operating profits for the fourth quarter, when the accounting change took effect.
One year later, revenue from uncollected claims was about $98 million, according to Halliburton's 1999 annual report to the S.E.C. That report, which the company filed in March 2000, included Halliburton's first public disclosure of the new policy.
Mr. Foshee said the company had not disclosed the change in 1998 because it involved such a tiny fraction of total sales. A year later, Halliburton decided to be especially conservative and disclose the new policy, he said. 
Total claims revenue rose to $106 million by July 2000, when Mr. Cheney left the company, and peaked at $234 million at the end of last year.
According to Mr. Foshee, the change in accounting practices reflected changes in the company's business. 
Before the late 1990's, Halliburton had generally worked under "cost plus" contracts, which guaranteed the company a small profit on top of its costs, whatever they were. But by 1998, he said, most of Halliburton's contracts were fixed price, requiring it to finish jobs for a set fee -- or else try to negotiate payment of cost overruns and change orders.
Though resolving such disputes can take months or years, the company decided it was reasonable to recognize at least part of the revenue from the claims even while they remained in dispute, Mr. Foshee said.
"I don't think that's a change in accounting policy as much as it's a change in business mix," he said. He added that Halliburton eventually collected on many of its claims and that its accounting practices reflected that experience.
"We file a claim, and I think we're pretty conservative -- we're fairly conservative -- about reporting the claim," he said.
That explanation was disputed by the former Dresser executives who joined Halliburton after the merger. They said that most of Halliburton's contracts had been fixed price even before 1998 and that the company made the accounting change to obscure large losses on several important construction contracts. 
Halliburton declined to disclose what percentage of its contracts were fixed price in any given year.
Accounting experts said that Halliburton's practices were aggressive. The change was "clearly a way of pumping up revenues and receivables," said Paul Brown, chairman of the accounting department at the Stern School of Business at New York University.
In general, companies are not supposed to book sales unless they are certain that they will be paid -- and how much they will be paid, Mr. Brown said. He asked how Halliburton could know it would be paid on a claim that a customer had the right to dispute.
"There's already a conflict here, or there wouldn't be these claims," Mr. Brown said. "How did Halliburton estimate the possibility that the change order was going to be resolved?"
Indeed, in its 1999 annual report, Halliburton warned investors that "the environment for claims and change orders has become more difficult in the past few years," contributing to increased losses.
Beyond the change in how Halliburton handled disputed claims, the company's books include one other indicator that analysts say can signal aggressive accounting. 
According to S.E.C. filings, Halliburton's accounts receivable -- sales booked by the company even though it had not yet been paid for them -- soared relative to its total sales during Mr. Cheney's tenure. At the same time, its competitors' accounts receivable fell slightly, S.E.C. filings show.
When Mr. Cheney became Halliburton's chief executive in October 1995, Halliburton had roughly 95 cents in receivables for every dollar in quarterly revenues. When he left in July 2000, the ratio was $1.20 in receivables for each dollar in quarterly sales. 
Over the same period, the average ratio of receivables to sales at five big competitors of Halliburton fell slightly, from 92 cents per dollar of sales in 1995 to 86 cents per dollar 5 years later.
The rising receivables are "a little bit of a red flag," said Edward Ketz, an accounting professor at Pennsylvania State University.
Halliburton's stock has plunged since the company merged with Dresser, mainly because the deal saddled Halliburton with huge legal liabilities from a Dresser subsidiary that manufactured asbestos-containing bricks.
Halliburton shares closed yesterday at $17.43, just below their level on Oct. 1, 1995; they stood at more than double that level when Mr. Cheney left the company. Since October 1995, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen 86 percent.

HEADLINE: With a Step Right, Senator Clinton Agitates the Left 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is drawing fire from her traditional liberal allies as a result of the position she has staked out in the debate over revamping the nation's welfare laws.
 Scores of protesters displayed their anger outside her house here in the Embassy Row neighborhood today, unhappy with her decision to back President Bush's drive to enact new work requirements that they say will ultimately harm welfare recipients. 
 "Senator Clinton needs to understand that the stakes in this debate are very high and that she will be held accountable for her actions," said Deepak Bhargava, the executive director of the National Campaign for Jobs and Income Support, a coalition of advocacy groups representing low-income communities. 
Mrs. Clinton, the New York Democrat, has joined a group of moderate and conservative Democratic senators in supporting a bill to increase the work requirement for welfare recipients to 37 hours a week, a significant increase over the current 30 hours. Mr. Bush would require 40 hours. 
In an interview this afternoon, Mrs. Clinton acknowledged that she had initially been reluctant to back the new work requirements. But she said she decided to support them after the bill's two main Senate sponsors, Evan Bayh of Indiana and Thomas R. Carper of Delaware, agreed to tie them to $8 billion in child care funding.
Mrs. Clinton and her aides also noted that she had secured more money for Medicaid, immigrants' benefits, and education and training for welfare recipients. In addition, Mrs. Clinton noted that the Senate bill maintained limited exemptions from work requirements for mothers of children under 6.
A longer workweek, her critics argue, would force states to abandon existing job-training and placement programs in favor of unpaid workfare assignments for legions of welfare recipients.
The advocates argue that in places like New York City, workfare has not helped substantial numbers of people move from government dependency into permanent jobs. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last week proposed shifting some of the city's welfare policies toward providing more job training for those leaving the welfare rolls. 
Mr. Bhargava and other advocates for the poor say that perhaps the most troubling implication of Mrs. Clinton's position is the message it sends to other Democrats. "It's a pretty stunning development, and it's had an outsized impact on the debate nationally because of who she is," he said. "She is perceived as a progressive Democrat, and so she is giving cover to other Democrats to do the wrong thing."
The other Democratic senators supporting the bill include John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia, Zell Miller of Georgia and John B. Breaux of Louisiana. 
Mrs. Clinton pointed out that the Senate bill was far better than one that the Republican-led House had advanced at Mr. Bush's urging. The House bill imposes a work requirement of 40 hours a week, and does not provide nearly as much money for child care. "It's a vast improvement," she said. "It's not even comparable."
The situation Mrs. Clinton faces is reminiscent of the balancing act that her husband, Bill Clinton, struggled with in 1996, when the left wing pleaded with him to preserve the nation's welfare program while the right urged him to dismantle it.
In the end, President Clinton upset his traditional liberal supporters by backing a measure that overhauled the program by, among other things, ending the federal guarantee of cash assistance for the poor.
Now, Mrs. Clinton finds herself in the cross hairs of an array of advocacy groups for the poor, including Families United for Racial and Economic Equality and Community Voices Heard, both based in New York. 
"This is the first time that Hillary Clinton has been attacked by the left," said Eric Hauser, an advocate for the poor here. "She has been a heroine to the progressive left for her entire career. Now, the progressive left is enraged, and rightly so."
Politically, Mrs. Clinton's position has puzzled some advocates for the poor, who note that she represents a largely Democratic state where there would be little fallout if she took a stand against the tighter restrictions.
"New York is not Arkansas," Mr. Bhargava said. "You just can't get away with this in New York. People feel too strongly about this and are too well organized to let you off the hook."
Some critics also expressed doubt that Democrats would be able to get all the money they want in negotiations with House Republicans. And Bertha Lewis, the executive director of New York Acorn, an advocacy group for the poor, noted that even Orrin G. Hatch, the conservative Republican senator from Utah, had supported a bipartisan measure that would keep the work requirement at its current level of 30 hours a week. 
"When you are right of Orrin Hatch, what is that about?" she said. "That's not good. She is right of Orrin Hatch. That's where our consternation comes in."

HEADLINE: In New Focus on Quality of Life, City Goes After Petty Criminals 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
New York City's prosecutors, police and probation officials said yesterday that they would begin cracking down on a core group of as many as 9,700 people who repeatedly commit petty crimes like prostitution, public drinking and drug use, but serve little jail time.
 The plan, Operation Spotlight, is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's latest twist on an idea popularized by his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani: that the best way to keep overall crime down is to focus on small offenses that damage the quality of life, while relying on a huge, aggressive police presence on the streets. 
 But the new administration's approach, shaped in a time of tighter budgets and a smaller police force, is at once more focused on certain offenders and also broader in the number of agencies involved and the potential impact. Mr. Bloomberg, noting that reported crime continues to decline in almost all major categories, said yesterday he wanted to use not only the police, but also prosecutors, the courts and probation officials to focus on petty criminals. 
"From beginning to end," Mr. Bloomberg said, "from the police officer who arrests a persistent offender, to the prosecutor who asks for bail, to the judge who imposes sentence, to the probation officer who monitors his or her release, everyone is going to be focusing on the career misdemeanor offenders." 
Mr. Bloomberg announced his plan at City Hall with Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly; three of the five district attorneys and senior aides to the others; the chief administrative judge, Jonathan Lippman; the probation commissioner, Martin Horn; and the criminal justice coordinator, John Feinblatt, one architect of the plan, which begins July 1.
The 9,700 figure cited yesterday was based on a statistical model developed by Mr. Feinblatt's office, officials said, and does not reflect a list of suspects whom the police intend to round up. Rather, under the program, when someone is arrested and identified as a repeat misdemeanor offender the police will speed processing of the evidence, and the defendant will be arraigned in a special part of Criminal Court in each borough, where the case will receive priority treatment, the mayor said. Prosecutors will highlight the case and recommend strong sentences, he said.
While judges have discretion over sentencing, an aide to Mr. Bloomberg said he expected they would mete out harsher punishments to some of the repeat offenders. Some defendants could get as much as a year in jail -- the maximum for some misdemeanors -- or agree to court-ordered drug treatment under such a threat.
Chronic offenders on probation will be more closely monitored, ensuring for example that they complete drug treatment, Mr. Bloomberg said. Probation violators will more quickly face revocation hearings, he said. 
This differs from the Giuliani administration's strategy, which churned tens of thousands of petty offenders through the criminal justice system. While they were checked for warrants and some were questioned about other crimes, most were released after 24 hours or sentenced to community service. Critics complained the courts were overwhelmed. Bloomberg officials said they did not expect Operation Spotlight to tax the courts or Rikers Island, where these offenders would serve jail time.
Underlying the new program is the statistical analysis by Mr. Feinblatt's office showing nearly 28 percent of all nonfelony crimes prosecuted in the city -- misdemeanors and violations -- were committed by 6 percent of the defendants. That same analysis found that roughly 9,700 defendants were arrested at least three times last year.
"These are the people who deal drugs, deface storefronts, and steal from our retail establishments," Mr. Bloomberg said. "They drive away tourists, they discourage shoppers, they devalue our neighborhoods, they hurt our economy."
This is the third and broadest effort by Mr. Bloomberg and Commissioner Kelly to build on the zero tolerance strategies of Mr. Giuliani. While the plan recognizes that the Police Department is operating with thousands fewer officers and scant resources, Mr. Feinblatt said it was based on "good criminal justice policy" rather than budget concerns.
The strategy of focusing on low-level offenses was also a foundation of Mr. Giuliani's crime-fighting successes. Known as the "broken windows" theory, it says that if smaller annoyances -- like broken windows -- are left unfixed, they will breed larger crime.
Defense lawyers and civil libertarians had mixed reactions. Susan Hendricks, a senior lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, which represents poor defendants, said past punitive approaches failed. 
"If this approach is focused more on treatment and the city is going to commit the resources to ensure there are enough treatment slots, then that would be something new and it could work," she said. "We're not in favor of crime either, and something that is effective at breaking the cycle of recidivism, something that's effective, is something we'd support."
Christopher Dunn, of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said, "The immediate concern that we have is the role of the courts in this proposal and whether or not defendants will get a fair trial in this special court proceeding." 
And one veteran jurist in Criminal Court said solutions to the seemingly endless parade of repeat petty offenders lay elsewhere, with remedies to the root problems of drugs, homelessness and other urban ills. "Not all these problems can be solved in court," the judge said.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
The War Is Long Over, But Vietnam Continues

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
It's an old journalist's trick, especially among foreign correspondents, to find revelation in the wisdom of cabdrivers. David Lamb, of The Los Angeles Times, had one of those perception-altering taxi rides on his most recent tour in Vietnam, 25 years after he'd covered the war there as a young reporter.
 Upon discovering that his driver had fought for the North Vietnamese, Mr. Lamb asked whether the cabby hated him because he was an American. The driver pulled over and said: "We fought the Chinese for 1,000 years, we fought the French for 100. You were here just for 10. You were just a blip in the history of a proud nation." 
 In "Vietnam Passage: Journeys from War to Peace," a one-hour documentary on most PBS stations tonight (and on WNET in New York on Sunday night at 10:30), Mr. Lamb presents the postwar experiences of six Vietnamese, who refer to that blip as "the American war." This surprising and affecting film, timed to coincide with Mr. Lamb's latest book, "Vietnam Now: A Reporter Returns" (PublicAffairs), is a vivid reminder that Vietnam didn't end 25 years ago. The war did.
 But for Mr. Lamb, and probably for most people in the United States, Vietnam fell off the radar screen when it disappeared from the nightly news. The value of this documentary lies not only in the informative and moving stories it tells, but for the pictures it shows. Mr. Lamb and the filmmaker, Sandy Northrop (who is also his wife), recall the past not through images that have become well known to Americans but through unfamiliar and revealing archival film and photographs. These focus on the Vietnamese experience of the war and its aftermath, including the country as it appears today, looking remarkably capitalistic but still exotic.
The stories include wartime tragedy and triumph but also the less dramatic process of rebuilding families and lives in altered circumstances. The subjects include a family separated by the war, a Vietnamese man who emigrated to the United States and has raised his family here, and how people adapted (or didn't) to the new regime after the North Vietnamese took control.
One woman, jailed in South Vietnam for six years for supporting the Ho Chi Minh government in the north during the war, now fights the new system as it has moved toward a market economy. "This struggle is even harder than the struggle for liberation," she says. "During war it's easy to distinguish your enemy. Now your enemy is bureaucratic."
Mr. Lamb and Ms. Northrop have created an elegant and textured piece of work that combines richly detailed human stories within a smart framework of politics and history. They deal with the harsh, punitive reality of re-education camps, to which 400,000 South Vietnamese were exiled within their own country. 
But they also sympathetically convey the story of Nguyen Thanh Trung, an American-trained pilot who collaborated with the North Vietnamese. He bombed the Presidential Palace in Saigon in revenge for the death of his father, who had been killed by his fellow villagers when they found out he was a Vietcong soldier. (This story is accompanied by brutal photographs of a body, apparently the father's, being dragged around the village and thrown into the river.)
The documentary resonates with the way the past infiltrates the present, even for people like those portrayed here, who appear to have healthily accommodated vast changes. Binh Nguyen, the man who became a United States citizen, finally returned home as an executive for Federal Express, after trade resumed with Vietnam. Though his children were American born and completely American in outlook, he has always felt a yearning for his childhood home.
In Vietnam he meets an old friend, now chairman of a people's committee, something akin to a town council. The two men are wearing almost identical clothing, dark pants and dress shirts. They look like American businessmen who have taken off their ties, except that they hold hands un-self-consciously.
The camera accompanies the expatriate to the stall in a market where his mother used to sell betel nut, which he describes as the equivalent of chewing tobacco. "How do you explain to an American that my mother used to sell betel nut?" he asks. "How do you tell an American friend about a war that you lived through and he only saw on television?"

FRONTLINE/WORLD
On most PBS stations tonight (check local listings)
More on altered perceptions: Tonight PBS also presents a new magazine program called "Frontline/World," focusing on rarely examined countries and cultures. The premiere episode makes it clear that the unhinged feeling Americans have experienced since Sept. 11 is chronic pain in many parts of the world. 
A strong report from Sri Lanka, "Living With Terror," examines life in a country that leads the world in suicide bombings. Another segment focuses on Sierra Leone, where gunrunners from Ukraine -- and indifference in the United States and elsewhere -- have contributed to horrific massacres. The program also includes a nicely filmed but unsurprising report on the effects of television on Bhutan, the last country in the world to get cable. Cartoon Network in, indigenous culture out.

HEADLINE: Japan Intervenes to Stem Yen Rally 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 22 

 BODY:
Worried that the recent rise in the yen's value could snuff out the country's fragile economic recovery, Japan intervened in the currency markets today for the first time in nearly eight months, but failed to turn the tide.
 Analysts said the Bank of Japan sold yen and bought dollars about three times during Tokyo trading, and briefly pushed the yen to 125.06 to the dollar from a peak value of 123.53. But later trading erased the move, and by late afternoon in New York the yen was back where it started the day, settling at 124.22. 
 The intervention came after comments by the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, who called the yen's recent gains speculative and too rapid. The yen has risen 7.5 percent against the dollar since April 1.
The effort to halt the yen's rise is evidence of Japan's commitment to protecting one of the country's few sources of growth: exports. Last week, the cabinet of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said that the recession that began in late 2000 had ended, basing the declaration on rising shipments of goods to the United States and Asian neighbors.
The Bank of Japan seconded that view in its monthly report today, though it noted that consumer spending remained weak. 
Any faltering of exports would put Mr. Koizumi under heavy political pressure to propose a supplemental budget of extra spending, a step he is reluctant to take because of Japan's escalating fiscal deficit.
Many of the country's largest manufacturers, including Honda Motor and Matsushita Electric Industrial, depend heavily on overseas sales, and are banking on an exchange rate of about 125 yen to the dollar in their earnings forecasts. But sustaining that rate will be hard for Japanese policy makers.
"This is not only about the yen's appreciation, but also the slumping dollar," said Hideki Naito, managing analyst at Standard & Poor's/MMS in Tokyo. "If the dollar continues to drift lower, O'Neill won't say anything," he added, referring to Paul H. O'Neill, the American Treasury secretary.
The United States economy posted fairly strong growth in the first quarter, mostly because of strong consumer spending; other sectors remain less vigorous, including steel makers and other manufacturers who face cost pressure from foreign competition. A weakening dollar offers them some relief.
Japan's economy, meanwhile, is only just rumbling to life. Economists expect the first-quarter statistics, due in early June, to show growth for the first time in a year. The brighter outlook has attracted some foreign investors to buy Japanese stocks, adding upward pressure on the yen. The main stock index, the Nikkei 225, rose 1.4 percent today and is up 13.5 percent for the year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After Japan sold its currency yesterday to stem a recent rally, the yen fell fractionally against the dollar, to 124.22 from 124.09. The Nikkei 225 index, meanwhile, gained 160.82 points, to 11,961.98. (Agence France-Presse)
