HEADLINE: Russia's Compass Points West 

 BODY:
Ever since Peter the Great looked to Europe in the late 17th century as a model for modernizing Russia, the integration of Russia and the West has been an alluring but unfulfilled dream. This week, as President Bush visits Moscow and St. Petersburg, the splendid city by the Baltic that Peter founded, he can bring that dream closer to realization. Building on the political and economic changes that have rolled across Europe since the cold war ended, Mr. Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia have brought Russia to Europe's doorstep. With further work, they can guide it across the threshold. 
 The events of Sept. 11 united Washington and Moscow in new ways, and Mr. Putin's supportive call to Mr. Bush just hours after the terror attacks helped seal the friendship that was developing between them. The nuclear arms reduction accord that the two leaders will sign in Moscow, followed a few days later in Italy by the confirmation of a new relationship between Russia and NATO, are the most tangible symbols of a growing partnership. Underlying these achievements are powerful historical forces that have drawn East and West together since the demise of Communism and the collapse of the Soviet empire. 
 It has not always been a pretty process. The introduction of democracy and free markets to Russia after 1,000 years of tyranny has produced painful economic and social dislocation. The sudden contraction of Russia's military power and global reach has left the nation stunned. Even now, vestiges of Russia's historic ambition can be seen in Moscow's nuclear assistance to Iran, its misbegotten romance with Saddam Hussein and lingering bitterness over NATO's war with Yugoslavia three years ago. Yet through these years of turbulence, Russia under Boris Yeltsin and Mr. Putin has been drawn westward by the gravitational pull of trade, financial markets and democracy.
As Russia and the West converge, Washington and Moscow are approaching a state of nearly normal relations, free of the high drama -- and disappointments -- that so often marked cold-war summit meetings. Once the arms treaty is signed, committing the nations to cut their arsenals of long-range nuclear weapons by two-thirds by 2012, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin will have to turn to the tough business of controlling the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, combating terrorism and enhancing economic cooperation. 
For Mr. Putin, that means setting aside longstanding secrecy about the Soviet Union's elaborate biological weapons program so that Moscow and Washington can work together to inventory, secure and ultimately destroy remaining armaments and the germ labs used to make them. Mr. Bush, for his part, must not shrink from publicly distinguishing between a carefully managed battle against terrorism, like the war in Afghanistan, and Moscow's brutish military campaign to suppress Chechen separatists. Mr. Bush should also speak up on behalf of a free press and the rule of law, principles that Mr. Putin has often been quick to bulldoze. 
Fully integrating Russia with the West will take years, and a great deal of skillful diplomacy by American, European and Russian leaders. Strong-arming Russia will not work, and a disdain for international treaties, like Mr. Bush's renunciation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, will not help. But with enlightened leadership on all sides, the visit of an American president to Moscow may someday seem little different from a stop in Paris or Berlin.

HEADLINE: As Bush Heads for Russia, Hopes for an Investment Plan Fade 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 22 

 BODY:
With President Bush barely a day away from Moscow, it began to appear today that he would not be bringing with him economic proposals to transform his first Kremlin meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin into anything more than a funeral service for the cold war.
 In Moscow, that was a clear disappointment for those who have held out hope that Mr. Bush might use such proposals to signal that talk of a new Russian-American alliance will yield tangible riches soon. 
 The Russian government said today that negotiators for both sides had put the final flourishes on the centerpiece of the meeting, an agreement to reduce each side's nuclear stockpiles by two-thirds or more. 
The two presidents are also to sign a nonbinding agreement setting out a new framework for bilateral relations. 
And the Kremlin indicated that it would sign three other agreements dealing with cooperation against terrorism, stabilizing world energy supplies and expanding cultural and governmental contacts.
But none of the announcements mentioned what some Russians were seeking as much as any arms-control accord: an increase in investments, economic incentives or other policy changes that would help stimulate the Russian economy.
A spokesman for Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans, who is in Moscow for the three-day meeting, said he knew of no plans to sign any such economic agreements.
More galling to some officials -- though expected -- was the word that Mr. Bush would not bring promises of action on the two economic issues of greatest concern to them: the repeal of the Jackson-Vanik amendment and American certification of Russia as a market economy.
The Jackson-Vanik amendment, aimed squarely at cold war restrictions on the movement of Soviet Jews, bars the president from giving favorable tariff treatment to nations that restrict free emigration. Congress has routinely waived the ban for Russia during the last decade, but Russian officials see its permanent abolition as a symbol that the United States recognizes Russia's transition toward democracy.
Mr. Bush supports lifting the ban, but legislation to do so sits today in a committee of the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, with no clear date for further action in sight.
One Congressional official said that the amendment was snarled in an unrelated legislative dispute over American textiles.
"There were some missteps on the administration's part," the official said. "They just couldn't get it through the House, and they thought they had a tough road in the Senate."
The United States has also held out hope of Russia's gaining the legal status of a free-market economy, which would entitle it to an array of benefits in trade with the United States.
But a Commerce Department officer said today that the quasijudicial process leading to that decision was only now completing the period of public debate, with the United States Import Administration still to conduct deliberations of unknown length.
Russia must meet six standards to win market-economy status, and on some -- like the degree to which the government controls the allocation of natural resources -- the country's compliance may be an open question.
Officially, the Russian government has played down the delays in both procedures, saying that the White House's commitment is a clear signal of American trust even if real benefits have not yet materialized.
And, stymied economic hopes aside, there are the week's negotiated accomplishments, of which the so-called framework agreement for bilateral relations is the most important. It makes what the Kremlin called a "politically binding" declaration that the two nations will not aim military actions at each other and will seek to cooperate on foreign policy and economic issues.
A senior American official said tonight that the agreement would also take the first steps toward American-Russian cooperation on a limited defense against ballistic missiles.
The United States announced in December that it was withdrawing from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the foundation of most arms-control accords, so that it could begin developing such a defense. Russia continues to argue that the withdrawal is a serious mistake.
The senior official said the framework agreement would commit both sides to set up a long-discussed center to exchange data on missile launchings and tests.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Votes to Include More People in Sept. 11 Relief 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
A Senate panel approved a measure today that would expand the number of New Yorkers eligible for emergency housing aid as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center.
 The action was in response to reports that the Federal Emergency Management Agency had denied thousands of needy families the financial aid they needed to avoid eviction from their apartments or foreclosure of their homes. 
 The agency has acknowledged that one reason for the denials is that agency officials decided to limit such benefits to individuals who could prove that any income they lost was a "direct result" of the Sept. 11 attack. The agency limited such aid to people working south of Canal Street, officials said. 
The emergency housing measure was included in a $31 billion emergency spending bill that the Senate Appropriations Committee approved unanimously this afternoon, Senate staff members said.
Even though some officials say the agency has moved to correct the problem, the housing measure was inserted in the spending bill at the urging of New York's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat.
"FEMA's policy was so narrowly construed that thousands of New Yorkers who were economically devastated by the attacks on Sept. 11 were denied the help they deserved and help they desperately needed," Mr. Schumer said. "That never should have happened," he continued, "and our new provision directing FEMA to expand its definition of those eligible for mortgage and rental assistance should make sure it never happens again."
The House Appropriations Committee did not include any such housing provision in the emergency spending bill it approved earlier this month. But it is unlikely that House leaders will oppose the housing provision, since the money to finance it will come from a $21.5 billion disaster aid package that President Bush agreed to provide New York after the attack, Senate aides said.
The housing provision requires the federal agency to provide mortgage and rental assistance to anyone whose earnings were hurt by the attack, provided that person works in Manhattan or earns 75 percent of his or her wages from business conducted in Manhattan.
The applicant would have to have received a late notice or an eviction or foreclosure notice. The provisions would also reimburse applicants who were mistakenly turned away, providing them with assistance to cover their mortgage or rent payments from the time their initial application should have been approved.
The agency has acknowledged that some 15,000 people got faulty aid applications that increased the chances that they would be denied assistance. Hundreds of others were turned down because their claims were judged under outdated eligibility requirements, officials said.
Since December, Congress has appropriated roughly $10 billion to the agency to respond to the physical and economic impact of the attacks.
The emergency spending package approved today provides an additional $5.5 billion as part of the $21.5 billion in disaster relief aid that President Bush pledged to New York. It includes $90 million for periodic health screenings of workers and volunteers at ground zero, money that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sought.
Government officials have estimated that people in the New York disaster region lost about 75,000 jobs and $4.5 billion in income.
As of late last month, FEMA had provided less than $65 million to help economically distressed people. That is only a fraction of the amounts the agency distributed in the months after other major catastrophes.

HEADLINE: Cuba's Other Face 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 President Bush is simply wrong in saying Fidel Castro's revolution "has brought Cuba's workers and farmers and families nothing -- nothing -- but isolation and misery" ("Embargo Remains Until Cuba Alters Policy, Bush Says," front page, May 21). 
 According to the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, Cuba maintains the lowest level of infant mortality and the third lowest level of illiteracy in Latin America despite the overwhelming pressure of the United States embargo. 
A realistic approach to Cuba by the United States must begin by acknowledging the Castro government's undeniable achievements as well as its widely acknowledged shortcomings.

ANDREW SCHRANK
New Haven, May 21, 2002

The writer is an assistant professor of sociology at Yale University.

HEADLINE: Security Council Tries to Ease Tensions Between U.S. and Iraq 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 22 

 BODY:
Diplomats on the Security Council, even including the United States' European allies, are working quietly but persistently to head off American military action against Iraq by trying to persuade Saddam Hussein's government to reopen the country to arms inspectors. 
 Privately, the diplomats say they are constantly and keenly aware of the threat of American military action, which one diplomat described as hanging like a sword of Damocles over their discussions. A failure to persuade the Iraqis to allow the inspectors back in, they say, would only strengthen the hand of those within the Bush administration who favor war, led by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. 
 The United States is alone among the 15 Security Council members in leaning toward a military route. Many believe that if Iraq once again allows inspections it may create a substantial diplomatic obstacle between Bush administration hawks and an Iraqi invasion. At the same time, they say, it may also exploit divisions within the Bush administration and bolster those, like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who favor diplomacy. 
"The move is to help Colin Powell over Rumsfeld," said one European diplomat on the council. "Maybe we are wrong. But the idea is that if you deploy hundreds of inspectors throughout Iraq and they do a good job, and they are not prevented from doing a good job by the Iraqi authorities -- so there are a number of ifs -- then it will be very difficult for the Pentagon to justify that military action is justified and the choice will be in hands of President Bush."
The inspectors are charged with the task of making sure that Iraq is stripped of weapons of mass destruction, which the Bush administration fears Baghdad could pass to terrorist groups. The Bush administration appears willing to invade Iraq to guarantee that cannot happen. 
The inspectors left in December 1998, on the eve of American and British airstrikes, after years of stonewalling and standoffs by Iraqi officials. Their return now, diplomats hope, would make an American assault unnecessary. It is in any case a precondition for lifting the economic sanctions that Iraq has lived under since it invaded Kuwait in 1990. 
The Council members recently agreed to modify those sanctions, in a step that the United States hoped would increase pressure on Mr. Hussein to live up to his obligations by making it harder for him to claim that ordinary Iraqis are being unduly punished by the sanctions. 
The optimism of some Security Council members notwithstanding, it is impossible to predict whether Iraq is ready to let the monitors return. For the moment, however, the goal, is "unity of the Council," as diplomats say. "The more the Security Council remains united on forcing Iraq to fulfill its obligations completely in accordance with Security Council resolutions," said another European official, "the more the hands of the doves are strengthened in Washington." 
For their part, senior American officials say they will in the meantime continue to operate on two tracks. On one track, they will use international pressure, diplomacy and the sanctions, to tighten the noose on Baghdad. On the other, they will keep alive the military option to topple Mr. Hussein.
"Not everyone agrees with us on the concept of a regime change," one American official here conceded. "But we're working on that."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Decision Roils Party's Convention 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
New York Democrats tried yesterday to generate some excitement for their party and the coming election, but Andrew M. Cuomo's decision to skip the party's convention threw a long shadow over the political theatrics. 
 Party leaders had drafted James Carville, the colorful speaker and former campaign strategist for President Bill Clinton, to inspire the 353 delegates and hundreds of elected officials who came to the Sheraton New York Hotel in Manhattan for a gathering whose outcome was largely preordained. 
 Mr. Cuomo's announcement yesterday that he would stay away and attempt to gather enough signatures on petitions to gain a spot on the ballot threw his supporters at the convention into confusion and robbed the two-day event of what little drama it had: the fight between Mr. Cuomo, a former federal housing secretary, and the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall. 
Mr. McCall had locked up the support of a majority of the delegates, but it was unclear whether Mr. Cuomo had the 25 percent he needed to win a place on the primary ballot. Many delegates, including some Cuomo supporters, said they were offended by Mr. Cuomo's decision to back out.
"I didn't like it," said Andrea Paternoster, a bank officer from Delaware County who supports Mr. Cuomo. "I understand it's a calculated risk he's taking, but people have worked for him, have supported him, and he's walking away from them."
Mr. McCall and his supporters crowed about Mr. Cuomo's decision, calling it a sign of the weakness of the Cuomo campaign.
Delegates seemed divided about the effect of Mr. Cuomo's decision. Many speculated that it would reinforce his effort to portray himself as an outsider running against the Democratic machine, even though he is the son of a former governor and has worked in government posts for many years. Other delegates scoffed at the notion that Mr. Cuomo could succeed in trying to run as a outsider. "I don't believe it passes the laugh test," said Assemblywoman Susan John of Rochester. "He's the son of the former governor. His father once ran the party."
Mr. Carville arrived from Washington in the midst of this confusion to deliver a stemwinder to fire up the rank-and-file party members. While a band played Dixieland, Mr. Carville, wearing sunglasses, took the stage, rolled up his sleeves and proceeded to denigrate Gov. George E. Pataki as beholden to powerful business interests. 
In his Louisiana accent, Mr. Carville blamed the governor for rising auto insurance rates, failing dairy farms, high electricity costs, rising local taxes, the shrinking upstate economy and low student test scores. He also attacked the governor's record of increasing state debt and failing to finance a program that cleans up toxic waste sites. 
"He has accumulated, not a record to run on, but a record to run from," Mr. Carville said as the delegates, who had been lethargic through most of the speeches, applauded loudly.
Michael McKeon, the governor's spokesman, dismissed Mr. Carville's remarks as a partisan attack. "I don't think the raging Cajun knows the governor's record in New York," Mr. McKeon said, using Mr. Carville's nickname. 
Mr. Carville also tried to remind the audience of what he saw as the party's bedrock principle: that government can serve to protect the average citizen from powerful and rapacious business interests. He tried to portray Mr. Pataki as a man who put his own political advancement and the interests of business above those of average people.
He also urged New York Democrats to set aside petty grievances within the party and concentrate on the election. "Stop the whining and let's start the winning right now," he said. 
Mr. Carville's speech was the high point of a day of tedious addresses that left some officials yawning. 
The party unanimously nominated Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general, to run for re-election. Mr. Spitzer faced no opposition among Democrats after having acquired a national reputation in the last four years with a string of publicized lawsuits. Most recently he forced Merrill Lynch to pay a $100 million fine for advising people to buy stock in companies with which it had provided investment banking services. 
"What a difference four years makes," Mr. Spitzer said as he came to the podium to loud applause. In 1998, he had struggled to gain support from the party.
The designation of Mr. Spitzer came after other party leaders laid out the themes of the offensive against Mr. Pataki, a moderate Republican who has taken up many traditionally Democratic issues, like health care for the poor, and made them his own. The governor is a formidable opponent and extremely popular among voters, including Democrats, according to polls. He also has about $16 million in campaign funds. 
Sheldon Silver, the Manhattan Democrat who is the speaker of the State Assembly, said Mr. Pataki was now claiming credit for programs that the Democrats developed and that he initially resisted, like health insurance for poor children and their parents. "It's time to send this make-believe Democrat packing," Mr. Silver said. 
Mr. Cuomo's sudden absence seemed to dominate the largely ceremonial proceedings yesterday. The delegates and elected leaders jostled in the hallways of the hotel, trading theories about what it meant and whether it was a smart move. Some speculated that Mr. Cuomo might have lacked enough votes to force a primary. Some said Mr. Cuomo risked alienating the party workers he would need if he makes it to the fall election. Others said it was a clever tactic and would upstage Mr. McCall. 
Rather than the convention becoming a two-day celebration of Mr. McCall's crushing victory over Mr. Cuomo, it becomes a more humdrum affair. Mr. Cuomo will be able to claim to be a maverick trying, as he said yesterday, "to change the culture of Albany."
"There is a big risk," said Stuart Brody, the Essex County party chairman, who supports Mr. Cuomo. "But there is also a big reward. A lot of Democrats feel that the party has not been as effective as it could be and should be in connecting to our constituencies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, at the state Democratic convention in Manhattan yesterday. He has enough delegates for the nomination, but Andrew M. Cuomo is hoping to force a primary. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: White House Acknowledges More Contacts With Enron 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
White House officials had more extensive contacts with Enron executives in 2001 than previously disclosed, according to a document released by the Bush administration today in response to a request for information from a Senate committee.
 The document describes contacts -- including meetings, phone conversations, letters and e-mail messages -- that concerned the national energy policy report produced by Vice President Dick Cheney, the California energy crisis, Enron's collapse last fall and appointments to administration posts, including the head of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. 
 The White House document also disclosed that Enron executives, including Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman, attended numerous White House functions, including the 2001 inaugural, the Easter Egg roll, T-ball games, speeches and social events.
The release of the information came hours after a deeply divided Senate panel voted to issue two subpoenas to the White House for information about contacts with Enron, with Democrats accusing the White House of resisting earlier requests for information and Republicans suggesting that the move was politically motivated.
The White House document released today was prepared in response to an earlier request for information from the Governmental Affairs Committee, whose chairman is Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the former Democratic vice presidential nominee. While it came after the subpoena was issued, it was not a legal response to it. 
Aides to Mr. Lieberman said tonight that after a brief review of the document, the panel regards it as short of the information being sought. "It appears the White House is still providing only what it thinks is relevant, rather than what the committee asked for," said Leslie Phillips, a spokeswoman for the committee. "We just don't know if the information is everything they collected, or just what they're willing to tell us. This would not have in any way averted a subpoena."
Before the White House document was released, a spokeswoman said administration officials were "rather perplexed" that the panel had "taken this highly unusual step to issue subpoenas without having reviewed" the material. 
The vote in the Governmental Affairs Committee this morning was 9 to 8 along party lines to issue the subpoenas. It came after more than an hour's debate that included a heated exchange between Mr. Lieberman and Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi.
The subpoenas were the first issued by Congress to the executive branch in the continuing inquiry into Enron's collapse and are likely to be resisted by the White House, which has often complained that Congress is encroaching on its executive power and constitutional prerogatives.
In another battle with Congress over the same kind of issue, the Justice Department sought today to dismiss a lawsuit filed by the General Accounting Office seeking to obtain records of meetings last year between energy industry executives and Mr. Cheney's energy task force.
The Justice Department's motion in federal district court here argues that the G.A.O. is trying to "improperly inject itself and the courts into the president's exercise of his powers." The G.A.O.'s position, the Justice Department said, "would revolutionize and violate the separation of powers doctrine that has made our nation's government so strong."
A spokesman for the G.A.O. declined to comment, citing the pending litigation.
In another development related to Enron today, many of the nation's largest energy traders told FERC that they did not engage in the manipulative trading tactics in California outlined in internal Enron memorandums released by the commission this month. But several of the companies, including Williams and Mirant, said some trades had similar characteristics to those outlined in the memos. The companies maintained, though, that the trades had been made under different circumstances or adhered to market rules.
The traders made filings today at the energy regulatory commission in response to a demand from investigators examining accusations of manipulation during the California power crisis of 2000-01. Today, the commission widened its investigation again, ordering natural gas traders in Texas and Western states to disclose whether they engaged in fake "wash trades," selling gas back and forth at the same price. Such trades do not incur losses or profits, but allow traders to claim inflated revenue. Investigators are examining whether wash trades also allowed traders to increase reported prices for gas and electricity, thus affecting prices for the entire market.
The subpoenas, delivered this afternoon to the offices of the president and vice president, call for all communications, including records of White House visits, between Enron and the White House since 1992 that in any way deal with eight federal agencies including the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition, they seek records of contacts between the White House and officials at the eight agencies regarding Enron. They also seek records of contacts between Enron and the White House over the formulation of the national energy policy, covering similar ground as the G.A.O. except that the accounting office is also seeking records of contacts with other energy companies.
The subpoenas demand that information be turned over by June 5. The White House called the action unnecessary today but did not say whether it would contest the subpoenas.
Democrats on the committee said the White House had been dragging its feet for the nearly two months since the panel sent its first letter seeking the Enron-related information. "It's clear to me that there is a very determined decision not to respond to substantial parts of the committee's request for information," Mr. Lieberman said. "At the least, it's slow walking; at the worst, it's stonewalling."
But Republicans, led by Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, the ranking minority member of the committee, called the move premature and said there was no reason to burden the White House with a subpoena when the administration was preoccupied with the war against terrorism and even Democrats on the panel agreed there had been no suggestion of White House wrongdoing related to Enron's collapse.
The debate in the committee intensified after Mr. Cochran suggested that the subpoenas were a politically motivated fishing expedition intended to smear the White House.
"It makes me wonder, are we doing this to attract the attention of the public by suggesting" that the White House has some involvement? Mr. Cochran said. "It makes me very suspicious," he said, adding that the panel was seeking so much information from the White House that "if you got everything you asked for, you wouldn't know what to do with it."
In a sharp voice, Mr. Lieberman quickly responded to the "personal" criticism, telling Mr. Cochran, "Your suspicions are unwarranted, and in my opinion unfair."
In a letter tonight to Mr. Lieberman, the White House counsel, Alberto R. Gonzales, referring to the president's office, said, "Our inquiries thus far have disclosed no instance in which Enron approached any person within the E.O.P. or the office of the vice president seeking help in connection with its financial difficulties prior to bankruptcy."
"In addition," Mr. Gonzales said, "the communications we have identified thus far reflect only appropriate and responsible actions by government officials."
The seven-page document, released by the White House this evening, illustrates how Enron officials approached many people in the Bush administration with specific requests or to discuss specific topics, like electricity policies, tax credits for wind power, the California energy crisis, and legislation governing power-plant pollutants. It also shows that Mr. Lay recommended 21 people for jobs in the administration, though only 3 ultimately received appointments.
The document lists at least 19 meetings between White House and Enron officials -- including five meetings with Vice President Cheney's energy task force -- and at least a half-dozen phone calls. The actual number cannot be determined, as contacts with some White House officials are described as "a few communications" or as a "small number of telephone calls."
The information includes a number of contacts already disclosed, like a a half-hour meeting on April 17, 2001, between Mr. Lay and Mr. Cheney to talk about "energy policy and the energy crisis in California."
It also lists phone calls that Mr. Lay made to Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser, and another administration official, urging the appointments of Patrick Wood III and Nora Brownell to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Both were eventually appointed, though in several crucial matters they have backed policies that Enron fought hard to defeat.
The document also notes calls Mr. Lay made to senior administration officials seeking assistance as Enron was collapsing late last year, and it details the debate in the administration about the company's problems. The White House has always said it did not do anything to intervene on Enron's behalf.
But the information released tonight does disclose at least a dozen new meetings or phone calls related to energy policy or issues of significant importance to Enron, mostly with three White House officials: Robert McNally, a special assistant to the president for economic policy, whose name had not been previously disclosed by the administration as having any contact with Enron; Lawrence B. Lindsey, the chairman of the National Economic Council; and Steve Ruhlen, deputy assistant to the vice president for legislative affairs.
For example, it says, "Dr. Lindsey had a few communications with Ken Lay in the winter and spring of 2001, most likely about the California electricity shortage."
At the time, Enron was aggressively fighting efforts to impose limits on soaring power prices in California. Administration officials came out against the price caps, but President Bush's two appointees to FERC, Mr. Wood and Ms. Brownell, supported a move last summer to impose price limits across the western United States that California officials credit with helping bring prices under control.
On April 6, 2001, Mr. Lindsey also attended a meeting with Mr. Lay, Mr. McNally and several other Enron and White House officials to discuss "electricity and bundling issues," the latter a reference to aspects of electricity deregulation. "Mr. Lay also talked to Dr. Lindsey after the September 11 attacks to state that confidence and investment plans were deteriorating in the wake of the attacks." The White House said Enron did not ask Mr. Lindsey for help as it collapsed last fall.
Without elaborating, the document also says that Mr. Lindsey "may have mentioned Enron in passing in explaining an economic concept relating to the electricity grid" during a meeting with Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff. The rules governing the nation's electricity were a crucial policy issue for Enron, which sought to have the federal government wrest more control of the grid away from state utility commissions.
Mr. McNally appeared to have had even more contact with Enron officials, including seven meetings in 2001. "The main issues discussed in these communications were multi-emissions policy (Enron supported four-pollutant legislation on power plants) and electricity policy," the White House document said. Of the seven meetings, one, which included the director of the energy task force, had already been disclosed, and another was the April 6 meeting that also included Mr. Lindsey.
In the months before the energy policy report was released last May, Mr. Ruhlen "received a small number of telephone calls" from Pat Shortridge, whom the White House identified as an Enron governmental affairs official and personal friend of Mr. Ruhlen. 
In the calls, Mr. Shortridge was seeking "information concerning the likely components of the president's energy plan." The calls were similar to others Mr. Ruhlen had with other energy executives, and in them he "disclaimed knowledge" of details of the plan, the White House said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Documents Show Broader Enron Contacts
Documents released by the White House showed that administration officials had more extensive contacts with Enron executives in 2001 than previously disclosed. The contacts included meetings, phone conversations, letters and e-mail messages, and concerned a range of issues, from a national energy policy document and the California energy crisis to appointments of administration officials.
 The release of the information came hours after a deeply divided Senate panel voted to issue two subpoenas to the White House, with Democrats accusing the White House of stonewalling earlier requests. Page A1. 

An Arthur Andersen investigator testified that a partner who confessed to shredding Enron documents needed legal advice about what documents should be saved. C4.

Gap Searches for Different Leader
More than anything, it was Millard S. Drexler's sixth sense for fashion that helped Gap become a major retailer. So when Gap went wrong, employees said, it was because Mr. Drexler's fashion sense was off. But with Mr. Drexler's resignation, Gap has decided that the new chief should be more schooled in management than in merchandising. C4.

Adelphia Close to Deal With Family
Adelphia Communications is close to a deal under which the family that controls the company would give up all its board seats and supervoting rights, turn over about $1.2 billion in cable assets and forgive $575 million in debt, people briefed on the matter said last night. C5.

Bond Sale in Russia Canceled
A Russian oil company, Tyumen Oil, canceled a half-billion-dollar bond sale after its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, implied that it had made an accounting error in the company's books. World Business, Section W.

Skip-the-Ads TV Upsets Advertisers
Personal video recorders have made it easy for consumers to watch prime-time programs whenever they want, bypassing the commercials. But the devices have raised concerns among advertisers and TV executives who see them as a threat to commercial TV. A1.

A Late Rally for the Markets
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 52.17 points, to 10,157.88. The Nasdaq jumped 9.27 points, to 1,673.45, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index gained 6.14 points, to 1,086.02. C6.

Japan Intervenes on the Yen
Japan intervened in the currency markets for the first time in nearly eight months but failed to turn the tide. The intervention came after comments by the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, left, who called the yen's gains speculative and too rapid. The effort to halt the yen's rise is an indication of Japan's commitment to protect exports, one of the few sources of growth. World Business, Section W.

Bankruptcy Overhaul Is Threatened
Congressional negotiators have been unable to overcome differences about an abortion-rights provision that is threatening to scuttle a bill overhauling the bankruptcy system. A22.

Riding Infomercials Into Prime-Time
A company that makes cleaning products will use the success of its late-night infomercials to jump into prime-time. Advertising. C5.

Using Names to Explain Change
A sociologist uses the shifting popularity of names for children to explain changes in the fashion industry. Tastes may change, the sociologist says, but the changes reflect preferences for novelty, conformity and divergence. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW; 
Little Ones, Are You Haves or Have-Nots?

BYLINE:  By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
Around the turn of the century, there was Lewis Hine (1874-1940), who photographed children toiling in mills and factories. And then there were the Pictorialists, led by Alfred Stieglitz (1864-1946), who took charming, romantic pictures of children in the toils of middle-class privilege. Which children were really better off? This is one of the questions raised by an insightful show with a cumbersome title, "Priceless Children: American Photographs 1890-1925 -- Child Labor and the Pictorialist Ideal," at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University.
 The show was organized by the Weatherspoon Art Museum of Greensboro, N.C., with George Dimock, associate professor of art history at the University of North Carolina, serving as curator. In some 138 vintage black-and-white prints, it juxtaposes for the first time Hines's sociological approach to photography with that of the aesthetically oriented Pictorialists (who also included Gertrude Kasebier, Fred Holland Day, Clarence White, Edward Weston and Edward Steichen). 
 Although it seems self-evident that the children who worked in factories were worse off than those brought up in sheltered circumstances, it was not necessarily so, Mr. Dimock writes in his catalog essay. The working-class children "often embody a freedom, exuberance, sociability and autonomy that their more privileged and closely guarded peers might well have envied," he says. 
On the other hand, the bourgeois home was not always "a safe haven in a heartless world," he points out. In some cases it could be a fragile, vulnerable shelter with "a claustrophobic sense of isolation." In others, the Pictorialist image blandly covered up the pain of its subjects.
In any case, Hine and the Pictorialists (or Photo-Secessionists, as the group styled itself) produced remarkable photographs of children at a time when perceptions were changing: from the traditional agrarian view of a child as a contributing worker in a family to a modern urban regard for the young as economically useless but emotionally "priceless" individuals.
Still, in the period this show covers, child labor was considered by many to be a useful contribution to the capitalist system and even beneficial for the child. But as an employee of the National Child Labor Committee and an ardent subscriber to its progressive beliefs, Hine was out to do away with it.
In his work with the committee, from 1907 to 1918, he traveled tens of thousands of miles and took some 5,000 photographs of what he considered exploited children and their families. At each shoot, he made notes, like this one in 1908 for a superb portrait of a grim-looking cotton mill employee in South Carolina looking defiantly at the camera: "A typical cotton mill boy. 12 years old -- one year in mill. Weaver -- 4 looms. Got 40 cents at start -- 60 cents now. Brother and Pa in mills."
Sometimes, to be sure, the notes were judgmental of his subjects as well as their working conditions. "She chews snuff," he observed of a mother who worked with her two boys in a Georgia mill. And for a photo at a glass factory in West Virginia that showed employees tranquilly polishing and wrapping bottle stoppers, he noted, "Morals in glass factory are proverbially bad." 
Hine, born in Oshkosh, Wis., began his career as a science and geography teacher at the high-minded Ethical Culture School in New York. He took up photography around 1903 with an eye to its use as an educational tool. At the school's suggestion, he photographed his now famous series of immigrants at Ellis Island so that his elite students could connect them with the immigrant Pilgrims. He mastered photography sufficiently to teach it as an art at the school, where he insisted that students observe the principles of old master composition.
In 1908 he was hired by the committee, which wanted visual data from a "broad sociological outlook" to document its fight for enforceable child labor laws. Although most of Hine's photographs -- many made under less than ideal conditions -- took account of this, he considered aesthetic matters, too, and some of these images have great artistic as well as documentary merit.
Among them is a famous 1908 shot of a wide-eyed spinner in a North Carolina cotton mill standing beside her formidable machinery in a ruffled skirt and blouse, her hair in pigtails, looking directly at the camera in a not-to-be-fooled-with gaze. She was 51 inches tall, Hine noted. Another, from 1910, depicts a 14-year-old Postal Telegraph messenger in uniform with his bicycle in Wilmington, Del., posed before a photogenic car. "Works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m.," noted Hine. "$4 weekly. Visits houses of prostitution. Smokes."
While Hine was making his earnest rounds, the Photo-Secession artists busied themselves with fine art photography that was poetic and metaphorical in its concerns. Aspiring to the work of painters and printmakers, they thought of composition, subject matter and even print surface in "artistic" and spiritual rather than documentary terms.
Their photographs projected a romantic, idealized view of childhood, with subjects drawn mostly from their own families or those of friends. The children were usually portrayed as happy, well-kempt and cherished, or as symbols of something else.
A model Pictorialist was Kasebier (1852-1934), whose famous 1899 confection "Blessed Art Thou Among Women" shows a mother and her young daughter in a pose that Mr. Dimock calls "the quintessential distillation of the 'priceless' child." The girl, docile and expensively dressed, stands in a doorway with her white-gowned mother, whose arm encircles the child in loving togetherness. 
Even more distant from the work of Hine is that of perhaps the most idealistic and symbolically oriented of the Pictorialists, Fred Holland Day (1864-1933). A wealthy Bostonian influenced by artists like Oscar Wilde and Aubrey Beardsley, he posed his subjects in exotic ways and elaborate costumes using themes from literature, drama and religion. One of his proteges and frequent subjects was an impoverished Syrian immigrant, Khalil Gibran, later to become famous as the author of "The Prophet." The 15-year-old Gibran is shown here in an arty high-contrast portrait of 1898, picturesquely garbed as an Arabian.
Clarence White (1871-1925) made many idealized photos of attractive children and their families, including his own. Several here are from an extended portrait series of 50 family images commissioned in 1904 by Stephen and Jessica Reynolds of Terre Haute, Ind., part of a circle of progressive thinkers toward which White gravitated.
The portfolio was meant not just as a family record but also as a utopian portrayal of family harmony. One of the photos here depicts a tender moment in family life: Jessica gazing affectionately at her daughter, Jean, as the adolescent girl lies on her bed in a dreamy state, the kind of emotional encounter that Hine would shun.
But later, as a young woman, Mr. Dimock notes, Jean committed suicide, one of several bad endings he recounts in the saga of these "privileged" children. His overall point is that both Hine and the Pictorialists portrayed children in stereotypical ways, Hine by dealing with them as victims in need of rescue, the Pictorialists by viewing them through a romantic scrim. 
Some editing would help here. The Hine images by and large are small and somewhat repetitive, and the Pictorialists' work is not arranged to offset them with clarity. Still, the show is absorbing, made the more so by its thoughtful thesis.

"Priceless Children: American Photographs 1890-1925 -- Child Labor and the Pictorialist Ideal" is at Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, through July 13.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Whitnel, N.C." (1908), by Lewis Hine, from "Priceless Children." (Grey Art Gallery)

HEADLINE: Guthrie Theater Plans Are Imperiled by Veto 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 23 

 BODY:
By vetoing $24 million to build a new home for the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota has made that theater the latest victim of a wave of state and local budget cuts that are reducing arts programs across the United States.
 The new Guthrie complex was envisioned as a cultural center for the upper Midwest, with three stages and several classrooms. The architect Jean Nouvel had already drawn up design plans for the project. 
 Mr. Ventura cut $377 million from a $979.1 million bond issue approved by the Minnesota legislature. The Guthrie "brings in a lot of money; it adds fabric to our community," he told The Minneapolis Star Tribune, but said that the state could not afford the $24 million. He also vetoed $9.5 million for a new planetarium in Minneapolis, $8.2 million for the Minnesota Zoo and $5 million for the Minneapolis Children's Theater.
Advocates for the Guthrie argued that the theater had outgrown its 40-year-old building and needed a new one to maintain its position as one of the country's leading regional theaters. But on a radio program on Monday in which Governor Ventura emphasized the state's fiscal problems, he asked, "Is government in the theater business?" He added: "What was wrong with the old theater? Seems fine to me."
After years of steady expansion, public financing for the arts has begun to drop substantially as a long economic boom ends. Gov. Gray Davis of California, who is facing a multibillion-dollar budget gap, has proposed cutting the California Arts Council's budget by nearly half, to $18 million from $32 million, for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Nationally prominent California theaters like the La Jolla Playhouse and the San Diego Repertory Theater are expected to be among those that will receive far less state money.
The Massachusetts House Ways and Means Committee has voted to cut its state cultural council's budget to $10 million from $19 million. Institutions likely to be affected range from a small children's art program in the Jamaica Plain section of Boston to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams.
States that have traditionally given little to arts groups are now giving even less. The Georgia Council for the Arts has announced that its grants to cultural institutions this year will be $2.5 million, down from $2.7 million last year. This will be the smallest amount the council has distributed since 1989.
Cities have joined states in making cultural cutbacks. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, where the budget gap is estimated at $5 billion or more, has proposed cutting the Cultural Affairs Department budget to $110.4 million this year, a reduction of $19.1 million. Many involved in the arts locally fear that, given the size of the deficit, the New York City Council will not be able to restore much of the proposed cut, as it did in the past. 
Mayor Anthony M. Masiello of Buffalo has recommended cutting all city funds for the arts. One of the mayor's supporters, Councilman Joseph Golombek Jr., told the City Council at a meeting this month, "If you ask my constituents, 'Would you like more police officers or more arts?' my constituents would tell me they want more officers and to forget about the arts."
The King County Office of Cultural Resources, which serves Seattle and the surrounding area, will have a budget of $700,000 in the coming fiscal year, compared with $1.3 million this year and $2.3 million last year. Officials are considering turning the office into an autonomous authority that will raise private as well as public funds.
Future prospects for the proposed Guthrie complex also look bleak. "This project was conceived during the dot-com boom of the mid-90's," said Paul Metsa, a Minneapolis musician who heads a group campaigning to preserve the Guthrie's current building. "The governor decided that it's just too expensive, given today's conditions. A lot of people would probably agree. This puts the whole project in doubt because they were counting on that state money to give them momentum to raise the rest of what they need."
Joe Dowling, the Guthrie's artistic director, called the governor's veto "a serious body blow" and said the executive committee of the theater's board would meet soon to review "what steps we can take to move the project forward." Earlier he had acknowledged that "without this money, we will have to delay the project for quite some time or even abandon it altogether." He said the theater would continue but would have to curtail its theatrical and educational ambitions.
"In terms of encouraging new writers, staging new plays and co-productions, and sending our plays out to other places, we won't be able to do what we hoped," he said. 
"We won't reach that national or international level," he added. "Other theaters that get the funds they need will surpass us."
The new Guthrie complex was to have cost $125 million. Private fund-raising began 18 months ago, and since then, nearly $60 million has been raised. Those in charge of the drive were confident that they could raise considerably more, but considered state support essential. 
The legislature ended its session on Sunday, hours after voting to approve the bond issue, so it cannot override Governor Ventura's veto. Bond issues for nonemergency projects in Minnesota are considered only every two years, so it is unlikely that the legislature will reconsider the Guthrie project until at least 2004.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
First Cars: Ah, Sweet T-Bird Of Youth

BYLINE:  By GAY JERVEY 

 BODY:
ONE was an 11-year-old child, so entranced by his first glimpse of it at the 1939 World's Fair that he later sketched the vision from memory. Today, he has both the framed drawing and its inspiration at his Connecticut home. Another was determined to surprise his wife with a 40th birthday present that would remind her of a time when she felt young, adventurous and full of promise. Still others were influenced by a specific movie, a television show, a glimpse of something on the street -- or just an overwhelming desire to go as fast as humanly possible.
 They come from varying walks of life, from far-flung corners of the country and from different generations, yet they all share the same thing: a love of cars, in most cases very specific cars. And their love borders on obsession. 
 The 11-year-old was Malcolm Pray Jr., and the object of his desire was a 1936 Delahaye, one of only seven ever made by the French company. Twenty-five years after he first laid eyes on it, Mr. Pray found the Delahaye on Long Island and drove it home to Greenwich, Conn., where he now has a collection of more than 80 vintage automobiles. 
 The doting husband is a 44-year-old Manhattan lawyer named Lawrence Savell. His wife, Cathy, dreamed of a 1966 Pontiac Catalina convertible, which she had first talked wistfully about when the two were dating. After searching high and low, Mr. Savell used the Internet to find the exact same car his wife had driven as a high school senior in Massachusetts and presented it to her, complete with the original 1966 license plates and a CD of 1960's songs he had made for her. 
"You see a certain car, and you say, 'I want that and I'm not stopping until I get it,' " said Edward Gunyo, a 50-year-old financial consultant in Minneapolis who spent nearly 15 years lusting after the 1963 Buick Electra convertible, which had first mesmerized him at an auto show. In 1978, he finally stumbled upon one, buried in a friend's garage. 
"I told the guy that I had to have it," Mr. Gunyo said. "And I gave him my '52 Buick for it." To this day, Mr. Gunyo keeps a $2 toy model of the Buick, a birthday present in 1963, displayed in a glass case, and from time to time, he takes his Electra out for a drive.
"A lot of this is simply wish fulfillment," said David Brownell, who was the editor of Hemmings Motor News from 1983 to 1999. "In my case, I grew up down the street from a garage that specialized in sports-car tuning, and I would stand on the street corner on Saturdays and watch this wonderful parade of MG's and Jaguars and Austin-Healeys go by. And I would tell myself that I had to have them."
Today, Mr. Brownell's garage houses a 1924 Bentley, a 1961 Morgan and a 1954 Austin-Healey.
Car enthusiasts tend to fall into several camps. There are the rich and serious, like Mr. Pray, who amass collections that turn other gearheads British racing green with envy. And then there are those who are held in thrall by specific models out of sheer nostalgia. Whatever the case, the automobile is far more than just a means of transportation: it is a personal time machine, a reminder of who we were when we first spotted it years ago.
"Ask 100 different people why they have that one special car, and you'll get 100 different reasons," said Chris Wolfe, the author of "The Buick Riviera: 1963-1973," published by Classic Motor Books. (A lover of vintage American cars, Mr. Wolfe was once so determined to own a particular 1966 Riviera Gran Sport that he traveled from his home in Denver to Cheyenne, Wyo., and used a machete to cut the car out of the weeds in an abandoned salvage yard.)
In the early 1950's, the Museum of Modern Art recognized the automobile as an art form, and since then, striking examples have often been described as "rolling sculpture," a term that some clearly do not find hyperbolic.
Growing up in the 1960's, one Manhattan architect describes himself as being so "flabbergasted by gorgeous cars" that he would spend hours drawing pictures of them. He is particularly fond of BMW's, and years later he spotted a 3.0 CS parked on the street in Greenwich Village. From then on, he would take detours to visit it, as he strolled along to dinner or a movie. (He asked that his name not be used to protect his obsession.)
After searching for his own 3.0 CS -- at one point he went to Monterey, Calif., to attend a BMW show -- he decided that the 3.0 CS, like many beauties, would just be too high strung. So he opted for what he considered the next best thing, a BMW 6-series coupe that he found in Chicago.
When that car was later totaled in an accident, the architect was determined to replace it with a BMW that was as close to the original as possible. He found his new car on a business trip in Southern California.
"It was sort of like you see this incredible blonde," he said, laughing. "You see them, and then you lose them. But then suddenly you see them again, and you just can't believe your luck!"
Others want a particular car for the simple pleasure of driving it. Take Dr. John Carbone, an orthopedic surgeon in Baltimore.
For Dr. Carbone, 40, the worst part about medical school was not the hours nor the pressure, but the fact that he was forced to drive "a little economy car, and it was making me nuts." After all, his first love was a 1980 Fiat Spider 2000 that he bought in high school. 
In the mid-90's, when Dr. Carbone was a resident in surgery, Porsche produced the Carrera 4S, a special edition of its all-wheel-drive sports car. And Dr. Carbone vowed to own one. Now he does, and he drives daily. 
"Let me tell you something about a great car," Dr. Carbone said. "When I'm at the wheel in a car that's fun to drive and I have got time for myself where I can regroup mentally, I can focus. It becomes an enjoyable experience as opposed to just transportation."
Then there are those who collect cars because they represent particular eras. For 48-year-old Wayne Maddox, who owns Maddox Vintage Autos and Parts in Denver, that era is the 1950's and 1960's, which are exemplified to him by the television shows that he was glued to growing up -- the likes of "The Beverly Hillbillies" and "The Dick Van Dyke Show." 
So Mr. Maddox owns a 1957 Dodge, a 1959 Chrysler New Yorker and a 1956 Lincoln Continental Mark II and recently built a copy of the police cruiser featured in "Car 54, Where Are You?"
"Cars are tangible markers of happy times in your life," Mr. Maddox said, "times that you want to go back to."
Thomas Cotter, a 48-year-old automotive public-relations and marketing consultant in Davis, N.C., would agree. Ever since he was in the fifth grade, Mr. Cotter had yearned for a 1964 Cobra convertible. Until several years ago, though, the car had eluded him because it was too expensive. But then in 2000, he sold his marketing business and came into some cash.
"I said to my wife, 'It's Cobra time!' " Mr. Cotter said. Through the Internet, he found the perfect Cobra in Walnut Creek, Calif., and plunked down $167,000 to buy it. "When I saw it, I said, 'Oh my God, that's my car! Unmolested."
Mr. Cotter traveled to California and drove the Cobra home to North Carolina along two-lane highways, including Route 66. And despite bits of snow and rain, he never once put the top up.

HEADLINE: Notes From San Jose; 
Silicon Valley Grows Up

BYLINE:  By Claire Tristram; Claire Tristram writes frequently about technology and business in Silicon Valley.

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
On some stretches of Highway 880, curling around the east side of San Francisco Bay, you can drive by row after row of pristine office buildings, constructed just before the bust, never occupied by a single tenant. These days, Silicon Valley's traffic, like the valley's ambitions, isn't as ferocious as it used to be. Sometimes it's even possible to get from San Francisco to San Jose in less than 90 minutes.
 Maybe because I have lived in this part of the world since the Macintosh was new, I tend to remember Silicon Valley more for its excitement than for its excesses. I can still feel the jaw-dropping amazement that struck me the first time I saw the World Wide Web, in a computer lab at Silicon Graphics in 1994. Sock puppets and Super Bowl ads I tend to forget about. 
 So in the midst of the biggest bust the valley has seen since the early 1990's, I console myself with the knowledge that the excitement will return, as it always does. Right now the most important story for Silicon Valley just may be in Washington, where the valley and Hollywood are fighting over the future of digital entertainment. Congress is currently considering legislation that would require the computer industry to develop "security system standards" to protect the transmission and duplication of digital content.
This is not just an intrastate feud between Northern and Southern California. It is a fight with global implications, and the valley's peculiarly technophilic culture, usually part of its charm, may not serve it so well.
Of course, what some find charming others see as condescending. Back when Napster was still in the early stages of being sued for copyright infringement, its executives would publicly express their belief, with all sincerity, that Napster would one day be embraced by the music industry: the industry just didn't understand the technology yet.
Alas, understanding never came. Despite credible studies suggesting that sharing music files online actually leads consumers to buy more CD's rather than fewer, the association pressed forward with its suit and Napster was shuttered, its remains subject to a fire sale just last week. Some 80 million Napster users were scattered to the wind. And digital music distribution has become a dead zone where investors fear to tread.
The same broken dialogue is now repeating itself between Silicon Valley and Hollywood. Hollywood went to Congress to block any sale of DVD's without legislatively mandated copy protection. It sued to block the sale of MP3 players and digital VCR's because these devices make it easy to make fast, durable, portable copies of music or movies.
Silicon Valley responds -- in that rational, superior way technologists sometimes have -- that of course digital technology makes possible better reproductions that last longer than their analog counterparts. Hollywood, valley executives say, doesn't understand the upside potential and is stifling innovation. Besides, these guys said the same thing about the VCR, and in 2001 consumers spent more than twice as much on videos as they did at the box office.
In other words: Hollywood, you just don't understand.
It may not be the most politic approach. But it represents a fundamental difference in viewpoint: Silicon Valley doesn't see digital theft as a problem that can be solved -- there, done. It's more like an arms race, of an incredibly positive sort, with each innovation demanding new strategies and providing new opportunities. The computer industry has sold an all-digital product -- software -- for decades. It can be copied and distributed every bit as easily as digital movies can. And yet the valley has largely succeeded, through a relentless publicity campaign as well as litigation, in preventing the widespread piracy of its intellectual property.
Hollywood's latest bid for protection from digital theft is called the Consumer Broadband and Digital Television Promotion Act, sponsored by Ernest Hollings of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee. At its heart, the legislation aims to force Silicon Valley and Hollywood to work together to come up with a way to protect copyrighted digital material; if they don't, the government will step in. Technologists see any "solution" as impossible, or at least fleeting, since no software has yet been written that can completely prevent piracy.
But simply stating "you just don't understand, Senator" -- even if it is a perfectly reasonable response -- isn't going to work in this latest battle, as Silicon Valley is learning. Hollywood does a far better job than the valley of speaking in one voice on Capitol Hill. Painfully, if not surprisingly, Sen. Dianne Feinstein, former mayor of San Francisco, is a co-sponsor of the Hollings bill; Hollywood has contributed roughly twice as much money to her as Silicon Valley has.
So the discourse is changing. Andy Grove, the chairman of Intel, will speak to anyone who will listen about the importance of the free market, which is the standard technolibertarian argument. But he now also acknowledges the valley as a powerful part of the mainstream economy and speaks of the fight as one mature industry against another. Why should the government, he asks, have to protect the movie industry from new technology?
Silicon Valley, a famously fractious place, is also becoming more unified. Mr. Grove and Steve Jobs, chief executive of Apple, have been vocal opponents of the Hollywood proposal. The Business Software Alliance, an industry group known for its vigorous pursuit of digital pirates, which includes Microsoft and I.B.M. as members, is also opposed to the legislation. 
Still, old habits die hard, and one of the valley's oldest is its tendency to thumb its nose at authority (even as it exercises a fair amount itself). Gateway, the large computer maker, runs television ads that urge its customers to download music (with permission from the artists) from its Web site. Regardless of the effectiveness of these tactics, they have succeeded in angering Hollywood.
In some ways, this populist activism is curious for an industry that has increasingly served the needs of business rather than those of consumers. But maybe that's the best thing about this fight. It has galvanized this place as nothing has for at least a couple of years. It reminds the industry of its relevance. And maybe, just maybe, by exposing its immaturity -- after all, the technology industry can no longer act like a brilliant but misunderstood child -- this debate will help Silicon Valley grow up.

HEADLINE: The West Virginia Way, Then and Now 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Fight for the Soul of Coal Country," by Michael Lipton (Op-Ed, May 17): 
 As a child growing up in West Virginia, I heard stories from my grandfather about life as a coal miner in the 1920's. In those days, coal companies maintained an iron grip over miners and their communities. 
The message I took from my grandfather was that the fight against the coal companies was not just about a paycheck but a way of life.
Eighty years later, West Virginians are still fighting to protect their way of life. But today, residents of coal country have to worry not only about the economic landscape but also the landscape itself. With a wink and a nod from the Bush administration, coal companies are now dynamiting mountaintops and pouring the leftover rubble into streams and creeks.
With closed-door deals between politicians and coal company executives, who needs the 1920's?

ROBERT COX
Chapel Hill, N.C., May 17, 2002

The writer is a director and former president of the Sierra Club.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Rise, Hint of New Capital Spending 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23 

 BODY:
The nation's factories, hard hit in the economic slump last year, gave off fresh signs of improvement in April, with orders for manufactured goods rising for a fifth consecutive month. 
 The Commerce Department reported today that orders for durable goods, items expected to last at least three years, jumped 1.1 percent, with demand especially strong for cars, communications equipment and machinery. 
 Economists said the data might point to the beginning of a turnaround in capital spending by businesses, something necessary for a broad recovery in the economy. Deep cuts in such spending were an essential factor in the economic downturn. 
"This report seems to indicate that the collapse in investment is behind us and we are in the beginning stages of a rebound," said Joel L. Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisers. 
The 1.1 percent advance followed a 0.2 percent increase in March and was larger than many analysts had expected. Factories are increasing production as businesses begin to replenish inventories. Through much of 2001, many companies worked to reduce their stocks of unsold goods. 
In April, new orders for cars, trucks and auto parts jumped 12 percent, the biggest increase since August 1998. The month before, orders in those categories fell 1.2 percent. 
Even with the vehicle and parts increase, orders for all transportation equipment fell 2.6 percent in April -- resulting from an outsized drop in aircraft orders of 37.1 percent.
Excluding transportation, durable goods orders increased 2.9 percent in April, the biggest increase since October. 
Orders for communications equipment rose 12 percent, after an 11 percent decline in March. Machinery orders were up 4 percent after a 1.5 percent drop. 
In another economic report, fewer Americans filed new claims for unemployment insurance, but people who are out of work continue to have trouble finding new jobs. 
The Labor Department said today that for the week ended May 18, initial jobless claims dropped by 9,000, to 416,000, an eight-week low. But even with the decline, economists said claims were still high, suggesting that the job market remained sluggish. 
The number of laid-off workers continuing to draw jobless benefits climbed in the week ended May 11 to a 19-year high of 3.87 million.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Recession? Don't Tell the Video Game Industry

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 23 

 BODY:
Spurred by technology advances that create ever more realistic renderings of adventure, sports fantasy and violence, the video game industry is in a remarkable boom.
 As the industry gathers here for this year's Electronic Entertainment Exhibition, or E3, it appears to have created its own economy. Despite the recession, a prolonged technology slump and Sept. 11, sales of video game hardware, software and accessories increased 43 percent last year, to a record $9.4 billion, according to the market research firm NPD Group. 
 A number of industry executives and analysts say that the current economic wave is rooted in both the cycle for new generations of video game players and the demographic shifts that have taken game playing out of the realm of cult status and into the mainstream. 
"Two generations have now grown up with computing and interactivity," said Doug Lowenstein, president of the Interactive Digital Software Association, the industry trade group that sponsors the conference. "Playing video games is as natural to these generations as watching television and listening to the radio was to earlier generations."
Sales of game software alone reached $6.4 billion last year, putting the game industry in striking distance of Hollywood, which had box-office sales of $8.35 billion in 2001. And video game executives predict this year will be even stronger.
"Last fall the U.S. video game market simply took off," said Bruno Bonnell, chief executive of Infogrames Entertainment, a maker of games for video game consoles and personal computers that has experienced a turnaround in its business recently.
A key element of the boom is the realism that new technology has brought to the games. "The video game industry has come of age," said Roger McNamee, a Silicon Valley technology investor. "The visual look of the games is astonishing." 
The increasing move toward realism could be seen in the movie-like appearance of games like Sony Entertainment's "Getaway," which is based on 50,000 digitized images of downtown London, as well as a remarkable crop of 2003 football games from Electronic Arts, Sony's 989 Studios, Sega and Microsoft.
The games take advantage of a technology known as motion capture that is now widely used in the industry, which uses the digitized performance of real athletes. Their moves are stored in a database on the game disk and seamlessly woven together to give a remarkably lifelike feel. 
The industry is also benefiting from an explosion of tie-ins between video games and Hollywood movies like "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," "Lord of the Rings," "Spider-Man" and even a three-movie deal for the video game derivative Laura Croft.
Indeed, it was Ms. Croft, the digitized creature, not her flesh-and-blood doppelganger, Angelina Jolie, who made news here Monday by signing with Creative Artists Agency in the first-ever Hollywood agent deal for a digital character.
The new version of the program, scheduled to ship in November, will be titled "Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness." In it, the digitized animation of Ms. Croft will be made up of 5,000 polygons -- the virtual wire frame that underlies an animated figure -- compared with 500 in earlier versions, making her much more lifelike. Doom III, which will be released next year, renders some characters with as many as 500,000 polygons. The current generation of computer hardware from all three video game makers is specially designed to make it possible to render millions of polygons almost instantaneously.
As game software and hardware become more elaborate and the profit potential grows, the development budgets of hit software titles are swelling as well. Costs now routinely fall from $3 million to $6 million, and $10 million is no longer unusual. The development team for the latest Laura Croft game, which is being produced in England, has jumped to 50 from 15.
And when the costs of translating games to multiple formats and marketing them are included, expenses may reach as high as $50 million to $60 million, software executives said. 
Nevertheless, hit titles like last year's top-selling "Grand Theft Auto III," which has shipped more than three million copies at a typical retail price of $49 since its introduction last fall, can be wildly profitable. That goes a long way to explaining the intense rivalry among the three video game player manufacturers: Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony.
Sony, which brought its PlayStation 2 to market two years ago, is clearly in a commanding position at the moment, and its executives declared victory in their rivalry with Microsoft at a news conference before the exhibition opened earlier this week.
"This is a harvest year for us," said Ken Kutaragi, president and chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment Inc. While video game players are initially sold at a loss to build market share and to entice software developers, he said that the PS2 is now profitable, even after the company recently cut its price by $100, to $199, in an effort to put pressure on its rivals.
In fact, much of the discussion at this year's show centered not around whether Microsoft would be able to catch Sony, but whether it would be possible for Microsoft to edge out Nintendo, whose GameCube is now doing well after early miscues.
Although Microsoft made an ambitious showing at this year's event, much of the industry is still skeptical that the company will be able to translate the slim technical lead of its Xbox into a major factor in the market. Many game players at this year's show said that although the Xbox appeared to have a slight technical advantage, Microsoft had been able to develop only one or two games that exploit it.
