HEADLINE: Scientists Develop the Universe's Baby Pictures 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE 

 BODY:
Using a radio telescope so high in the Andes that they needed oxygen masks to visit it, astronomers have taken what they described yesterday as the most detailed pictures yet of the birth of the universe, resolving for the first time the seeds from which clusters of galaxies grew.
 The observations, made by an array of microwave antennas known as the Cosmic Background Imager, mapped minute variations in the brightness of radio waves thought to be left over from the Big Bang. They reveal the universe when it was only some 300,000 years old and about as hot as a cool star, stippled with faint hot and cool patches, about one-hundredth the apparent size of the moon. 
 Analysis of the images, astronomers said, confirms what is rapidly becoming the conventional theory of the Big Bang, which says that the universe was born in a fiery blast 14 billion years ago, is geometrically "flat" over the largest cosmic scales and is dominated today by a mysterious dark matter and by an even more mysterious dark energy that is now pushing the cosmos apart. 
The new analysis, they said, also supports a controversial modification of the Big Bang theory that holds that the universe underwent a brief spurt of hyperexpansion, known as inflation, during the first instant of time.
At a news conference yesterday at the National Science Foundation in Washington, Dr. Anthony Readhead, an astronomy professor at the California Institute of Technology and the leader of the multinational project, called the results "a very powerful confirmation of the standard cosmological model," adding, "For the first time, it places theories of galaxy formation on a firm observational footing." A set of five papers by Dr. Readhead and his collaborators has been submitted to the Astrophysical Journal Letters.
"It is hard to imagine a more satisfying marriage of theory and experiment," said Dr. Richard Bond of the Canadian Institute for Theoretical Physics, who worked closely with the Caltech team. "One thing after another falls into place for these theories we've been working on."
Astronomers and cosmologists outside the team said the work was important. "It's exciting that when you look at new phenomena, things still work," said Dr. Max Tegmark, a cosmologist at the University of Pennsylvania. 
Dr. Michael Turner, a cosmologist at the University Chicago, said the new work was emblematic of "the new age in cosmology, where we have more data than parameters." 
The cosmic background, a nearly uniform hiss of microwave radiation that fills the sky, has riveted astronomers' attention ever since it was discovered in 1965 by Dr. Arno Penzias and Dr. Robert Wilson, Bell Laboratories researchers and subsequent Nobel laureates.
According to theoretical calculations, the primordial gases of the early universe should have been laced with tiny temperature variations, the result of acoustic waves in the rapidly expanding fireball. The fireball was, in effect, ringing like a bell, with a main note and overtones.
The "notes" on which the early fireball was singing give a direct way to calculate cosmological parameters like the geometry of space-time, the density of the universe and its rate of expansion.
However, because water vapor in the atmosphere also emits microwaves and the cosmic radiation is very faint, it can be studied only from balloons and satellites. It was not until 1992 that NASA's COBE satellite first detected broad ripples in the cosmic background. Two years ago, a pair of balloon-borne experiments with higher resolution, nicknamed Boomerang and Maxima, succeeded in detecting the first of those cosmic notes, whose frequency indicates the geometry of space-time. According to Einstein's theory of general relativity, space is warped in various ways, depending on the density of mass and energy in it. Modern cosmologists, including Einstein, have long favored a "flat" universe with no overall warp, a prejudice which was confirmed by Boomerang and Maxima.
Last year Boomerang and another experiment at the South Pole called DASI found the next two higher notes on the cosmic scale, whose relation helps theorists gauge the densities of ordinary and dark matter in the universe. Similar results were submitted to the journal Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society yesterday by a team of European astronomers, based on observations from the Very Small Array at Tenerife in the Canary Islands.
The Cosmic Background Imager, which was designed for high-resolution observations, was built at Caltech and shipped to a site 16,700 feet high in Chile's Atacama desert to get it above interfering water vapor in late 1999. It has now found at least four notes, fading in strength as they go higher, Dr. Readhead reported.
This damping at high frequencies is an important result, several astronomers said, because it was consistent with theoretical predictions that the higher notes would be blurred and fade the way low notes persist longer than high notes when a bell is struck.
Moreover, Dr. Readhead said that an analysis using only the high notes yielded the same cosmic parameters as a previous analysis based on the lower frequencies. That was important, he said, because it was an independent test of the standard model.
"Nature would have to be doubly mischievous to make us come to the same wrong answer from two different sets of data," Dr. Readhead said.
The confirmation of cosmic flatness is particularly vital to the inflation hypothesis, which was ventured first in 1980 by Dr. Alan Guth, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Inflation makes a proposal for what propelled the Big Bang -- a repulsive form of gravity," Dr. Guth said at the news conference.
According to Dr. Guth, a brief burst of antigravity would have ballooned the nascent cosmos to enormous proportions, smoothing its irregularities and causing the observable universe to appear flat the way a balloon up close looks flat. Dr. Guth based this idea on theories of high-energy particle physics, and at the time there was little evidence that the universe was flat.
The new data also are consistent with another prediction of inflation, namely that all the notes in the fireball should contribute nearly equally in a kind of cosmic "white noise."
Dr. Guth recalled doing the latter calculation back in 1982. "I never thought for a moment that in my lifetime these calculations would be compared with observations," he said yesterday.
Dr. Bond said that although these results did not prove inflation, their consistency with it would make it hard for the authors of alternative theories.

HEADLINE: Manhattanites Fared Best In New York City in 1990's 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The 1990's benefited Manhattan and Manhattanites far more than they helped the rest of New York City and much of the region, according to new data from the 2000 census that suggest that the four other boroughs and some suburban counties ended up at least in some ways worse off.
 Manhattan had the biggest percentage increase in median household income of any county in New York State and of all but one county in New Jersey. It had the state's biggest jump in the median earnings of men, the median value of housing skyrocketed and the number of families in poverty dropped. 
 By contrast, Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island had some of the state's biggest percentage declines in median household income and some of the only drops in median family income. All four had a rise in poverty and big dips in men's median earnings. Housing values slipped. 
The data, made public yesterday, puzzled some people who said they had expected to see the economic gains of the late 1990's more broadly shared. New York City officials raised doubts about the reliability of the income and employment numbers, which they said other government figures contradicted.
Some economists and demographers suggested that heavy immigration into Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, and some nearby cities, might have helped suppress the median income figures. While immigrants may have been making more than they did before they came, many were also making less than many of the native-born New Yorkers who moved out of the city in the 1990's.
But other economists said New York City in the 1990's also lost some higher-paying jobs in sectors like government and gained lower-paying jobs. New York City was hit harder than other areas of the country by the recession of the early 1990's, they said, and took longer to recover.
"The report reminds us what a microcosm New York City is of things that have gone well and things that have gone badly," said Jared Bernstein, a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal policy organization in Washington.
According to the numbers for New York and New Jersey, median household and family incomes rose over all in both states. But poverty rates on average rose. On the other hand, the percentage of female-headed households with children in poverty dropped, part of a nationwide decline.
In New York, the top 10 counties with the biggest percentage increases in household income included not only Manhattan but also Columbia and Putnam. The counties with the biggest drops included Dutchess and Ulster. In Rockland County, there was a slight decline.
Only Hunterdon County, N.J., with a 12.68 percent increase, topped Manhattan's 12.32 percent jump. Other New Jersey counties with big gains included Somerset, Monmouth and Morris. Those with the least improvement included Essex, Hudson, Passaic, Union and Bergen.
"How could people buy all those McMansions?" said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, remarking on the less-than-exorbitant growth in median income. "Why were Nieman Marcus and Saks doing such great business?"
He said that the answer lay in capital gains among the small percentage of people who have them -- a form of income not included in the Census Bureau's definition until it is realized. "That's what I think gave shape to the real high-end expenditures during the second half of the 90's," he said. "It was really capital gains income."
While median income rose modestly in many places and was flat or declined in others, per capita income grew significantly. A rise in per capita income at a time of little change in median income is seen as an indicator of a widening gap between rich and poor.
Per capita income is derived by dividing total income by the population; for that reason, it is sensitive to extremes on either end of the income spectrum. Mean household or mean family income is simply the income of the family in the very middle; extremes affect that figure less.
New York City planning officials questioned the reliability of the census data on income and employment. They said State Department of Labor data showed big increases in the number of people employed in and around New York, while the census showed no gains. They said other government data also suggested increases in income citywide.
They said those disparities might be traceable in part to the city's success in tracking down people for the 2000 census who had been missed in 1990. Since many of those people are assumed to have been on the lower end of the income spectrum, they said, their addition to the census may have contributed to a misleading result.
The new data illuminate for the first time everything from percentage of the population born outside the United States to the languages they speak at home and the percentage of people's income they spend on rent.
In New York City, nearly 36 percent of all residents were foreign born -- slightly below the 1910 peak of 41 percent. More than one-third of the foreign born lived in Queens and one-third lived in Brooklyn. An additional 16 percent were in Manhattan, 13 percent in the Bronx and 3 percent in Staten Island.
The number of New Yorkers of Italian ancestry, long the largest group, dropped by 17 percent, to 690,000, or nearly 9 percent of the population; the number of people of Irish ancestry dropped by one-fifth, to 422,000. The number of residents with West Indian ancestry grew by 40 percent, to 550,000, and the number of people of sub-Saharan African ancestry more than doubled to 122,000. Of the population age 5 and over, 48 percent spoke a language other than English at home, up from 41 percent in 1990. Nearly half of those said they were not proficient in English. 
In New Jersey, the foreign-born population increased by more than 50 percent, to more than 1.4 million, or 17.5 percent of the population. One-quarter of all residents over age 5 spoke a language other than English at home. Italians, Irish and Germans remained the three leading ancestry groups, making up 46.4 of the state's population.

HEADLINE: Pope Banishes a Shadow Left By Bulgaria's Tie to Shooting 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 23 

 BODY:
John Paul II reassured Bulgarians this evening that he bore no grudge over accusations that the Bulgarian secret service may have tried to have him killed in 1981.
 "I say to all that I have never ceased to love the Bulgarian people," the pope told a throng of well-wishers crowding the square outside Alexander Nevsky Cathedral immediately after arriving from Baku, Azerbaijan. 
 The ailing pope, who took language lessons in the Vatican before he left, began his speech in Bulgarian, but his quavering voice was hard to follow. When he reached the allusion to the 1981 assassination attempt, the pope turned his text over to an interpreter. The crowd responded with cheers. 
Three Bulgarians were charged with aiding the Turkish gunman, Mehmet Ali Agca, but were acquitted by an Italian court for lack of evidence. The verdict, in falling short of a clear "not guilty," has cast a shadow on Bulgaria ever since.
John Paul's five-day tour of Bulgaria and Azerbaijan is his first foreign trip since sex abuse scandals began engulfing the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.
But the pope's efforts to return attention to his peace-seeking missions in Eastern Orthodox territory were dimmed by news that yet another American bishop, Rembert G. Weakland, archbishop of Milwaukee, is under suspicion.
Archbishop Weakland acknowledged he paid $450,000 to settle a sexual assault complaint against him by an adult male student 20 years ago, though he denied the charges.
The pope did not mention the matter tonight, and his press secretary made it clear the Vatican did not want the scandal to seep into the papal journey. "As a matter of procedure, we do not comment on topics, even big ones, while we are away from the Vatican out of courtesy for the country we are visiting," the spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said tonight. "When we return to the Holy See, a comment is possible."
Once a Communist state, Bulgaria wants a Vatican stamp of approval as it seeks entry to the European Union and NATO. The pope's presence in Bulgaria provides the kind of absolution the government has long sought. Even some Bulgarians doubt the acquitted men were entirely innocent.
"We want to apologize that it happened and show him that the Bulgarian people did not have anything to do with his attempted murder," Venka Misteva, 65, an economist, explained as she waited for a glimpse of the first pope ever to visit Bulgaria.
The pope wants another chance to visit a mostly Eastern Orthodox country after previous trips to Romania, Georgia and Ukraine, steppingstones in his lifelong goal of mending the 1,000 year rift between Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.
In Baku earlier today, the pope tried to show his good intentions by promising $20,000 toward the million-dollar ransom that Chechen bandits have demanded from Azeri Orthodox Church leaders for the return of one of their clerics.
Patriarch Maxim of Bulgaria attended the welcome ceremony today, led by Bulgarian President Georgi Parvanov, but kept an icy distance. 
The two religious leaders will meet when the pope pays a courtesy call on Friday, but no joint prayer services are planned. "We did not invite him," the patriarch said recently. "We only responded to his desire to visit us."
Orthodox leaders fear that the wealthier, more powerful Catholic church is using reconciliation as a Trojan horse to push into Orthodox territory and convert their believers.
The pope got a warmer response from Orthodox believers in Azerbaijan, where they form a tiny minority of that mostly Muslim nation and find common cause with the even tinier Catholic community of 120 people, including expatriates.
It took many hundreds of foreign visitors and Muslim guests to fill the 5,000 seats in the Palace of Hard Ball Games where the pope celebrated mass this morning. "Thrilled and flabbergasted," is how James Tilley, an Oklahoma oilman in Baku who assisted at the altar, said he felt when he heard the pope was coming so far for so few.
During the service, the Baku congregation also felt a moment of fear when a man on crutches scuttled through the crowds and came within 15 feet of the pope before security guards grabbed him. After determining that the man, Kazim Azizov, an addled Azeri refugee from Armenia, was harmless, security guards escorted him back to the altar so he could kiss the pope's hand and receive a papal blessing.
Tamara Akhundova, an Azeri Muslim, said she was moved. "To me the pope looks like a very old, sick man who has a lot of love in his heart."

 BODY:
 Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew 26.6 percent in April as exports rose for the first time in more than a year.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: THE SHOE BOMB CASE; 
Prosecutors See Plot in Attempted Bombing

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 23 

 BODY:
There is evidence that the man accused of trying to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight with bombs hidden in his sneakers did not act alone, according to court documents filed today.
 A memorandum by federal prosecutors in the case of the man, Richard C. Reid, stated that "an examination of one of the explosive devices in Reid's shoes disclosed evidence of a confederate (or confederates)." 
 Investigators have ruled out Mr. Reid as the source of a human hair found in the bomb and a palm print found on the paper used to make the detonator, the memorandum said. Mr. Reid, it said, "was not unassisted in his efforts to destroy" American Airlines Flight 63 on Dec. 22. 
The 36-page memorandum, filed in response to a motion to lift restrictions on Mr. Reid's ability to communicate with his lawyers, also stated that Mr. Reid wrote in an e-mail message to his mother two days before the flight that he had "a duty" to "help remove the oppressive American forces from the Muslim land."
Mr. Reid, a British citizen, is charged with nine counts, including attempted murder. An indictment against him issued in January contends that while the plane was in flight, Mr. Reid, 28, tried to light a fuse sticking out of the tongue of one of his black high-top sneakers. Flight attendants and passengers overpowered Mr. Reid and the flight was diverted to Boston.
The indictment also asserts that Mr. Reid received training at Al Qaeda terrorist camps in Afghanistan. On Monday, Robert S. Mueller III, the F.B.I. director, said he believed "an Al Qaeda bomb maker" made the explosives in Mr. Reid's shoes.
The prosecutors' memorandum said Mr. Reid told law enforcement agents after his arrest that "he decided to choose an American target after the United States began bombing the Taliban in Afghanistan."
According to the memorandum, Mr. Reid "claimed to have chosen to attack an airplane because he believed an airplane attack, especially during the holiday season, would cause the American public to lose confidence in airline security and stop traveling, leading to a substantial loss of revenue which would, in turn, hurt the American economy."
On Monday, Mr. Reid's lawyers filed a motion to suppress the statements he made to law enforcement officials. The motion contended that Mr. Reid had either invoked his right to remain silent, or was unable to stop talking because of the Valium and other drugs that doctors on board the flight used to sedate him.
Mr. Reid's lawyers did not return calls for comment today.
The document filed today said that Mr. Reid wrote an e-mail message to his mother, Lesley Hughes, on Dec. 20, saying, "What I am doing is part of the ongoing war between Islam and disbelief (and as such a duty upon me as a Muslim)." --------------------

Advisory on Rail Attacks
(By The New York Times)
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Transportation Department advised subway and rail systems around the country on Wednesday to remain alert because of the possibility of terrorist attacks, a spokesman for the Transportation Department confirmed this evening.
The action falls short of being a warning, because there was no specific information about where or when such an attack might occur, said Chet Lunner, a spokesman for the Transportation Department. But, Mr. Lunner said, "information came from the intelligence community about the possibility of actions against subway trains."
Reuters reported this evening that subway and rail systems had been warned.
The advisory did not call for any specific actions, other than maintaining alertness. The Department did not issue any public announcement.

HEADLINE: In New York, a Long Way From Here to Here 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
New Yorkers who are smug about not having to spend hours on traffic-jammed highways to get to work may be surprised by some sobering news yesterday from the Census Bureau: that people in four of the five boroughs fritter away more time getting to work than those anywhere else in the state.
 In fact, the average travel times for residents of Staten Island, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens top not only those in every one of the state's 58 other counties. They also exceed the average trips to work in every county in New Jersey, Connecticut and most of the rest of the country. 
 Those four boroughs beat out every county in all 29 states that the bureau has reported so far in the flood of 2000 census data being let loose this month -- a group that includes California. Manhattan, which stands 11th in New York State in commuting time, ranked 193rd nationwide. 
By contrast, Los Angeles County, the notorious butt of freeway-congestion jokes, was in a relatively respectable 252nd place nationally, neck and neck with Sullivan County, N.Y. (Yes, the one in the Catskills. The one with the covered bridges.)
"That's why I don't live there anymore," Alan E. Pisarski, the author of "Commuting in America," said of New York City. When a reporter said she had assumed people chose to live in the city at least in part to get to work quickly, Mr. Pisarski burst out laughing.
The city's standing as the capital of interminable commuting comes as no surprise to those who study such things. They said it had long been so. Several cited a basic law: The higher the rate of public transit ridership in a community, the longer the average travel time to work.
Rapid transit is a relative term.
So New Yorkers, who live in the city with the highest rate of transit ridership in the country, and who, from time to time, like to believe that some special virtue inheres in that fact, are being penalized for their willingness to cram themselves into subway cars and buses to get to work? "It depends on the alternative," said Anthony Downs, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington and the author of "Stuck in Traffic" (Brookings, 1992). "You don't know how long it would take them to drive."
Mr. Downs advises automobile commuters elsewhere to equip their cars with air-conditioning, a stereo radio, a telephone, a CD player, a microwave oven and an attractive traveling companion and then to "treat being stuck in traffic as part of their leisure time."
And New Yorkers?
"My basic advice would be move somewhere else," he said.
According to the Census Bureau, the average travel time to work for people living in Staten Island in 2000 was 43.9 minutes, up more than 10 percent from the 1990 average. For Brooklyn, it was 43.2 minutes; in the Bronx, 43; in Queens, 42.2; and in Manhattan, 30.5. All of those times had risen, too.
The problem is at least threefold, analysts said. It is not only that New Yorkers ride public transportation. It is also that a high proportion of the region's employment base works in the central business district. The figure is about 40 percent, compared with 15 to 20 percent in, say, Boston, an economist said.
Whereas most people elsewhere work in the county where they live, many New Yorkers are different, said Bruce Schaller, a consultant on urban transportation issues. More than half of all Queens residents who work do so in Manhattan, he said; 46 percent in Brooklyn do; and 40 percent in the Bronx.
Then there is New York City's sheer density and size.
"The fact is, it's possible to live in New York City and live in the northern Bronx and work in southern Brooklyn, which is a very long distance," Mr. Pisarski said.
As a result, it can take longer to travel into Manhattan from southeastern Queens than to travel into Manhattan from Philadelphia, said Robert Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association. Round-trip commuting from places like Canarsie in Brooklyn or Co-op City in the Bronx swallows hours.
"My mom uses the M23," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit riders advocacy group, referring to the crosstown bus. "Even as a 77-year-old, it's a close call whether she should walk or take the bus."
Peter Nixon, a consultant who moved from Brooklyn to Livingston, N.J., four years ago, said his old commuting trip into Manhattan was "a prison sentence."
He would be in the car before sunup and still never get to work in a reasonable amount of time. Now, he said, he sleeps in and is never late.
"Go back to that commute?" he said yesterday. "Never again."
The lower average travel times of suburbanites is explained in part by the fact that a relatively small proportion of suburbanites commute into New York City -- contrary to what many city residents think.
For city residents, living within a brief commuting time from one's work is a luxury enjoyed mostly by those who can afford to pay for it, Mr. Pisarski said.
Mr. Downs from Brookings made the case that congestion in general was not even a problem. It is simply the mechanism society uses to ration limited space during periods in which far more people want to use that space than can fit, he said.
"It is actually performing an important social function," he said. "Nobody believes this but me. But it's true."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Internet: Online Advertising Slipped In 2001 

BYLINE:  By Susan Stellin (NYT) (Compiled by Steven P. Rosenfeld) 

 BODY:
 Internet advertising revenue in the United States fell 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 2001, to $1.7 billion, the Interactive Advertising Bureau announced yesterday. It said the results were "not unexpected" considering the overall decline in advertising and the economic slowdown. For all of 2001, marketers spent $7.2 billion on Internet advertising, down 12 percent from 2000. The figures were compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the Interactive Advertising Bureau, an industry trade association. The report also noted that consolidation in the online advertising market had continued, with the top 10 media companies garnering 76 percent of Internet advertising revenue last year. Susan Stellin (NYT)

HEADLINE: Designation in Hand, McCall Comes Out Firing in Convention Speech 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
As he accepted the designation for governor from the Democratic State Convention yesterday, H. Carl McCall recalled his own rise from poverty to power and vowed that if elected, he would devote himself to guaranteeing all children in New York State a first-rate education.
 The party delegates threw Mr. McCall their unanimous support after his main rival, Andrew M. Cuomo, stunned many of his supporters by pulling out of the convention. 
 Party leaders charged yesterday that Mr. Cuomo did so because he did not have the support of 25 percent of the delegates, which is needed to win a place on the primary ballot, a claim the Cuomo camp disputed. Mr. Cuomo said he would get into the Sept. 10 primary by circulating petitions, portraying himself as a populist running against the party machinery. 
Mr. Cuomo also continued his effort to divert attention from Mr. McCall's moment in the spotlight yesterday. He announced his first television ads yesterday, which will begin appearing upstate this week. The advertisements assail Gov. George E. Pataki's handling of the upstate economy and urge the state to hire some upstate companies to handle the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan. 
Without Mr. Cuomo, the convention quickly became a boisterous rally for Mr. McCall, the state comptroller and the first black man to win statewide office in New York. At noon, he took the stage at the Sheraton New York Hotel in Manhattan, surveyed the sea of faces and bouncing "McCall for Governor" signs, and said exultantly, "I have waited a long time for this."
He portrayed himself as a boy who grew up in a Boston housing project on welfare but rose in society because he had received a good public education. He said his mother had taught him that education "was a sledgehammer, that it could knock down any obstacle anyone put in front of me."
"I stand before you as someone who once received a welfare check, but because of education, I now sign every check issued by the State of New York," the comptroller said as the 353 delegates rose to give him an ovation. 
Mr. McCall described Mr. Pataki, the two-term Republican incumbent, as a do-nothing governor who had failed to solve a list of problems. The schools are crumbling and underfinanced, he charged. College tuition is too expensive. Too many jobs are leaving the state. The elderly cannot afford prescription drugs. The fund for cleaning toxic-waste sites is bankrupt.
He also derided Mr. Pataki for appearing in expensive public-service announcements that helped his image at a time when the schools need more money. "Prime-Time Pataki has misused hundreds of millions of our tax dollars, hundreds of millions of tax dollars, to cover the airwaves and cover up his failures," Mr. McCall said. 
"We've had enough of Prime-Time Pataki. It's time to change the channel," he added.
Mr. Cuomo began what he called a "people's campaign" by concentrating his fire not on Mr. McCall but on Mr. Pataki with the advertisements raising questions about the upstate economy. "We're going to tell the truth of what he did to upstate New York," Mr. Cuomo said in a news conference. "They abandoned upstate New York."
In one, Mr. Cuomo argues that upstate New York should share in the contracts arising from the rebuilding of downtown Manhattan. A second says, "Our children are leaving because right now the upstate economy is the slowest in the United States."
Mr. Cuomo unveiled the new advertisements at a campaign rally in which he bound his campaign with that of Charlie King, a candidate for lieutenant governor and a longtime friend of Mr. Cuomo's. He said he and Mr. King were running as a ticket. 
The step may have limited practical effect because there are separate primaries for governor and lieutenant governor, but it could mean political gain for Mr. Cuomo, a white candidate, because Mr. King is black.
Mr. Pataki's aides disputed the claims made by both Democrats, saying the governor had created jobs, given the schools financial support and protected the environment. "Carl McCall's partisan rhetoric will not change that," said the governor's spokeswoman, Mollie Fullington.
Ms. Fullington also challenged the assertion in Mr. Cuomo's advertisements that the upstate economy was the slowest in the nation. "Andy is playing fast and loose with the facts," she said.
In his convention address, Mr. McCall promised to add $8 billion to the state education budget in his first term if elected. In a nod to suburban and rural voters, he also promised to cut property taxes.
His speech seemed intended to draw a distinction between himself and Mr. Cuomo, the son of a former governor. Mr. McCall referred several times to his own rags-to-riches history, saying he "had to fight for everything I've ever gotten in life."
"My path to this stage, on this day, was not easy," Mr. McCall continued, "but it doesn't matter that I came from poverty. What matters is that I know the way to opportunity, and I am determined to create a state where every child has the same chance to succeed that I had."
As Mr. McCall basked in the delegates' applause, discontent grew among county party leaders who support Mr. Cuomo. Several said they had hoped to hear Mr. Cuomo speak at the convention, to take his measure as a candidate. Others said they felt abandoned after months of publicly supporting the former federal housing secretary even when the majority of party leaders were backing Mr. McCall.
"The negative fallout is significant," said Stuart Brody, the Essex County Democratic chairman, who is a strong supporter of Mr. Cuomo. 
Although Mr. McCall's campaign visibly gained ground yesterday, the designation of the convention may not be decisive. Mr. Cuomo is likely to collect enough signatures to get on the ballot, and in the past the candidate the convention has chosen often loses the primary, political consultants say.
By law, to get on the primary ballot, a candidate must either get a quarter of the weighted votes of the convention delegates, or collect thousands of signatures from around the state.
For weeks, it seemed a foregone conclusion that Mr. Cuomo would reach 25 percent, because party leaders who can swing large blocs of votes had said they would push him over that mark if he needed help. Those leaders -- top party officials, county chairmen, elected officials and, in particular, Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker -- had made similar moves in the past to ensure that well-known candidates reached the ballot.
A number of top Democrats said yesterday that it became clear on Monday that Mr. Cuomo could not get 25 percent on his own and that he had not sought help from party officials. 
Some of those same officials declined to discuss the matter Wednesday, but yesterday they said Mr. Cuomo had insulted them by characterizing the convention as a bosses' cabal removed from the people.
"He didn't have the numbers," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the state Democratic chairman. "There were messages sent, publicly and privately, that if he needed help, it would have been available, but he wouldn't ask. We didn't want to be the bad guy, we didn't want the party to be the bad guy, but that's exactly the spin he wants."
Mr. Cuomo said the party leaders were mistaken. He said he chose not to seek a vote at the convention to make a statement about his independence. 
"We had more than the 25 percent," he said. "I'm certain about that. But I don't want to do this through Democratic delegates. I want to do this with the people."

HEADLINE: McDonald's Growth Continues 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: OAK BROOK, Ill., May 23 

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation intends to continue opening new restaurants at a rapid pace, its chief executive said today, despite sluggish recent results that have prompted some analysts to question its ambitious strategy.
 More than half of the company's income now comes from 120 countries outside the United States, and the chief executive, Jack Greenberg, said that percentage would continue to grow in spite of economic difficulties in some regions. 
 He told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company remained on pace to open 1,300 to 1,400 McDonald's restaurants this year, all but 350 of them abroad.
That is similar to the 1,319 McDonald's restaurants that opened last year and down slightly from the previous year, and will push McDonald's, the world's biggest restaurant company, past the 30,000 mark.
"The opportunity outside the United States is just so enormous," Mr. Greenberg said after the session at company headquarters. While trimming operations in Latin America and some other areas, McDonald's is focusing on the most stable international markets.
The company has also cited plans to open 100 to 150 restaurants of its other, recently acquired, brands: Donatos pizza, Chipotle Mexican Grill, Boston Market and Pret a Manger. 
Only Boston Market is profitable so far, however, and Mr. Greenberg said the McDonald's brand "is still our largest and best growth opportunity."
While shareholders may be unhappy about McDonald's recent struggles, no one in the overflow crowd at the annual meeting voiced it. That may be because the long-slumping stock is up 15 percent this year.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Laughs to the Left, Laughs to the Right

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Heaven only knows what sort of mischief and deviltry takes place at Congressional Christmas parties. But occasionally a hint of the goings-on has escaped in the form of "Capitol Steps," the irreverent show that traces its origins to the entertainment provided by a group of aides asked to enliven a Senate Foreign Relations Committee Christmas party in 1981.
 Now those irrepressible satirists, who bubble their way to New York every year or two, are puncturing the powerful with their latest scattershot onslaught of comedy, "Capitol Steps: When Bush Comes to Shove," playing through Aug. 31 at the John Houseman Theater. 
 Mostly political and highly topical, performed by a five-member cast backed by a keyboard, this fast-moving combination of skits and songs ranges from Washington to Kandahar and from Broadway to the Middle and Far East, as it forages for material. 
Although the quality ranges from side-splitting to simplistic, the show on the whole provides a happy evening for those who yearn for the lighter side of the news and derive pleasure from seeing the mighty made ridiculous.
Conforming to stereotype, here are the pretzel-loving President Bush as an amiable dope, and his wife, Laura, served up cloyingly sweet. In similar fashion, the comedy -- conceived, written and directed by Bill Strauss, Elaina Newport and Mark Eaton -- pokes fun at familiar figures like the Clintons; the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan; the Israeli Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat; Vice President Dick Cheney; Senator Strom Thurmond; and Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, who reads bedtime stories, including a version of "Snow White" that dispatches its heroine into the remote lair of a bearded clan.
Casting a jaundiced eye on local heroes, the show zings Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for his weekend disappearances with "Bye Bye Bloomberg," set to the music of "Bye Bye Blackbird"; in "On Broadway," the comics tell where to find the seamy New York that vanished when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cleaned up the streets; and in "When You're a Met," music from "West Side Story" underscores the hostility between fans of the Mets and those of the Yankees.
The show reaches its pinnacle with two eruptions of "Lirty Dies," an outpouring of spoonerisms in each act. The first looks back at the 20th century, a time when Richard M. Nixon declared, "I am crot a nook," and Gush and Bore began their runs for the presidency. The second examines the pedophilia scandal involving the Roman Catholic Church.
Aided and abetted by plenty of wigs, beards and props, the versatile cast members draw on popular and show tunes as they set their sights on women in Congress, the Enron scandal, the economy, the far right, environmental issues, Microsoft, airport security, shoe bombers and other terrorists, pop stars, cloning and -- in another highlight -- relations with China.
Those who complain that politicians and government are good for nothing are wrong. "Capitol Steps: When Bush Comes to Shove" makes clear that more often than not, they're good for a laugh.

HEADLINE: Water Crisis Grows Into a Test of U.S.-Mexico Relations 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: GUERRERO VIEJO, Mexico, May 22 

 BODY:
Half a century ago this town was drowned. The United States and Mexico built a huge reservoir by damming the Rio Grande, under a treaty to divide the water of the mighty river.
 Now the ghost of Guerrero Viejo has risen. The reservoir, drained by drought, thirst, population growth and personal greed, holds one-twelfth of its capacity. The town, once deep under water, stands on dry land. On the water's edge, two miles away, horses and cattle graze on grasses that should be five fathoms under. 
 The treaty is falling apart, along with any pretense that the United States and Mexico are not on the verge of political war. The water-management policies of both nations for the border can best be described in three words: pray for rain.
Under the terms of the treaty, Mexico now owes the United States 456 billion gallons of water -- enough to quench the thirst of New York City for a year. The water should have flowed down the Rio Grande over the past decade, but didn't.
President Vicente Fox says he is preparing a plan to pay the debt back. Exactly how is a mystery.
"We can't pay it off, we don't have the water," said Enrique Martinez governor of the state of Coahuila, which borders Texas. He added a sober prognostication: "I think the struggle for water will be the gravest problem of this century."
This same struggle is simmering worldwide: rivers and reservoirs are running dry as a growing population fights over a shrinking source of life. The issue is testing the political friendship between Mr. Fox and President Bush, who knows it well from his days as Texas governor.
The two presidents discussed the debt twice in the past two months, once face to face at an economic summit meeting in Monterrey, Mexico, and again by telephone last week.
What started as a local dispute along the Rio Grande has turned into an international imbroglio, a question of national security for Mexico and a matter of survival for several million Texans and Mexicans. The crisis is shocking people on both sides of the border into seeing that there may be limits to growth.
In the Rio Grande valley, where the population has gone from 200,000 to 20 million since the water treaty was signed in 1944, the United States and Mexico "have been promoting growth" -- industrial and agricultural -- "as if there were no limit," said Alberto Szekely, Mexico's national water secretary. "And water is one," he said. 
"Both sides were warned long ago that something like this would happen," he said. "But they were working on free trade and avoiding political issues like this." Water policy on both sides of the border, he said, has been marked by negligence and wishful thinking.
One-third of the water that flows to the Rio Grande above the Falcon dam is supposed to go to south Texas, and the remainder to Mexicans downriver. But with rivers and reservoirs at record lows, people on both sides of the border, dependent on the water for drinking and irrigation, fear their fields and towns will dry up and blow away.
 South Texas farmers, who have taken their case to the State Department, blockaded the border at the Pharr international trade bridge today in protest, demanding that Mexico pay back the water. Jo Jo White, the manager of one of the largest irrigation districts in the Texas border region, joined the protest.
"In 30 to 60 days we'll be out of water if Mexico doesn't comply," Mr. White, who manages irrigation for 300 farmers and 60,000 acres, said in a telephone interview. "The crops in the ground will be lost. The growers, who have been living on the edge -- it'll be the nail in the coffin for them." Mexico has "shorted us, and they shorted their own growers twice as much," he said. "This is not only an American problem." 
The Mexican farmers near the river are petitioning President Fox to resolve the debt, run up by two past presidents, without destroying their parched lives.
"We really are out of water," said Juan Luis Zapata, a sorghum farmer wearing a New York Yankees baseball cap, in the town of Camargo, 35 miles downriver from the Falcon reservoir. "The government hasn't managed the water for the benefit of the people. Water has always been used as a kind of political power."
In Texas and in Mexico's Tamaulipas State, where Mr. Zapata lives, the farmers point upriver to the state of Chihuahua, where they claim officials are hoarding billions of gallons.
"We don't have any water," Patricio Martinez, the combative governor of Chihuahua, says flatly. He has defied both Mr. Fox and many American visitors, including Mr. White, by saying that his state's waters are sovereign -- treaty or no treaty. "The harsh truth is that drought is a fact of life in northern Mexico and the southwestern United States," he said.
President Fox says Mexico, which has less water per capita than Egypt, has spent decades squandering what it has, "without planning, without sense."
To help him pay his old debt, Mr. Fox has asked the United States to let him take on a new one. In order to build a water system that does not waste half its flow through leakage and evaporation, Mr. Fox has asked Mr. Bush to loan Mexico about $420 million, or something less than a penny of financing for every 10 gallons owed.
This idea has infuriated the Texans, who see the request as blackmail. Governor Rick Perry, who succeeded Mr. Bush, has urged the president to not loan Mexico a dime until the debt is paid.
"We feel abandoned by a home-grown president who knew what was happening all along," Mr. White, the Texas farmer, said.
Mr. Fox's advisers fear that the United States will not agree to bargain with them on immigration and economic issues unless the debt is paid. The water issue has thus become a major point of discord in relations between two nations that seemed in exceptional harmony during Mr. Bush's first months in office.
In Mexico's Congress the opposition Institutional Revolutionary Party, which ran Mexico for seven decades until Mr. Fox's election, is skeptical of his promise to make good on the water debt.
"The water the U.S. is demanding doesn't exist," said Silvia Hernandez, head of the Senate committee on North American relations. "The plan won't work."
But back in Camargo, Mr. Zapata wipes the sweat from his brow, surveys his stunted sorghum with a weary gaze, and says there is no choice for Mexico.
"Look, this is an international treaty -- we signed it," he said. "But without our own water, every day, every year, we will keep going backward until we're gone."
There is only one alternative, he said: "Pray to San Isidro," the patron saint of farmers, to make it rain.

HEADLINE: Bill for Emergency Spending Bogs Down in Partisan Rancor 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23 

 BODY:
A $29.4 billion emergency spending bill for military operations and domestic security was caught up in a partisan firestorm in the House today, and the result was a session that headed deep into the night as Democrats dragged out debate in a dispute over the national debt.
 The legislation, including money for the war in Afghanistan, airline security, counterterrorism and New York City's recovery, became a vehicle for both parties to showcase campaign themes. For a second day, debate was testy, punctuated with partisan applause. 
 The Democratic minority used maneuver after maneuver to keep debate running for hours in protest of House leaders' rolling political favors for various Republicans into the bill, along with language that would pave the way to raise the limit on the federal debt without a politically painful separate vote. 
Striking a central campaign theme, Democrats repeatedly accused Republicans of trying to escape accountability for their own fiscal policies.
The Democrats blamed President Bush's 10-year, $1.3 trillion tax cut for helping bring the Treasury Department up against the $5.95 trillion debt limit, which the administration seeks to raise by $750 billion. They said new federal deficits and borrowing would threaten the long-term solvency of Social Security. 
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, said the Republicans "want to get the political credit for cutting people's taxes" but "don't want the part that they don't want to address, which is you have got to raise the credit limit on our credit card in order to give the tax cut to the wealthiest Americans."
The Republicans, meanwhile, accused Democrats of turning their backs on the nation's fighting forces. 
"American soldiers are dying, unfortunately," said Representative C. W. Bill Young, the Florida Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee. "We are going to move this bill to completion."
In the Democratic-controlled Senate, which has its own $31 billion version of the emergency bill, the tactics were reversed today. There it was the Republicans who sought delay.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, tried to bring the bill to the floor for 10 hours of debate, reminding lawmakers that Mr. Bush had once said he wanted it passed by Memorial Day.
But Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, instantly objected, complaining of political pork in the bill. Mr. McCain said he had found one provision that would help the halibut fishing industry in Alaska with loan authority, and spoke sarcastically of "an emergency for halibuts." 
"It's disgraceful," he said. "We're going to change the way we do business around here."
Democratic Senate aides quickly told reporters that the provision was actually part of the president's budget request and was a technical correction to existing law.
The battles over an antiterrorism measure, just days after the administration had issued a series of warnings about the likelihood of future terrorist attacks, were a sign of the hardening partisanship as the elections draw closer, with control of the House and the Senate in the balance.
A number of major bills are now caught in disputes between the Senate and House, including further tax cuts, an effort to regulate health maintenance organizations and energy legislation. The Senate did manage to give final Congressional passage today to a $3 billion measure to help defend against bioterrorism.
Republicans accuse the Senate of obstructing Mr. Bush's agenda and are calling on Americans to restore them to the Senate majority as a way of supporting him. The Republican National Committee today e-mailed out a "Daschle One-Year Performance Review," rating the senator "unsatisfactory."
Senate Democrats, on the other hand, say they have stopped "extreme" Republican measures like further tax cuts for corporations and oil drilling in an Alaskan wildlife refuge.
"Some people call our refusal to rubber-stamp the Republican agenda obstruction," Mr. Daschle said at a rally today. "I see it as rejecting failed ideas in the name of real solutions. And I call that progress. "
Eager to leave for Memorial Day, House Republican leaders began taking action tonight to force a final vote on the emergency measure sometime before dawn. Both parties say the bill, which includes $5.5 billion for New York, will eventually pass the House.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Bill Giving Wider Trade Authority to Bush 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23 

 BODY:
The Senate tonight passed a broad trade bill that would give President Bush the authority to reach trade agreements that are largely immune from Congressional tinkering but would greatly increase aid to workers who lose their jobs because of foreign competition.
 The 66-to-30 vote brought the White House close to a top legislative priority that administration officials say will make it easier to expand trade, allowing Mr. Bush to reach trade accords that Congress could accept or reject, but not amend. 
 The Senate's lopsided approval followed razor-thin passage of trade authority in the House late last year, the first time in eight years that both houses of Congress have agreed to grant the White House the enhanced negotiating powers. 
That handed Mr. Bush a significant victory at a time when the administration has angered major allies abroad and free-trade conservatives at home by slapping punitive duties on imported steel and supporting huge subsidies for farmers.
The 41 Republicans who voted for the bill were joined by 24 Democrats and one independent. Five Republicans and 25 Democrats opposed it.
House and Senate negotiators now must try to reconcile substantially different versions of the bill in negotiations that will pit Democratic demands for more worker protections against Republican preferences to limit costly welfare provisions.
The compromise to grant Mr. Bush so-called trade promotion authority won the support of the Senate Democratic leadership only after weeks of partisan haggling. It would triple the money spent on aid for displaced workers to $1.2 billion annually. The government would also begin paying 70 percent of the health insurance costs for people whose jobs disappear because of imports.
"Senators realize that we cannot stick our heads in the sand and that we need to deal with globalization," said Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat and a main sponsor of the bill. "But we also insisted that the benefits of trade go to workers and not just to companies."
Mr. Bush agreed to support increased aid as the price of restoring trade authority. Five presidents have had the enhanced negotiating rights, but the powers expired in 1994 and Congress repeatedly denied them to President Bill Clinton.
Robert B. Zoellick, Mr. Bush's chief trade negotiator, said today that the trade authority "will provide the administration with the tools to pry open markets and negotiate the best deals for our workers, farmers, and consumers."
Mr. Bush wants to use the authority to create the world's largest free trade zone by expanding the North American Free Trade Agreement to 31 additional countries, mostly in Latin America, by the end of his first term. By that time the administration also aims to conclude a global negotiation to liberalize trade that began late last year in Doha, Qatar.
But the bill still faces obstacles. Administration officials say Mr. Bush cannot sign the measure if it includes a Senate provision that would bar changes in American antidumping laws. The restrictions are a slap at the administration after it agreed to discuss the laws, which allow countries to retaliate against low-priced imports, in Doha.
Administration officials say they will be hard pressed to reach trade accords if Congress unilaterally takes some sensitive issues off the table. Many countries have demanded that agreements address disparities in the way nations use domestic trade laws to block imports.
The trade bill passed by the Republican-led House in December did not authorize extensive new aid for workers and it did not bar Mr. Bush from negotiating antidumping rules. 
Supporters say they are optimistic that the strong Senate vote paved the way to complete work on the bill.
"There is no doubt now that we're going to get this to the president," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa.
Opponents say they expect a grueling rematch in the House, where the trade measure passed by a single vote in December and where both Democrats and Republicans had hoped to avoid a second vote close to Congressional elections.
Though the margin of victory in the Senate proved heartening to the administration, the Senate has historically supported trade with far less hesitation. The prolonged wrangling over the bill indicated growing reluctance to support trade accords among Democrats and Republicans who represent districts with large numbers of blue collar workers.
Even the Bush administration, which entered office vowing to promote trade around the world, has used protectionist measures to help steel, farm, timber and textile industries more readily than the Clinton administration did. That has created a backlash among trading partners, some analysts say.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, demanded a high price for pushing the bill through the Senate by insisting on extensive worker unemployment and health benefits that have not often been part of trade bills.
Republicans protested what they considered a Democratic effort to turn a relatively small trade-related program that supports retraining of workers who lose jobs to foreign competitors into a vehicle for wider health care coverage and large increases in unemployment benefits.
The bill would provide benefits to many workers indirectly affected by trade, like those who supply parts to a company that closes because of foreign competition.
Welfare provisions in the Senate bill may help the Bush administration round up a few more Democrats in the House. But they could also cost votes among free trade Republicans.
In sign of the battle to come, House Democrats have begun a drive to keep the Senate bill intact and to demand more trade concessions from the administration before the measure comes before the House.
Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, a Democrat who is often considered a bellwether on trade measures, said trade accords these days were no longer just about tariffs but also about domestic policies, like antidumping and antitrust laws. He said the administration needed to give Congress a more hands-on oversight role.
"We can't agree to allow negotiations about domestic law and regulations that Congress doesn't have the power to change," Mr. Matsui said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Max Baucus, second from left, a Montana Democrat who is a main sponsor of the trade bill, talked with Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia, who opposed the legislation. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

Debate Grows Over Links In Government to Business
Disputes over contacts between corporations and senior government officials who regulate them have become an almost daily ritual of Washington life. While the debate is not new, it has heated up. Senate Democrats have become emboldened in challenging an administration with strong pro-business leanings.
 The issue has also underscored the differences in disclosure among executive departments and independent agencies. Page C5.

HEADLINE: City Wants Stock Exchange To Invest More for Complex 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Bloomberg administration has asked the New York Stock Exchange to double its investment, to $900 million, in a plan for a heavily subsidized trading complex that former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani once called a "Christmas gift to the city." 
 The Bloomberg administration views the proposed project, which could cost taxpayers more than $1 billion in cash and tax breaks, as too expensive, especially in light of the city's sluggish economy and a multibillion dollar budget gap. 
 Both sides have problems with the three-year-old deal to build a modern trading complex and 50-story tower across the street from the exchange's home on Wall Street. But neither the city nor Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the exchange, wants to be accused of scuttling the project, when the city's financial district is still coping with layoffs, corporate relocations and the destruction of the World Trade Center. 
At a meeting with top executives of the exchange on May 16, the deputy mayor for economic development, Daniel Doctoroff, proposed that the exchange raise its contribution to the project, to as much as $900 million, from about $450 million, according to one person who was there and another who was briefed on the talks. 
"What may have been a bad deal three years ago is now untenable," said Harvey Robins, a former city director of operations and a critic of the project. "The question is whether the financial community recognizes that the world has changed and that the mayor's call for shared sacrifice is a message that clearly applies to them." 
But the Bloomberg administration does not expect all the money to come from the pockets of the exchange. As part of the proposal, Mr. Doctoroff suggested that the exchange apply for a wide range of federal incentives for the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan, including tax-free Liberty Bonds, accelerated depreciation and cash grants. Mr. Doctoroff declined comment, as did Ray Pellecchia, a spokesman for the exchange. 
Under the 1998 deal with the Giuliani administration, the city committed to buying the block bound by Wall, Broad and William Streets and Exchange Place, at an estimated cost of $450 million. The city and state also agreed to provide subsidies to build a 10-story building of trading floors: $225 million in cash from the state, $255 million from the city and $160 million in tax breaks. The city had initially planned to sell the development rights to a 50-story tower over the trading complex to offset the cost of the land. But after the attack on the trade center in September, Mr. Grasso declared that "a 900-foot tower post-Sept. 11 is not a salable transaction." He has since backed away from his objection to the tower, city and state officials said, but he remains concerned about security. The fate of the tower is unclear. 
With the yawning gap in the next city budget estimated at more than $5 billion, the city wants to reduce its obligations to the project. The state, which is also facing fiscal problems, recently assured Mr. Grasso that it remained committed to providing $225 million. The city has asked the exchange to add to the $450 million it had pledged to spend on construction and outfitting the trading complex. 
The new proposal delighted urban planners, budget watchdogs and even some investment bankers who have long criticized the size of the subsidies for the project. They have also questioned the need for an expensive trading complex with the advent of electronic trading. "It's a relief that they're trying to restructure the deal," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "I would think some of the federal aid ought to help." 
Mr. Grasso did not attend the meeting a week ago and has not revealed his reaction to the new proposal from the Bloomberg administration. 
The project has already cost millions of dollars. And the city, which is paying $3 million a month to hold onto the land for the project, has agreed to pay $160 million for an apartment building on the site, owned by the Rockrose Development Corporation, and made a $22 million down payment on the $220 million purchase of an office building at 23 Wall Street from J. P. Morgan Chase. 
Despite the deposit, J. P. Morgan Chase demanded that the city pay $2 million a month in penalties because the acquisition did not close as expected last December.
